167.
RICHARD ALBERT HIRST
, Unlawfully using violence to
William Carver, with a view to compel him to abstain from work. Second Count, for intimidating him. Third Count, for a common assault.

p.hi: applied to quash the Second Count of the indictment, on the

ground that the Court had no jurisdiction to try it; the First Count was the only one upon which the defendant had elected to be committed, and the Second Count charged a distinct offence of intimidation, and did not include in it the substance of that charged in the First Count. After hearing
sustained the objection, and quashed the Second Count.

div1.p: WILLIAM CARVER . I live at 2, Wiltshire Road, Brixton, and am a bookbinderâ€”I entered the service of Messrs. Shaw and Sons, of Fetter Lane, on 27th Octoberâ€”at that time I knew there were certain disputes going on between Messrs. Shaw and Sons and their employÃ©sâ€”there were a lot of men walking up and down, as pickets, to see if anyone came to take work there, and try to persuade them to go to the Society's rooms, and to pay their fare backâ€”I have seen the prisoner there as one of the pickets many times between 27th October and 16th November; he was there nearly every day; I have heard him say, "Come out, and be men"â€”that was said by him as well as the other picketsâ€”they followed us as we went along the streets, walking by the side of us, calling us rats, and all that, bâ€”â€”old rats, and "You want your dâ€”d bâ€”â€”old heads knocked off"â€”I was desirous of obtaining lodgings near my work, and on 16th November I spoke to Mr. Gordon, the manager, about itâ€”I went out about half-past twelveâ€”when I got outside I saw the prisoner just alongside the front doorâ€”I went out at the front door and turned up Fetter Lane; the prisoner followed, meâ€”he said, "What do you mean by coming and taking work out of other people's hands?"â€”that was the first thing he said to meâ€”then he called me a bâ€”â€”old ratâ€”I said I did not want to have anything to say to himâ€”I went on, he still following meâ€”he kept abusing me with filthy language, saying, "You bâ€”â€”old rat, you ought to have your dâ€”bâ€”old head knocked off"â€”he followed me from one hundred and fifty to two hundred yardsâ€”I asked him what he was following me about forâ€”he said he would follow me as long as he had a mind, and where he had a mindâ€”finding he was following me in this way, I went back to Shaw and Sonsâ€”I came down Fetter Lane; before doing so I went down West Harding Street, thinking he would not follow me thereâ€”finding he did not give over following me, I turned to go back to Shaw's, and when I turned the prisoner struck me on the side of the face with his handâ€”I said, "If you strike me again you will have to pay for it"â€”he struck me a second time in the same wayâ€”I then went back in the direction of Shaw'sâ€”I saw Police Constable 434 outside, and I said to him in the prisoner's hearing, "I give this man in charge, he has been striking me"â€”the policeman said, "Would Mr. Shaw be willing that he should be given in charge?"â€”I went on and happened to come across Mr. Shaw Bond, and I made a communication to him, and he came out and spoke to the prisoner; I did not hear what he saidâ€”it was in Fetter Lane that this assault took place. (A plan was produced, and the witness marked upon it the place where the assault took place as just in West Harding Street)â€”the new men came by train of a morning, for the first part of the time, and were escorted to work by the police.

Cross-examined. If was unusual for one of the new men to go out in the middle of the dayâ€”I asked permission in the morningâ€”I did not see a member of the firm or a clerk watching at the door when I went outâ€”I heard there was a clerk looking out at the doorâ€”I believe

thirteen men in this department went out after notice, and thirteen new men were taken on; there was some dispute about working overtimeâ€”the new men were not members of the unionâ€”the prisoner did not ask me to join the union on the 16th; he had asked me along with the restâ€”after coming out at the front door I went on towards Holborn; I did not stopâ€”West Harding Street is not the first turning from Shaw's; there is a little turning firstâ€”the second time the prisoner struck me was in the face, and on the lip; both blows were on the side of the faceâ€”when I spoke to the policeman I believe he said, "Can you show me any mark?"or something of the sortâ€”he did not say, "You have got no mark,"or "I can't see any mark"â€”he said he had not seen the blow struckâ€”I did not mention to the policeman about my lip being cutâ€”I went to the Mansion House with Mr. Gordon, the manager; he wrote out the information for me; it was written out at Shaw's, one of the clerks wrote it outâ€”I don't think Mr. Shaw Bond was present, or either of the partnersâ€”when I told the policeman that the prisoner had struck me, the prisoner said, "I never struck the man at all"â€”when one of the firm said, "What business have you to interfere with my men, why did you strike him?" I did not hear the prisoner reply, "I did not strike him"â€”I think nothing was said in the information about my lip being cutâ€”I told the Lord Mayor that the two blows cut my lip just inside.

Re-examined. I first found out that my lip was cut when I got into the shop, I showed it to my shopmatesâ€”it could not be seen from the outside; it was just as if it was done by being knocked against the teeth and breaking the skin.

ARTHUR SKEATS . I am a clerk to Shaw and Sonsâ€”on 16th November, about half-past twelve, I was inside the premisesâ€”I saw Carver go out and walk up Fetter Lane towards Holbornâ€”I saw the prisoner following himâ€”I went out and looked up the road after themâ€”I did not follow themâ€”I crossed over to the opposite side, and saw them as far as the corner of West Harding Streetâ€”the prisoner was walking behind Carver and talking to him, not quietly, rather excitedlyâ€”at the corner of West Harding Street a cart intervened; after the cart had passed I saw them turning down West Harding Streetâ€”I then went into the shopâ€”I afterwards saw Carver come back, I did not see anything about his lip then, I did afterwards; in the afternoon he showed it to me; I noticed that it was cut; I did not see anyone but the prisoner following Carverâ€”I saw Tickner at the Police-courtâ€”I saw him on the 16th outside Shaw's, walking up and down as a picketâ€”he did not follow them up Fetter Lane.

Cross-examined. It was mere idle curiosity that took me to the door to look after Carverâ€”the clerks can go out when they pleaseâ€”I did not know that Carver was going outâ€”the new men were brought and taken back by omnibus morning and eveningâ€”it was an unusual thing for one of the new men to go out in the dayâ€”the other men outside did not follow the prisoner and Carver, they remained about the doorâ€”I noticed Tickner that day particularlyâ€”there were three men, including the prisonerâ€”I had no motive for watching themâ€”Tickner could not see the prisoner and Carver going up the street; he was on Shaw's side of the wayâ€”the cart was in Fetter Laneâ€”anyone on Shaw's side would not have a better opportunity of seeing the cart than I had, he would not
see the cart at all; the road there bends very muchâ€”I think this is the first time I have mentioned seeing the cart.
Re-examined. Tickner was on Shaw's side, walking up and down outside the door. (The witness pointed out on the plan the position in which he and Tickner were standing.)

FREDERICK ROBERTS (City Policeman 434). On 16th November, about half-past twelve, I was stationed outside Messrs. Shaw's premises on account of the strike thereâ€”a little after twelve Carver came up to me and made a complaintâ€”he said, "I have been assaulted; I give that man (the prisoner) in charge for assaulting me"â€”I said, "I don't see any marks of violence upon you"â€”he then went into the shop and came out with Mr. Bondâ€”he said to the prisoner, "Hirst, I know you; I shall apply for a summons against you"â€”I said I would take him into custody if he pressed it; but Mr. Bond suggested that a summons would meet the caseâ€”the prisoner said, "I never struck him"â€”I had seen the prisoner as a picket outside on several occasions.

Cross-examined. I had been there on special duty for several days, on and offâ€”when Carver came up to me I did not say, "Would Mr. Shaw like me to take him into custody?"â€”I did not ask Carver if he had got any-marks; I said, "I don't see any marks upon you"â€”the prisoner said at once, "I never struck him, I only spoke to him."

RICHARD SHAW BOND . I am one of the partners in Shaw and Sonsâ€”shortly before 27th October a number of our men went out on strike, Hirst among themâ€”Carver was one of the new men taken on in their placeâ€”on the 16th November I remember Carver going out and coming back and making a communication to me; in consequence of that I went to the door and saw Hirstâ€”I asked him if his name was Hirstâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I then asked him why he struck Carver or "my man"â€”he said, "I never struck him"â€”I then asked why he interfered with him at allâ€”I think he made no observation to thatâ€”he could hear what I saidâ€”this is a correct plan.

Cross-examined. Hirst had been about two years and a half with the firm; he bore the character of a peaceable man while with usâ€”there had been a difference with the thirteen men about overtime, and some were discharged, and then the remainder of the thirteen men gave notice to leave.

JAMES GORDON . I am manager to Messrs. Shaw and Sonsâ€”on 16th November Carver came to me for permission to go outâ€”he went out about half-past twelveâ€”I was not there when he came backâ€”I took down the information in this matter from Carver's dictation.

WALTER GREEN . I live at 149, Penton Place, and am a journeyman bookbinderâ€”I was employed by Shaw and Sons as a new handâ€”I saw Carver when he came in on 16th Novemberâ€”I noticed that he was rather excitedâ€”after speaking to him I noticed that his upper lip was swollen on the right sideâ€”I looked inside the lip and I saw a cut; it was a straight cut, just as if it had been torn against a tooth, the result of a knock.

Cross-examined. I know that a summons was taken out against the prisoner for an assaultâ€”I knew it from lodging with Carver at the time; I was the only one of the hands that lodged with himâ€”I noticed the cut in the shop, about twenty minutes to one; that was before he went to the Mansion Houseâ€”I did not go there with himâ€”he did not mention

anything to me about the case after he came back; he told me he had been before the Lord Mayorâ€”I then went to the solicitor and said I had seen the cut; I can't exactly say the day, it was a week or a fortnight ago; Mr. Gordon asked me to goâ€”I told him what I had seen; that was after I had been before the Lord Mayor.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate:"I did not strike him."

EDWARD TICKNER . I live at 171, Lynton Road, Bermondseyâ€”I had not been in the employment of Messrs. Shaw; I was employed to attend outside the premises and see the men coming in and outâ€”I was paid to watch about the premisesâ€”I was there on 16th November; I saw Carver come out of Messrs. Shaw's; he turned to the right towards Holbornâ€”I saw Hirst there; we were both walking up and down, Hirst followed Carverâ€”I looked over them, and walked towards them; they were talking together; they walked a little way just before they came to the turning of West Harding Street; nothing happened; they stopped there, and Hirst turned round to come back again, Carver came back as well; he spoke to the constableâ€”I did not lose sight of the two men all the timeâ€”Hirst did not raise his hand to Carver, or strike him in the faceâ€”if such a thing had occurred I must have seen it.

Cross-examined. I was taking part with the strikers against Messrs. Shawâ€”I am a vellum binder; I am twenty years of ageâ€”I earn 32s. a week as a vellum binderâ€”I was paid eightpence an hour while picketing, seven shillings a day, but that was from half-past seven in the morning till seven in the eveningâ€”I had been about two or three days picketing at Shaw's; I went on till the society took me offâ€”I am a member of the unionâ€”I was a very energetic picketâ€”I kept my attention towards the doorâ€”I did not go away from the door; we were walking up and downâ€”I kept my eye on the door; that was my practice all the timeâ€”I saw Carver come outâ€”Hirst was speaking to him quite quietlyâ€”they did not turn round into West Harding Street, not at any timeâ€”there was no cart there while the men were there; the road bends a bitâ€”I was on the right side of the road going towards Holborn, that is the same side as West Harding Streetâ€”I was walking up and down as far as the doorâ€”if they had gone into West Harding Street they would have gone out of my sightâ€”I walked up to about there (marking on the plan); I could not see into West Harding Street.
Re-examined. It was part; of my duty to look after the other pickets and see what they were doingâ€”the new men never came out in the daytime before that.
By the JURY. There was no cart in the road; it was quite clear.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
â€”
NOT GUILTY .

175.
CHARLES BROWN (30) and
JOSEPH CHARLES BAILEY (21)
, wilful and corrupt perjury.

JOSEPH WEBB . I am band-sergeant on board H. M. ship Rodneyâ€”on September 2nd I was coming out of the Britannia Theatre, Hoxton, and met a short, thick-set man, with a dark moustacheâ€”I went with him to what I now know as the Central Club, St. Luke'sâ€”I saw Liddiard and Noll there; they entered into conversation with me, and I remained there some hoursâ€”I saw Charles Hastie a very short distance from me, but had no conversation with himâ€”he left about twenty minutes before meâ€”I left about 2 a.m. with Liddiard and Nollâ€”I said good-night to them outside the club, and walked on by myselfâ€”when I had got about one hundred yards, Liddiard, Noll, and another man came up to me, and the one who is in prison now, put his hand in my pocketâ€”I said, "Don't try and thieve, because if you are hard up I will give you a shilling, willingly; I have got to travel to-morrow, and want to go to bed"â€”they got me on the ground and assaulted me, and the one who is missing was on my chest and stole my money, Â£8 15s.; he got offâ€”I called "Murder!" and "Police!" and some constables came up; Brown came up first and held the two men till Lemoine came up; they took one each, and I went to the station and made the chargeâ€”I gave evidence next day before the Magistrate; the two men only were in custody then; they were remanded till 7th September, when I attended, and Hutchinson and Hastie were also in custodyâ€”I only saw three men engaged in the robberyâ€”I did not see Bailey at the time of the robbery or on the way to the station, but I saw him at the Police-station.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I returned to the Police-station during the dayâ€”I went about with Brown next day to see if he could apprehend the third manâ€”I believe Bailey had been to the Inspector and told him he knew who the third man wasâ€”I said at the station that I recognised Hastie as being in the crowd, but not taking part in the robberyâ€”I think Hastie was taken into custody after Hutchinsonâ€”when Hastie was arrested I said that there were only three men thereâ€”the Inspector said, "Can you recognise that man as being in the club?"â€”I said, "No"â€”I told him that three men assaulted me, not fourâ€”I said if the right man was caught and convicted I would reward himâ€”no crowd had collected when Brown came upâ€”I saw nobody but the police, but I was nearly stunned.

Re-examined. I cannot say whether Brown was present when I spoke of the reward to Baileyâ€”I said, "Are you quite sure you know who this man is?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "If you can find that man I will reward you"â€”the statement was, I believe, on the day after the robbery; I do not know who was present.

CHARLES HASTIE . I am a bookmaker's assistant, of 22, Galway Street, St. Luke'sâ€”I am a member of the Central Clubâ€”on September 3rd, about 12.50 a.m., I was in the bar and saw Webb, Noll, and Liddiard thereâ€”I knew Noll and Liddiardâ€”I left about 1.15, leaving them thereâ€”I went to the corner of Manton Street, and was twenty-five minutes talking to Townsend and Bow, who came out of the club with meâ€”I got home about 1.30, went into the yard, and was in bed at two o'clockâ€”I did not leave Galway Street till next morningâ€”when I got to Galway Street Mrs. Linski let me inâ€”there is no truth in the assertion that on the morning of September 23rd I assaulted and robbed Webbâ€”when Smith apprehended me I said, "What do you want me for?"â€”he said, "Being concerned in a highway robbery with violence," and then Brown came up and took hold of meâ€”I said, "I am innocent"â€”I was taken to Old Street Station, and saw Inspector Burnham, and said, "I am innocent of the crime; I don't know anything more about it than you do"â€”I know Jerry Flynn; he resembles me, but he is much shorter.
JAMES TOWNSEND . On the morning of September 23rd I saw Hastie at the corner of Galway Street, and left him there about 1.35.

CATHERINE LINSKI . On this' Wednesday night I was staying at 22, Galway Street; I did not live thereâ€”Mr. Hastie came in about 1.40 or 1.45â€”I saw him shortly after he came in, and saw him go into his roomâ€”shortly after this the clock struck twoâ€”he was actually in his room then.

WILLIAM BURNHAM . I was Police Superintendent; I am now pensionedâ€”I had charge of Old Street Stationâ€”on September 3rd, about nine o'clock, I heard a charge of robbery when I went on duty against Liddiard and Noll, who were in custodyâ€”en the same day I went to Clerkenwell Police-court and saw the prisoner Brown; he said that the two prisoners, and a third man who had got away, had robbed the prosecutor, on the same day Liddiard and Noll were brought before Mr. Horace Smithâ€”I heard no fourth man mentioned then who had been concerned in the robberyâ€”next day, September 4th, Bailey called at the station and asked me for the officer in the case of the highway robberyâ€”I took him into the library and left him with Brown, and in a short time they both came to me, and Bailey mentioned the name of a man who they said was the third man; it was not Hutchinson or Hastieâ€”I gave them instructions, and Bailey left the stationâ€”I saw Brown the same evening, and again next day; he went on reporting to me verbally about the caseâ€”I did not know of the arrest of another man on Saturdayâ€”I was away on Sundayâ€”on Monday the 7th, about 7.45, I was at home, and Brown came to me with Bailey, and said that Hastie was the man wanted, and he wanted me to hear what Bailey had to sayâ€”I said, "If you have any evidence to connect Hastie with the case you go and arrest him"â€”they did not tell me of the arrest of any other manâ€”when they spoke of Hastie I took it that he was the third manâ€”I went to the station and found Hastie there in Brown's custodyâ€”we ail went to

King's Cross; Webb was thereâ€”I asked Brown what evidence he had before I took the charge; he produced Bailey, who said he saw either Liddiard or Noll take something from Webb's pocket while he was on the ground, and hand it to Hutchinson, who handed it to Hastieâ€”Hastie said, "Speak the truth, man, speak the truth"â€”I said, "I will take down in writing what you have to say"â€”I took it down; this is it: "I am innocent, I was in bed at the time; I saw the prosecutor in the Central Club, and left him there with somebody who I can point out. I went out with Jemmy Townsend, and left him at the corner of Langston Street about half-past one o'clock"â€”Hastie was taken before the Magistrate the same day; he and Hutchinson were charged, and remanded till the 10thâ€”I first heard of Hutchinson's arrest when I got to Old Street station; that was the first I heard of a fourth manâ€”I did not speak to Brown or Baileyâ€”Brown had said nothing to me up to that time about seeing anything taken by the other men handed by Hutchinson to Hastieâ€”on the 10th they all came before Mr. Horace Smith, and Bailey first gave his evidence on oathâ€”I believe Brown followed him in the witness-box; he had been in Court, I believe, during Bailey's examination; that was Brown's first statement in my hearing of his having seen anything passâ€”they were all committed for trial to the September Sessions of this Court, and a true bill was foundâ€”I believe Bailey attended as a witness before the Grand Juryâ€”the case was adjourned to the next Sessionsâ€”Bailey afterwards came to the station with Paling, the landlord of the Rum Puncheon; I do not know the dateâ€”he said he felt very uncomfortable, and had brought Paling to make a statementâ€”I took it down, this is it, it was read over to him, and he signed it as correctâ€”he left with Palingâ€”I reported the matter to my Superintendent, inquiries were made, and the case was taken up by the Solicitor to the Treasury; and at the October Sessions, I think, the case against the four men came on for hearing before the late Recorder; the prosecution against Hastie was withdrawn, and Liddiard and Noll were convicted and sentenced (See vol. cxiv., p. 1151)â€”neither of the prisoners were examined as witnesses; some time after a warrant was applied for against bothâ€”Brown had been gone about two days; he was suspended, and I did not see him again till he was brought back in custody.

Cross-examined. Brown has served under me about three years, but I have known him seven years; he has been in the force ten years; he has been commended, and was a very good constableâ€”when Bailey came he simply said that he wanted to see the officer who had charge of the case, to give some information concerning the robberyâ€”I took him into the library to Brownâ€”if Brown had further evidence I should say, "Go and arrest the man"â€”I do not recollect Bailey saying that there were three or four men; I understood from Webb that there were several presentâ€”when Hastie was taken in custody he signed the charge-sheetâ€”I cannot say whether he signed it against four men.

Re-examined. He said he did not recognise Hastieâ€”Brown was commended by the Magistrates at Clerkenwell in July, 1889, for tact and forbearanceâ€”I do not know that in 1883 he was cautioned and reproved for improperly taking a man in custodyâ€”I have been asked whether four persons were mentioned; they were, but not by Brown; Hastie was one of those persons.

HARRY CAVENDISH . I am clerk at Clerkenwell Police-courtâ€”on 7th September a charge was made against Hastie and Hutchinsonâ€”Bailey was called, he was the second witnessâ€”he was sworn; I took down what he said, and he signed itâ€”this is it: "I live at 97, Old Street, St. Luke's, labourer. At 2.30 on Thursday morning last, 3rd instant, I was passing through Central Street, St. Luke's, close to the Central Club, and saw a lot of row outside the club. I saw prosecutor lying on his back on the ground, and the prisoners, Liddiard and Noll, were kneeling on his chest. I saw these two prisoners (Hutchinson and Hastie) standing round, and one of the other men, Liddiard or Noll, handed something to Hutchinson, and he handed it to the prisoner Hastie, and they parted and went away.

Cross-examined. I can't say what the something was; I did not see it, I saw the hand pass it; a policeman came up afterwardâ€”I did not like to tell him then, because I did not want to be in the case I could not see who the two men were. One of them handed something to Hutchinson, and he handed it to the prisoner Hastie I never saw the constable Brown until this occasion. The man was stooping down over the prosecutor when he handed the something to Hutchinson; the other man was kneeling on prosecutor at that time. Hutchinson passed the something to Hastie, and they went away I am certain as to the men Hutchinson and Hastie, etc."â€”the policeman Brown was then called and sworn; he said, "I apprehended the prisoners Noll and Liddiard at the time of the robbery. I saw then the prisoner Hutchinson pass something to Hastie, who put it in his pocket, and I heard it jingle. Hutchinson went away through Lever Street, and Hastie went towards Old Street. I apprehended Hutchinson at 11.30 on Saturday night; prosecutor was with me, and said, 'That is the man who assisted to rob me. 'I told Hutchinson the charge; he said, 'I don't know Liddiard and Noll, I am innocent. 'I apprehended the prisoner Hastie this morning. I told him the charge; he said, 'Believe me, I don't know anything about it; I was in the club, I saw prosecutor and others there, and I left before they did; the prosecutor was drunk, and was paying for half-pints of gin; he had on him Â£10 in gold, two watches and chains, three rings, and Â£2 10s. in silver.

Cross-examined. I know Hastie as living in the neighbourhood, not by name. I saw Liddiard kneeling on the prosecutor; I only saw four men round; I saw no others. I pulled Liddiard off the prosecutor, and I never let go of him. Prosecutor had no stick; he was quite sober. Re-examined. I found Noll and Liddiard both kneeling on the prosecutor, and I got hold of them both. Liddiard was wearing the prosecutor's hat. Police-constable 240 came up, and Liddiard dropped the prosecutor's bat and. said, 'Where is my hat?' The prosecutor's hat was then on the ground, and his name was written on it.

Cross-examined. Liddiard was sober; he did not say his hat had been knocked off by the prosecutor. I am sure prisoner Noll was on the prosecutor. I did not know the witness Bailey till he came to the Police-station at about 11.30 on Friday morning, and he then told me what he had seen. Police sergeant Reynolds had given me Bailey's name and address on Thursday night as a witness who had seen the affair. I believe it was Noll who passed something to Hutchinson; he passed it just before I got hold of him; he was then kneeling on the prosecutor, Liddiard was also kneeling on him and holding him down, etc."â€”on the 10th he was recalled, the evidence was
read over, and he was cross-examined. (This being read, stated that he saw Liddiard kneeling on the prosecutor, and four men round; and that he did not see Bailey at all.)

THOMAS SMITH (Policeman G 215). On September 7th, about 8.30 a.m., I was called into the Inspector's office, Old Street, and saw Sergeant Gooding, and received instructions from himâ€”I saw the prisoner Brown in the charge-room, and left the station with himâ€”as we neared Central Street he said, "Wait a minute, there is a lad over the road I want to see, and went over the road and fetched Hastie, who I had never seen beforeâ€”I said, "Who is this lad you have got; we do not want him with us"â€”Brown said, "Will you come and have a drink?"â€”I refused, and we went towards Hastie's residenceâ€”Brown said, "Come into the Royal Oak; you can wait inside, and you will see us bring him by"â€”I went on to 22, Galway Street, and as I was knocking at the door I saw Brown following meâ€”I found Hastie at home, got him out into street, and Brown arrested him, and said he would be charged with two men in custody for highway robbery with violence, and receiving the money; he said, "I know nothing whatever about it"â€”we two walked beside him and passed the Royal Oakâ€”as we neared the Police-station I saw Bailey following about ten yards behind, in Central Streetâ€”Hastie was detained at the station, and put with other men; Bailey was brought in, and Sergeant Gooding said, "Pick out the man who you think it is," and he went and touched Hastie and said, "That is the man"â€”he was then taken to Kings' Crossâ€”on a subsequent day I said to Brown, "If I had known I would not have gone with you"â€”I was afterwards called upon to make a report.

Cross-examined. I think I made the report about September 20th, after the case against Hastie and Hutchinson had been withdrawnâ€”I have left it at homeâ€”I did not put in the report, "You wait here, and we shall come by with Hastie. "

Re-examined. This (produced) is the report I made; what I was speaking of is a copyâ€”I was afterwards called upon to make a report, which I did on 15th Octoberâ€”this is it (produced); this is my signature to it.
By MR. HUTTON. I did not tell the Inspector when I got to the station that Bailey was told to wait there while Hastie was brought by.

WALTER GOODING (Police Sergeant J). I am stationed at Leyton nowâ€”on 12th September I was stationed at Old Street, and about 8 a.m. the prisoner Brown came in and said he knew the fourth man, who was wanted in the case of highway robberyâ€”I asked him who it was; he said "Charley Hastie"â€”I said, "Does Sub-Inspector Burdon Know this?â€”he said, "Yes; he told me to get whatever evidence I have, and to a apprehend Hastie"â€”I said, "What evidence have you got?"â€”he said, "I have got a witness, but he is not here; he saw the Highway robbery, and also saw the fourth man receive some money, which was the proceeds of the robbery"â€”he said nothing at that time about having seen money pass between the third man and the fourthâ€”I sent Police Constable Smith with him, because I thought he might want assistanceâ€”three-quarters of an hour afterwards Brown and Smith returned with Hastie, and Brown said, "This is the man"â€”I asked turn where his witness was, that was Bailey; I said, "Has he seen him?"

â€”he said, "No; he has not seen him yet"â€”I said, "You must take care he does not see him, because we shall have to get some people that he may be properly identifiedâ€”he went to the library, and I went out and got some people as near as possible to Hastie's stampâ€”I went and saw Bailey, and asked him if he could identify the fourth man who was wanted on the charge of highway robberyâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I took him to the charge-room, there were seven or eight men there, he went straight to Hastie and said, "That is the man; I saw him receive the money from the third man"â€”Hastie said, "I am as innocent as a newborn baby"â€”I went with him in a cab to King's Gross, where he made a statement in my hearing.

ARTHUR SEWELL (Detective Sergeant G). On 29th October, about nine p.m., I took Bailey in Old Street on a warrant for perjury and subornation to commit perjury, which was read to him at the stationâ€”he said, "It was not my fault"â€”I looked for Brown during October and November, but could not find him; I know his parents' address.
Cross-examined. He lived at the station till he was suspendedâ€”it is within my knowledge that he only went to his parents the day before ho was apprehended.

ALFRED GOULD (Detective Sergeant). On 8th December I went with a warrant to Stutton, near Ipswich, to the house of Brown's parents, and saw Brown thereâ€”I had been looking for him for some timeâ€”he said, "I am pleased to see you come for me, sergeant, as I intended giving myself up in the morning to the county police."

BROWN and BAILEY
GUILTY on the Third Count

BROWNâ€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

BAILEYâ€”
Four Months' Hard Labour.

176.
ARTHUR JAMES OVERY (22)
PLEADED GUILTY to two indictments for stealing post letters containing two postal orders, the property of
H. M. Postmaster-General.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

177.
JOSEPH THOMAS NIOHOLLS (37)
, Unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, 15s., Â£6 6s., and other money;
also attempting to obtain Â£50.

PHILIP DELOW . I am a farmer, of Potter's Farm, Stanford-le-Hope, Essexâ€”early last year I wished to borrow Â£100, and saw an advertisement in the Essex Weekly 'News, in consequence of which I wrote to Mr. J. T. Nicholls, Savoy House, Strand, London, and on February 7th I received this reply. (Enclosing an application form to be filled up and returned)â€”I have seen the prisoner write; this is his writingâ€”I filled up the prospectus and enclosed a post office order for 15s., and in a few days I called at Savoy House and saw the prisoner, who said he wanted six guineas, and then he would grant me the Â£100â€”I gave him Â£2 and promised to send the rest by post-office orderâ€”I went home, and somebody afterwards called on me and I paid him the balance of the six guineasâ€”when I was at Nicholls' office he said he would send me the money on Friday or Saturday, but I never received itâ€”I afterwards received this letter. (Dated February 29th, 1891, from the prisoner, asking the witness to send him the amount of his rent, Â£50, to April 6th, upon which he would send the loan.)â€”I afterwards received this telegram:

"Send up the Â£50 by next post, and will arrange satisfactorily.â€”Nicholls."â€”I did not send itâ€”he had asked me to send the Â£50 rent, so that he could hold it in hand, and then he would let me have the loanâ€”that was after I had paid him the six guineasâ€”I refusedâ€”on March 2nd I received this letter. (From the prisoner, stating that he could not proceed further till he received the amount of the rent, and offering to return the amount paid for telegrams.)â€”I still declined, and received this letter. (Dated March 4th, inquiring whether the witness intended to send the amount of rent, as the landlord had the first claim.)â€”I again refused, and then received this letter. (Dated March 6th, from the prisoner, to the same effect.)â€”after that I called on the prisoner with my wife, at Savoy House, and he wanted Â£15 more for interest on the loan; I paid him Â£10 down, and sent him Â£5 by post-office order the same nightâ€”he said there was going to be a large committee there, and he would send the loan down early on Saturday morning, if he did not on Fridayâ€”I received no moneyâ€”I wrote to him, and received this letter. (Dated March 10th, from the prisoner, stating that he would write at the end of the week.)â€”I called at Savoy House on the 23rd, but he would not be seenâ€”he told me two or three weeks running that he would send it on Friday or Saturdayâ€”I afterwards got this letter (Dated March 28th, from the prisoner, stating that he would send the cash on Friday, or that the witness could call on Saturday; but it would be better to send it to save the expense of coming up.)â€”I never received the moneyâ€”on April 4th I called again with my wife, and the prisoner said that he would send it on Friday or Saturdayâ€”I went again, and he would not be seen; his clerk talked to him through a tube, and then said Mr. Nicholls was not well and could not see us to-dayâ€”we called again on the Saturday, and he said he could not pay us then, but if we called at three o'clock he would grant us the loan; we called at three, and waited till nearly four, but the office was locked upâ€”I never received any portion of the moneyâ€”I believed he was carrying on the business of a money-lender, and that induced me to part with the money.

Cross-examined. I live on the Southend line, twenty stations down; someone came down from Nicholls one morning to value my property; he was there about half a dayâ€”someone also came down from the Charing Cross Bank; I do not know who or what he came forâ€”the Charing Cross Bank was not named to meâ€”I am not aware that they were to negotiate the loanâ€”the six guineas were not to pay for the valuationâ€”the second valuation did not take a whole dayâ€”the prisoner has not offered to pay me Â£15 on several occasions; he has never offered to repay me or to pay me any moneyâ€”he did not say he could pay me if I would take Â£15â€”I have been farming twelve months last Michaelmasâ€”I began in December, but I took the farm before thatâ€”the rent is Â£50 a year, and the tithe Â£50; I pay Â£100â€”I would not take Â£150 for my furnitureâ€”I received this letter asking whether he should send the Â£15.
Re-examined. There were two valuations, both prior to my parting with the Â£15, and prior to his letter asking me for the Â£50 rentâ€”I had this letter of March 6th before I paid the Â£15.

ESTHER DELOW . I am the wife of the last witnessâ€”I went to the prisoner's office twice with my husband, who paid the prisoner Â£5 on the first occasionâ€”we did not see the prisoner on the second occasion; he

had locked himself upâ€”I heard his voice speaking to his clerk through a pipe, but could not hear what he said; but it was that he could not see us; we called again on the 3rd, and found the office locked up.

Cross-examined. I was standing against the door when I heard his voiceâ€”I saw him against the door, and he locked himself inâ€”he told us to go on the Saturday, and my husband wentâ€”the prisoner said he would return the Â£15 which had been paid for interest, but he would not return the Â£6 6s. unless we had the Â£100; he told me once, in a letter, that he would let us have all the money back if we did not have the loanâ€”Mr. Kershaw has the letterâ€”I know that he was trying to get the loan from the Charing Cross Bank to lend to usâ€”I do not know that a valuer came down from the Charing Cross Bankâ€”the valuer did not demur to the furniture and fixtures and say that they were worth much less than my husband statedâ€”I did not speak to him, but he said to me, "Mr. Nicholls will let you have the money"â€”I was surprised afterwards to see another valuer, but I did not know which bank he came from; he said he had come to value our fieldâ€”I was told afterwards that this valuation was from another officeâ€”I believed we were doing business with Mr. Nicholls.

Re-examined. We received a communication from the prisoner prior to the second valuer coming downâ€”this letter of February 17th states that he had not been able to come down owing to the foggy weather, and here is another of February 7th. (This was to the same effect.)

JOHN WORTHER . I am a clerk in the High Court of Justice, Bankruptcy Departmentâ€”I produce the file of proceedings in the bankruptcy of Joseph Thomas Nichollsâ€”the petition is dated March 24th, 1891, and the judgment alsoâ€”the adjudication is May 27thâ€”the prisoner filed a statement of accounts on 14th July, and an amended statement on the 25th, by which it appears that his debts amounted to Â£2,109 19s. 10d., and the assets were nil.

DANIEL JOHNSON . I am ledger-keeper at the London and County Bank, Covent Garden branchâ€”the prisoner had an account there which ceased in 1890â€”no money has been paid in sinceâ€”he had the account two years and nine months.

THOMAS WILLIAM KERR . I am a clerk in the office of the Official Receiverâ€”I produce the books supplied to the prisoner for the purpose of the bankruptcyâ€”I have not examined them; a few entries were made in March, but nothing of any consequence; nothing in the way of substantial business being carried on on the premisesâ€”none of the entries in March relate to Delow.

CHARLES GATTAN (Detective Sergeant E). On October 8th I received a warrant for the prisoner's apprehension, and took him on the afternoon of the 30th; I read the warrant to himâ€”he said, "I cannot explain that, I have offered to pay the money back"â€”I took him to Bow Street; he made no reply to the chargeâ€”I found some papers in a small hand-bag.

GUILTY*.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

178.
ELLEN GILES (37)
, Feloniously throwing a corrosive fluid upon
Charles Goodson, with intend to disfigure. Second Count, to do grievous bodily harm.

GEORGE DAVID LOWE KNIGHT . I am a surgeon, of 410, Brixton Roadâ€”on Monday morning, 14th May, about one, I saw the prosecutorâ€”he was suffering from burns on the right side of the face and neckâ€”his vest and shirt were burnt right through, evidently by some corrosive fluid; I should say it was oil of vitriol, sulphuric acid, that is the only fluid that would do itâ€”I saw the bottle; nothing was left in it but just a film of fluid, which was very acidâ€”the burns on the clothes show that the fluid must have been oil of vitriol.

CHARLES GOODSON . I am a carpenter, and live at 2, Sussex Road, Brixtonâ€”the prisoner lived with me as my wife for about three yearsâ€”on Sunday night, 13th December, about eleven, we were both in the room; I was on the bed with my coat offâ€”my wife was sitting on a chair by the side of the bedâ€”she had come in about eleven, after meâ€”she had had a little to drink, I was soberâ€”she went to a little dressing-table drawer, and pulled out a bottle; I did not know what it wasâ€”she put it to her mouth, I thought she was going to take something, then she dashed it in my face; I happened to turn round at the time and it came in my faceâ€”as I moved to get out at the door I could feel it was something burning me, and she dashed it at me as I went to get out of the room; it went right down the side of my face, the rest was in the back of my hair, as I was retreatingâ€”before this there had been some noise about some woman, unknown to me; she said she was going to do it; I thought she meant burning some pawnticketsâ€”I rushed out to go to a doctor, and met the police sergeantâ€”I told him about it, and I gave her in charge; she came back with meâ€”my waistcoat and shirt were injured; I saw the bottle found in the fireplaceâ€”I cannot say that it is the same bottle that she took out of the drawer; there had been a label on it, but it was burnt off; it was quite hot when the sergeant took it upâ€”these (produced) are the garments I had onâ€”I had no use for any corrosive fluid in my business or the prisoner's.

Cross-examined. On the Sunday we drank together; I had some four ale, and you had some port wineâ€”you have given me fourteen black eyes in less than six monthsâ€”you have brought this all on yourselfâ€”you have come at night and annoyed me with your drunken fits; was a woman to stand all this and say nothing?

JOHN PALMER (Police Sergeant 55 W). On Sunday night, 13th, I was at Loughborough Park Station, and saw Goodson there; he was without hat, coat or bootsâ€”I saw him go to Dr. Powers; he made a complaint to meâ€”I noticed his head was very wetâ€”he was very excited, rubbing his neckâ€”I looked at the back of his neck, it was very redâ€”Dr. Powers examined himâ€”I went with Goodson to 2, Sussex Road; I saw the prisoner thereâ€”in her presence he said she did itâ€”he said, "I shall give her into custody"â€”she said, "I will go with you"â€”she was taken to the station and chargedâ€”when the charge was read over she said, "Yes, I did it; and I wish I had killed him"â€”I left her at the station, and went back and examined the roomâ€”there were signs of a struggle; the bed was in order, and there was a lot of fluid on the bedclothes, and it had burnt holes, and some on the floor

and wall; there were splashes on the wall, and the wood-work and flooring were slightly eaten in with the liquidâ€”there was evidently more than one dash of the liquid, evidently twoâ€”I searched for a bottle, and found this one in the fire-place, downstairs, not in the bedroomâ€”there was very slight Are in the fire-placeâ€”the bottle was quite hot; there was a label, it was partly rubbed off; I could see distinctly the word "Poison" on the label; it has been rubbed off since.
Prisoner's defence. He treated me very badly, and I could not stand it any longer; I meant to take it myself, only he annoyed me, and I did do it thenâ€”I did not know what was in the bottle.

GUILTY, under very great provocation. â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

179.
EMILY SPRINGALL (42)
, Unlawfully neglecting
William Walter Springall, aged five months, in a manner likely to cause suffering and injury to his health.

JOHN JONES . I am assistant foreman on the London and Southwestern. Railway, and live at 4, Alma Road, Larkhall Lane, Claphamâ€”the prisoner came to lodge with me on Friday, 4th November; she occupied one roomâ€”she brought with her two children, a baby about five months old and a little girl fifteen years oldâ€”on Saturday the 7th, she was drunk, violent, and very abusive, using Very filthy language; this continued till 9 or 10 o'clock at night, she then went outâ€”she came back about half-past twelve so drunk that she fell on the stairs with the baby in her armsâ€”my wife got out of bed and took the baby from her, and kept it for some time, while I carried the prisoner up to her room and put her on the floorâ€”I heard her say several times, "You bâ€”â€”, little bâ€”â€”, I will chop your bâ€”â€”little head off"â€”on the Sunday and Monday and Tuesday she was very quietâ€”on Wednesday night she was drunkâ€”I did not see the baby at all during the Week, not till the following Saturday, the 12th, when the prisoner came home drunk at two in the afternoon, using vile languageâ€”I had given her notice to leave on the Monday; she had the baby in her arms, and she said, "I will cut your bâ€”â€”little throat"â€”she threw open her window and was screaming out; the neighbours came round and complained, and I went to the station, and a constable was sent to the houseâ€”she went out between eight and nine, and I saw no more of her till she returned at a quarter past twelveâ€”she went upstairs swearing, and she went into her room; I went up after her and tried the door, but could not open it; my wife came up, and then the door was thrown wide open, and I saw a man hiding behind the doorâ€”I asked the daughter if it was her father; she said, "No," and I put the man outâ€”all this time the baby was lying, on the bed crying violentlyâ€”the prisoner was drunk and violent; she had a can of beer in her hand, and said she would break every window in the houseâ€”I gave her a push, and she staggered and fell over an earthenware jar; she would not get up, and I said the best thing was to christen her, and I sprinkled some water over her face; at last she quieted down, and went to sleepâ€”I heard noises and bad language in the night, and then a yell, and I went and fetched a constable.

ALICE SPRINGALL . The prisoner is my mother, I live with herâ€”I am sixteenâ€”my little brother was five months oldâ€”on Saturday, 12th December, I went out at a quarter to ten to see a little friend homeâ€”I

came back at a quarter to twelveâ€”mother was out, she came in about ten minutes afterwards with Mr. Stubbs, to whom she was going to pay some money; she had the baby, it cried once, but nothing to speak of, because I was at home and looked after it; it did not cry when I had itâ€”Mr. Jones came upstairs and threw some water over mother, saying, she wanted christeningâ€”she was drunkâ€”she had fed the baby about seven o'clock, and she fed it again that nightâ€”in the middle of the night mother roused me and said, "Baby is dead; there is no life," and she asked me to go down and fetch Mrs. Jonesâ€”I did so, and she came up and then fetched a policeman, and he fetched a doctorâ€”when Mr. Stubbs was there the baby was not crying; it was lying on the bed asleepâ€”my father does not live with my mother.
Cross-examined. I never saw you strike the baby or do anything to itâ€”you always fed it from the breast, not with any food; it never wanted for anything.

ARTHUR GORING . I live in Clapham Road, and am a divisional surgeonâ€”on 13th November, about twenty minutes past five, I was called to the house, and saw the child; it was about five months oldâ€”it had been dead between half an hour and an hourâ€”the prisoner was sitting in a chair, hugging the child; she was drunk, and in a very excited stateâ€”I have since made a post-mortem examinationâ€”there were no external marks of violenceâ€”the body was well nourishedâ€”the stomach was quite emptyâ€”some hours must have elapsed since it had had food; between three and four hours; that would be a longer time than usualâ€”I did not examine the prisoner to see whether she had milk for the childâ€”the immediate cause of death was pressure on the brain from a clot; there was the rupture of a small vessel at the base of the brainâ€”I could not say whether the child had had a fitâ€”I should say either a fit or screaming would produce such a ruptureâ€”want of food would cause screaming.

JOSEPH DUBERRY (446 W). On 13th November I went with Jones to the prisoner's roomâ€”she was there, and had the child in her armsâ€”I asked her several times to lay it down; she refused to do soâ€”I asked her if the child was deadâ€”she said it wasâ€”I looked at itâ€”the prisoner was very excited, and appeared to be drunkâ€”I fetched the doctor, and he said it was deadâ€”the room was in a very dirty state; the bed was a heap of rags; I did not see a sheet or blanket on the bed.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi:
The prisoner was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the
manslaughter of the said child,upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

180.
HENRY JONES** (25) and
JOHN SMITH** (22)
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully attempting to commit burglary.â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour each.

181.
JAMES FREDERICK NOLAN
, Unlawfully converting to his own use Â£95 13s. 2d., which was entrusted to him with a direction in writing.

p.hi: The prosecutor instructed the defendant to purchase a marked lot in the catalogue of an auction tea sale, and the prisoner afterwards applied for and received from him a cheque for the money, which he afterwards stated he had used for his own purposes. The
ruled that this did not amount to a direction in writing, and directed a verdict of

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

182.
CHARLES FLINT and
JAMES BROWN
, Unlawfully conspiring to steal the goods of
John Charles Potter and Co.

JOHN WOODS . I am manager to C. and C. J. Potter, paper stainers and manufacturersâ€”we employ nearly 2,000 workmenâ€”the basement of our London premises is part store-room and part officesâ€”Flint has been our salesman twenty-seven or twenty-eight yearsâ€”his wages were 27s. a weekâ€”I have seen Brown thereâ€”we have three salesmen on the ground floor and one on the basement, each of whom is provided with a book similar to this (produced) which is Flint's book; it is a manifold book in triplicate, two copies being made by the usual carbon paperâ€”the salesman hands the book to the cashier, and the cash boy takes the extension of the items, and takes the cash, and takes one of the triplicates out and puts it on a file, and tears out the second and gives it to the customer, receipted, or. to the salesman for the customer, and the third remains in the bookâ€”in consequence of information I had set a watch prior to December 7thâ€”on December 9th Brown came to the warehouse about 12.15 and went down alone into the basement where Flint was"â€”he then came from the basement with Flint, who had a parcel in his hand wrapped in white paperâ€”he went to the front counter, wrapped it in Drown paper, and tied it with stringâ€”I saw him make out the triplicate note in a book which he handed into the office to the cash boyâ€”Gerald Daniels was the clerk at the cash deskâ€”Flint gave the parcel to Brown, who left the warehouseâ€”Detective Saunders, whom I had employed, was outsideâ€”I went out to the Bed lion in Cannon Street, and saw Brown; the roll of paper was leaning in a corner close to himâ€”I said, "I think you have just got back the parcel of goods from the firm; can I see it?" I had been to the cash desk and ascertained that it was eight pieces of lining at 4d., 2s. 8d.; he did not answer me, and was very much agitatedâ€”I tore the end of the wrapper out, and there were four pieces of sanitary paper in it, six pieces of bedroom paper, and one piece of border, value 9s. 4d.â€”they were all papers which we manufactureâ€”there was no lining paper there at allâ€”I have seen some scraps of paper produced from a house at Deptford; they were all made by usâ€”I said, "Where is the white lining paper you bought?"â€”he said, "These are a few pieces that are not lining paper; I have two or three pieces besides"â€”the detective was outside in plain clothesâ€”I went back to the warehouse and called Flint, who followed me into the office, Brown followed him, and the detective lastâ€”Flint spoke first; he said, "They were given in exchange for some goods I had to return"â€”Brown repeated that and added, "One a piece of border"â€”one of the partners was there, and they were chargedâ€”Flint said to the partner, "I hope

you will look over this affair, it will be a great disgrace to me with your family; the amount is not much, and I will repay it"â€”I said to Brown, "You were in here on Monday"â€”he said, "I was not"â€”I showed Flint the cash paperâ€”this entry is in Flint's writing; "December 7, Mr. Brown, four oil, eight oaks, three lining, at 4d., 1s.; six, numbered 438, at 1s. 6d. Received with thanks, pro C. C. W., E. W."â€”those are the initials of the witness Whiteâ€”Flint said, "This is not the Brown; it is another Brown"â€”I saw this counterfoil of the very document found on Brownâ€”at that time Brown had not been searched, and Flint did not know that the invoice would be found on himâ€”they were given in charge and taken to the stationâ€”a detective was sent down to where Brown workedâ€”Neville showed me pieces of some of our 1892 patternsâ€”there is no record in our books of 1891 of any cash sale to Brown of papers of this descriptionâ€”Brown bought the cheapest goods we had.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I have been five years at the London branch of the businessâ€”before I was engaged at the mills I was travellingâ€”I have not ascertained that Flint has been in the service of the firm since he was thirteen years of age; we generally send our books to the paper-mill to be destroyed every ten yearsâ€”there has been a change in the management and in the partnershipâ€”customers sometimes desire to change their papers, but we do not always do it; if we do it an entry is made in the rough-credit book, which is open to all the salesmen on the ground floor and basementâ€”we should give you a credit note for the difference, and if you did not like to take it we should give you the moneyâ€”I am not supposed to know that they make mistakesâ€”if I suspected a man I should be more strict; the difficulty would be less with an old hand, he would know his duty so much betterâ€”Flint practically had carte blanche; there was no restriction in the warehouse to his getting goods of every sort and descriptionâ€”I have seen Brown there frequently as a customer during the five years I have been thereâ€”he might not say to a customer, "You may have this and bring it back to-morrow,"because we have spoken to him about it very oftenâ€”we never allow a man to have goods for others which he has not brought backâ€”I have not looked through Flint's book to see whether the entries are put against the lining, but instructions were given to himâ€”all papers bear numbers.

Cross-examined by MR. WARBURTON. I have never seen this card beforeâ€”I understood that Flint lived at Enfieldâ€”I do not know that Brown has been in the habit of dealing with other people in a large way; I have found out nothing about him; I could not find out where he lived, though I asked Flintâ€”this was in broad daylightâ€”he had no bag; I took the parcel and asked him if I could open it; he made no reply.

Re-examined. About eighteen people are employed at Cannon Street; we have three recognised salesmen, but seven or eight people act as salesmen if we are busyâ€”if a cash customer has purchased goods, the number would be specified on the ticket, and desires to exchange them; the number is specified on the ticket, and that would be deducted from the total, and he would pay the differenceâ€”if a customer brings back paper and does not make a purchase he gets a credit noteâ€”Brown has been during the last twelve months, and has dealt largely in quantity, but not
in priceâ€”we have sold him more of one pattern than we hare received from the mill.

WILLIAM SANDERS (City Detective). I was employed on private business at Messrs. Potters, and was there on December 9th, and saw Brown leave with a parcel; he went into the Bed Lionâ€”I told Mr. Ward, who went into the Red Lion, while I waited outsideâ€”he came back, and we were passing through the warehouse into Mr. Wood's private office, and as we passed Flint he said to Flint, "Say, change"â€”I was in plain clothesâ€”I heard Flint say that that was not the same Brownâ€”I found a counterfoil of this entry on Brown.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. Both Flint and Brown went into the office, and one partner was there; Brown never mentioned "Change"in my hearing.

WILLIAM WOODS . I am clerk to the prosecutorsâ€”I saw Brown come into the warehouse about 2.30 on the 7thâ€”he came in again at 3.30â€”he came in again on the 9thâ€”he had nothing with himâ€”he asked for Flint on the 7th, who was not in, and he went out againâ€”I saw Flint there with Brown at 3.30 on the 7th; Hint took four pieces of sanitary paper from the rack, which were made up in brown paper, and I did not see them againâ€”I have seen the invoices found on him, there is nothing about sanitary paperâ€”the price of the paper is from 1s. to 4s. 3d.â€”I was acting under instructionsâ€”I saw Flint, on the 7th, pass his invoice-book into the cash desk.
GEORGE WHITE . I am entering clerk to Messrs. Potterâ€”on December 7th Flint passed me in his book, and this is the fac-simile of my writing by manifold.

GERALD DANIEL . I am entering clerk to the prosecutorsâ€”I was at the desk on December 9th when the bill was made out from Flint to Brown for paper, price 2s. 8d.â€”I handed the 2s. 8d. to the detectiveâ€”no entry was made to Brown that day but this one, to my knowledge.

EDWARD NEVILLE . I am a traveller, employed at 51, Cannon Streetâ€”I accompanied Saunders to Bow Street on the 9th, and saw these remnants of paper which would be sold by Potter and Co.; nineteen out of the twenty were 1891 patternsâ€”I made inquiries about Brown, and went to a house at Rotherhithe where some papering work had been done, and some of this sanitary paper used; the job required more paper to finish itâ€”the paper was of the kind sold by Potter and Co., and a dado border was required to complete itâ€”I saw Brown come to 51, Cannon Street on the 7th and 9th; he brought no parcel on either occasion; to the best of my recollection he had his hands in his pockets.

GUILTY.â€” Recommended to mercy by the fury. â€”
Ten Months' Imprisonment each, without Hard Labour.

183.
JESSIE LAZENBY (22)
PLEADED GUILTY to forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£10, with intent to defraud.â€”
Four Months Hard Labour.

184.
FRANK BALDWIN (26)
, to obtaining, by false pretences, from
Frederick Oatley Bynoe,
Robert King, and others, photo
graphic lenses, with intent to defraud,
and to four other indictments for forging orders for delivery of lenses.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour. And
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(185).
ARTHUR KING (50)
, to feloniously demanding money, with menacesâ€”
To enter into recognisances of Â£20 to come up for judgment when called upon.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

186.
FREDERICK SHELL (24),
HENRY KING (19), and
ROSE SMITH (18)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Lawrence Bucknill, and stealing four coats and other goods, his property.

â€”SHELL and KING
PLEADED GUILTY .

EDWARD JOHNSTON (22 Y). I noticed the shop window broken at 153, Caledonian Road, Islingtonâ€”the hole in the window was large enough for a man to put his hand throughâ€”there was an iron railing in front of the windowâ€”I made inquiriesâ€”I went with Marony to 44, Pulteney Street, Islingtonâ€”the prisoners were thereâ€”I knockedâ€”Smith said, "Who's there?"â€”I said, "I want to see your husband"â€”she made no replyâ€”I knocked again and received no answerâ€”I knocked a third time and said if the door was not opened I would force itâ€”I received no answerâ€”I forced the doorâ€”the prisoners were in bed togetherâ€”on the floor were seventeen shirts, five coats, trousers, vests, and handkerchiefs, which have been identified as having been stolen from the shopâ€”I said, "Get up; you will be charged with committing a burglary at 153. Caledonian Road"â€”I convened them to the station in a cab.
JOHN AKERS (576 Y). At 12.30 a.m., on 24th December, I saw Smith with Shell in the Caledonian Road, near Copenhagen Street, at a distance of about 150 yards from the prosecutor's premises.

JOHN LAWRENCE BUCKNILL . I am an outfitter, at 153, Caledonian Roadâ€”my shop was safely shut up at 11 p.m. on 23rd Decemberâ€”the shop front was quite safeâ€”I was disturbed by the police about three a.m. on 24thâ€”I found my shop window had been brokenâ€”the articles (produced) are a portion of those I missedâ€”I was shown them by the police, and have identified them as my propertyâ€”these things could have been reached by a man's hand being thrust through the windowâ€”I knew the prisoners by sight.

STEPHEN MARONY (Police Constable Y). I went with Johnston to 44, Pulteney Streetâ€”we apprehended the prisonersâ€”they were taken to the station in a cabâ€”after a statement by Shell, Smith said, "I know who put us away. "
Smith's defence. I never said that I am innocentâ€”it was not my place to get up and open the doorâ€”I was at home at 11.30 when they came homeâ€”it seems very hard I should be brought into it.

SMITHâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

SHELL PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction in September, 1889, and KING to a conviction in July 1889, at this Court.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude each.

187.
THOMAS HAMMOND
, Unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, orders for the payment of Â£71 15s. 6d., Â£80 18s. 8d., and Â£71 17s. 1d.; and other Counts for making false entries, with intent to defraud.
ALFRED HODGKINSON . I am a solicitor, and Deputy-Coroner for the

North-Eastern District of the County of Londonâ€”I keep a diary showing the inquests I holdâ€”the expenses of each inquest are entered on a voucherâ€”at the close of each inquest the prisoner's duty was to pay the expenses, and put the voucher-paper for my signatureâ€”voucher 40 relates to an inquest upon the body of Charles Reeceâ€”I held the inquest on 19th August, at the Old Ford Smead Road Board school, and not at the Vestry Hall as described on the voucherâ€”I find a charge of 5s. for removing the body to the mortuary, and 7s. for hire of the room for the inquestâ€”those expenses were not incurred nor allowed by meâ€”those figures were not on when I signed the voucherâ€”the total stood at 7s.â€”it is now Â£1 19s.â€”the body was in the house where the deceased died, and the inquest was held in the Board schoolroomâ€”they are in the same streetâ€”voucher 49 relates to an inquest on the body of Frank Whiteâ€”I held that inquest at the Shoreditch Town Hall, and not at the Vestry Hall in the Old Artillery Ground as describedâ€”on the same day I held two inquests at the Shoreditch Town Hallâ€”there would be only one payment of 7s. for the hue of the roomâ€”I find by voucher 47 that 7s. was paid, and was properly charged in the first inquestâ€”the 7s. was not paid on the inquest on the body of Frank Whiteâ€”this voucher of the inquest was not signed by meâ€”I did not authorise anybody to sign itâ€”those are the only two inquests I held in this case.

Cross-examined. The vouchers would be presented to me at the end of the three inquestsâ€”No. 40 being one inquest, would be presented at the end of the inquestâ€”I have no doubt I looked at the heading before I signed itâ€”I did not notice "Vestry Hall, Bow," or I should have altered the wordsâ€”I do not say whether the words were in or outâ€”I am not in the habit of signing without noticing the place insertedâ€”in a document like that with die confidence I had in the prisoner I took it to be properly filled upâ€”in Shoreditch I might sign the document without the place being inserted in it, but not in Bowâ€”the heading is always put before the inquest is heldâ€”the place might be changed prior to the jury being summonedâ€”the place might be changed after it is filled inâ€”it might be filled in too soonâ€”I said at the Police-court the place of holding the inquest might be altered at the request of friendsâ€”vouchers sometimes have alterations upon them at the time I sign themâ€”I will swear the 7s. and the 5s. were not in when I signed the voucherâ€”I always check the figures before I sign the voucherâ€”I held three inquests on 19th of August, one at Tottenham, another at Hackney, but this was the only one in the prisoner's districtâ€”the voucher was shown to me by the County Council early in Decemberâ€”No. 49 also has the wrong addressâ€”the body was tying in the Shoreditch Mortuaryâ€”the old Artillery Ground is between Spitalfields and the mortuaryâ€”that is not in Bow; it is a long way offâ€”Old Ford refers to No. 40â€”I cannot tell you whether the inquest was held at the Board school at the request of the father of the boyâ€”I never heard of the rule that the Coroner should settle with his officer at the end of each inquestâ€”if the officer wanted money ht would ask, and I would give it himâ€”it was not the Coroners duty to recoup for the expenses incurred after each inquestâ€”Dr. Macdonald would have no knowledge of my expenses, except I made a declarationâ€”on one occasion I made a declarationâ€”I signed vouchers, but not these.
Re-examined. In case of an alteration I always initialled the voucher

â€”the hire of the hall would not be paid before the inquest, but amounts to be paid might be inserted in the voucherâ€”the prisoner would not get the signature of the witness before the inquest, nor pay the money.

RODERIC MACDONALD , M. D. I am Coroner for the North-Eastern District of the County of Londonâ€”the London part of the district is divided into three sub-districtsâ€”the prisoner is my officer for one districtâ€”he was also clerk of the office in which the accounts of the whole district were keptâ€”it was his duty to make out vouchers for each inquest, showing expenses paidâ€”also to pay the expensesâ€”he ought to obtain the signature of the person to whom each item was paid upon the voucher and place it before me to signâ€”in the office he kept the registerâ€”in it he would enter the totals of the amounts paid at each inquestâ€”at the conclusion of each month I send the vouchers to the London County Council, with a statutory declaration that they are correct, and obtain payment from the Councilâ€”the prisoner rendered me an account at the end of each month, showing how he stoodâ€”I supplied him from time to time with the money he wanted, and settled up at the end of each month with a chequeâ€”voucher 4, of 4th November, 1890, refers to an inquest held by meâ€”it purports to show two sums of one guinea each were paid to Dr. Ryan, one for giving evidence, and the other for a post-mortem examinationâ€”it appears to be signed by Dr. Ryanâ€”the signature for the post-mortem is similar in appearance to the first signatureâ€”the total is Â£2 14s.â€”it appears to have been altered from Â£1 13s.â€”the total in the register is entered as Â£2 14s.â€”that appears to have been alteredâ€”I have the depositions I took on that inquestâ€”I find there was no post-Mortem examinationâ€”looking at the voucher 18, 8th November, I did not hold that inquestâ€”the voucher shows two sums of one guinea paid to Dr. Roberts for giving evidence and holding a post-mortem examinationâ€”Dr. Roberts' signatures are against the itemsâ€”the second signature is like the firstâ€”the total is Â£2 17s.â€”that appears to have been altered from Â£ 16s.,â€”the register appears to have been altered in the same wayâ€”looking at the depositions, I find there was no postmortem examinationâ€”on 13th January, 1891, I held an inquest on the body of William Downsâ€”I find two sums of one guinea entered to Dr. Barber with his signature against eachâ€”the signatures are like each otherâ€”the total, Â£2 18s., appears to have been altered from Â£1 16s. or Â£1 17sâ€”I find from the depositions there was no post-mortemâ€”it is entered in the register as Â£2 18s.â€”I have my original slip of thatâ€”it appears to have been altered in the register, but it is not so definite as the othersâ€”I made out the expenses of each inquest separate from the voucherâ€”that was checked with the voucherâ€”my slip shows the amount of expenses of the inquest was Â£1 16s.â€”these slips have been retained in the office for the purpose of comparisonâ€”on 30th May, 1891, I held an inquest on the body of John Smithâ€”that voucher shows two sums of one guinea paid to Dr. Barber, with his signature against eachâ€”the total is Â£3 1s.â€”that has been altered from Â£2 1s. registry entry is Â£3 1s.â€”I find from the depositions no post-mortem examinationâ€”I have the slip showing Â£2â€”on 17th June, 1891 I held an inquest on the body of Hannah Reesâ€”a guinea is entered Dr. Phillips for post-mortem examinationâ€”the total has been altered from Â£1 11s. to Â£2 12s.â€”it is changed in the same way in the register-for each month in which these inquests

were held I have settled with the prisoner by giving him a cheque to pay expensesâ€”the amounts have been drawnâ€”these are the chequesâ€”these are the accounts which the prisoner rendered to me, showing the total sums dueâ€”they are made up on the supposition that the register is. correctâ€”I have paid the larger amounts how appearing on the voucher to the prisonerâ€”I have received those amounts from the County Councilâ€”in consequence of an investigation at the offices of the County Council, my attention was called to this matter by the Council.

Cross-examined. I have been satisfied with the prisoner's conduct in every wayâ€”I never bad reason to complain of him; I found him a capital servantâ€”these vouchers were prepared in the office ready for the sums to be obtainedâ€”rarely an inquest has been changed at the last momentâ€”as to No. 40, the inquest would have taken place at the Vestry Hall, which is in the parish of Bow, had it not been held at the Board School, and the prisoner would naturally fill in "Vestry Hall, Bow"â€”he would put in the voucher beforehand the expenses which one expects to be incurred, such as 5s. for the Jury, 5s. for removal of body, and 7s. for the hire of the roomâ€”there is nothing irregular in thatâ€”the place of inquest was changed to oblige the peopleâ€”the number of my inquests vary, but they average about twenty a weekâ€”some days I might have ten or twelve, or even moreâ€”there is plenty of time for the vouchersâ€”I do not agree that the vouchers are frequently completed very hurriedly, they may be in Mr. Hodgkinson's casesâ€”I give the same answer when the inquests are ten in a dayâ€”we then have always to rush from one inquest to anotherâ€”I sign the vouchers in batches; not after every separate inquestâ€”one batch may include five, six, seven, or eight inquestsâ€”the officer would get the signatures of the witnesses as we were going alongâ€”the prisoner would have to continue paying expensesâ€”he could ask for a cheque on account, and occasionally I gave him oneâ€”I have seen other alterations in the registerâ€”I find some hereâ€”there are instances of alteration where the voucher has been accurateâ€”they may have arisen in consequence of witnesses having left the Court without signing, and their signatures have had to be obtainedâ€”that has not arisen from hurryâ€”in cases where a post-mortem is held, as a, matter of course Hammond was understood to give the order; but where there was any doubt, Hammond consulted me, and I crave the orderâ€”he gave the order in a number of oasesâ€”if he had given the order he might insert the amount in the voucher before the inquest; or if he intended, because it was known whether a post-mortem would be heldâ€”in most cases he would have authority to insert one guinea for the doctor's attendance, not alwaysâ€”the vouchers would all be in Hammond's 'possession at the end of the dayâ€”they would be filed in the officeâ€”at the end of the month I would sign a statutory declaration verifying the amountsâ€”I should have the vouchers by me when I signed the declarationâ€”there was nothing to prevent my examining them and detecting a mistakeâ€”Mr. Hodgkinson's vouchers were in Hammond's chargeâ€”when I signed the declaration they would be includedâ€”an improvement would be to write the totals in words, but I had implicit trust in the prisonerâ€”Mr. Hodgkinson had an opportunity of examining. the vouchers, and sometimes the statutory declaration would not be made at his office, but another near at handâ€”I would not sign for Mr. Hodgkinson unless I knew he had an opportunity of checking the vouchersâ€”
I have known Hammond a very long time, but he has been my officer only three and a half years.

Re-examined. I never critically examined the vouchers at the end of the month; I took it for granted they were in the same condition as when they left my handsâ€”if an item in a voucher had not been incurred it would have been my duty to strike it outâ€”this slip is made out for the day's workâ€”I compare it with the voucherâ€”the alterations must have been subsequentâ€”except one, the alterations are all to larger figures.

WALTER BARBER . I am a licentiate of physic and qualified medical man, practising at Roman Road, Bowâ€”I gave evidence at the inquest on the body of William Downs, held on 13th January, 1891â€”I did not make a post-mortem examinationâ€”that is my signature against the guinea for giving evidence, but not against the guinea for the post-mortemâ€”I did not authorise anyone to sign itâ€”the second signature is a very good imitationâ€”I gave evidence at the inquest on the body of Edward John Smith, on the 30th May, 1891, for which I received one guineaâ€”I did not make a post-mortem examinationâ€”I received no guinea for sameâ€”the signature opposite it is not mine, nor signed by my authorityâ€”it is very like itâ€”I gave evidence on the 17th of June, 1891, at the inquest on the body of Susannah Beesâ€”I made no postmortem examination, and received no fee for it; this is not my signatureâ€”I did not authorise anyone to sign itâ€”one guinea was paid me by the prisoner for giving evidence.

THOMAS ROBERTS , M. D. I gave evidence at the inquest on the body of Robert Garrod on 8th November, 1890â€”I received one guinea from the prisonerâ€”I did not make a post-mortem examination, nor receive a fee for doing soâ€”that signature is not mine, nor signed by my authorityâ€”it is like my signature.

WILLIAM JOSEPH RYAN , M. D. I gave evidence at the inquest on the body of Mary Ann Newson, held on 4th November, 1890â€”I made no post-mortem examinationâ€”I received a guinea for giving evidence, but not a guinea for a post-mortem examinationâ€”the first of these signatures is mine, but not the secondâ€”I never authorised anyone to sign it.

WILLIAM REES . I am a caretaker at the Smead Road Board Schools, at Bowâ€”my son, Charles Rees, died shortly before 19th August, when the inquest was held by Dr. Macdonald, in my house in the school buildingâ€”the body was not removedâ€”no room was hired, nor any payment made for the room for the inquest.
Cross-examined. The inquest was held at my house, at my own request.

ROBERT LOGAN I am a clerk to the Vestry, at Bowâ€”the offices are at the Vestry Hallâ€”I would be the proper person to receive payments for the hire of rooms at the Vestry Halfâ€”I did not receive any for the inquest held at the Board Schoolâ€”the signature, "Robert Logan,"is not mineâ€”I never authorised it.

Cross-examined. I have been paid for inquests held at the Vestry Hall by the prisonerâ€”I used to settle about every three monthsâ€”I did not wish to receive money in driblets, because I did not give any voucher.
ELIZABETH BEAVIS . I am the daughter of Benjamin Beavis, and live at Fleur-de-Lis Street, Norton Folgateâ€”he is the keeper of the Court

House, Norton Folgateâ€”he is infirm, and unable to attend; he is 67 years of ageâ€”I produce a certificate of his illness. (To the effect that he woe offering from bronchitis, and unable to attend)â€”I have done his writing for him for some timeâ€”I or my sister in my absence sign receipts for himâ€”the signature, "Benjamin Beavis,"referring to the inquest on Frank White, is not my signature, nor my father'sâ€”my father gave evidence at the Police-court; I was present; the prisoner was there. (The deposition of Benjamin Beavis read at follows: "I live at No. 9, Fleur-de-Lis Street, Norton Folgate. I am the keeper of the Court House, at Norton Folgate. It is also the Vestry Office. I look at voucher No. 49, referring to the inquest on the body of Frank White on 23rd September, 1891, the signature on it opposite 7s. is not mine.
Cross-examined. I believe the money has been paid to me.")

CHARLES GETHEN (Policeman E). On 15th December I went to prisoner's house with Dr. Macdonald and Mr. Hodgkinson, the Deputy-Coronerâ€”I arrested the prisoner on a warrant for unlawfully, by false pretences, obtaining from Dr. Macdonald 3s. and 7s., with intent to defraudâ€”he said, "I do not know what this means, but I suppose I must go. "

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
â€”
GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy on account of his old age and long service.
Defalcations stated to have occurred in about 220 cases in two years.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

188.
ELIZA DOWLING (36)
, Breaking and entering the shop of
Louis Senecal, and stealing therein eight necklaces, five albert chains, twenty-six brooches, and three pairs of earrings. Second Count, receiving.

MATTHEW TIERNEY (238 B). I am a police-officer in plain clothesâ€”on 8th January, at 1.30 am., I was on duty in Pelham Streetâ€”the prisoner was loitering about in a very suspicious manner in the Fulham Roadâ€”I watched herâ€”I saw her break the plate-glass of a jeweller's shop, 42A, Fulham Road; the glass is 10 ft. by 8 ft.â€”she afterwards took these articles (produced) from the window, through the broken glass, and ran awayâ€”I produce a list of themâ€”it is correctâ€”I rushed out from my hiding-placeâ€”when she saw me she turned back into the Fulham Road; I apprehended her, I told her I was a police-officer, and should take her into custody for breaking and entering a jeweller's shop, and stealing the articles mentioned in the chargeâ€”she became very violent, in consequence of which I blew my whistleâ€”Kenna came upâ€”with his assistance I took her to the stationâ€”she was chargedâ€”at the window she had a coal-plate, which was afterwards found to have been missed from a few shops offâ€”I heard the glass falling, and the sound of ironâ€”this is a piece of the glass.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I did not see you pick up some things.

JOSEPH KENNA (Sergeant B). About 1.35 a.m., on 8th January, I heard a policeman's whistleâ€”I proceeded in that directionâ€”I saw the prisoner in Tierney's custodyâ€”she was very violent and abusiveâ€”Tierney said he saw her break the window of a jeweller's shop; I took hold of her arms, and a quantity of jewellery dropped to the ground, which was picked up by the constable, and we conveyed her to the stationâ€”while the officer was gone to make inquiries I saw her throwing these brooches and
earrings into the fireâ€”I took them away from herâ€”she made no statement.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. It was not a piece of paper you were throwing into the fire.
SARAH REYNOLDS (Female Searcher). I searched the prisoner about four a. m, on 8th January, I found some jewellery in her pocketâ€”it is in the lift produced.
LOUIS SENECAL . I am a jeweller, of 42A, Fulham Roadâ€”all this jewellery produced is mine.

p.hi: The prisoner's defence was that she did not break the window, but picked up the jewellery.

div1.p: GUILTY .*

â€”She then
PLEADED GUILTY
to a conviction at Clerkenwell in February, 1891.â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.

189.
JAMES LEMAN (18)
, Robbery with violence on
James Cooney, putting him in fear, and stealing his chain and seal.

GEORGE WHITE (Divisional Surgeon of Police).
