I saw the prosecutor about 28th Decemberâ€”he was suffering from twisted shoulders and a swollen and grazed cut, and complained of pains in the abdomen-jaundice supervened; he is unable to leave his roomâ€”I saw him last yesterdayâ€”he has been under my care ever since about 28th December.

ALFRED GOULD (Policeman G). On 1st January I saw Cooney examined in the prisoner's presence, the prisoner had an opportunity of cross-examiningâ€”I apprehended him on the same day, 31st Decemberâ€”I told him the charge; he replied, "All right. "
Deposition of JAMES COONEY, of 477, Liverpool Road, Hollow ay, builder., read:â€”

"On 28th ultimo, between 3.30 and 4 p.m., I was in Castle Street, and a man came behind me and threw me down and took my chain, with 30s., and ran away. As I was getting up another man put his knee in my buck and threw me again. The prisoner is like the man who first attacked me, but I cannot swear to him."

HENRY BATEMAN . I shall be nine in Marchâ€”I knew the prisoner prior to 28th Decemberâ€”I saw him that evening running near Whitfield Street, and two boys following, then the old gentleman [Cooney] comesâ€”I heard the same old gentleman give his evidence at the Police-courtâ€”I. saw the prisoner run down Wood Street and Old Street, when I lost sight of himâ€”I went to the Police-station and said something to the constable.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. It was the other boy who failed to pick you out at the stationâ€”I said I was quite sure it was you.
GEORGE FREDERICK BUSH . On evening of 28th December I saw the prisoner running with two othersâ€”an old gentleman followed, whom I afterwards saw at the Police-court.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I said I was not sure you were the man.
Re-examined. I had previously seen the prisoner hanging about a beer-shop.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate:" I was away from eleven in the morning till a quarter-past eight that night."

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, stated that he was at work that day for his.
father, a bootmaker, and woe not the man running, and another boy named Crow failed to identify him.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

190.
JAMES FITZPATRICK (25)
, Robbery with violence on
John Corbyn, and stealing a metal cross and part of a watch-chain.

JOHN CORBYN . I live at 6, Euston Street, Euston Squareâ€”early on 24th December I passed up Russell Street into Endell Streetâ€”I had a cup of coffeeâ€”two men and a woman asked me to treat themâ€”I said, "I have not money to treat you with"â€”I had two sovereigns, a half sovereign, a watch in my waistcoat pocket, and a shilling in my left trousers pocket, and sixpence in the rightâ€”I had a watch-chainâ€”they pushed me down and held me on the ground, and pressed a hand over my throat; I had no power; they rifled my pocketsâ€”the coffee stall-keeper came and assisted me, and I called "Police!"who came promptly, and deserve the highest commendationâ€”this is a piece of my chainâ€”I had it before I was robbed.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I saw you at the stationâ€”I was not asked to pick you out.

THOMAS BLYTH . I live at 6, Goldsmith's Buildings, Drury Laneâ€”I keep a coffee-stall at the corner of Bow Street and Endell Streetâ€”I was there about 1.30 a.m. on 24th Decemberâ€”the prosecutor came upâ€”the prisoner and two others were thereâ€”I served the prosecutor with a cup of coffee at a halfpenny, when the prisoner and the other two asked him for some tobacco; he said he had not any; they kept saying they lived up towards Euston Square, was he going that way, as they would see him homeâ€”he told me to give the woman a cup of coffee; I said, "Ton have not paid for what you have had"; he said, "That will be all right, I'll pay you for both"â€”I served the young womanâ€”he gave me sixpence, and I gave him threepence-halfpenny changeâ€”they got one on Â«ach side of him, and the prisoner behind him, and got him down in the roadâ€”he cried for help; I ran and picked him upâ€”the prisoner ran awayâ€”I have no doubt he is the man.

HENRY HARWOOD (213 C). I heard a whistle, and went in the direction of Endell Streetâ€”the prisoner ran past meâ€”I turned and ran after him, and threw him downâ€”he pulled the buttons off my coatâ€”he put his hand in his pocket and threw something outâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”I met Hewittâ€”I marked the spot and went back to itâ€”I did not find anythingâ€”I pointed out the place to Hewittâ€”the prisoner was charged at the stationâ€”he made no reply.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. Other constables came up when I caught youâ€”I did not know what you threw away.
Re-examined. I was holding the prisoner.

JOHN HEWITT (392 E). I was on duty in Macklyn Street on 24th Decemberâ€”I saw the prisoner runningâ€”I caught hold of himâ€”he threw me down and fell himselfâ€”I afterwards saw him in the custody of Harwoodâ€”Harwood told me to go to a certain placeâ€”I went thereâ€”I found this piece of chainâ€”I showed it to the prosecutor at the station.
GUILTY .*

â€”He also
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerkenwell in September, 1887.â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

191.
CHARLES AUGUSTUS BYNOE (30)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a warrant for the payment of Â£7 16s., with intent to defraud.

p.hi: were instructed on behalf of the Defendant; but upon consultation with the Defendant it was arranged that he should conduct his own defence.

div1.p: JAMES ADAM KIRK . I live at Walton Villa, East Moleseyâ€”I was intimately acquainted with the late Constance Henrietta Pottsâ€”towards the end of 1888 she went to reside at No. 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”at the same time I went there to reside with her; at that time it was a boardinghouse, kept by the prisoner and his mother, Mrs. Bynoeâ€”I believe the prisoner is a doctor by profession; his practice was conducted at 301, Euston Road, but he lived at 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”Miss Potts' health at that time was very feebleâ€”we remained there to the end of 1889, I thinkâ€”during that time there was a changeâ€”I understood the house was sublet to a Mrs. Cock, and the prisoner and his mother leftâ€”at the time I left Sirs. Cock was still thereâ€”Miss Potts and I went to lodge in Gower Street for a short timeâ€”we then removed to Walton Villa, East Moleseyâ€”towards the end of February we removed to Endsleigh Gardensâ€”I stayed at Walton Villa till the end of July, 1890, and then tame to Londonâ€”from July, 1890, down to July, 189), I find that I once returned to East Molesey, I think about August or September; I never went back after thatâ€”from that time I never saw Miss Potts again during her lifeâ€”she died on 29th July, 1891â€”I went down to see her as she lay dead, but I did not see her, I was only just in time for the funeral, that was early in Augustâ€”between September, 1890, and July, 1891, I did not see Miss Potts at allâ€”she was a lady of independent meansâ€”she was in the habit of consulting me with regard to her business affairs; to my knowledge she had several sums of money invested in different securitiesâ€”she had Â£400 invested in the debenture stock of Messrs. Courage and Co.â€”she consulted me with regard to that investment, and I attested the transfer under which it was passed to herâ€”this is the transfer; it is signed, "James A. Kirk"â€”that is my invariable signatureâ€”I do not believe I ever omitted the initial of my second nameâ€”besides that investment, I know generally of three others, in Euston Procter, the Mortgage Company of the River Plate, and some Â£10 shares in another companyâ€”I was with her from February to July, 1890, when I leftâ€”I can tell you nothing after that.

CHARLES SPREAG . I am secretary of the London and Universal Bank, 449, Strandâ€”the prisoner came"there on 20th February last; he had with him these four dividend warrants; one of Courage and Co., of 1st October, 1890, another of the Mortgage Company of the River Plate of 15th July, 1890, another of the same company of 15th January, 1891, and one of Euston, Procter and Co., of 30th June, 1890â€”he asked to have them cashed for Miss Pottsâ€”I said we could not cash them, but we would collect themâ€”they were made out to Miss Pottsâ€”I asked if Miss Potts had a banking accountâ€”he said no, that she was an in
valid,

and could not leave the houseâ€”I said we should have to send to Endsleigh Gardens, Miss Potts' address, to inquireâ€”I asked her address and he gave itâ€”one was a country cheque, and I said that would have to go away for collection, and would not be cleared for two or three daysâ€”he said, "Very well; and when it is cleared you can post on a cheque to Miss Potts, "the other three he could have later in the dayâ€”I said when they were clearedâ€”he then left and called later in the day, and I paid him in cash for the three warrantsâ€”the fourth cheque I posted; that to 1, Endsleigh Gardens, to Miss Potts, I think on 23rd Februaryâ€”the prisoner came again on 25th with that cheque; it had been inadvertently crossed, and I paid him in cashâ€”I next saw him on 12th March, when he brought this dividend warrant, dated 30th September, 1890, issued by the Buenos Ayres Railway Companyâ€”it was valid only for three months after the date of issueâ€”I noticed that it had been re-datedâ€”that was collected the same as the others; he called back later, and we paid the cash for itâ€”on 2nd April he brought this dividend warrant of 1st April, 1891, issued by Courage and Co., for Â£7 16s.â€”he was paid for that at the timeâ€”he called again on 20th April, and produced this dividend warrant of 17th April, issued by the Buenos Ayres Company, for Â£4 18s.; he was paid cash for thatâ€”I saw him again on 18th July, when he brought a dividend warrant issued by the Mortgage Company of the River Plate, for Â£8 15s. 6d., under date of 15th July; that was paid in cashâ€”at the time these different documents were presented to me I saw the signatures C. H. Potts to themâ€”I believed them be genuine signaturesâ€”I have no doubt that the prisoner is the man who brought them.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. Someone was sent to Endsleigh Gardens; that was our usual courseâ€”I have inquired of our messengers it one did not got the other is not certainâ€”I would not like to swear that I did sendâ€”the warrant of Messrs. Courage of 1st April was presented to me on the 2nd; the perforation was the 3rdâ€”the one of 20th February was perforated on the same date; also the one of 12th Marchâ€”the perforations are made by the bankers, not by us.

JOHN WATT . I am secretary to Messrs. Courage and Co.â€”on 19th August, 1889, this certificate was issued by the Company to Constance Henrietta Potts, whose registered address in the book of the Company is 1, Endsleigh Gardens; that continued to be her registered address; we never knew any otherâ€”the interest on our debenture stock accrued and was paid in October 'each yearâ€”in the ordinary course of business these dividend warrants were sent to Miss Potts in April, 1890, October, 1890, and April, 1891; and they came back to the Company through their bonkers, having been paidâ€”the dividend warrants of October, 1890 and April, 1891, were issued to Miss Potts in relation to these holdings of hers on the Â£400 stock on the dates which they bearâ€”I had no notion on their return to us that they had not been signed by Miss Pottsâ€”on 9th March, 1891, I received this letter, purporting to come from Miss Pottsâ€”I answered that letter, asking for an indemnity; a correspondence ensued between myself, and, as I imagined, Miss Potts; my letters were addressed to Miss Constance H. Potts, 1, Endsleigh Gardens, N. W.â€”on 2nd April I received this letter of indemnity enclosed in this letter; it purports to be signed by Miss Constance H. Potts, and attested by Mr. James Kirkâ€”I believed in the genuineness of that document, and sent a

duplicate certificate in a registered letter, addressed to Miss Constance Potts, 1, Endsleigh Gardens, N. W.â€”a shilling fee was due to the Company on the re-issue of the certificate, which we receivedâ€”on 9th April I received this letter, purporting to be signed by Miss Potts.

Cross-examined. The letter dated 9th April came to us in the ordinary post on the 9th or 10th, most likely the 9th; the certificate was posted on the afternoon of the 8thâ€”we have received letters which we supposed to come from Miss Potts, the signature being the sameâ€”to my knowledge we never received letters purporting to come from Miss Potts with any other signature.
Re-examined. We have in the book before me a record of the issue of fresh certificatesâ€”the letter of 9th April acknowledges the safe receipt of the certificates.

WILLIAM JAMES CAPATHERWAITE . I am a postman in the employ of the Post Officeâ€”I have been in the habit of delivering letters to 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”I believe I know the prisoner by sightâ€”I think I have seen him go into 1, Endsleigh Gardens many a time for about eighteen months from nowâ€”on 8th April, 1891,1 delivered a registered letter at 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”I have the receipt for it, which I then took; I did not see it written, it was given to me at the door when I delivered the letterâ€”I could not remember the date without referring to this document.
ROBERT JAMES WILLIS . I am manager of the investment department of Mr. John Shaw, of Wardrobe Chambersâ€”I remember the prisoner coming to my department on 17th April, 1891.

This evidence was not pursued, as it was after the date of the offence charged. GRACE TAGG. I am the wife of John Tagg, of 3, Auckland Villas, Dennis Road, East Moleseyâ€”I remember Miss Constance Potts coming to live there in February, 1890â€”Mr. Kirk came to my house for me to go and see her, as she wanted someoneâ€”I went and saw her at Walton Villaâ€”I cannot fix the date; it was in February or March, 1890â€”from that time I continued to be in attendance upon herâ€”I did not live in the house; I slept there occasionallyâ€”I was there part of the dayâ€”I think Mr. Kirk remained there till about the end of July, 1890â€”he then leftâ€”during the time Miss Potts was at Walton Villa I can hardly say she was ill all the time she was there; she was not wellâ€”she died in July, 1891â€”she was not so very well for some time before her death, because she was suffering from dropsy for six months; she had crutches, and she would take hold of my arm or hold on to the furniture; and if she was out she would walk with whatever she could place her hand on; she used to crawl up and down stairs on her hands and knees, and I assisted her at other timesâ€”she went out from time to time for a carriage drive, or be pushed in a Bath chairâ€”she would not walk that I know ofâ€”to my knowledge she did not go to London from the time she arrived at Moleseyâ€”she died from dropsy, she was stout before and at the time of her death.

Cross-examined. There was no disagreement between Miss Potts and Mr. Kirk that I am aware ofâ€”Miss Potts never walked out alone while I was with herâ€”she could not walk unassisted; I daresay she could walk with assistanceâ€”I never saw her walk except with her crutches or holding on to a chairâ€”I never saw her walk in the Gardens aloneâ€”I knew her by the name of Miss Constance Henrietta Potts, that was the

name I always knew her by, never by any other nameâ€”I saw tradesmen's bills come to the house in the name of Kirk, not to Mrs. Kirkâ€”I saw the undertaker's bill, that was made out to Miss C. H. Potts, but I won't swear itâ€”I saw the certificate of her death, the name of dropsy was on it, and some other name which I cannot pronounce, I cannot tell the nameâ€”Miss Potts was not a temperate person; she was in the habit of drinkingâ€”I never knew her run out into the street when in that conditionâ€”I never heard of her doing such a thing.

ARTHUR EDWARD EARL . I am a clerk in the office of the Buenos Ayres Railway Companyâ€”the name of Miss C. H. Potts appears in the books of the company as holding ten shares, called U sharesâ€”they were purchased by her in July, 1889â€”her registered address in the company's books is 1, Endsleigh Gardens; I never received any notification of any change of addressâ€”the interest accrued, and was payable in October each year; and on 30th September the dividend warrants are dated, to pay the October interest; on 30th September we sent this dividend warrant to 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”our warrants are valid only for three months after the date of issueâ€”in March, this year, I received a letter, dated 9th March, purporting to come from Miss Potts, relative to that dividend warrantâ€”I believed it to be a genuine letter, and in accordance with the request contained in it, we redated the warrant 9th March, and sent it to 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”on 12th March two further letters came purporting to be from Miss Potts, dated the 11th; in consequence of one of those letters I replied on the 12th to Miss Potts, giving certain instructionâ€”on 13th March I received a letter, and on the 16th I sent to her a form of letter of indemnity and a statutory declaration; on the 2nd April those documents were returned to meâ€”this letter of indemnity purports to be signed by Constance H. Potts, and attested by James Kirkâ€”I believed in the genuineness of that document; enclosed with it was this statutory declaration purporting to have been made before John Evans, a Commissioner for Oaths, of 10, John Street, Bedford Bowâ€”I believed in the genuineness of that document, and issued this duplicate certificate, it is dated 22nd April; it was sent to Miss Potts, 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”in April a further dividend accrued to Miss Potts, it bears date 16th April, the date of payment was 1st March.

Cross-examined. I received a letter dated 7th March, 1891; I answered it on the 9thâ€”I also received one dated 11th, which I answered on the 12th; I also received one on the 2nd April, that was answered on the 3rd; the letter dated the 13th I did not answer until the 16thâ€”the stock is not still registered in Miss Potts' name, it is soldâ€”one transfer was registered on 22nd October, 1891, the other on 5th November, 1891; there wire two transfers to make up the seventeen sharesâ€”nothing was said at the time of the transfer beyond the letters that have been put in; no letters were written about the transferâ€”the sale was by Miss Potts as far as we knewâ€”I see by a note I have that it was executed by Mr. Kirk, the executor of Miss Pottsâ€”the transfer itself is at our officeâ€”as far as I know no question of overdue interest was raised at the sale of the stock.

JOHN EVANS . I am a solicitor and a commissioner for taking oaths, of 11. John Street, Bedford Bowâ€”I did carry on business thereâ€”the signature to this statutory declaration, dated 2nd April, 1891, is not mine, or written by my authority; no person of the name of Potts made a statutory declaration before me on 2nd April, or at any timeâ€”I have my
call-book here; it contains the name of every person who called on that dayâ€”some years back I had in my service a clerk of the name of Bynoe he left me, I think, four or five years ago.

EDWARD OLIVER . I am secretary to Euston, Proctor and Co., engineers, carrying on business at Lincolnâ€”the name of Miss Constance Henrietta Potts appears in our books as the owner of Â£400 debenture stockâ€”it was not purchased by her, it was applied for through Messrs. Makin, Venables and Co., of London, before the allotment was made in July, 1889â€”she was not the original allottee; the stock was transferred to her by a deed dated 27th November, 1889; her address being 1, Endsleigh Gardens, N. W.â€”we had no notice of any changeâ€”we sent the first warrant in December, 1889, and the second in June, 1890, to that addressâ€”the first warrant was for Â£5, and the second for Â£9 15s.â€”the dividend of June, 1890, was returned to us through the bank about February 9th; after that date a correspondence was opened, and letters came purporting to be from Miss Potts, and I answered themâ€”on 13th March I received a letter announcing the loss of certificates, and applying for new ones; it stated that all the papers were lostâ€”a letter was written to Miss Potts on the subject; after that there was a correspondence with Messrs. Oliver, her solicitors; as the result of that correspondence certificates were issued.

PHILIP HENRY LYNE . I am the registrar of the Mortgage Company of the River Plate, Limited; their offices are at 61, Moorgate Streetâ€”the name of Miss Constance Henrietta Potts appears in the books of the company of 1, Endsleigh Gardens, as owner of Â£400 debenture stock, purchased in August, 1889â€”I never received notice of any change of addressâ€”as the interest accrued, dividend warrants were sent to that address, dated 15th July, 1890, and 15th January, 1891â€”they are the ordinary dividend warrants issued by the company; one is in my own writingâ€”they have been returned as paid by our bankersâ€”this letter, of 11th March, 1891, was received by us on the 12th, relating to the loss of some certificates; it purports to be signed by Miss Potts, and is addressed from 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”that letter was answered the same day; I have the letter-book here, with the press copy of the reply, requesting an indemnityâ€”I think we had a second letter from Miss Potts on 2nd April, 1891, enclosing the indemnity and a sixpenny stamp for the declaration.

Cross-examined. We returned the indemnity on the 2nd April, with the sixpenny stamp, because we had been in communication with her solicitors, Messrs. Oliver and Sons, and they advised us that the certificates were not lostâ€”this is the letter; we heard nothing more from themâ€”it appeared from their letter that a fraud had been attemptedâ€”we always return an indemnity if we do not issue a duplicateâ€”the stock was sold by the executor, Mr. James A. Kirkâ€”we were not asked about overdue interest.

FREDERICK WRIGHT . I am a member of the firm of Wright and Odell, sheriffs' officers for the County of London, at 52, Chancery Laneâ€”I knew the prisoner some three or four months ago; at the time I had an execution against his mother, or a Mrs. Bynoe, a widow, on 9th June, 1891â€”we had to levy against Mrs. Bynoe, of 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”in connection with that execution we received these three letters, and on or about 11th June the prisoner came to our office and personally served me

with this writ for trespassâ€”I asked him if he was Mr. Augustus Bynoeâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Are you the same gentleman as wrote these three letters to us?"â€”he said, "Yes, I am"â€”they were not produced to him, but they were on the desk, he could not see themâ€”I retained the letters, as they were claims upon the furniture in the house.

WILLIAM NASH (Detective Sergeant). On 29th October last, about eight in the evening, in company with Inspector Field, I went to 301, Euston Road, and there saw the prisonerâ€”Mr. Field said to him, "We are two police officers; this gentleman,"pointing to Mr. Addison, who was with us, "will tell you what we are here for"â€”Mr. Addison said, "I give this man in custody for forging the name of Mr. Kirk to a transfer of debenture stock for Â£400 on Courage and Sons, the brewers"â€”I said, "I arrest you on that charge"â€”the prisoner said, "Who do you say charges me?"â€”Mr. Addison said, "I charge you on behalf of Messrs. Courage"â€”shortly after the prisoner said, "I know nothing about it, more than Miss Potts and Mr. Fork did reside with us at Endsleigh Gardens"â€”up to that time there had been no mention of Miss Potts' nameâ€”I then took him to Hunter Street Police-stationâ€”whilst waiting in the charge-room he said, "I don't fear this charge in the least, out it is most unpleasant; this comes of doing a kindness: after Miss Potts left Endsleigh Gardens a letter came for her; I found it open, I afterwards read it, it referred to a transfer of Courage and Co.'s stock. I wrote to Miss Potts; afterwards a great number of letters came for Miss Potts; some were opened; I found one relating to other stock; I wrote to Mr. Kirk, and asked him to call for the warrantâ€”my brother met him and asked him to call for the warrant"â€”he was then chargedâ€”on searching him I found, among other things, some memorandums and this duplicate certificate relating to seventeen Tucuman shares of the Buenos Ayres Companyâ€”the prisoner asked to be supplied with the private address of his solicitorâ€”he asked for his pocket-book, and he wrote down the name and address; this is itâ€”I handed it to Inspector Fieldâ€”I think he made a copy of it for the prisoner's use, and the original was retained and was produced before the Magistrateâ€”I found no warrant on him, only the certificate.

Cross-examined. I don't recollect your calling it a warrantâ€”you said you were not quite sure whether the warrant was on Courage and Co.â€”you said you had telegraphed to Courage and Co. not to transfer, as Miss Potts had left Endsleigh Gardensâ€”after that you said a number of letters came for Miss Potts, and one of them contained another warrant pi took it that when you said you had telegraphed to Courage and Co. it related to the letter that was first opened; you afterwards said you were not 'sure it was on Courage and Co.â€”I made a note of the conversation; there is nothing in that about your not being sure.

WILLIAM FIELD (Inspector). I was present at the arrest on 29th Octoberâ€”I have heard Nashs evidence; he has given the conversation with the prisoner substantially accuratelyâ€”I heard the first part of the conversationâ€”I did not hear that part about having sent a telegram; I was not in the same room at the time.

JOHN WATT (Re-called.) I never received or saw a telegram from the prisoner or anyone else, telling me not to transfer Miss Potts' stock, as she had left Endsleigh Gardensâ€”we had a notice of a transfer in April or May, 1891, purporting to be from Miss Pottsâ€”we got a transfer from the broker on the Stock Exchange; I do not fix the dateâ€”we did not

send her notice that any transfer had been lodged; it is not usual to do so; we deal with the brokers on the Stock Exchange, not with the sellers themselvesâ€”I did not receive any telegram from the prisoner in relation to the transfer of Miss Potts' stock.

MR. OLIVER (Re-called). There was a telegram received by me in relation to a transfer; I believe the date of that was the 17th February, 1891â€”in acknowledging the telegram, unfortunately the name was left out, although it must have been from Miss Potts, because it was an acknowledgment to her.

MR. WATT (Continued). This is the telegram we got, "Do not transfer debenture from Potts to Philpot, entered at Cannon Street, 1.30, 17th February, 1891;"we acknowledged that telegram to Miss Pottsâ€”in consequence of that telegram there was great difficulty created about the Â£100â€”we communicated with the broker and Miss Potts about itâ€”afterwards we heard from Oliver and Sons, and I received authority from them to register these deeds which proported to be signed by Miss Pottsâ€”the transfer was afterwards registeredâ€”there was some trouble before it was registeredâ€”we received three authorities before the directors were satisfied; those authorities are hereâ€”the first was from the brokers, dated 21st Februaryâ€”we wrote to Miss Potts, and receiving no reply, we wrote again, then we wrote to Oliver and Sons on 10th March, explaining the whole matter; they sent us another authority, which was not accepted, as it was not witnessedâ€”the last authority is dated 18th March, that is missingâ€”the signature to the authority was not like Miss Potts'â€”I did not say there was an attempted fraud, the difference in the handwriting was the difficulty; I noticed the difference in the handwriting in the letters that came from Endsleigh Terrace and the handwriting to the transferâ€”we received the letter of 20th February, 1891, and replied to it on the 21st; on 24th February we received another letter from Endsleigh Gardens, I think that was not in the same handwriting as that of the 20thâ€”on 10th March I enclosed the letter received from Miss Potts to Messrs. Oliverâ€”By the COURT. The interest on the warrant of 30th September. was paid in to the London and Westminster Bank, according to Miss Potts' written authority; that is the warrant that the prisoner is charged with forging her name toâ€”on 15th December we had received authority from Miss Potts to pay her dividend into the London and Westminster Bank; we acted on that authority; the other dividend had, gone to Endsleigh Gardensâ€”I received this letter from Endsleigh Gardens: "Dear Sir,â€”I have been very ill or would have replied before; the other three I have not dealt with, and have lost all the papers; will that prevent me from selling them? Can I get a new certificate?"â€”that letter is in the same handwriting as all the Endsleigh Gardens correspondence; I answered it to Endsleigh Gardensâ€”from that time I received no further letters from Endsleigh Gardens in connection with this matterâ€”the correspondence was then continued between Messrs. Oliver and myselfâ€”they sent me an authority which was unattested, they kept that, and I signed another dated 18th Marchâ€”that was signed by Miss Potts and witnessed by Grace Tagg; that came from East Molesey.

J. A. KIRK (Re-called). It is not true that I received any letter from the prisoner asking me to call for a dividend-warrant in relation to any of Miss Potts' stockâ€”it is not true that the prisoner's brother afterwards met me and told me of the receipt of that dividend-warrant, or as to its

being at 1, Endsleigh Gardensâ€”I am familiar with Miss Potts' handwritingâ€”this dividend-warrant of 1st April, 1891, is not in her handwritingâ€”this second one of Courage and Co. is not signed by her, nor the three from the Mortgage Company of the River Plate, nor this of Huston, Proctor, or the two from the Buenos Ayres Railway Companyâ€”the letters addressed to Courage and Co., commencing 7th March, 1891, are not in Miss Potts' handwriting; none of the letters here are in her handwritingâ€”I have before me the letter of indemnity, addressed to Courage and Co., of 28th March; that is not signed by Miss Potts; the attestation is not mineâ€”I say the same of the letter of indemnity sent to the Buenos Ayres Company pasted in this book; nor is this statutory declaration of 2nd April signed by Miss Pottsâ€”this is the genuine signature of Miss Potts to this transfer of 17th August, 1889, and this is my attestation, my ordinary signatureâ€”this signature of Miss Potts to the authority sent to Ruston, Procter is her genuine signature; it is dated 18th March, 1891; it is witnessed by Grace Tagg.

Cross-examined. I was residing at Endsleigh Gardens towards the end of 1888â€”you left shortly after, I think it was the day before Christmasâ€”I think I saw you there again occasionally, certainly once if not moreâ€”I could not say if you were cognisant of Miss Potts haying purchased stock in 1889; I should think it very likely, because she generally talked about her affairs pretty openly with many peopleâ€”I believe she purchased this stock in August, 1889â€”I have no occupation nowâ€”I have been secretary to two or three different companies; one was the Emerald Mines of Columbia, another was the Halifax Cableâ€”I don't think I can give you the dates; it is within the last two or three yearsâ€”in December, 1888, I think I was secretary to the Emerald Minesâ€”I never was a clerk or employed in a stockbroker's officeâ€”my salary as secretary was Â£120 a yearâ€”previous to that I was in a merchant's office for two years; I left that to go to the Emerald Minesâ€”I have no recollection of having said that I left Endsleigh Gardens in consequence of a disagreementâ€”I think it was in consequence of a disagreementâ€”I did not say at Bow Street that it was in consequence of a disagreement with youâ€”when I left there I went to Gower Streetâ€”I left no address, because it was Miss Potts' especial wish to cut off all connection with Endsleigh Gardens, because she disliked you and your motherâ€”I left there, I think, in January, 1890â€”I have not a thorough knowledge of all matters connected with the Stock Exchangeâ€”I have very little knowledgeâ€”I have speculated on the Stock "Exchange; a friend Knew that it would be wise to buy certain things, and I bought them; that was all I knew about itâ€”I knew all about Miss Potts' businessâ€”I also knew Oliver and Sons perfectlyâ€”at Molesey, in February, 1890, I suppose I instructed"the post-office about my letters; it is my usual habit, bat I cannot swear to it; Miss Potts did not, because she was never out except in a carriage, and I was always with her if she wasâ€”there was no notice of removal to the post-office that I could swear toâ€”I was on most intimate terms with Miss Potts; I suppose, I may say, my relation to her was that of her most intimate friendâ€”she left me, in her will, everything she possessed, with a small reserveâ€”I went to Molesey to live with herâ€”she was known there as Miss Constance Potts; I will swear thatâ€”I am a member of the Junior Constitutional Clubâ€”I do not remember, at Endsleigh Gardens, promising you to get an

appointment for your brother on the Stock Exchange, or somewhere in the Cityâ€”I do not remember talking about him at all, or where he had been employedâ€”in February, 1891, no re-directed letters came to me at the club; I am quite certain of itâ€”to the best of my knowledge I have had no re-directed letters at the clubâ€”I swear positively that I did not have a letter from you at the club on 17th February, 1891, in which were enclosed several warrants and cheques for interest of different kinds for Miss Pottsâ€”I have met Dr. Bedortha once in the street; I can't say the date; I do not recollect speaking to him, I think I merely nodded and passed onâ€”I think it impossible that he could have told me that there were cheques at End sleigh Gardens for Miss Potts, or I should have taken notice of itâ€”I left Molesey, and Miss Potts, in July, 1890â€”I left because I could no longer control her, and it was very unpleasant; and there was no use in my stayingâ€”she drank a little, and the doctor attending her specially requested me to keep it from her; I could not, and in doing so there were often scenes; so I cut it short by goingâ€”there was no question as to the use of her money; absolutely none, neverâ€”I don't know whether she thought she was defrauded in. the manner she has been; I don't think she had any idea who it wasâ€”I don't think she even suggested any name to meâ€”after I left in July I only saw her onceâ€”I frequently received letters at my club I communicated with Oliver and Sons after I left Molesey; they knew my club address; I don't know whether they knew any otherâ€”they knew Miss Potts' address.

Re-examined. Miss Potts once mentioned to me the name of a person who had defrauded her; that was when she was off her head, after losing her watch at End sleigh Gardens; she suspected everybody, and everyone that came near her was immediately suspectedâ€”I can hardly say whether intemperate habits were indulged in at End sleigh Gardens; at first I thought it was hysteria, but from what I knew later on I thought it was due to alcoholic fits; in those fits she would accuse persons, and she would accuse me, but not in her sound sensesâ€”I was on extremely good terms with her, and under her will she left me the whole of her property, with a small reserveâ€”the date of the will was 14th February, 1889â€”I knew of the existence of the will prior to her death; she told me of her intention with regard to her property; I did not write to her after I had left her; she wrote to me many times, asking me to come back, but I never answered, I thought it best notâ€”I think I met Dr. Bedortha at another house kept by Mrs. Bynoe in Upper Woburn Placeâ€”I do not remember having any conversation with him after I left Endsleigh Gardens; there certainly was no conversation in which he mentioned cheques or warrants being at Endsleigh Gardens, that I am sure of.

GEORGE SMITH INGLIS . I am an expert in handwriting, of 8, Red Lion Square, Holbornâ€”I have had before me a number of documents in this case, among them the transfer of 17th August, 1889, bearing the genuine signature of Miss C. H. Potts, attested by Mr. James A. Kirk; also dividend warrants of Messrs. Courage and Co. of 1st October, 1889, 1st April, 1890 (Mr. Kirk here stated these to be in Miss Potts' genuine handwriting); those are all the documents upon which my opinion has been foundedâ€”I have examined with them a number of documents which have been produced, among them two dividend warrants of Messrs. Courage of

1st October, 1890, and 1st April, 1891; they are not in Mist Potts' handwritingâ€”I have examined these two dividend warrants, one from the Buenos Ayres Railway issued on 13th June, 1891, re dated 12th March, 1891, and one from Huston, Proctor and Co., of 30th June, 1890â€”I have compared those dividend warrants with the proved writing of Miss Pottsâ€”they are not Miss Potts' writing, nor her signatureâ€”two are dated 15th January, 1890, and a third 15th July, 1891â€”I have had before me the correspondence passing between End sleigh Gardens and Courage and Co., of 7th and 11th March, 1st and 9th April, 1891â€”also letters of indemnity of 28th Marchâ€”none of them are re-addressedâ€”none are in the handwriting of Miss Pottsâ€”I have become familiar with the writing of James Kirkâ€”I have compared Mr. Kirk's signatures on the transfer of the 17th August, 1889, and on the indemnityâ€”the signature is not hisâ€”I have also directed my attention to the statutory declaration purporting to be signed by Miss C. H. Pottsâ€”comparing the signatures with the correspondence from 7th March to 2nd April, I say they are not those of Mils C. H. Pottsâ€”the signature of the attesting witness is not that of Mr. Kirkâ€”the correspondence from February, 1891, has been before meâ€”also the Euston, Proctor dividend warrants of 31st December, 1889, for Â£5 13s. 2d. (A 1), and 30th June 1890 (A 2), the letters of 20th February, 1891 (A 3), the 24th February, 1891 (A 4), 11th March, 1890 (A 5)â€”the warrant marked A1 of 31st January, 1889, is genuine, the signature is that of Miss Pottsâ€”A 2 to A 5 are not in Miss Potts' writingâ€”I have A 7 and A 8 before me, letters of 11th March and 1st April, 1891â€”they are not the genuine writing of Miss Pottsâ€”I have had letters before me said to have been written by Mrs. Bynoe, and signed by the prisonerâ€”three letters (produced) by Wright, a witnessâ€”K 1, K 2, and K 8â€”I have examined themâ€”I can only find two here and the writâ€”I had these three letters, 1K, 2K, 3K, and the writ (J), before me in my office, and the pencil memorandum referred to by the police officers as having been written in their presence, and I have compared them with the prisoner's writing, as also the correspondence with the four companies, including the two letters of indemnity, the statutory declaration, and dividend-warrants issued by Courage and Co.â€”the dividend warrants are written by the same person who wrote the letters K1, K2, and K3, and the writ J, signed Â° Chas. A. Bynoe," and the pencil memorandaâ€”the signature to the declaration, "Constance H. Potts,"is in the same writing as also that of the attesting witness, "Jas. Kirk."

Cross-examined. I am not infallible in my opinions; I make mistakes sometimesâ€”Mr. Netherclift and I disagree sometimesâ€”my first report in this case is dated 28th October, 1891, and the second 4th Novemberâ€”did not say at the Police-court that the signatures "C. H. Potts "were written by the person writing those three lettersâ€”I came to the opinion, after examining the letters at the Buenos Ayres Railway Company, that they were in the handwriting of the same person who wrote the three letters, and it was not till I examined them there that I formed an opinion independent of anything elseâ€”my report of the 28th October was on the document in the Courage case, in which there are some signatures of Constance H. Potts said to be forgedâ€”I had those before me before making the report; I should say this writing is disguised (referring to a paper); I should say it is the same writing as the lettersâ€”I

should say this letter is in disguised writing, the same as the other letters (referring to the letter received by the prisoner in Holloway Prison)â€”there is a hesitancy in the writing, the envelope seems to be in the same writingâ€”take that first "from,"for instance, in the letter; there is a shakiness in it which is not natural.

Re-examined. I had thirteen documents before meâ€”three of them genuine signaturesâ€”seven I was to investigate, and three of them are the letters produced by Mr. Wrightâ€”after making my report I went to the Buenos Ayres officeâ€”the Buenos Ayres certificate was found on the prisoner's arrest on 29th October, and then I extended my examination, and I then saw the letter of indemnity and the statutory declarationâ€”on making my second report I had before me the writ and pencil memorandum; and with those, as well as the three letters, I examined the Buenos Ayres correspondence, the Courage correspondence, and that of the Mortgage Company of the River Plate.

FREDERICK GEORGE NETHERCLIFT . I have been an expert in handwriting for many years, practising at 10, Bedford Rowâ€”I have examined the documents referred to and the four batches of correspondenceâ€”I had before me the admittedly genuine signatures of Miss Constance H. Potts and of James A. Kirkâ€”except one of the latter's, they are forgeriesâ€”the letters of indemnity are forgeries, as also the statutory declaration and the dividend warrants.

Cross-examined. I had your admitted writing before me in the documents K1, K2, and K3, and I think a copy of the writ. filled in by you marked Jâ€”the letters are forgeriesâ€”this is not Miss Potts' writing; it is the same writing as the other documents, I believeâ€”these letters bear characteristics of your writing, disguisedâ€”it does not appear to be a woman's handwritingâ€”it is a schoolboy styleâ€”I believe it is yoursâ€”all expert evidence is an opinion.
Re-examined. These are all written in an acquired hand.

JAMES A. KIRK (Re-examined). After Miss Potts' death, acting under her will, I went to her solicitors, Messrs. Oliver, and then went to the London and Westminster Bank, Holborn branch, where her securities wereâ€”I went over the different documents, and found Courage's original certificateâ€”they were left at the bank for safe custodyâ€”I also found the Buenos Ayres certificate, and a Â£400 debenture bond of the Mortgage Company of the River Plate, and three Â£100 debentures of Huston, Proctor, and Co.â€”before going to the bank, Messrs. Oliver told me that Miss Potts had sold out Â£100 of the latterâ€”I did not tell Miss Potts, about the 9th April, that Dr. Bynoe had a registered letter for her.

Further cross-examined. I had no correspondence with Messrs. Oliver. in the early part of last yearâ€”I have not been through Miss Potts' banking account for that periodâ€”I am her executor and principal legatee.

p.hi: The folk winy witnesses were called by the prisoner:

div1.p: ELIZABETH JANE BYNOE . I am a widow, of 1, End sleigh Gardens, and am your motherâ€”you leave home at 8.45 a.m., and go to your surgery in the Euston Road, and see patients from 11 to 1, and visit in the afternoon, and come back to tea, and are usually in the surgery from 7 to 9, and at home from 9.15 to 9.45â€”you took possession of 1, End sleigh Gardens in October, 1888â€”Miss Potts and Mr. Kirk came to reside

there at the end of October or early in November, and left the 24th Decemberâ€”they were friendly at that time, and continued to visit us afterwardsâ€”a letter came for Miss Potts early in April, I think, or the end of March; she had gone to 58, Gower Street, and I sent my son John to ask for her address, and they would not or could not give itâ€”as I had passed I had seen her sitting at the window of 58, Gower Street, and I sent the letter by my daughter, and she left it thereâ€”several letters came for her after thatâ€”early in February last one got opened, we could not tell who by, but we believed it was by a man of 70 that you had as resident patient, and I thought it was our duty to sec to itâ€”a letter came for Miss Potts in February; you went to the City, and got the address out of the "Directory,"of Mr. Edward C. Philpot, but you could not gain any information there, and then you got the address of Ruston, Proctor and Co., in the City, and went there; and you then wrote to Mr. Kirk, at the Junior Constitutional Club, for his advice; you nut the letters that had previously arrived for Miss Potts in a largo envelope, and addressed them to Mr. Kirk; they had the names of companies on the backs of themâ€”I afterwards saw an answer, thanking you for sending the letters, and a telegram; letters subsequently came for Miss Potts, and they were re-directed by you, as you said Mr. Kirk objected to receiving letters addressed to him by a lady; I posted some, and my niece someâ€”a letter came for Miss Potts on the evening of the 14th July, which I posted immediately, and you never saw it; you said that you intended not to send any moreâ€”one had got opened, and you had written several times to ask Mr. Kirk to send for the letters, or come for them himselfâ€”Mr. Kirk wrote threatening to action you for opening Miss Potts' letter and not sending it on to him; that letter contained a duplicate certificate of Buenos Ayres stock; in August you were aware that Miss Potts had died in July, and had left Mr. Kirk all her property.

Cross-examined. I remember the 14th July distinctlyâ€”I see now by the evidence that that was the letter containing the dividend warrant from the Mortgage Company of the River Plateâ€”I swear my son never saw that letterâ€”it was posted by meâ€”four or five letters were put by me in a large envelope in February, and addressed by me to Mr. Kirk at the Junior Constitutional Clubâ€”the letters accumulated from July, 1890, to February, 1891; a letter had been opened by a resident patient, an old gentlemanâ€”we did not see him open it, but he was the only person in the dining-room, 'and the letter was placed on the side table by the man-servantâ€”I have not read the evidence of Mr. Spreag on this pointâ€”J heard Mr. Spreag say at Bow Street that four dividend warrants were presented to him by my sonâ€”that has not shaken my evidenceâ€”I have heard some correspondence that passed between 1, End sleigh Gardens and Messrs. Courage and Co.â€”Miss Potts was never at 1, End sleigh Gardens from the beginning of 1891â€”I have heard of a registered letter of the 9th April that came to End sleigh Gardensâ€”if I signed for it and see the signature I shall know if it is mineâ€”this is my signatureâ€”I must have received the letter, or I should not have signed my nameâ€”my son wrote and told Mr. Kirk that there was a registered letter at End sleigh Gardens, and that he must send a messenger for it, and the messenger came, and I went with him to my son's surgery, and my son delivered the letterâ€”he had put it in his pocket for safetyâ€”I do

not know who it was fromâ€”I have seen the certificate from the Buenos Ayres Companyâ€”it was some time early in the yearâ€”my son took possession of itâ€”it was put in a bookcase in his library, and remained there for monthsâ€”his sister, on arranging his books, picked it up and gave it to him, and he kept it from that time forwardâ€”I did not know who Miss Potts' solicitor wasâ€”in February a messenger came from Mr. Oliver, in consequence of a telegram my son had sent to stop the sale of some of the Euston, Proctor stockâ€”I did not ask him his addressâ€”the telegram was sent, believing it was not sold by Miss Potts to Mr. Philpot, our address being givenâ€”Mrs. Koch left End sleigh Gardens in March, 1890â€”my son was not in partnership with me in the houseâ€”he took resident patients after Mrs. Koch gave it up as a boarding-houseâ€”the furniture was hisâ€”I was constantly thereâ€”my second son was employed by Mr. John Evans, a commissioner for oaths, of 10, John Street, Bedford Rowâ€”the furniture at 1, End sleigh Gardens was not under a bill of sale, I swearâ€”it is not true there was a sale of furniture there on the 29th September, 1890â€”I had a house at 22, Upper Woburn Place; there was no sale thereâ€”I do not know what you mean by a saleâ€”we sold the house as a going concern to a lady in May, 1891â€”we have had a bill of sale with a Mr. Tylerâ€”that was in September, 1890â€”I did not quite follow the date, but there was no sale last yearâ€”there was a transfer of the debt to Mr. Alexander, but not a saleâ€”he goes sometimes by the name of Maitlandâ€”I believe my son paid one instalment in respect of the hire of the furniture, and then stopped, because Mr. Maitland was going through the Bankruptcy Court; and he and his clerk both wrote for it, and Maitland told my eon that the Receiver in Bankruptcy would not accept the documentâ€”that is what my son told meâ€”the house at 22, Upper Woburn Place was my son'sâ€”there was no sale at Endsleigh Gardens, or 22, Upper "Woburn Placeâ€”there was an agreement entered into with a Mrs. Trencher, in reference to the sale of 22, Upper Woburn Place some few years agoâ€”she gave Â£160 deposit for the purchase of the house and businessâ€”she took possession of the house, and wanted certain repairs done, and insisted on my sending away two boarders that she had fallen out withâ€”she made a great confidant of meâ€”she was addicted to drink, and was quite sure that she could not manage the place, and wanted me to take it backâ€”I remonstrated with her, and said I could not take it back, for I had used her money, and if she would try to give up her habits she could make a good living, for I had brought up my children and educated them there; and she said she could not because of the drink; my son subsequently attended her at four different lodging-houses in the locality for delirium tremensâ€”I took it back, and we undertook to pay her Â£150â€”I cannot say how much my son has paid; I know he paid her some in May.

Re-examined. I remember the messenger came from Messrs. Oliver some days after you told me of having sent a telegram to Euston, Proctor, and Co.â€”I had no opportunity of asking his addressâ€”he said he had come in consequence of the telegram and the stoppage of some stock of Miss Potts.
By the JURY. My niece posted the letter to Mr. Kirk containing four or six lettersâ€”my son never saw it after it was left in my charge.
CATHARINE PAYNE EMTAGE . I am the wife of Professor Emtage, M. A., Professor of Science, University College, London, and am your

sisterâ€”I remember Miss Potts and Mr. Kirk coming in November, 1888, to End sleigh Gardensâ€”we left there on the 24th December, 1888, they remainingâ€”there was no disagreement between themâ€”you took possession of End sleigh Gardens again in March, 1890â€”I remember letters coming there, and some for Miss Pottsâ€”some were opened, or found open, by some members of the family in January lastâ€”in March, 1890, I carried some for Miss Potts to 58, Gower Streetâ€”the circumstance of the letters being opened was freely spoken of, and visitors knew of itâ€”I came to End sleigh Gardens on the 8th of July, 1891â€”I left on the 17thâ€”during that time a letter came for Miss Pottsâ€”I believe you were out of the houseâ€”I saw it. on the tableâ€”mother took it up and re-directed it to Mr. Kirk, at the Junior Constitutional Clubâ€”I believe it was posted by Edith, my cousinâ€”you had no means of getting possession of that letterâ€”I believe it was on a Mondayâ€”it was before luncheon-timeâ€”when you came in mother told you she had re-directed a letter of Miss Potts' to Mr. Kirk, at the club, and you laughed and said he would get very much chaffed at a letter coming to him at the club in a lady's writingâ€”in August, 1891, you said that Mr. Kirk had written you threatening to action you for opening a letter to Miss Pottsâ€”I remember coming to End sleigh Gardens on the 31st of August, when I found your library considerably upset, and I arranged your booksâ€”I found several letters and papers, amongst which was one connected with Miss Pottsâ€”I remember opening it and looking at it, and handing it to you; or rather, I said, "Here is something belonging to Miss Potts"â€”you said, "You had better give it to me," and you took it and put it in your pocketâ€”it was something of this kind: (Referring to a paper)â€”I do not know that you were aware of Miss Potts' death soon after I came to End sleigh Gardens.

Cross-examined. I lived at End sleigh Gardens up to December, 1888, and returned to it in March, 1890; and about April or May I took a letter round to 58, Gower Streetâ€”that was the last known address of Miss Pottsâ€”I left in July, 1890, and went to End sleigh Gardens again in September of the same year to stay a short time, and went again in December, 1890â€”I went again in the spring of 1891, and the summerâ€”I knew letters had accumulated there for Miss Potts, and saw some in July, and some in the spring of 1891â€”I came to London on the 15th of April, when some two or three more letters cameâ€”they were put into an envelope, and I saw someone have them to postâ€”I did not see them put into the envelopeâ€”I only heard of their arrivalâ€”I do not remember the name on the envelopeâ€”I think it was on a Monday that I saw the letter in Julyâ€”I have only a slight thing to go byâ€”I simply saw the envelope was directed to Miss Potts, and had no information of what it containedâ€”I did not know that these letters directed to End sleigh Gardens were being opened there on the day of their receipt.

PROFESSOR W. T. A. EMTAGE , M. A. I am Assistant-Professor of Physics and Mathematics, of University College, Nottingham, and am your sister's husbandâ€”I came to End sleigh Gardens in July last yearâ€”a letter came for Miss Potts, which was posted onâ€”I did not see it that I remember.

MARY ANN GOODING . I am generally called Edithâ€”I am your cousinâ€”in March, April, June, and July of last year I was living at 1, Ends
leigh

Gardens, and remember letters coming for Miss Potts, and some being redirected to Mr. James A. Kirk, Junior Constitutional dub, Regent Streetâ€”I posted some, and remember posting one in July, when Mr. and Mrs. Emtage were there.

Cross-examined. I cannot exactly tell the dateâ€”Dr. Bynoe may have been there at the timeâ€”I am sure I posted the letterâ€”Mrs. Bynoe generally used to give me her letters to postâ€”I was asked as to this about three weeks ago by Mrs. Bynoe, the prisoner's motherâ€”I have been living with her; she told me I was to be very careful about that letter, because it was about money mattersâ€”I did not see if there was the name of any company printed on the back of itâ€”in January or February I had a letter to post, containing four or five letters in a large envelopeâ€”I was there when the letters were put in and the envelope closedâ€”the prisoner directed them, and Mrs. Bynoe gave them to me to postâ€”I was at End sleigh Gardens from January to July, and saw a good many lettersâ€”the letters addressed to Miss Potts were sometimes opened by the prisoner.

Re-examined. I never saw you open a letter, I did not quite understand the questionâ€”I never saw you open a letter directed to Miss Pottsâ€”I went home to stay in Gloucestershire, at my mother's, for a little while, and came back last Septemberâ€”you did not have the letters after they were directed to Mr. Kirkâ€”I put them into the post-box myself.

JOHN BRIGHT . I am hall porter at the Junior Constitutional Clubâ€”I have seen you somewhere; I cannot remember whereâ€”put your hand over your beard (the prisoner did so)â€”I remember your calling at the Junior Constitutional Club about February last year, and you asking for Mr. James A. Kirk; as a member of the club he has received letters at all timesâ€”I cannot swear that he received some letters re-directed about February, but to the best of my opinion he did receive one or two.
Cross-examined. I cannot pledge myself to that positivelyâ€”I cannot say who it was came.

B. T. BEDORDA. I am manager of a patent medicine company, and live at 50, Upper Bedford Placeâ€”I heard in the early part of last year that several letters were at End sleigh Gardens for Miss Potts, and of certain letters having been opened that contained valuablesâ€”there was no mention of chequesâ€”I think Mrs. Bynoe said there were coupons in one of them, or something of that sortâ€”I was there at a musical evening in the beginning of 1890 or the latter part of 1889â€”there was a large company, and Mrs. Bynoe spoke out before them, and asked if anyone knew Mr. Kirk's or Miss Potts' address, when I immediately spoke up, and said I frequently met Mr. Kirk; and she requested me to say to him that there were some valuable letters thereâ€”it is easier for me to recollect the incident than to place the timeâ€”I attached no importance to the matter, but if I were going to speak of it offhand I should say it was a year or two agoâ€”having been charged with that commission, I should naturally have told him, and I believe I didâ€”I could not say the exact language I employed, but after greeting him in the usual friendly way I said I believed there were letters at Mrs. Bynoe's for him.

Cross-examined. Or in which he was interestedâ€”I do practiseâ€”we deal in various patent medicinesâ€”mine is not an English diplomaâ€”it could not have been later than 1890, I think, that this conversation

occurredâ€”I did not attach any importance to it at the timeâ€”it is such a strong impression on my mind that I would sooner swear that I did speak to Mr. Kirk about it than not to swear to itâ€”I can swear that I believe I told him.
Re-examined. I associated it with the evenings I spent at Mrs. Bynoe's house.

ALBERT EDWARD PELLING . I am a warder at Holloway Gaolâ€”I think I remember handing you two letters on Tuesday lastâ€”I have handed you letters nearly every dayâ€”I cannot identify this letter particularly (produced)â€”these are my figures, B 255â€”it came in the ordinary wayâ€”letters are opened, read, and initialled by the Governor before they are sent to the prisonersâ€”these are the chief warder's initials at Holloway, and the letter was read by the chief warder before you received it; you were anxious to send a telegram to your solicitor directlyâ€”I came shortly after for the letter, and handed it to Mrs. Bynoe; paper of that kind is not supplied in the prisonâ€”I should say it was impossible for your friends to hand it to you when visitingâ€”visitors are in the visiting box, and are about two feet or rather more from the prisonerâ€”there is wirework each side of the visiting box, and there is a warder present.

Cross-examined. The prisoner might supply himself with such paper outside the prisonâ€”the warder keeps the prisoners under his eye, and sees that nothing is passed to them or from themâ€”I do not know how often the prisoner's mother visited him; she frequently cameâ€”I have heard of things being introduced into the prison and passed by visitors to prisoners.

Re-examined. I have not heard of a letter being passed in that condition, because that has gone through the chief warder's handsâ€”the wire network I have spoken of is very closeâ€”I cannot say the size, I have never examined it very particularlyâ€”I should say the squares are less than an inch, so that the paper would have to be folded small; it was not so folded when handed to you. (The Utter was read)â€”"Sir,â€”I have only just heard that you are charged with writing some letters and signing some cheques in the name of Constance H. Potts, from February to July last year. I was asked by a young man I am very fond of to write some letters, dated from 1, End sleigh Gardens, and some from Hampton Court, and to sign a lot of cheques in the name of Constance H. Potts, and I did it. He told me it was quite right, as the lady had given him the cheques, but was too ill to be troubled with them. One day early in May, I think it was Tuesday, I went to the City and met him, and we went to the office of 'John Shaw' marked on the window. I was told to write my name on the back of a cheque, and I wrote Constance H. Potts. "(The letter went on to state that the writer's friend received the money, and that he gave her Â£2 for herself and paid her fare)â€”it continued, "I would come forward and give evidence for you, but I should get into trouble, as I went to the City and signed cheques and said I was Miss Potts; but if you would like me to communicate with the Judge at the Old Bailey, put an advertisement in the Daily Telegraph to 'Constance,' saying you would like it, and I will do so,"&c.
The prisoner. There is a suggestion in the letter that I should put an advertisement in the Daily Telegraph, which I did; I do not know if any
letter has been sent to any Judge here: I do not suppose your Lordship would have heard of it.
The COURT. NO.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: ROBERT JAMES WILLIS . I am manager of the Investment Department of John Shaw, outside broker, of 1, Wardrobe Chambersâ€”the prisoner called on the 17th April and produced this certificate for Â£400 Courage debenture stock, dated 8th April, 1891 (produced)â€”I said it bore a very recent dateâ€”he said, "This is a duplicate certificate; Miss Potts has lost the original"â€”he had previously asked me for a price of the stock, and I gave him, roughly, a priceâ€”I was satisfied with his explanation, and he asked me to sell the amount of stockâ€”I at once communicated with brokers connected with the Exchange and sold it, and gave him a contract noteâ€”on 27th April I directed a letter to Miss Potts, at 1, End sleigh Gardens, enclosing form of transfer for signature, with instructionsâ€”on the 28th or 29th April the prisoner called with the transfer which I had sent (produced)â€”it purported to be signed by Constance H. Potts, and to be attested by James A. Kirk, which I believed to be genuineâ€”the 1st May was Stock Exchange Holiday, and the 2nd and 3rd were Saturday and Sundayâ€”on the 4th he called for a cheque for the stock, and I referred him to Mr. Lane Gieve, the managerâ€”I was present, and Mr. Lang Gieve said, "I will give you a cheque payable to Miss Potts," and I went to see that the cheque was drawnâ€”it was then handed to the prisoner, crossed (produced)â€”the prisoner looked at it, and said, "I don't think Miss Potts has a banking account; how can she get the money?"â€”Mr. Lang Gieve said, "If Miss Potts will call I shall be very pleased to open the cheque and make it payable to bearer"â€”the prisoner took it away with himâ€”on the 5th I happened to go into Mr. Lang Gieve's room and saw the prisoner there with a ladyâ€”I felt satisfied that the lady was Miss Potts, and that we were giving the money to the right personâ€”I have no doubt as to the prisonerâ€”I think I saw him before the 17th.

Cross-examined. I feel positive it was you who calledâ€”I think it was between twelve and two when you called with the ladyâ€”I can't say whether she was young or oldâ€”I think she was middle-agedâ€”more gentlemen than ladies come there.

ALFRED LANG GIEVE . I am general manager to Mr. John Shawâ€”on the occasion in question (the 4th May) Willis said to me, "This gentleman wants to be paid for the Courage Brewery debenture"â€”I said, "The stock is sold, but we have not had Miss Potts' instructions to give him a cheque," and I explained that I should require Miss Potts' instructions for him to receive the money; "but,"I said, "I will tell you what I will do; I will give you a cheque crossed to the account of the payee only, so that it can only go through Miss Potts' bank," and I did soâ€”I explained to him the consequence of crossing the cheque, and he said he did not know that Miss Potts had a banking accountâ€”I told him if Miss Potts would call I would make the cheque an open one, so that bank notes could be got for itâ€”he then left, and the next day called with a lady, whom he intimated was Miss Potts, who had come in accordance with my remark on the previous day, and wanted the cheque

to be altered, so that she could get bank notes for itâ€”he handed it tome and I cancelled the crossing, and marked it "pay cash," and initialed itâ€”it was on the Capital and Counties Bank, Ludgate Hillâ€”it was then either handed to them, or I got the notes and handed them, and they leftâ€”I did not particularly notice the lady; she did not appear to be an invalidâ€”I did not see the prisoner again until he was arrestedâ€”I did not pick him out at Bow Street first, hut pointed to another manâ€”I have not the slightest doubt as to the prisoner now.

Cross-examined. I was rather too precipitate when I went to Bow Street to identify you; you and the lady were about a quarter of an hour in the officeâ€”she was rather short, and I should say medium in build and colourâ€”the whole circumstances were, recalled to my mind when I looked at you carefullyâ€”I think if I saw the lady again I should recall her featuresâ€”I should say they came to the office about twelve o'clock; it was before I went to lunch, and I generally go from one to 1.30.

ROBERT MCGREGOR JOLLY . I am cashier at the Ludgate Hill Branch of the Capital and Counties Bank, where Mr. John Shaw has an accountâ€”this cheque for Â£419 10s. was cashed there on 5th May lastâ€”I have the numbers of the notes paid for itâ€”amongst them were these notes (produced).

CHARLES JOHN WILLIAMS . I am clerk in the Bank of England, and inspector of bank notes in the bank-note departmentâ€”I produce bank notes, value about Â£415â€”they were brought to the bank to be changed into gold on 5th May lastâ€”five are endorsed "James Kirk, 1, Endsleigh Gardens, N. W. "
By the COURT. I did not cash themâ€”they were all brought by the same person at one time.

JAMES A. KIRK (Re-examined). The signature to this transfer is not Miss Potts', neither is the signature of the attesting witness, "James Kirk,"mineâ€”I always sign "James A. Kirk"â€”I was not residing at End sleigh Gardens on the 30th April, the date of the transferâ€”the endorsement on the cheque is not Miss Potts'â€”the endorsement on the bank notes is not mineâ€”I did not go to the Bank of England on the 5th May.

G. S. INGLIS (Re-examined). The signature to the transfer is not Miss Potts', but the prisoner's; so is this signature, "James Kirk," and the endorsement on the cheque of the 4th Mayâ€”as also the endorsements on the five Bank of England notes.
F. G. NETHERCLIFT (Re-examined). I quite agree with Mr. Inglis.

p.hi: The prisoner called further evidence at to alibi.

div1.p: ELIZABETH JANE BYNOE (Re-examined). You came home about mid-day on the 17th Aprilâ€”there were two gentlemen friends of your brother's there and you went with them into the drawing-roomâ€”to my certain knowledge you never left the house again till 4.30â€”there were present, besides yourself, Mr. Warren, Mrs. Pattison, my youngest daughter, Miss Edith Gooding, and my second son; Mrs. Emtage came on the 15thâ€”you had a dispute with the gas company on 30th April, and they disconnected the gasâ€”on the 5th May you settled itâ€”you were at the gas company's most of the morningâ€”you came home about 1.15â€”we lunch at 1.30, but we were a little late in consequence of the gas, by which we cook, having been cut offâ€”you went out about 2.15 to visit a patient, and came back

in a cab a little past three, when the gas man came to connect the gasâ€”you did not leave again before 4.30; you had no lady in your company that I know ofâ€”you showed me the gas receipt (produced).

Cross-examined. My attention was first called to the 17th April, at Bow Street Police-courtâ€”on 30th October, I remembered it was two days after my daughter came from Nottingham, and we arranged to go out that evening to the Mohawk Minstrelsâ€”it was my son's usual habit to come in about elevenâ€”the dispute with the gas company was in respect of another house account that we had already paid, and they would not take one account without the other; we went without gas for five days, and then I urged my son to go and pay them the disputed amount, as we could not do without gasâ€”on the 5th May my son came in about 10.45 and remained five or ten minutes, and then went out to see a patient that was very ill, and returned about 1.20â€”he went out again and returned in a cab about three.

Re-examined. Since my daughter came up unexpectedly on the 15th April I have concentrated my mind on certain datesâ€”your dispute with the gas company was not due to pecuniary pressure; the gas was consumed by the person to whom you let 22, Upper Woburn Place.

CATHERINE P. EMTAGE (Re-examined). After breakfast on the 17th April I went to your surgery with a message from mother, and I went in an omnibus to Oxford Circus, and did some shoppingâ€”I returned to End sleigh Gardens soon after twelve, and found you thereâ€”we had some gentlemen visitors, and were talking in the dining-room, and then we went to the drawing-roomâ€”you did not leave the house again before 12.30â€”we all lunched together at 1.30â€”you left at 4.30.

Cross-examined. I remembered this date at Bow Street, the second day we were there, early in Novemberâ€”suddenly remembered the date when I was going through everything I had done, and I remembered going to the Mohawk Minstrelsâ€”I came to London on the 15th.

Re-examined. This was the first time I had visited my mother since my marriageâ€”I was a little home-sick, and I came without giving notice, and took you by surpriseâ€”I fix the date by several little matters, on talking it over with my husband, which are not convenient to mention in open Court.

ELLEN WOODS . I am a domestic servant, in the employ of Mr. Jeffreys, of 85, Albert Street, Regent's Park, and was so employed on the 3rd, 4th, and 5th May lastâ€”on Sunday, 3rd May, Mr. Jeffreys was taken ill, and you were calledâ€”on Monday you came to see him between 11 and 11 30, and on Tuesday, 5th, between 11 and 11.30â€”I did not see you after that.
Cross-examined. That was the last I saw of him.

WILLIAM MARTIN JEFFREYS. YOU saw me on the morning of 3rd May at 85, Albert Streetâ€”I was taken illâ€”I had previously had a severe cold, which apparently developed into an attack of influenzaâ€”I had a sudden attack of heart-disease, and fell insensible on the floorâ€”you usually saw me about 11.15â€”you stopped about half an hour.
Cross-examined. It would take perhaps about half an hour to drive from there to Doctors' Commons.

EDWIN DOWDING . I am clerk to the Gas Company, Horseferry Roadâ€”you came there on 5th May, in reference to some dispute, within a few minutes of 12 o'clockâ€”you were a little troublesome, and were there

some time and saw the managerâ€”you were there from forty to forty-five minutes, and left as near as possible at 12.40â€”directly after you left I despatched a telegram to our district office, instructing them to re-connect the supplyâ€”I have a copy of it, taken by means of carbonised paperâ€”I saw no lady with you.
Cross-examined. I was inside the gas company's premises and did not go outside, and did not see how the prisoner came to the premises or leftâ€”he would certainly leave about 12.40.
Re-examined. Our office is exactly opposite Broadwood's pianoforte manufactory, about 200 yards from the Middlesex side of Lambeth Bridgeâ€”it would take some time to get to Doctors' Commons.
Further Cross-examined. The prisoner paid us on that dayâ€”the account had been outstanding for some time.
By the JURY. Our place would be a little out of the way to Doctors' Commons.

EMMA GRIFFITH . I am a domestic servant, and was in your employ in May lastâ€”I remember the gas. being cut off and re-connected about three o'clock, I should say, on the 5th May; I also saw you about half an hour about luncheon time; we were a little late that day on account of the gas which we cooked byâ€”I remember you mending a roller blind that day, and your saying, "Mrs. Griffith, the gas is now on"; and I said, Thank your, sir."

Cross-examined. I was a general servant, and am not now in the serviceâ€”I left last summerâ€”I remember the prisoner's grandmother speaking to me about the gasâ€”the prisoner was generally home to luncheonâ€”I was in the service from March till July.

EMMA SULLIVAN . I was in Mrs. Bynoe's service as cook for some yearsâ€”I remember going there on the 5th May, when I saw youâ€”it was my birthday, and I was sent by my mistress with whom I then livedâ€”I asked for a drink, and the missus gave me a shillingâ€”I stayed from 1.15 till 2 o'clock.
Cross-examined. I came back to the service, and am there now, and have seen Mrs. Bynoe from day to dayâ€”she has mentioned the case to me, and about the doctor being here.
THOMAS CREW . I am in the employ of Mr. White, cab proprietor, and went there last Mayâ€”I saw you there on the 4th and 5th May, about dinner-time.
Cross-examined. There was no clock in the stable, so I should not know the time to a few minutes.

WILLIAM TOWERS . I know you well as living in the locality for some few yearsâ€”I am a fitter, in the employ of the gas company, and went to your house about 3.10 on the 5th May, when I saw you thereâ€”I connected the gas, and you stood there till I finishedâ€”I left about 3.35â€”I did not see you drive up in a cab.

p.hi: Several witnesses deposed to his good character.

at great lengthy commenting upon the evidence, declaring his innocence, and pointing out that other persons were in possession of all the facts of the case, which would enable them more easily than himself to commit the offence with which he was charged.

div1.p:
GUILTY â€”
Nine Years' Penal Servitude.

192.
HENRY THOMAS (43)
PLEADED GUILTY to uttering a forged cheque for Â£100, after a conviction at this Court.

193.
EDWARD AUGUSTUS DANDO
, Unlawfully obtaining three orders for Â£100 each, with intent to defraud.
MR. KEMP, Q. C., and MR. H. AVORY Prosecuted, and MR. GEOGHEGAN

SAMUEL SCOTT MCMILLAN . I am a member of the Royal College of Physicians, Edinburgh, but have retired and live at Goldhawk Road, Shepherd's Bushâ€”prior to June, 1891, I became acquainted with the prisoner, and he visited at my houseâ€”on June 1, in consequence of a communication I received, I called at his place in Lincoln's Inn Fields, and when I got into his private room he had a letter in his handâ€”he said, "Here is a letter from a gentleman who wishes to join me at the Munich Theatre at the German Exhibition; it will be a good thing, like the Italian Exhibition; I should like you to take it up instead of him"â€”he said he had given Professor Herman Â£600 for his share in the profits of the theatre, and he was to get half the profits; that he had put in Â£300 and wanted another Â£300â€”he read a great part of this document (produced) to me, and said if it was good enough for him to put in Â£300, it was good enough for meâ€”I wanted to take it to my solicitor, but he said, "Leave it to me, I will look after your interests, as I am looking after my own; will you take it up or shall my friend?"(he had a friend who offered him Â£50 more)â€”I said, "I will take it up with you" he said, "I owe you some money, and I shall then be able to pay you off when we work the theatre; the Â£300 will be repaid before any profit by Herman and myself"â€”I said I would find the Â£300, and left, and received this agreement by post next morningâ€”his clerk, Mr. Holmes, called on me, and I tendered him this cheque for Â£100. (Dated June 4th, 1891); it is endorsed by the prisonerâ€”I afterwards handed him these two cheques for Â£100 eachâ€”they are endorsed by the prisoner, and were paid by my bankersâ€”I parted with them because I believed his statement that he had advanced Â£300.

Cross-examined. I have lent him money, and he owed me money at the time of this transactionâ€”I had lent him Â£15 in the May before this June, and he owed me more than thatâ€”I have retired from my professionâ€”I have never been to the Italian Exhibition; I have to the Germanâ€”I heard that the theatre of the Italian Exhibition had cleared Â£4,000â€”I have been in Manchester and Ealingâ€”I have lent money on mortgageâ€”I have assisted one or two, but I am not a money-lenderâ€”when the prisoner borrowed Â£25 in July I found out that he had not put this Â£300 in the theatre, and found that I had been swindledâ€”I went to my solicitor, and he advised me to prosecute the prisoner, and he was written toâ€”if he had paid me I don't mink I should have prosecuted himâ€”this is not the first time I have prosecuted a man to whom I have lent money; a man robbed me of Â£500, and I put it into Mr. Besley's handsâ€”the solicitors in that case were not the same as my solicitors nowâ€”he was sent for trial here, but he was not triedâ€”Mr. Avory asked me

if he was acquitted, and I said "Yes"â€”my solicitor sent me a cheque for Â£500; I did not ask him where it came from, I did not want to knowâ€”I do not know who signed the cheque, I had not the cheque at all, my solicitor backed it and gave me the differenceâ€”that was not muchâ€”these proceedings were not taken against the gentleman purely with the view of forcing his friends to payâ€”he bought my house for Â£500, and I thought he had got it very cheapâ€”I did not take his money; my solicitor took it-that is not the reason why I waited from July to November in this caseâ€”I said to Mr. Avory, at the Police-court, "Not getting my money from the defendant, I put the matter into my solicitor's hands; I was induced to advance the money because of the success he said it would be"â€”I had other reasons, which I was prepared to giveâ€”Mr. Avory said, "Is that your only reason?" and I said, "I cannot think of anything else,"because I had answered the other questions previouslyâ€”I would not have put Â£300 in if he had not put money inâ€”I did not ask him where he got the Â£300 from; I was told by two parties that he had just received Â£500; one of them was his brotherâ€”I did not ask for the money he owed me; he said I should have that after the Exhibitionâ€”Mr. Herman went with me to the Police-court to get the warrantâ€”the prisoner was written to several times, and asked what he meant by such conduct, and he promised to payâ€”my solicitor has his answer.

Re-examined. In the Â£500 case, what was done was done with the sanction of the Court, but I was waiting downstairsâ€”when I advanced the Â£300 I was on terms of intimacy with the prisoner, and was not pressing him for the money he had advancedâ€”I never advanced money on any speculation before, but only on mortgage at 4 per cent, and on a life policy.

ANN WESTON .
