My mother and I have for many years resided with Dr. and Mrs. McMillanâ€”I have frequently written letters for himâ€”on June 1st I went with him to the post-office in Lincoln's Inn Fieldsâ€”my mother and I waited outside while he went into the office, and next morning the prisoner's clerk, Holmes, came to the house for a chequeâ€”I do not recollect drawing a cheque for Â£100, but this cheque (produced) is my writingâ€”on, I believe, June 5th I went and saw the prisonerâ€”I wanted to know what he wanted the money for, and said, "I think you are in a great hurry about it"â€”he produced a deed, and told us about the theatre; I asked him if it would be a safe thing, and he assured us that it would be; he read some of the clauses of it, and said he had invested money in it, and the doctor was going to take half a shareâ€”after that visit I drew the other two cheques for Â£ 100 eachâ€”these are them; they are in my writingâ€”on July 7th wrote him this letter. (Complaining that he was not there when the called with her mother the day before)â€”I received this reply. (Stating that he had had financial troubles, and required considerable funds to meet them, but hoped things would be all fight that week, and that he considered the business would realise a good profit under favourable management.)â€”on 27th July I wrote this letter, to which he replied on July 28th. (Stating that no one could estimate the terrible trouble he was involved in, but that the Borax Company would answer if successfully floated, but that he was without the means to return the payment for the theatre).
Cross-examined. I have been in the habit of writing Dr. McMillan's

letters for him, and taking an active part in any business lie has to doâ€”before he had the first cheque he received a letter from the prisoner on the 3rd, and there was a difference between Dr. McMillan's version of the interview and the prisoner's versionâ€”in spite of that, Dr. McMillan told me to write the cheque, and no step was taken to stop it.

HENRY HERMAN . I am a conjurerâ€”I entered into a speculation in respect to the Munich Theatre at the German Exhibitionâ€”I entered into an agreement with the prisoner to advance moneyâ€”I did not receive Â£300 under this agreement (produced)â€”after it was signed I asked him about it, and he said, "It is a matter of form, which is done every day; I do not want to spend more than Â£300"â€”I received Â£185 from the prisoner after signing the agreementâ€”the theatre was artistically a success, but financially a failureâ€”it was only shut up for one day; it was not exactly closed; there were always performances going on; it went on up to the termination of the German Exhibitionâ€”my part was not closed; one performance was closed, but I had five performances.

Cross-examined. The theatre at the Italian Exhibition was a great successâ€”I have been connected with theatrical matters since 1847â€”I got out of this without losing much money; I lost my timeâ€”the weather was not artistically a success last yearâ€”I estimated the value of the spectacle at more than Â£1,200; the other exhibition was Â£4,500â€”Dr. McMillan asked me to get Dando's share assigned to him; that must have been on 30th Julyâ€”Dr. McMillan came to see me, and I went and saw Dando in consequence of what he saidâ€”on 21st July a meeting of the creditors of the theatre was called at Messrs. Crass' office, virtually by meâ€”they were Dr. McMillan's solicitorsâ€”no money was forthcoming then, and on the following Saturday the theatre was closed, and the money returnedâ€”that was the only occasion when the theatre was closed and the money returnedâ€”Dr. McMillan told me that Dando would assign his shareâ€”I swore an information against Dando at the Police-courtâ€”it was handed to me in the lobby of Bow Street Police-court, and I read some parts of itâ€”the solicitors for the prosecution wrote me a letter which I think covered more than two pagesâ€”it looks like threatening meâ€”this is itâ€”I said at the Police-court that the theatre would have been a success if it had not been for the inclement weather.
Re-examined. The information was in my possession some time, but it was not the same information.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
194.
WILLIAM GEORGE (26)
, assaulting
Mary Ann Duncan, with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

195.
JOHN ALGERNON LATHAM
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully obtaining money by false pretences, with intent to defraud.
Recommended to mercy by the prosecutor.â€”Two Months' Hard Labour.
(For cases tried this day, see Surrey cases.)

196.
LAWRENCE WOODBINE CLOETE (41) and
HUGH MACPHERSON (44)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a transfer of 200 shares in the
Simmer and Jack Gold Mining Company, with intent to defraud; two other Counts varying the form of charge.

EDWARD GODEFROI . I am a stockbroker, of 11, Copthall Courtâ€”I know Cloeteâ€”on 30th June, 1890, he borrowed of me, in the name of the Development and Investment Company, Limited, Â£600â€”as security he deposited this transfer of 200 shares in the Simmer and Jack Gold Mining Companyâ€”No. 3,716, that is executed by Cloeteâ€”the numbers in the body of the transfer are on the shares; they are not very distinctâ€”referring to my book I find the numbers are 27,476 to 525, 54,508 to 12, 71,800 to 4, 59,158 and 9, 18,551 to 5, 13,984 to 14,008, 71,795 to 9, 59,160 to 2, and 15,367 to 466â€”twenty sharesâ€”they are the numbers as they originally stood crossed out on the transfer in red and black, and there is a reference "see back"â€”on the back is another set of numbersâ€”this is my cheque for Â£600, drawn on my bankers, and made payable to the Development Investment Company or bearer, and that is the cheque that represented those. 200 sharesâ€”that loan was repaid, Â£400 on 16th, Â£100 on 18th, and Â£104 17s. 6d. on 22nd Julyâ€”the extra Â£4 17s. 6d. is made up by the stamp, Â£1 15s., and interest at 10 per cent, Â£3 2s. 6d.â€”I thereupon retransferred to Cloete or the Development Company 200 shares in the Simmer Company on 80th Julyâ€”unlike bonds to bearer, you can retransfer any sharesâ€”this transfer is numbered 3,715 in the right-hand corner, and is in Cloete's nameâ€”these shares are numbered 49,387 to 411, 49,362 to 71, 7,819 to 23, 7,729 to 7,808, 4,871 to 40, 52,563 to 77, 62,888 to 62, 5,580 to 89, and 12,031 to 40â€”the numbers on the back of Cloete's transfer to me are the same as the shares I transferred to Cloeteâ€”so that the original shares which Cloete transferred to me have substituted in their place the shares which I transferred back to himâ€”when I was asked to lend money I did not do it myself, but through Besley, a dealer in the market, and directly the shares were put in my name by Cloete I transferred to Besley, and simply passed the transaction through, interest and everythingâ€”that transfer is 3,717â€”in this book I first find a transfer from myself to Cloete, 8,716; then one from Cloete to me; 3,717 is from myself to Besley, the same shares which I got from Cloeteâ€”the numbers are altered in the transfer from myself to Besleyâ€”it appears as if I transferred to Besley the actual shares I actually transferred back to Closte.
Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I have been repaid the Â£600 loanâ€”Besley, unless he has transferred them, holds good sharesâ€”he had a good titleâ€”there was no purchase in the market.

HERBERT FISHER . I am a clerk to Deloite, Dever and Co., accountants by direction of the directors, in December, 1890, I examined the books and documents found at Mr. Cloete's office, which was used as the office of the Simmer Companyâ€”I have been able to trace the shares transferred by No. 3,716 transfer to Mr. Godefroi; I have the certificatesâ€”Cloete. did

not hold the shares which by 3,716 he purported to transferâ€”this ledger shows he held none at that timeâ€”the total shares he dealt in are 680â€”he bought shares on 2nd, 5th, and 22nd June, and on July 23rdâ€”I have one certificate in the name of Edward James Burgess, of 1st April, 1889; Nos. 27,476 to 525; next 8th April, 1889, same name, 54,508 to 12, 71,800 to 804, 59,158 and 9, 18,551 to 5, 13,984 to 14,008, and 71,795 to 9; next 20th May, 89,588 to 62, name, Mark L. Laberchini, and one dated 14th July, 1890, 15,367 to 466â€”the 100 held by Burgess were surrendered to the company in exchange for new certificatesâ€”they remained undealt with and in his hands, if dealt with at all, till long after this transactionâ€”I can tell when he got them from the guard-bookâ€”I have one transfer here, dated 29th March, 1889, from Alfred Bight, of Kimberley, to Mr. Burgess, No. 431â€”the next one is No. 464 from Joseph Duncan McVicar to Edward James Burgess, of 29th March, 1889, Nos. 54,508 to 12â€”465, 29th March, 1889, from Bight to Burgess, Nos. 71,800 to 804; 466, 28th March, 1889, from Francis Charles Matthewson to Burgess, Nos. 59,158 and 9; 467, 28th March, 1889, from Dolera Cohen to Burgess, 5 shares, 18,551 to 5; 468, March 29th 1889, Bight to Burgess, 25 shares, 13,984 to 14,008; next 469, 28th March, 1889, Bight to Burgess, 5 shares, 71,795 to 799; 716, 14th May, 1889, Percy James Russell to Burgess, 3 shares, 59,160 to 162; and 3,413, 30th May, 1890, from Jules Friedlander, of Johannisberg, to Laberchini, of Vienna, 15,417 to 416, and 15,367 to 416â€”I make one correction; I find at this time Cloete held 100 shares; they are different numbersâ€”I cannot speak of the state of things at Cloete's officeâ€”I merely had a few minutes' conversation with Burgess and came away, and the books were immediately afterwards sent to usâ€”I have had a good deal of experience with regard to registration, and I do not think I have seen any set of books in such general disorderâ€”I produce transfer executed by Cloete to Macpherson, No. 3,345 of 6th Juneâ€”it would be presented at the office with the certificate in the name of the transferorâ€”it transfers 330 sharesâ€”Macpherson transfers them to third personsâ€”I have a list of those persons (produced); they are the same numbersâ€”I have traced the numbers, and they correspondâ€”I have a counterfoil of the receipt-book, which shows Cloete dealt with those shares which he had already transferred to Macphersonâ€”a provisional receipt is given to a transfer, which is afterwards exchanged for the certificateâ€”the counterfoil of the receipt-book is 1,976, Cloete to Bailey, 330 sharesâ€”there are no detailsâ€”I have the corresponding certificate here of 28th Julyâ€”Arthur Cecil Bailey represents the shares transferredâ€”Bailey brought me the transferâ€”he did not leave itâ€”I have had it since; it was left by the Development Companyâ€”also 100 shares were sold; twenty to E. Aldersen, and various other people, by Macphersonâ€”one transfer is in the name of Cloeteâ€”Macpherson transfers to Cloete ten sharesâ€”the books show those shares had been sold previouslyâ€”they were already in the names of other persons.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I commenced my investigation of the books early in 1891â€”two transfers bear Cloete's signature; one to Bailey, the other to Macphersonâ€”also one to Godefroiâ€”the transfers are filled up with other writings, not Cloete'sâ€”the alterations are not made in Cloete's writingâ€”Cook, a clerk of the Simmer Company, abscondedâ€”I heard thatâ€”I know nothing of Jaffrayâ€”I have been told he has gone

â€”I heard Macpherson make a statement at the Police-courtâ€”the certificate is lodged at the company's office, and examined with the registerâ€”a borrower would sign a transfer of the shares held as securityâ€”all the details would be filled in by clerks, not by Cloeteâ€”Cloete's office was a large oneâ€”the business of a number of companies was conducted by the Development Company thereâ€”Cloete was the managing director of the Development Companyâ€”about three clerks were employed on the Simmer Company's businessâ€”Macpherson's name does not come into the books as operating clerk on the Stock Exchangeâ€”Bailey has not demanded the 330 sharesâ€”the certificate was lodged for verificationâ€”Bailey's loan was paid offâ€”nobody claims the 330 shares.

Re-examined. I know Macpherson's writingâ€”this is his signature. (Readâ€”Signed H. Macpherson:" Holloway Prison, 7th November, 1891.â€”I wish, in the interests of justice, to repeat the statement I caused to be conveyed to the Simmer and Jack Company last June, namely, that the only persons responsible for putting in circulation the duplicate shares of the company, to the extent of 630 shares, all I know of, are R. A. Jaffray, W. B. Cook, and myself. These shares were sold through Messrs. Lane Brothers, 17, Tokenhouse Yard, to whom the business was introduced by Jaffray. The proceeds, rather over Â£2,000, were equally divided between the three of us. The transfers for these shares were put on the books by Cook, in place of a like number of genuine shares which had been sold by me on Mr. Cloete's behalf, the transfers of which were kept back and destroyed. All this was done without Mr. Cloete's knowledge. All the stock and share business of the office was managed by me, Mr. Cloete placing in me the most implicit confidence, seldom ever looking to the accounts. I abused that confidence in the manner above stated. I have also to state that Poster, whose name has been mentioned, had no hand in the conspiracy."
DR. ALLIOTT. I have been attending Arthur Bailey for influenzaâ€”have sent him to St. Leonards; he is not fit to come here and giv evidence.

The deposition was read of Arthur Cecil Bailey, on October 29th, 1891:" I am a member of the firm of Wood, Neame, and Co, stockbrokers, of 1, Drapers' Gardens, City. The defendant Cloete and the Simmer and Jack Gold Mining Company had offices in the same building. To the best of my belief the offices were the same. I have had business with the defendant Cloete as to both the sale and purchase of shares. I knew the prisoner Macpherson as Cloete's clerk. I never had dealings with Macpherson as principal. I saw Macpherson from time to time with respect to the business I was doing for Cloete. I have sold shares in this gold mining company on instructions from Mr. Cloete without certificates. In ordinary course, if it was not intended to carry over, a transfer would be lodged at the company's office for verification. The particulars for the filling up of the transfer would be obtained from Mr. Cloete. "Also, on 10th November, 1891: "On the 27th May, 1890, I sold to Mr. Wenkheim 100 shares of the Simmer and Jack Mining Company by direction of Mr. Cloete. I had had previous transactions with Mr. Cloete, of which I kept a record in my books; at the time of that sale he was indebted to me in a balance of Â£25 18s. 1d. I produce a press copy of the statement of account sent to the accused about the 28th May. I cannot say

by whom it would be posted. The usual course would be to post these letters. I produce a cheque for Â£401 11s. 5d., dated May 31st, 1890, payable to S. Cloete, Esq., or bearer; that cheque was given to Macpherson. It was copied by usâ€”the National Bank account payee. The amount of that cheque was for the balance due to Cloete after deducting the amount of Â£25 18s. 1d. owing by him. The course of business is for the broker to whom I sell to give the name of the transferee. I received from Mr. Wenkheim the names of the transferee and the brokers. I received certain names and certain parcels of shares from Mr. Wenkheim. The general rule with Mr. Cloete's shares was to prepare the transfers, as far as we could. They were then handed to Mr. Macpherson, to complete, in accordance with written instructions signed by Macpherson (produced). I have no doubt it was followed in this case; I know of nothing to the contrary According to the usual custom we should then receive them back from Macpherson completed. I received payment for these 100 shares from six different brokers, viz., Krailsheimer, 15 shares; Borthwick, Wark and Co., 20; Greatorex, 20; Lowenstein, 30; Koblyn and King, 5; and Godefroi 10. Against those payments I handed over the transfers; they were all from Macpherson to the different brokers, except the last 10 to Godefroi, which were from Cloete to Macpherson. I find from an entry in my books that the numbers of the 15 to Krailsheimer were 785,016 to 30, of the 20 to Borthwick, Wark and Co., 46,258 to 46,262, and 15,882 to 196; of the 20 to Greatorex, 76,971 to 5, 78,501 to 5 and 78,506 to 15; of the 30 to Lowenstein, 62,513 to 32 and 60,143 to 152; of the 5 to Hoblyn and King, 46,253 to 7; and of the 10 to Godefroi, 78,531 to 40. On the payment of the cheques the transfers would be handed over to the buying broker. On the 27th June, 1890,1 made a loan to Cloete of Â£1,000. I am quite sure I saw Mr. Cloete himself. It was on the security of 330 Simmer and Jack share. He paid Â£500 off on August 15th; there was a further loan on September 5th of Â£250. I think Mr. Cloete saw me nearly always with reference to this loan. In the usual course a fortnightly statement would be rendered. I believe it was Macpherson who delivered the transfers of the 330 shares upon which we made the advance. Lawrence Cloete was the name of the transferor, I was the transferee. I caused it to be lodged at the office of the Simmer and Jack Company. I received a receipt, and in due course the certificate (produced) marked O. I afterwards had a communication from the accountants, and saw Mr. Fisher, and made an examination of the books. I spoke to Mr. Cloete about what I had ascertained; I said I had had a communication from the accountants, Deloite, Dever and Co., and the certificate did not appear to be regular; I should think this was about March last. Mr. Cloete expressed surprise at anything being irregular with the certificate; and ultimately, on the 16th April, 1891, the loan was paid off. We then handed him back the certificate. I produce cheque for Â£1,000 dated June 27th, 1890, payable to L. Cloete Esq.; it bears his endorsement, I believe. I had no business with Macpherson as a customer. I acted with him as Mr. coete's clerk. When I handed back the certificate to Mr. Cloete I handed him a retransfer for the shares, not a blank transfer; a transfer from me to him. There was no conversation. "Also 16th, November, 1891;".
Cross-examined by MR. C. O. HUMPHREYS, on behalf

of Cloete. I am now one of the partners of Wood, Neame and Co.; I became a partner about March, 1889. I am not mistaken in saying that Mr. Cloete saw me with reference to the Â£1,000 loan; I was always there, and Mr. Cloete used to call and ask for Mr. Neame, who was seldom there, and I saw him. Mr. Macpherson generally saw me with reference to matters of detail, such as particulars of transfers of shares. I knew Mr. Cloete had interviews with Mr. Neame as to the Â£1,000 loan; I don't know if Mr. Cloete was a buyer of shares at that time; our firm never bought or sold shares of any kind with the Development Company. It was I who made the loan of the Â£1,000 on behalf of the firm. I can't say if I have had cheques for the Development Company; we should take any cheques that he paid in. It would be quite an ordinary circumstance for the certificate not to be given to me when selling shares. The instructions for the transfers would be given by a clerk as being matters of detail.
Cross-examined by Macpherson. On the 27th May the 100 shares were sold at Â£4 6s. 3d. per share. They have been under Â£3 per share on more than one occasion, I believe."

EDWARD JAMES BURGESS . I live at 40, St. James's Road, Brixtonâ€”I was a clerk to the Development Company at 1, Drapers' Gardensâ€”Cloete was managing directorâ€”he was connected with other companies, which had offices there and at No. 18â€”I was there till Christmas, 1890â€”Cook was a clerk especially engaged on the Simmer Company's businessâ€”he was assisted by Foster, Gower, and Eldridgeâ€”they were paid by the Development Company, some weekly and some monthlyâ€”in 1889 Gower's duties were transferred to another clerkâ€”I was London secretary to the Simmer Companyâ€”up to then I was employed by the Development Companyâ€”certificates would be brought to me for examination and signatureâ€”Cloete instructed me to have the certificates examined by clerks, as he said my time was too valuable to be wasted in examining certificatesâ€”from then they were examined by two clerksâ€”I signed them without personally examining them, believing them to be correctâ€”Macpherson was the Stock Exchange clerk of Mr. Cloeteâ€”he had nothing to do with the Simmer Companyâ€”he sat, when in the office, with his back to the back of Cook and Fosterâ€”Cook and Foster went away about August or September, 1890â€”they disappeared suddenlyâ€”I heard from Macpherson they had gone to America from Eustonâ€”I saw Macpherson constantly in the officeâ€”Cloete also mentioned thatâ€”I told Macpherson I heard they had gone to Australiaâ€”Macpherson at my request wrote to the landlord of the hotel where they stayedâ€”I knew from Macpherson they were staying at an hotel at Liverpoolâ€”he gave me the reply to my letter and the name of the vessel, and said they were gone to New Yorkâ€”I gave that letter to Mr. Gilchristâ€”the certificates for the 200 shares bear my signatureâ€”100 of these were purchased in March and April, 1889, and they were placed in my name as secretary of the Neva Syndicateâ€”they remained in my possession till they were handed over to Dr. Neva in February or April, 1891â€”I had not the slightest knowledge those shares were being dealt with by Cloete or Macpherson so as to place them in the hands of other people.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I did not suspect any fraudulent or secret ideaâ€”I was too busy as secretary to examine the certificatesâ€”I acted as secretary to other companies as wellâ€”they conducted their business in the same officeâ€”I had to sign a great many certificatesâ€”I

know Jaffrayâ€”he was secretary to the De Kaap Company, one of the companies whose business was carried on at the same officesâ€”he sat in the same room with the other clerks who have been mentionedâ€”he cannot be foundâ€”Cloete signed a great many documents, relying upon their being correct when brought to him for his signatureâ€”this certificate is signed by Edward Godefroi, in the presence of H. Gregg, of 11, Copthall Courtâ€”Cloete's signature is witnessed by J. J. Ridley, a solicitorâ€”the others are witnessedâ€”the transfer clerk would retain the transfer, and paste it in a book, with which Cloete had nothing to do.

Re-examined. The clerks of the transfer department were in the pay of the Development Company, of which Cloete was the managing directorâ€”they got no benefitâ€”no money was traced to themâ€”the forms seem correct.

ALFRED SULLY . I am an accountantâ€”I am the liquidator of the Development Companyâ€”that company was wound up in December last yearâ€”I believe there will be some assets coming from snares, but very little, Â£1,000 or lessâ€”I have examined the pass-books of the company with the National Bankâ€”cheques were operated upon by Cloete, and countersigned by Evans, "pro"secretaryâ€”Cloete, from the books, owes the company Â£12. 000â€”agreements were entered into with Cloete, Burgess, and the Colonial Syndicateâ€”these are copiesâ€”they come from Somerset House. (These were entered into in July, 1888, and reciting that certain cash and shares are paid to these persons in consideration of their transferring certain property to the Development Company)â€”I do not see any payment in the books to these peopleâ€”I see a minute of shares allotted to Burgessâ€”I have not seen any transfer or trace of scripâ€”most of the shares, rights, and interests of the company have been transferred to another company. since the agreements and before I investigated, in consideration of shares and cash paid to the Development Companyâ€”that consideration has been received by the Development Companyâ€”much of it has gone.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. Cloete is disputing the claim made by me on behalf of the Development Companyâ€”the books were not well keptâ€”Cloete has a counter-claim against the Development Company of Â£12,000 to Â£15,000â€”in that Â£12,000 is included Â£5,000 as salary, and another Â£4,000; but on the other side there is an amount owing by himâ€”I am told Mrs. Cloete has wealthy connectionsâ€”the company's assets consist of a largo number of shares which have not been realisedâ€”the transfer of the Development Company's business to another company was about July, 1890â€”the assets were transferred to the new company, and part of the arrangement was that the Development Company should go into voluntary liquidation.

EDWARD JAMES BURGESS (Re-examined). This is the agreement I entered into with the Development Company when it was first formed. (Transferring the witness's shares in the Butter and Bassett Tin and Copper Company to the Development Company, in consideration of Â£6,500 in cash and Â£6,000 in paid-up shares of the Development Company)â€”I had no shares in the Bassett Company at that timeâ€”I was to receive them from Cloeteâ€”he promised me them for my services as his nomineeâ€”I never had themâ€”I never transferred any to that companyâ€”as secretary I received my salary, but I never received any sharesâ€”nor Â£6,500 in cashâ€”I do not know who the Colonial Syndicate consisted of except Cloete.
HENRY TAYLOR (City Detective Inspector). On the morning of 26th

October I went with a warrant to 7, Drapers' Gardens, with Inspector Seager, who told Cloete who we wereâ€”I handed Cloete the warrant to readâ€”he read itâ€”he said, "I have been robbed by my own clerks"â€”on the way to the station he said, "You do not suppose I should be such a d-d ass as to commit myself for this paltry sum? I have twenty companies in my office, and my confidential clerk frequently lays papers before me for my signature; I have never signed a certificate for these shares"â€”shares were mentioned in the warrant, which is not hereâ€”it was for fifteen shares in Simmer and Jack Gold Mining Companyâ€”on 27th October I was at the trial of Cloete before the Magistrateâ€”a communication was made to me; I went to the corridor of the Court and saw Macphersonâ€”I said, "Is your name Hugh Macpherson?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Have you come here to surrender yourself to me to-day?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I read the warrant to him and said, "Are you the person mentioned in that warrant?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”he was conveyed to the station, the charge was entered, and I returned to the Guildhallâ€”there I was asked by the solicitor for Cloete, when I was giving evidence, "Is it not a fact that Macpherson has stated that he would take all the blame upon himself?"or words to that effectâ€”I answered, "No; not to me"â€”I was not in Court when Macpherson's statement was madeâ€”I saw Macpherson go from the dock to the cells, the same place as Cloete had goneâ€”on 11th November Macpherson handed me the statement which has been read.
Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I believe Macpherson attended the Police office in the old Jewry to surrender (Macpherson here denied this); I was under the impression he had done so.

ALBERT HARRIS . I am the gaoler at the Guildhallâ€”I was present when the defendants were before the Aldermanâ€”I heard the question put to Taylor as to Macpherson having made a statement exonerating Cloeteâ€”Taylor replied that he had not done soâ€”when the Court adjourned at midday the defendants were taken to the cellsâ€”I heard them talking togetherâ€”I did not hear what was saidâ€”after the adjournment Macpherson said to the Alderman, "I wish to state that Mr. Cloete is not guilty, he knows nothing of this matter at all. "

JOHN CHANDLER . I am one of the firm of Plack, Chandler and Co., hide and tallow brokers, 17, St. Mary Axe, Cityâ€”up to 30th March, 1890, I had another partner, who then went outâ€”the defendant had been confidential clerk and book-keeper for about twelve yearsâ€”his duties were to keep the books, to pay wages, to receive from the wharf at Stony Lane moneys due from charges there, to pay them in to the head office, or the Imperial Bank where we bank, and enter the items into the booksâ€”after March, 1890, my attention was directed to the freight and to the charges accountâ€”in

consequence of looking into the matter I spoke to the defendant about itâ€”I first made an examination of the books at Stony Lane in June, 1890â€”Mr. Child is our warehouse keeper thereâ€”books were kept there showing charges received by Child on account of the firmâ€”the prisoner initialled Child's book for the charges paid over to himâ€”the prisoner kept, in the petty cash-book, the payment of wagesâ€”he was authorised to draw the sum necessary for wages at St. Mary Axe and Stony Laneâ€”in June I made an extract from Child's bookâ€”I took out amounts to the total of Â£256 5s. 4d. initialled by the prisoner as received by himâ€”I then examined the cash-book and found a deficiency of Â£114 oddâ€”in consequence of that result I had the amounts for the two previous quarters taken out, and found a deficiency on both those quartersâ€”I called in the assistance of Mr. Moore, an accountantâ€”I spoke to the prisoner about it, and he was suspended about the 23rd Juneâ€”he said he knew he had allowed his books to run into arrears, and that his conduct had been abominable in allowing things to get into such a state, but he could not give any information with regard to the deficiencyâ€”we told him to make up the books, which he failed to doâ€”after his suspension correspondence took place, and an appointment was made for him to come to the office of Messrs. Carpenter, my private solicitor; he came with his solicitor, Mr. Wireâ€”I asked him to explain the deficiency of Â£114 11s. 5d., the figures of which were given him beforehand in writing, to give him time to make the explanationâ€”he said there were slips (which were handed to me) which would show the money had been paid in wages; I said, "If these charges have been used to pay wages, how do you account for the fact of your having drawn from petty cash Â£750 and the total amount paid out for wages r"â€”he had debited petty cash from day to day; he said the wages had been paid out of these chargesâ€”the whole of the wages he had charged against petty cashâ€”he would still have a balance in handâ€”his solicitor said, "Stop; don't go into petty cash; you came here to go into charges"â€”that was the end of the interviewâ€”the following day I received a letter from his solicitor threatening an action for slanderâ€”I was still examining the booksâ€”about 25th September I saw Messrs. Wontnerâ€”the result of the information from the books and that interview was that I charged the prisoner at the Guildhall with falsificationâ€”that charge came before one of the Aldermen on 7th October, 1890â€”the prisoner was represented, and an application was made for a postponement pending the civil proceedingsâ€”then another action was commenced against me for wagesâ€”those actions were consolidated, and came on in the High Court in November lastâ€”then the falsification charge came on before the Alderman, and that., accounts for the lapse of time.

Cross-examined. The prisoner had a large number of transactions through his handsâ€”he was cashier, and under the supervision of my third partner, Mr. Baron, and occasionally my ownâ€”Mr. Baron is not hereâ€”he ceased to be a partner in March, 1890â€”the falsifications were continued till June, that is when I found them outâ€”I knew slips were usedâ€”I did not swear before the Magistrate I did not know of their existenceâ€”nor before Mr. Justice Denmanâ€”the slips have nothing to do with the falsificationâ€”I cannot tell you when they were first used, it was such an irregular proceedingâ€”I swore I did not think the slip system was in existence before the prisoner came into the officeâ€”I had no

knowledge of their use thenâ€”I deny that the prisoner gave me slipsâ€”I said I did not know of their existenceâ€”the money received by Child would be used for wagesâ€”Mr. Child's charges-book and wages-book would show the slips every dayâ€”I did not see all the slips before I suspended the prisonerâ€”I deny that moneys were paid into the bank amounting to the deficiencyâ€”sums were paid inâ€”they could be tracedâ€”the prisoner prepared a balance-sheet to March 31st, 1890â€”the balance-sheet was generally a couple of months after the quarter, but our books are balanced every quarterâ€”the statement was approved in Juneâ€”after Mr. Baron had leftâ€”the prisoner had a great deal of domestic troubleâ€”I believe he worked late at die office; all the clerks were there occasionally lateâ€”in some years a million to a million and a quarter would pass through the booksâ€”there are a large number of itemsâ€”criminal proceedings were in course when the action for slander was threatenedâ€”they were not actually taken.

Re-examined. The prisoner produced more slips at the civil trialâ€”I knew nothing of those till the trial came onâ€”the balance-sheet to 31st March, 1890, was based upon the books which the prisoner keptâ€”on that balance-sheet I should have lost Â£480â€”the money he paid into the bank did not represent the total moneys he had receivedâ€”supposing he ought to have paid in Â£50 in December, he paid in January Â£50 to meet that Â£50, having in the meantime received other Â£50 for other charges.

THOMAS CHILD . I am superintendent for Messrs. Chandler of the Stony Lane Wharfâ€”I have been in their service nearly eighteen yearsâ€”the slips were used to avoid money passing backwards and forwardsâ€”another reason was I could not always get money in time to pay men by 6 p.m.â€”charges were paid in by money and chequesâ€”I used what cash was required, and adjusted it on the slipsâ€”once adjusted, the slips were done with, and the balance of cash was sent to St. Mary Axeâ€”the slips showed the charges and the wages paidâ€”the books show the settlementâ€”the prisoner signed the wages-book for the day, I having paid him the money, and the charges-book, as having received the chargesâ€”a wages-book was also kept at St. Mary Axe by the prisonerâ€”the wages for the 22nd October amount to Â£8 3s. 9d.â€”his summary shows that was paid to himâ€”the total wages for the week was Â£56 8s. 3d. by the cash-bookâ€”that is kept by himâ€”that sum is debited to the firmâ€”moneys are shown to be drawn against that.

Cross-examined. The slips had been in operation possibly ten yearsâ€”I keep the charges-bookâ€”it shows the money received at the wharfâ€”it shows the money handed to me by the prisonerâ€”he signed as having received moneyâ€”this book does not show the balanceâ€”the slips did thatâ€”the slips ought to have been destroyed every day, they are of no valueâ€”they were to show the money received by me from the prisonerâ€”he could refer to no other document for that purpose.

Chandlerâ€”I have prepared the statement produced, showing the transactionsâ€”the prisoner has signed the charges-book on October 22nd, 1888, for Â£29 4s. 8d.; 25th, Â£21 1s. 1d.; 30th

Â£19 19s. 6d.; November 2nd, Â£30 6s. 5d.; 8th, Â£18 6s. 11d.; December 10th, Â£22 11s. 3d.; and for 26th May, 1889, Â£37 8s. 5d.; August 23rd, Â£27 13s.; 27th, Â£25 7s. 3d.; September 20th, Â£26 3s. 1d.; October 7th, Â£18 14s. 4d.; 24th, Â£17 0s. 11d.; 26th, Â£32 17s. 4d.; December 27th, Â£18 9s.; 18th March, 1890, Â£13 7s. 10d.â€”this document shows Â£118 18s. 7d. in three payments, from 22nd October to 8th November, entered in the cash-book; between 8th November and 2nd January inclusive it shows there sums of odd Â£22, Â£41, and Â£33 further receivedâ€”this paper shows all the sums put in the cash-bookâ€”there is no entry of an amount corresponding with the exact amount receivedâ€”the total received is Â£980 6s. 2d., credited in the cash-book Â£506 6s. 4d.â€”that is debited to himselfâ€”the deficiency is Â£473 19s. 10d.â€”that is omitted from the ledgerâ€”I have examined the paid cash-book for the same period, 22nd October, 1888, to 31st March, 1890â€”the amounts in the wages-book embrace all the wages as summarisedâ€”the prisoner has credited himself with themâ€”the same system of falling into arrear was followed after 31st Marchâ€”between March and June the deficiency is Â£157 16s. 3d.â€”during the whole of that time he had full funds and petty cashâ€”in the cash-book petty cash is entered, Â£124 3s. 4d. and Â£40, making Â£164 3s. 4d.â€”in the petty cash-book the Â£40 is not enteredâ€”he had Â£67 14s. 9d. and Â£40 petty cash the same dayâ€”he has posted Â£40 from the paid-out cash-book to the debit of "Paid Cash"in the ledger; and in making up the balance-sheet he writes, "By suspense account, Â£40"; then he transfers it out of the petty cash, reducing the balance to Â£60 15s. 7d., to make it agree with the small petty cash-bookâ€”the 40 sovereigns are not shown again.

Cross-examined. I have had a balance-sheet in which that item must have been introducedâ€”the prisoner has debited himself with itâ€”by "sums received by the prisoner,"I mean sums for which he signed on Child's bookâ€”cheques received for wages appear as petty cashâ€”those items I take from Child's bookâ€”I found about twenty-five slipsâ€”none relating to October 22nd, 25th and 30thâ€”I have the slips with the figures, making up the Â£118 18s. 7d.â€”they are made up of cheques and moneyâ€”money received from the wharf would be generally small cheques and moneyâ€”I have the slips relating to the items of 10th December, 1888, but not 25th May, 1889â€”the slips I have were handed me by Chandler and Co.â€”I have cheques for Â£7 0s. 10d., Â£2 7s. 2d., and Â£4 19s.â€”those were paid inâ€”the slip shows how the amounts signed for in Child's book are made up; the Â£7 0s. 10d. and Â£2 7s. 2d. cheques were paid into the bank, then the Â£4 19s. 2d. and Â£20 16s. 10d. leave Â£34 4s.â€”that was the amount signed for on 10th Decemberâ€”the cheques were paid in on 17thâ€”I have the slip of 26th October, which deals with the Â£32 17s. 4d.â€”it are made up of wages Â£19 12s. 4d. and Â£5 10s., making Â£25 2s. 4d.; the balance signed for is Â£7 15s.â€”on 20th September, Â£26 3s. 4d.; that shows wages Â£24 12s. 8d., giving the details, and charges Â£26 3s. 1d.; and Â£1 10s. 5d. is the amount received by Child from the prisoner.

GUILTY â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

202.
HENRY CONWAY (35)
, Feloniously entering the dwelling-house of
George Austin, in the night-time, with intent to steal.

GEORGE AUSTIN . I am a baker, of 13, New Street, St. Martin's Laneâ€”on 29th December, about 10.45, I unlocked the door and went in, having been outâ€”I found the prisoner concealed under the barrows which I keep in the shopâ€”I asked him what he was doing thereâ€”he said he had been knocked about by some men outside, and rushed in for safetyâ€”I told him I did not believe himâ€”I locked him in and went for a constableâ€”I asked an employÃ© to look after himâ€”as I was returning with the constable the prisoner broke open the door and rushed into the streetâ€”the constable made a grab at him and missed himâ€”the shop was shut for the night; he must have entered by turning the handle of the private door.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I saw no kicks on youâ€”I may have left the street-door open in the hurry to got a constable.

JAMES MURRAY . I am a journeyman baker, and work for the prosecutor at this shopâ€”about 9.45 the prosecutor called me upstairs and asked me to take care of the prisonerâ€”I saw the prosecutor go outâ€”I was left in chargeâ€”the prisoner said he had been assaulted, and asked me to let him go out at the backâ€”I said there was no back-way; he said he must go out; I said he could not go out till the prosecutor came back;â€”he pushed me on one side and burst the door open and ran awayâ€”the door was lockedâ€”I was in baker's clothes and could not go out.

GEORGE DEACON (197 E), I was called by the prosecutor, about 10.45, to his shopâ€”I was on duty about twenty yards away in St. Martin's Laneâ€”I saw the prisoner run away from the doorâ€”I tried to catch him at the doorâ€”I caught him in Hogarth Streetâ€”he asked me to let him goâ€”I said, "You had better come back with me first to the shop"â€”I found the door broken.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. You told me you got in the passage out of the way.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, said he went into the shop for defence, as he was knocked about, and his leys would show the marks; but he had no wrong intention.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

203.
JAMES COBB (27) and
JOHN MASON (30)
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£3 2s. 6d., with intent to defraud.

EUGENIE MOY . I am the wife of George Moy, the landlord of the Northumberland Arms, Well Street, Oxford Streetâ€”on 5th December, a little before eight p.m., the prisoners were in the barâ€”Cobb asked me to put this cheque through the bank, and lend Â£2 on itâ€”I told him I wouldâ€”on the Monday night he fetched the remainder of the moneyâ€”on the Wednesday morning the cheque was returned, marked "No account"â€”this is the cheque, endorsed "George Cobb"â€”Mason assured me the cheque was all right, and I should find Alexander Hutton and Co. 's name in the Directoryâ€”the prisoners were always in company when in my houseâ€”they lived next door, but had gone when we took the chequeâ€”I have seen the prisoners since, about a month back.

EDWARD PEARSE . I am a book-keeper to Alexander Hutton and Co., insurance agents, 138, Leadenhall Streetâ€”my firm does not bank at the London Trading Bank, Coleman Streetâ€”this cheque does not bear my firms signature.

JOHN KANE (Sergeant D). About four p.m., on 12th December, I arrested the prisoners at the Victoria Hotel, King's Crossâ€”I told them the chargeâ€”Cobb said nothingâ€”Mason pointed to Cobb and said, "I do not know the gentleman"â€”they were drinking togetherâ€”they were taken to Tottenham Court Road Police-station; Mr. Moy was thereâ€”Mason said, "If you do not charge, Mr. Moy, I will get you the money by Monday;" Cobb called out, "I'll go and get it now"â€”the prisoners refused their addressâ€”when charged they made no replyâ€”I searched Cobb, and saw Mason searchedâ€”I found on Cobb a cheque-book of the Middlesex Ranking Company between his shirt and drawersâ€”on Mason was found a blank cheque from the same book as found on Cobb.
Cross-examined by Cobb. I did not ask "for your addressâ€”the officer taking the charge asked three or four times for your address, and you refused; and I said, "It does not matter, I know the men."
Cross-examined by Mason. You never said you could prove Cobb had the moneyâ€”it was never mentioned.

p.hi: Cobb's defence was that the money was paid him in discharge of a debt; and Mason's defence, that he had only hen four weeks in England before his arrest. He was an artist decorative painter, knew nothing about the cheque, and refused his address to avoid a scandal.

There was another similar indictment against the prisoners.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude each.

div1.p:
204.
WILLIAM GRAHAM (27)
, Feloniously assaulting
William Wettstein, with intent to rob him.

FREDERICK BARAM (Policeman). On the night of 8th December I was on duty in Fleet Street with Police Constable Brooksâ€”I saw the prisoner with another man, and two men followingâ€”the prisoner turned up Hind Court, and a woman stood at the bottomâ€”just after I heard a cry of "Stop thief!"â€”I ran up the court, and saw the prisoner standing over Wettstein, who was lying on the ground; the prisoner was in the act of striking the prosecutorâ€”he ran awayâ€”I ran and caught himâ€”Brooks followedâ€”the prisoner said, "It is not me; it is a tall man"â€”I had not spokenâ€”I had hold of his right armâ€”I was 17 to 20 yards from him when I first noticed the prisonerâ€”I know him by sightâ€”I have seen him in Fleet Streetâ€”the prisoner was taken to the station and charged.

Cross-examined. There are five ways out of Hind Courtâ€”I ran about 80 yards before I caught the prisonerâ€”the time was about 9.45 p.m.â€”the prosecutor said, "He is like the man," and "I do not know who it is; I cannot charge anybody"â€”the prisoner did not ask me to get some of the crowd as witnesses.

WILLIAM WETTSTEIN . I am superintendent of the Court Restaurant, Strandâ€”on the evening of 8th December I went to Hind Court to make waterâ€”a man rushed down the court at my chain and watchâ€”I exclaimed, "Stop thief!" and "Police!"â€”someone came behind and pushed me on my back; my nose bled and my arm was hurtâ€”the man was the prisoner's heightâ€”I was struck from behind.
Cross-examined. I have said, "I do not know the man; I cannot charge anybody."
WALTER BROOKS (459 City). I was with Baramâ€”I was in plain

clothesâ€”I saw the prisoner with a tall manâ€”we watched them go up Hind Courtâ€”shortly I heard cries of "Police!" and "Stop thief!"â€”I saw the prisoner running from Wettstein, who was lying downâ€”I ran and caught the prisonerâ€”he said, "It's not me; it's the other man"â€”I think Baram caught him firstâ€”we ran up togetherâ€”I made inquiries, but could find no other man.
Cross-examined. I asked the prisoner what he ran for; he said, "To catch the man"â€”the prosecutor did not identify the prisoner.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I am not guilty of this offence. "

GUILTY.* The prisoner pleaded to a conviction at this Court in February, 1886.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
FOURTH COUET.â€”Monday, January 18th, 1892.

205.
WILLIAM CLARKE (24),
CHARLES HAWKINS (21), and
JAMES DAVIS (31)
, Breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Alan Duffus, and stealing his goods.
HARRY CLARKE (25),
FREDERICK CLARKE (32),
WILLIAM JONES (31),
FREDERICK WEST (19), and
HENRY CLAPHAM (40)
, Receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen.

MESSRS. C. MATHEWS and GILL Prosecuted; MESSRS. BEARD and SANDS appeared for Hawkins; MR. PURCELLF or item; MESSRS. GEOGHEGAN and SANDS for Frederick Clarice; MR. LAWLESS for Jones; MR. KEITH FRITH for West; and MESSRS. BURNIE and SANDS for Clapham.

JOHN CHANDLER (Inspector Y). On Sunday, 8th November, about 4.40 p.m., I was on Blackfriars Bridgeâ€”I saw a trap with a grey pony in itâ€”William Clarke was drivingâ€”Hawkins and Davis were with himâ€”they were going towards Clapham and Balhamâ€”I afterwards saw the pony and cart in the hands of the policeâ€”I had the men under observationâ€”I was in communication with Inspector Leach about the matter.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. Davis was in the middle of the cart, and Hawkins on the near side to the kerbâ€”I was on an omnibus going to the Elephant and Castle to meet Inspector Leachâ€”the trap was driving very quicklyâ€”I had the box-seat, and a good viewâ€”the prisoners had dark clothes and hard felt hats; not over their eyes, I had a good view of their faces.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I took a note of itâ€”I had not seen the cart beforeâ€”I have seen Davis with Hawkinsâ€”I afterwards met Leach.

JOHN CHANDLER (Police Constable G). On Sunday, 8th November, about three p.m., I was with Kydd in Wharf Road, City Road, keeping observation on the Queen's Head public-houseâ€”I saw a trap with a grey pony in it drive from the Queen's Headâ€”William Clarke, Davis, and Hawkins were in itâ€”I saw the same trap return about 8.50 p.m. the same day with the same menâ€”it pulled up at the Queen's Headâ€”I saw them get out and go into the public-houseâ€”I was present afterwards when the arrest was made.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I did not hear Davis tell Kydd and

Scott that he had seen them come to the public-house, nor say he had walked into the house just before the police went into itâ€”I was from 20 to 100 yards from the public-house when the traps drew up, on the opposite side in the shadeâ€”the cart did not pass meâ€”they went quickly into the house after the potman came to see to the horse.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. I have known Hawkins two or three years, not intimatelyâ€”I have spoken to him when I have seen him loiteringâ€”I believe they were dressed as they are nowâ€”the ground rises, but they went a smart pace towards Islington when they left the house to go towards the City Roadâ€”I believe William Clarke was drivingâ€”he was sitting on the off-side, the side of the public-houseâ€”Hawkins was in the middleâ€”he had that reefer jacket on.

ALAN DUFFUS . I live at 21, Sheepacre Road, Balhamâ€”on Sunday, 8th November, I left my house with my wife about 6.30 p.m.â€”we left no one in the houseâ€”it was securely fastenedâ€”I noticed Davis standing at the corner about 30 yards from the house, talking to a girlâ€”we came back about eleven p.m.â€”we had left a small glimmer of lightâ€”the gas was then full on in the top front bedroom, that aroused my suspicionâ€”I spoke to a neighbour and went into the houseâ€”I found the place ransackedâ€”in the dining-room things were taken from the sideboardâ€”the two best bedrooms were completely ransacked, turned over as if by an earthquakeâ€”I missed an aneroid barometer, gold brooch, six silver tea-spoons, silver tongs, six dessert-spoons, two silver jam-spoons, a Waterbury watch, a looking-glass, two coats, and one ulster coatâ€”I identified that property the next dayâ€”this is the ulster.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I gave evidence at the Police court on 10th Novemberâ€”the prisoners were placed in a room at the Police-station for me to charge themâ€”after that I said Davis was the man I had seen.

JAMES SMITH . I keep livery and bait stables, at 8, Ridley Road Dalstonâ€”I let to William Clarke a trap and grey pony on 8th Novemberâ€”he has had it several timesâ€”he said he was a commercial travellerâ€”I went to the station, King's Cross, and got the trap from the police.

ALFRED LEACH (Inspector G). For several days in November I had observation upon the Queen's Head, Wharf Roadâ€”Harry Clarke was the licensee and landlordâ€”just before nine p.m., on Sunday, 8th November, I was with other officers in the Wharf Roadâ€”I saw Hawkins, William Clarke, and Davis drive up to the Queen's Headâ€”they appeared to take something from the trap into the houseâ€”the potman then came out, looked in the trap, and tended the ponyâ€”soon after I went inâ€”I closed all. the doors, and went into the back parlour; the men appeared. confusedâ€”I saw in the parlour behind the bar, which is like a little bagatelle room, Jones, Davis, William Clarke, and Hawkins, Frederick Clarke, and two others not hereâ€”I said I was a police officer, and they had better not moveâ€”Constable Keith handed me a Waterbury watchâ€”he found it on the floor; Marony said there was a lot of property in another parlour, and the landlord was missing; I saw Maude Forde with a gold-headed umbrella; I took that from her, and a scent-bottle, and in consequence of her actions I sent her to the station; I said, "You will be detained; do any of you know anything about a pony and trap standing outside?"â€”they all denied knowing about it, and knowing each other: "I don't know this man,""What am I here for?" and so on, and tried to get

awayâ€”Jones said he was a working man, and came to have a drinkâ€”Duffus identified the Waterbury as hisâ€”I went to the trap, and found a looking-glass in the bottom of itâ€”that Duffus identified as stolen from himâ€”we searched, and Marony found some of Pickford's propertyâ€”I took charge of the prisonersâ€”For de made a statement, in consequence of which I spoke to Frederick Clarkeâ€”Harry Clarke was not thereâ€”he was arrested on November 23rdâ€”he made a statement at the stationâ€”Clapham was brought to the station on 8th Decemberâ€”he there made a statement to meâ€”I asked him questionsâ€”I told him he would be charged with being concerned with other men in custody with housebreaking and receiving, mentioning Mrs. Wilson's, of Chelsea, and that property had been stolen worth Â£100â€”I read to him statements made by Harry Clarke, and called his attention to some goldsmith's scalesâ€”he said, "Yes, they are my scales"â€”I took down what he paidâ€”"I lent them to Harry Clarke, I sent them to be repaired, and whilst they were being done Clarke asked me if I had a pair of scales; I said, 'Yes; but they are being repaired; if you like to pay the money for them being repaired you can have them'; from that time I have not seen them until now"â€”I asked him if he wished to give any explanation regarding the silver; he said, "Not at present"â€”he was charged, and said, "It is false"â€”the umbrella and scent-bottle were subsequently identifiedâ€”I took down particulars of what the prisoners were.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. Kydd and Scott were acting under my ordersâ€”I did not hear Davis say at the Old Street station that he had seen Kydd and Scott in Lever Street, nor Kydd reply, "You must have been following us about"â€”Jones asked something about the Wharf Roadâ€”Davis did not say he had not been in the trap, and had come into the house just before the raidâ€”the trap did not pass me, it came towards meâ€”I was twenty or thirty yards from the trap when it stoppedâ€”White joined me about 5.30 p.m.â€”we did not go nearer the trap till the prisoners had gone into the houseâ€”Davis was known by sight.

Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. There were twenty-five or thirty men thereâ€”I had three other officersâ€”after inquiries I let some goâ€”two other men and a woman were in the roomâ€”Jones said he was a bricklayer and came to drinkâ€”he gave a correct addressâ€”I searched him, I searched his houseâ€”I found no stolen property.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. I did mention this offence to Clapham when arrestedâ€”there was a full barâ€”I am known at the houseâ€”we have made one or two raids on it for gamblingâ€”there was confusion, and some said, "You are taking a liberty with me, guv'rner," and so on; we expect thatâ€”I did not question each individual, "Do you know these men?"â€”I was hard pressed for assistance; I had eight men to hold the house.
Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. Jones had a dog when arrestedâ€”I believe it was returned to his wife.
Cross-examined by MR. K. FRITH. I found nothing on West connected with the robbery.
ANDREW KYDD (Policeman G). I followed the inspector into the Queen's Headâ€”I heard something drop in the parlour behind the barâ€”I picked up a Waterbury watchâ€”Hawkins was nearest the doorâ€”I

searched William Clarke at the station, and found on him Â£28 10s. in gold, Â£1 10s. in silver, and 6 1/2 d. in bronzeâ€”he said his mother sent it to himâ€”he described himself as a traveller for the Shackle well Photographic Companyâ€”I found these ten photographs on himâ€”I searched Westâ€”I found on him Â£2 in gold, 8s. 6d. in silver, and 1s. bronzeâ€”I was not in Lever Street on that evening.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I know Davis by sightâ€”he suggested at the Police-court he had seen me in Lever Street at seven p.m.; that was a mistakeâ€”he did not say, "You must have been following us up then"â€”I was about 200 yards off the trap when it drove upâ€”I could not distinguish the faces of the men in it.
Cross-examined by MR. FRITH. The money found on West was handed over, by direction of the Magistrate, on the second remand, to his solicitor for his defence.
Cross-examined by MR. BEARD. I was about two yards from Hawkins when I heard the watch dropâ€”he was to the right of meâ€”others were nearâ€”he was in front of me.

JAMES SCOTT (Policeman G). I was present at the arrest at the Queen's Headâ€”Frederick Clarke said to me, "I do not know any of these men; they are all strangers to me"â€”he was taken to the Police-stationâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said, "It has nothing to do with me. I bought and paid for the things; I paid for Maude Forde"â€”he described himself as a farrierâ€”West said, "I am innocent. I only went into the house to have a drink; I did not know there was anything there. I do not know the others"â€”he was chargedâ€”he described himself as a tailor.
WILLIAM SARGEANT (Policeman G). I was in company with Leach when these arrests were madeâ€”I picked up this tab of an ulster coat off the floorâ€”Mr. Duff us identified it.

STEPHEN MARONY (Detective G). I assisted taking the prisoners to the stationâ€”I know the room where the Waterbury was foundâ€”I found some property in the room communicating by a doorâ€”that has since been identified by Mr. Duffusâ€”at the rear of the bagatelle-room I found these two jemmiesâ€”I find a distinct impression of the smaller one on Mr. Duffus' doorâ€”I saw the umbrella and scent-bottle taken from Maude Fordeâ€”I also found some crucibles broken up.

FRANK PICKFORD . I am a gardener, of 161, Manor Street, Claphamâ€”I lived at 13, Crescent Lane,. Clapham Park, on 8th November lastâ€”about 1.30 p.m. I went out, leaving the house fastened upâ€”I came back at 9.30 p. mâ€”I found the street door broken openâ€”I missed jewellery, value Â£6 10s.â€”this is it.
STEPHEN MARONY (Re-examined). I found this jewellery in the same room at the Queen's Head as the other property was found in.
MAUDE FORDE . I was barmaid to Harry Clarke at the Queen's Head from last August to Novemberâ€”two of the prisoners used to come thereâ€”they addressed each other by their Christian name.
Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. I was there three weeks before the arrest.

FREDERICK WATSON . I live at 59, Britannia Street, New North Road, Hoxtonâ€”I was formerly employed by Claphamâ€”I left him and went to Harry Clarke as barmanâ€”I was there two months or nine weeksâ€”before 8th Novemberâ€”I saw Harry Clarke there.

Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. I was originally charged, then I was dischargedâ€”I knew. Tones four or five weeks; I only noticed him in the concert-room when he used to singâ€”I said before the Magistrate, "I only noticed Jones sitting there"a month or five weeks backâ€”he attended concert nights and at boxing exhibitionsâ€”he was dressed like a bricklayer.
Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. Hawkins used to sing there, and attend the boxing entertainments.
GUILTY .

206.
JAMES DAVIS ,
WILLIAM JONES ,
FREDERICK WEST , and
HARRY CLARKE were again indicted for
a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Arthur Wilson, and stealing twenty-two ladles, spoons, and other goods. JONES, CLARKE, and
HARRY CLAPHAM
were also charged with feloniously receiving the same, to which HARRY CLARKE
PLEADED GUILTY.
MR. C. MATHEWS Prosecuted; MR. PURCELL appeared for Davis, MR. K. FRITH FOR West, MR. LAWLESS for Jones, and MR. BURNIE for Clapham.

NELLY WILSON . I am the wife of Arthur Wilson, of 34, Sidney Street, Chelseaâ€”on October 26th I left the house securely fastened, and went to Devonshire, leaving the house emptyâ€”when I drove away I saw a man walking up and down, who, to the best of my belief, was the prisoner Davisâ€”when I came back on the following Friday the police were in possession of the house, and I missed plate, jewellery, and other articles, value about Â£1,200â€”I have identified a large number of articlesâ€”there were marks where the front door had been prized open.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I heard that my property had been found at a public-house, and that some men were taken in the houseâ€”I was not shown a number of men togetherâ€”I saw Davis and said, "That is the man I saw walking up and down. "

HARRY CLARKE (the prisoner). I was the licensee of the Queen's Head public-house up to November 8thâ€”on that evening I got some information which induced me to leave the house somewhat suddenlyâ€”I was arrested on November 23rd, and made a statement to the policeâ€”on Tuesday night, 27th October, I believe, Harry Clapham came to my door about 9.30 and said that somebody was waiting for me upstairs; I went up, and found West, Jones, and another manâ€”they had a quantity of silver and plate in a sheet, which they said they brought in a van, which they had sent homeâ€”there were silver spoons, forks, and plated articles, a watch, some silk handkerchiefs, a silver tea or coffee pot, two cruet-stands, a toast rack, and several other articles, about 150 altogetherâ€”they asked my permission to leave the property till the next morning; I said yes, and they left itâ€”they returned the next morning, and Clapham joined then afterwardsâ€”they brought a pair of scales from Kettermarter, a butcher, in which I weighed the silverâ€”it came to 140 ounces, and Clapham and I agreed to buy it at 2s. an ounceâ€”I paid them Â£28, and they left, but West and Jones stayedâ€”Clapham and I cut the silver up with a pair of shears, and afterwards put it in a crucible, which we sent forâ€”we melted it at my house, in an ordinary fireplace, and Clapham took it to Roper's next morning, and brought back Â£23 odd and the ticket, which was destroyed at the timeâ€”it was sold at 3s. 5d.; it was fine silverâ€”some plated goods were left behind and put upstairs, in one of the bedrooms, under the flooring, where the police

Found these silk handkerchiefs, a large silver ladle, gravy-spoon, and a considerable number of articlesâ€”West said that Mrs. Wilson's house was furnished very wellâ€”Jones and West stayed for some hoursâ€”I believe Jones had money after the transactionâ€”I once had potman in my service named Mike Hawbridge; I do not know whether he is hereâ€”Watson, the potman who succeeded Hawbridge, brought the scales; they were returned the same day.

Cross-examined by MR. LAWKESS. I have not been told by the police that it would be better for me to give evidence, and I do not think it willâ€”I come forward in the interest of justiceâ€”I do not know whether to expect a heavier sentence by giving evidenceâ€”I known that this was the evening of the 27th, because we had a club meeting that nightâ€”I got to the public-house something after nine o'clock, and found them thereâ€”I returned next day, Wednesday, about eleven o'clock; Jones was there, he remained two or three hoursâ€”the money was given to them on the following day, Thursday, about twelve o'clockâ€”Jones was there then.

Cross-examined by MR. FRITH. I am twenty-five years oldâ€”when the police made the raid I ran away to avoid arrestâ€”my wife was taken up and was in prison for a weekâ€”I did not come forward to save her, I was taken in custodyâ€”we have been married four yearsâ€”I came to you and paid you money to get here offâ€”when I was arrested I made a statement to the police as to what I could say, but not on the night I was arrestedâ€”I pleaded guilty at the Police-court, but not the next dayâ€”I first made a statement about a week after I was arrestedâ€”that was at the Clerkenwell Police-court; two officers were arrestedâ€”that was at the Clerkenwell Police-court; two officers were present, and one of them took it downâ€”I do not expect to get better off by making this statementâ€”I saw Inspector Leach again when I was in Holloway Prison; another officer was present.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. Clapham was present the following morning before the silver was meltedâ€”I did not tell him I was hard up, and had some silver I wanted him to take to the assayersâ€”I paid the money after it was brought back from the refiners; I gave Clapham 15s. for it, but he had more than thatâ€”I did not tell him I wanted the scales for weighing tobacco.
Re-examined. I paid the money to one man, the man not in custody.

FREDERICK KETTERMARTER . I am a baker, of 5, Shepherd's Walk, Brixtonâ€”I know Harry Clarks as a customerâ€”I lent him a pair of beam scales in Octoberâ€”he fetched them himself, and brought them back the same night.

Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. I agree with what Watson said; he had only seen Jones four or five weeks before November 8thâ€”he was principally there on the nights of the concerts, in working men's clothes, as a builder.

FREDERICK WATSON . I formerly did odd jobs for Claphamâ€”I took a pair of scales for him to a shop in Goswell Road to be repaired; I paid 5s. for them, and took them away to the Queens' Head, and left them
with Harry Clarke, the landlordâ€”I afterwards went into Clarke's employment as potman five or six weeks before the arrests were made.

EDWARD BURDON (Police Sergeant K). On 23rd November I arrested Harry Clarke, and charged him with receiving stolen propertyâ€”he said, "If you had not caught me very soon I should have made away with myself; I have been led into this by a man who used my house."

SAMUEL ROPER . I am a gold refiner, of 7, Gardner Street, Clerkenwellâ€”I have known Clapham four yearsâ€”throughout the year 1891 I was purchasing gold and silver articles from him, watch-keys, chains, and ringsâ€”I knew him as a pipe-mounterâ€”on 30th October he brought me four lumps of molten silver, and asked me to give him an estimateâ€”I said it would have to be re-melted and assayed, and if he would call the next day I would give him the price; he did soâ€”the weight was 129 oz. 5 gr., and I paid him Â£23 5s. 6d., and gave him a ticket with the amount on itâ€”I had made other purchases of him during the month.
Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I saw nothing improper in the transactionâ€”he always behaved as a respectable man in my office.

STEPHEN MARONY (Police Sergeant). I assisted in the prisoner's arrest-râ€”I searched the house, and found under the floor of the first-floor landing the property which Mrs. Wilson identifiesâ€”I also found two jemmies which had apparently been usedâ€”I compared them with the door of the houseâ€”I found these shears (produced) at the public-house.

PHILIP WILLIS (Policeman G). On 8th December I arrested Clapham, and told him he would be charged with others in custody for housebreaking and receivingâ€”he said, "All right"â€”I sent him to the stationâ€”he gave his address, 17, Taplow Streetâ€”I went there; he occupies the first-floor fro atâ€”I afterwards went to Britannia Road, Islington, to a shop which had been used by Clapham; I know that from his brotherâ€”Clapham gave me an address and a key, but the door was unlockedâ€”I asked him if he wished to make any reply; he said, "Not at present"â€”these shears and four crucibles were brought to the station.

JOSEPH HINTON . I am foreman to Mr. Dove, a builder, of 131, Euston Roadâ€”in October the prisoner Tones was working under meâ€”he commenced on October 5th at St. Saviour's Church, Aberdeen Park, Highbury Road; I was working on the job myselfâ€”he worked till Saturday, November 7th, for 10 Â£ hours a dayâ€”he went at six a.m. and left at ten, excluding mealsâ€”on 26th, 27th, and 28th October he was at work; he was away on Tuesday, October 13th, that was the only day he was absentâ€”he was not absent on any other day, so that he could be in the City Road at twelve o'clock; I have got the time-sheetsâ€”he is a bricklayer.

Cross-examined. I have not been listening to the evidence to-day, I was out in the passage, I was called in and sent out againâ€”I only just spoke to the counsel, and went out into the passage againâ€”I was subpÅ“naed last week to come hereâ€”I went to the Police-station, and was told that I must come to speak to Jones' movementsâ€”to prove he was at workâ€”I looked at the time-sheets on Friday; they are in my governor's possession; I have not brought them.
Re-examined. A constable spoke to me, and sent me out of Courtâ€”a friend of mine said, "If I were you I would go to the inspector and ask
him"â€”I told him Jones worked with me five weeksâ€”he said, "You will have to come round and prove it."

JAMES SCOTT (Police Sergeant G). I have been in Court during this easeâ€”I have seen the last witness in Court standing by the side of his counselâ€”I called the constable's attention to him, and he turned him outâ€”he was in Court quite ten minutes.
GUILTY .

Smithers are the signatories, and have initialed the counterfoilâ€”in private account-book No. 2, in the prisoner's banking account, I find under 9th May Â£950 appearing to the credit of the accountâ€”the prisoner's credit balance stood the day before at Â£40 2s. 7d.â€”on 27th November, 1890, his credit balance was Â£362 14s. 10d.â€”these cheques are drawn on Glyn Mills, were cashed at Glyn Mills, and the notes with which they were cashed were paid into the prisoner's account at the London and Westminster Bankâ€”on 13th June, 1891, Â£200 was drawn to office cash, and appears in private account-book No. 2, and the same day it was paid into the prisoner's private account at the London and Westminster, and drawn out; it appears as Â£200 received from the London and Westminster Bank on that dayâ€”on 1st July Â£60 was drawn to office cash; it appears in the books, and I can identify itâ€”it was paid either to or on account of Mr. Wilfred Smithers, the prisoner's sonâ€”this is a receipt of 1st July for Â£60: "Received on account of A. S. C. Baringsâ€”a law was passed by which the debtors in Buenos Ayres were absolved from liability for a time from the payment of debts, so that no action for the payment of debt could be brought for a certain periodâ€”no doubt that deteriorated very largely the original securities, it has not yet fully recoveredâ€”the depression was in some cases even more than 25 or 30 per cent.â€”I know generally that

Mr. Smithers was interested in Argentine securities, and very probably suffered when the crash cameâ€”a call has been applied for on the shareholders of the bank, it has not been actually made at presentâ€”it would be rather a bold thing to say that the bank will be able to pay its debtsâ€”I daresay we have put that forwardâ€”Mr. Stewart, the Official Assignee, is not in Courtâ€”I attended the meeting the other dayâ€”I agree with the statement then made, that the gross liabilities were stated at four millions, of which three millions were expected to rank; so that upon this estimate the capital of the bank would, if realised; prove to be intact; but I may explain, as regards the branches, the uncertainty of all the values of the property would to some extent diminish the profitsâ€”assuming the values should turn out as we hope, there would be an estimated surplus of a million, Â£40,000â€”I have had access to the minutes of the companyâ€”I believe in the case of each loan by the bank to Mr. Smithers a proper minute was made, and a proper entry in the accountsâ€”I have in my hand the office cash-book, that is one of the regular books of the bank, open to inspection to any officer of the bank, and might be called for at any meeting of the board, and by the auditors if they desired to see itâ€”I find in this book, under the date of 10th October, 1890, this entry, "A. E. S., Â£200,"with a blue tickâ€”on 29th October, 1890, there is "A. E. S., Â£1,000,"ticked in the same way; on 27th November, 1890, there is "A. E. S. Â£2,500,"ticked, and with the number of the cheque, 7361â€”the next entry is 12th December, 1890, "A. E. S., Â£400,"ticked; then 2nd February, 1891, "A. E. S., Â£350"; the next is 28th April, 1891, "A. E. S, Â£200,"ticked in the same way; then 2nd May, 1891, "A. E. S., Â£350"; and on 13th May, "A. E. S., Â£950,"ticked in the same way; on 13th June, "A. E. S., Â£200,"ticked; and 1st July, "A. E. accountâ€”in Journal No. 11, folio 669, there is an amount stated to be received "from J. 0. Dalcaine, of Buenos Ayres, on account, on 24th July, 1890, as per A. E. S., Â£797 16s. 2d."â€”that is in a book which the auditors would have before them; farther on there is an entry of the Â£4,000â€”if Â£7,000 odd came from Buenos Ayres through the branch there to Mr. Smithers, it ought not to have gone on the head office suspense account; it ought to have gone on the floating branch entries accountâ€”it appears under "Suspense account"â€”if that amount was expected from J. C. Dalcaine, it should come to the account of Smithersâ€”in the next page Â£4,000 is entered, leaving a balance of Â£3,697; Dalcaine's name does not appear in that entry; that balance is transferred from the suspense account to the branches' floating interest account; in Journal No. 12, under date of 30th September, 1890, there is this item, "Transfer from suspense account, per contra, 24th July, 1890, balance of amount to be received from J. C. Dalcaine, on account of A. E. Smithers, Â£3,697"â€”it appears by that entry that Â£3,697 was expected from Dalcaine; there is not anything wrong on the face of itâ€”I don't see how it could be entered in any other way, except it went to the man directâ€”I take it that the real objection is that there was no separate account opened, showing at a glance the amount that had been received by Smithers from the cash of the bank, except of course that he ought not to have had that money in the first place at allâ€”the winding-up proceedings commenced before 14th July, 1891â€”that entry correctly states that Mr. Smithers did owe to the office cash Â£7,146 7s. 2d., which he could not repay; and it refers to the office-book, the items in which correspond with the items in the office cash-bookâ€”I should say that it should have been opened in his own name as a fresh account, as money taken from the cash-till, and called by its proper name, as withdrawn from office cash; that would represent the transactionâ€”that is certainly the purport of the entry; however it was entered it would not affect the position of the bank or the position of Smithersâ€”stating it in that way, and making reference to the pass-book, would necessarily call attention to how the account was made up; that was the inference that I think most would drawâ€”the moment reference was made to the cashbook it would appear what the real character of the transaction wasâ€”the rough office cash-book does not contain any of the entries which appear in the office cash-book, it is really only a copy of the account with Glyn, Mills and Co.; in pursuance of

it the entry was madeâ€”after I assumed the supervision of affairs at the bank, certain deeds relating to a house of Mr. Smithers, at Brighton, came into my possession; I believe it was freeholdâ€”the deeds are not entered in any bank book, so far as I have been able to ascertainâ€”in the securities-book securities lodged against each loan are entered; these deeds do not appear anywhere, but they were in possession of the bank and in the safe at the time of liquidationâ€”the property comprised in them realised Â£4,000, and that sum the prisoner has been given credit for in his general accountâ€”I should think about a month after the money was received he objected to it, and said he was entitled to get credit for it against the cashâ€”since liquidation Â£4,000 has been realised in that wayâ€”I was present at the Police-court when the prisoner was called on as to whether he had anything to say, and I heard what he said.

July entered in the loan account, and no entry suggesting it was a loan or treating it as a loan, except the one which the prisoner ordered to be madeâ€”no securities are entered as held against itâ€”the deeds of the Brighton house were not entered as security in any bank-book, as far as I knowâ€”if money had been taken from the till and not entered anywhere it would have been detected directly we came to make up the balance at the end of the month, if we compared the office cash-book with the amount of office cash in the ledgerâ€”a certain amount of money comes from Grlyn Mills into the till, and that must be accounted for when the cash is balanced at the end of every monthâ€”the office cash-book shows these entries to A. E. S.â€”there is nothing in these books to show that they have been before the auditors of the company, I can see no auditors' marks in themâ€”the amounts paid by Mr. Smithers in order to enable the balance to agree for the audit on August 30th were Â£9,307 4s. 4d. in 1889â€”the cash balance at the end of June, 1890, appears in the account of office cash in the ledger as Â£13,262â€”the balance appears as Â£13,260 8s. 8d. in the hands of the officers of the bank in June, 1890; the office cash-book shows only Â£6,917â€”Â£7,697 15s. 2d. is entered in the suspense account as money to be received from J. C. Dalcaine, on account of Smithersâ€”there is no transaction as to that in the booksâ€”if it were acknowledged between Dalcaine and Smithers, it had no business in the suspense account; there was a debt of Â£9,000 due from Dalcaine to the bank in the regular course of busi
ness;

there is nothing in the suspense account or branch floating entries account to suggest any connection of that sum with office cash; with the exception of Â£1,000 on 7th October, no sum of money was paid in by Smithers to meet the overdrafts, except the sum necessary to balance at the end of September, 1890â€”Â£672 16s. 10d., paid by a cheque of Smithers on the London and Westminster Bank; so that the auditors would again find that the actual balance corresponded with the balance as entered in the ledger; from 30th September, 1890, to 14th July, 1891, these continued takings of cash took place, and then we get the Â£7,146 odd loan account, which also remains unpaid.

ANDREW GEDDES . I was cashier at the bank from 1884 to 1888, and am still a clerk there; amounts of cash were from time to time paid out to Smithers which were not posted to the journal the following morning, like other payments out of office cashâ€”I do not know by whose orders they were so treatedâ€”I did not do the postingâ€”a clerk did that from the vouchers, cheques, and billsâ€”I have the office cash-book containing 29th Octoberâ€”Â£200 was paid out that day to McColl, and Â£287 to Walton on 31stâ€”Â£555 5s. to Dominiquez on 30thâ€”Â£100 to Famini on 1st November Â£100 to Witely on the 4thâ€”Â£170 to Walton on 7th, and Â£100 to Eiddâ€”Â£100 to Randall on 8th, and Â£100 on 13th, etc., total Â£2,500â€”they are the same persons as appear on the counterfoil of the cheque of 27th November.

Cross-examined. None of those counterfoils are in Smithers' writing; nor, as far as I know, had he anything to do with drawing them; after I was cashier, Fraser acted for a short time, and then Bellâ€”Wright was cashier when I came, and was so from 188. to 1884; when I became cashier, I came to know of the existence of the pass-book, as it is calledâ€”I am not sure when it commencedâ€”I dont remember seeing the earlier pass-booksâ€”they purport to show all payments made on Smithers' account, and his repayments were creditedâ€”there was no concealment of what was doneâ€”I never received any instructions from Smithers to omit any entries or to destroy the trace of any entries, or to do anything to conceal what was taking placeâ€”he was away in Buenos Ayres, on bank business, from August, 1889, till the following January or February, during which payments were made and received on his account as before, for which cheques were drawn by a clerk on instructions of the cashier, who would speak to the accountant about itâ€”cheques to replenish the office-till, or to meet current liabilities, would be laid before the directors, and the system of marking the amounts required on the counterfoils was observed of late, and the cheques would be handed to the cashierâ€”he might keep them in his drawer for a week if the money was not wantedâ€”the rough cash-book was practically an account with Glyn'sâ€”it would not be proper to have an account of those payments out of cashâ€”payments do, in fact, appear in the cash-book as "A. E. S."â€”the office cash-book is the regular book of the bank, and the rough cash-book the sameâ€”every penny paid to Smithers is accurately recorded in the office cash-book and the pass-book.

Re-examined. The counterfoil of this Â£2,500 cheque is initialed by Rogers and Smithers, and Smithers signed itâ€”Â£2,500 is an exceptionally large amount for office cash; the usual amount is about Â£1,000.
JOHN REED . I was bill clerk in the English Bank of the River Plate, I prepared the cheque of the 27th November, 1890, for Â£2,500, and
