I entered the amounts which now appear in the counterfoilâ€”I cannot say from whose instructions; as a rule, I received my materials for entering the amounts either from Bell or Wrightâ€”I have no recollection of this particular case: I did not get the particulars from any book.
Cross-examined. I was not examined before the Magistrateâ€”Smithers had nothing to do with the entries in the book, so far as I know.

DAVID LINDO HENEY . I am a clerk in the English Bank of the River Plateâ€”I had charge of the securities and registered themâ€”there was a securities register, in which all securities held by the bank against advances were enteredâ€”there was also a book called the safe custody register, in which the deeds at the bank for safe custody were enteredâ€”I never heard of the deeds of the freehold house at Brighton being deposited as security at the bankâ€”they never passed through my hands.

Cross-examined. The safe custody register relates to clients who deposit their title-deeds and so on for safe custody with the bankâ€”I heard the deeds for the Brighton property were found in a safe at the bank.

JULIAN OLIPHANT BYRNE . I am a senior clerk at the Official Receiver's officeâ€”in August last I took possession of the bank premisesâ€”I went to the strong-room and examined the securities there with the last witnessâ€”there is an inner compartment to the strong-roomâ€”there was a small safe in the outer compartment, which was opened by Wright in my presenceâ€”there were in it some books and papers, and amongst others a brown paper parcelâ€”I could not be certain whether there was any name on it, but there was no labelâ€”it was put back again, and a month after I went again and examined the parcel, and opened itâ€”it contained deeds and other papers relating to some property at Brightonâ€”I gave instructions in August, when I took possession, that no documents were to be removed from the bank.

Cross-examined. There is a kind of inner chamber in the strong-room, called the treasury, where securities are kept that are deposited with the bank for safe custody, in different receptaclesâ€”there were two or three boxes of Smithers' at the bankâ€”the deeds were not in either of thoseâ€”there were books and papers there belonging to Wright, the accountantâ€”he kept the key, which I had to get from him.

JOHN MENZIES WEIGHT . I am clerk at the English Bank of the River Plateâ€”I was formerly accountantâ€”this parcel of deeds relating to the house at Brighton was handed to me by Smithersâ€”I said when before the Magistrate that it was about a year ago, roughlyâ€”I could not say exactly, but it would be about eighteen months agoâ€”he gave them to me to take care of; I have no recollection of Smithers saying they were securities for money he had of the bank; I put them into the safe, where they were foundâ€”soon after the bank suspended, Smithers asked me to give him back the parcel that I had taken care of for himâ€”I said I could not do it, as I had received instructions from Mr. Byrne, which he had received from Mr. Stewart, the Official Receiver, that I was to deliver nothing over to Mr. Smithersâ€”my attention was called to the entry in the ledger debiting Smithers' loan account with Â£7,146 7s. 2d.â€”the entry came out of that pass-book, and was debited to the loan account by Smithers' instructions, four days, I think, before the bank suspendedâ€”I dictated the slip to Bell; I think it was dated tae 14th Julyâ€”I had, in 1890, caused to be made these entries transferring Â£7,600 to the suspense account by
Smithers' instructionsâ€”I also transferred the balance of Â£3,600 to the branch floating entries account.

Cross-examined. Smithers had one box, I think, with his name upon it, which was kept in the outer safeâ€”he had the key of itâ€”if he had intended to treat these deeds as other documents belonging to him, there was nothing to prevent him putting them in and turning the key, but he told me to take care of them, as they were valuable deeds or papersâ€”it might be further back than I thought it was when he brought me the parcelâ€”I believe Messrs. Webb, Smithers' private solicitors, conducted the sale of his property, and accounted to the Official Receiverâ€”I have no recollection of his saying he wanted the deeds for Messrs. Webbâ€”I told him I could not hand them over, as I was told by Byrne not to do soâ€”I was cashier in 1881 when the bank startedâ€”Smithers would come and tell me ho wanted some money, and I would pay it out of office cashâ€”and so it grew from little to bigger thingsâ€”there was never any attempt at concealment, nor was I in any way conscious that I was doing anything fraudulent or dishonest or a party to itâ€”the auditors never asked for the office cash-books, they were available if they hadâ€”they were asked if they had everything they required, and always said, "Yea, we think so"â€”no books were kept concealedâ€”there were considerable payments made during Smithers' absence abroad from August, 1889, to February, 1890â€”I cannot say how much without seeing the booksâ€”whatever has been paid has been entered in those booksâ€”I knew Dalcaine personallyâ€”I learnt from Smithers that he had made large payments for Dalcaine, and expected to receive large payments from him shortly, which were to be applied in discharge of money paid to himâ€”about Â£8,000â€”Â£4,000 I believe came from that source (Buenos Ayres), and he said he was very much disappointed that more had not come forwardâ€”in the entry under the head of "Loan account"the balance of account in the cash-book Â£7,100 expresses the fact that Smithers is indebted to cash in Â£7,100â€”the entry, "To balance of your account in office cash, per pass-book, now debited to this account on your Mr. Smithers' instructions,"would not convey to anybody that the directors of the bank had authorised that to be treated as a loan to himâ€”I was nearly nineteen years in the River Plate before I came to this bankâ€”I have been in the employment of this bank from the beginning, and no imputation was made on me directly or indirectlyâ€”about January or February, 1890, two of the directors, Messrs. Moses and Cator, asked me to fetch up the office-book current at that time, and the one previous to it (produced); they show an accurate record of every penny paid to Smithers ("A. E. S. ")â€”Mr. Cator said, "Does Mr. Smithers keep a running account with the office cash?"â€”I answered, 'It cannot exactly be called a current or running account"â€”that although he took considerable sums from the office cash now and again, he had always repaid them up to that time by cheques either on the Westminster Bank or Brown, Janson; then Mr. Moses asked me if I could formulate some scheme by which this could be stopped or done in way withâ€”I said, "Yes; by opening another account at Glyn, Mills, (Currie, and Co. 's bank, under the head of 'Accountants' drawing account,'"cheques against which would only be signed by the secretary and accountant; and this new account would be audited by the board weekly, and in the same manner that the clean cash-book was done weeklyâ€”the main cash-bookâ€”from that date to this I have heard no

more about it, though I know Mr. Moses had a talk with the secretary about it alsoâ€”they did not give me any instructions not to make further advances, and the same system continuedâ€”Mr. Geddes made another suggestion, in the shape of a daily auditâ€”from the beginning to the end of this matter, aÂ«i far as Smithers was concerned, there was nothing that he told me to do, or not to do, that in any way suggested to me that he was trying to conceal something that he supposed to be fraudulent.

Re-examined. I signed the Â£2,500 cheque "pro secretary"; Smithers asked me to fill up the slip, and I did soâ€”Â£1,000 was the usual amount for office cashâ€”Reed would be told to draw the cheque, perhaps by myself, acting on Smithers' ordersâ€”certainly not Withoutâ€”it must be signed by two directorsâ€”he must have told me what he wanted it for afterwards, or it would not have been paid into the London and Westminster Bankâ€”the plan of specifying the amounts on the counterfoil is only about eighteen months or two years oldâ€”Smithers came down from the board-room one day and said, "The gentlemen upstairs are not pleased with the sums for office cash being so large; you had better tell those who draw the cheques to put the amounts on the counterfoils to show what the amounts are being drawn for"â€”that was before the bank failed, and after Smithers came home from America in 1890â€”when the auditors came in the beginning of October I put before them the books I thought they required; the cash-book, clean cash-book, all the vouchers belonging to the cash-book, journal, and ledgerâ€”they never asked for the counterfoils of the chequesâ€”they could have seen them, but they would not have shown the payments to Smithers, nor would the dean cash-bookâ€”the journal mightâ€”the pass-books (produced) show them better, and the office cash-book wouldâ€”they never asked for itâ€”the private account-book of Smithers was kept in a drawer, of which I had one key and Bell the otherâ€”the particulars of the counterfoils must have been got by Reed or Bell from the office cash-bookâ€”I have since learnt that some of those amounts had been long ago paid.
By the COURT. I did not think it my duty to complain to the directors about the chief director.

DANIEL LOFTON BELL . I am a clerk in the English Bank of the River Plateâ€”I was cashier there from November, 1888, till the bank suspended paymentâ€”this slip of instruction to carry the balance of Â£7,697 to Mr. Smithers' loan account is in. my handwriting; I wrote that by the direction of the accountant, Mr. Wrightâ€”this counterfoil of the cheque for Â£2,500, of 27th November, 1890, was at the time I was cashier; on the same date a cheque for Â£938 10s. 9d. was drawn for office cashâ€”on the counterfoil there appears a list of payments which that cheque purports to be made to meetâ€”I did not give instructions to Mr. Reed to put that list on the counterfoil; I did not see Mr. Smithers with regard to that matterâ€”I saw Mr. Wright, the accountant.

Cross-examined. I acted as cashier for some time, I think at the end of November, 1888, or more particularly as acting-cashierâ€”I paid some of the moneys at that period on Mr. Smithers' account out of office cashâ€”I had no idea that I was doing anything dishonest or wrong in the matter; I was only obeying instructionsâ€”I did not conceal the matterâ€”I entered the transactions in the office cash-bookâ€”I always understood that the moneys so advanced were each year made up by Mr. Smithers' payments; but I had no positive knowledgeâ€”I was cashier from

August, 1889, to February, 1890, when Mr. Smithers was abroad, except when I was occasionally absent from the officeâ€”while he was abroad I made payments on his account, under the accountant's, Mr. Wright's, instructions.

By the JURY. I was cognisant of the fact that these entries were omitted from the journal, and that the balance in the ledger did not agree with the office cash-book; it certainly struck me as peculiar, from the point of view of correct book-keeping.

GERALD VANDELINE I am a chartered accountant, of 12, Laurence Pountney Lane, Cannon Street, and one of the joint auditors of this bankâ€”the audit of 30th September, 1890, was under my personal supervisionâ€”on no occasion had I before me the office cash-book, I did not know of its existence, I had not before me the books called "The private account-books,"I have never seen them except in Court here, I did not know of their existenceâ€”Mr. Wright produced the books at the auditâ€”there was no entry in the books that were produced to me, showing that Mr. Smithers was making use of the office book of the bank.

Cross-examined. In the articles of association it is the duty of the bank to give the auditor a full list of the books of the bankâ€”I did not get a list of the booksâ€”it was the duty of the company to do that, it is not the duty of the auditor to ask for it; I asked for what books I wanted, and got themâ€”I got the general cash-book (it was handed to the witness); this is quite right, here are audit ticks upon itâ€”this is the cash-book, they called it "The clean cash-book"â€”this is the official cash-bookâ€”I don't recognise the word clean or fair cash-book, that word was only used yesterday in my hearing for the first time; when I asked for the cashbook they gave it me; it gives me the idea of being the official cashbook of the bank, and I can prove it, because the postings into the ledger are made from this bookâ€”the inspection of the book does not show me that it is nothing but a copy of some other booksâ€”a comparison between the ledger and the office cash-book showed the difference between the cash in hand in the one book and the actual amount of cash in the otherâ€”this is my certificate I signed to that audit.

Re-examined. The cash-book, journal, and ledger were produced, and the cancelled cheques were produced as vouchers, but not the counterfoilsâ€”I had no reason to suppose that there were other books in existenceâ€”these books were admirably kept, and perfect in themselvesâ€”from none of them could I ascertain the deficiency in question.

By the JURY. I did not see any entries in this clean cash-book of payments made to Smithers; there might be payments made to Smithers, but if so they would be passed to his ordinary account in the ledgerâ€”none of those figures appear in the clean cash-book.

WILLIAM ROGERS . I have been a director of the English Bank of the River Plate since its formationâ€”I occasionally signed cheques for office cashâ€”I see that I have initialed the counterfoil of this cheque of 27th November, 1890â€”at the time I signed this cheque I believed that these amounts were required for the purpose of replenishing the tillâ€”I did not know that cheques had been previously drawn for the same purpose.
By the COURT. I did not know that any portion of this cheque was going to be paid into the private account of the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Mr. Smithers has always borne a high character for integrity.
Re-examined. I had entire confidence in him.

MOSES HENRY MOSES . I have been a director of this bank from its commencementâ€”I was not aware at any time that Mr. Smithers was taking money out of the office cashâ€”I took a part in the loan of 5th of December, 1890, of Â£12,700, made to Mr. Smithersâ€”it was a liability which he said became due within one or two days, and he was quite unable to meet it, and the board was unanimously of opinion that it was necessary, in the interests of the bank, that the money should be advanced to Mr. Smithers, he giving such security as he could findâ€”he found a life policy, or several life policies, a charge upon the shares he held in the bank, and a second mortgage on two housesâ€”those securities were brought to us by Mr. Smithers and put by me in my own pocket and sealed by me with my own private seal, and then they were put in the bank treasuryâ€”the securities were not officially valued at the timeâ€”I was quite unable to form any estimateâ€”they were entered in the security book as a packet of securities, not in detailâ€”I am not sure how many shares Smithers held in the bank, X think between 260 and 300; they were Â£20 shares, Â£10 paidâ€”the security on the shares was a blank transferâ€”I imagine the value of the shares at that time was as Â£ 17 for the Â£10 paidâ€”I do not remember sending for Mr. Wright some time in 1890 and asking to see him with respect to the office cashâ€”I remember Mr. Cator doing soâ€”he spoke to me about itâ€”I was in the board-room when he asked to see Mr. Wrightâ€”I can't say that I was in the room the whole time of the conversationâ€”I was present part of the time and heard part of the conversation. (MR. JUSTICE CAVE interposed, and this was not pursued)â€”I did not on that day or at any other time examine this office cash-bookâ€”I have never heard of the existence of the private account-book.

Cross-examined. I had a high opinion of Mr. Smithers, in common with my co-directorsâ€”he has always borne a character for high integrityâ€”as far as I and my co-directors are concerned we have been no parties to this prosecutionâ€”I believe it has been a matter resting with the Official Assigneeâ€”I have certainly had nothing to do with itâ€”the revolution in Argentina took place previous to July, 1890, and in November that same year the well-known house of Barings stopped paymentâ€”that was a very great shock to public creditâ€”many persons who had property which in ordinary times would be saleable, found themselves for the time being with property which could not command a marketâ€”it was universally feltâ€”it was at that crisis that the last loan to Smithers was madeâ€”our shares stood at a large premium, the Â£10 paid shares were worth Â£ 17â€”Smithers' 280 shares would be worth Â£4,760â€”I am not aware that the policies have been valued at Â£2,500â€”I am not able to say what the value of the houses was.

By the COURT. Q. When the loan of Â£12,700 was made, do we understand you to say that for all you knew it was entirely covered by the securities?â€”A. No; on the contrary, we hardly thought that the securities would cover the loanâ€”I could not form any idea of what they were; it depended on the value of the house propertyâ€”we were afraid they would not cover the loan; we inquired of the prisoner if he had any other securityâ€”he said he had nothing better to offerâ€”I had no idea that at that time he had withdrawn about Â£8,000 from the office cash.
By the JURY. There is no private audit by the directors in addition

to the public audit; it was the custom of the directors on duty once a week to examine the banker's pass-book with the cheque-bookâ€”we never looked to see that the lodger agreed with the cash-bookâ€”I have seen it lying on the desk, but never looked at it.

CHARLES ALEXANDER CATOR . I was one of the directors of this bankâ€”I am in commercial life at 39, Lombard Streetâ€”I attended at the bank as a director from time to timeâ€”I never heard that Mr. Smithers was using the moneys of the bank till a fortnight after the suspensionâ€”on one occasion I became aware that a particular sum of money had been received by Mr. Smithersâ€”I believe it was in January, 1888, I was a director in attendance, and chairman at the time; it was while Smithers was away; he came back about the middle of the month, but did not attend till the last board meeting of the month, the last Friday in Januaryâ€”I had a conversation with Mr. Moses about the cash; it was a subject that had frequently engaged the attention of the directors, and I am sure none of us liked the amount of cash in the till, because it was a certain amount of temptation in the way of the clerks, and I spoke to Mr. Moses about it, and we agreed to have Mr. Wright up to the boardroom, and I spoke to Mr. Wrightâ€”after that time I said there should be entered on the counterfoils of the cheques drawn for office cash, in many cases, the particulars of the sums drawn for, and from about that time that practice was followedâ€”I heard a statement made by Wright of a conversation alleged to have taken place as to current account, and so onâ€”that statement is distinctly not correct, in my opinion, to the best of my recollection of what took placeâ€”the Â£2,600 for office cash was a very exceptional amountâ€”if a cheque came before me of an amount I thought unusual. I should ask the manager for an explanation; that would be the ordinary course I should pursue; if it had the amounts on the counterfoil I should accept it without any hesitation.

Cross-examined. This office cash-book was one of the books of the bank; I have seen itâ€”before the return of Mr. Smithers I had this book up in the board-room, and examined it in the presence of Mr. Moses and Mr. Wrightâ€”I could not tell you the dateâ€”it would be some time in January; not the first of the month, but later, in the middle of the monthâ€”I can't say that I turned over the pages; when I say it was examined, it was not very carefullyâ€”I have not the slightest recollection of these two entries succeeding each other, of 15th January: "A. E. S., pass-book, Â£279 14s. 4d., and A. E. S., Â£47 9s. 7d. "; that is as far as I can go, upon a matter of memory, two years agoâ€”I do not recollect asking Mr. Wright whether Mr. Smithers had a running account at the bank, and his suggesting how Mr. Smithers' cash transactions with the bank might be more easily checked by a separate account being paid to Glyn, Mills; that is distinctly untrue; that proposal came from Mr. Moses, not from Mr. Wrightâ€”I have not a doubt that Mr. Moses made that suggestion without the smallest reference to Mr. Smithers' accountâ€”we had an account at Glyn, Millsâ€”one of us thought that this cash was a temptation to the clerks, and so thought the system ought to be altered, and that was the whole object of that interview; there was no thought of Mr. Smithers' or any particular account in our mindâ€”I had the cash up before me on that occasion; there was about Â£6,000 or Â£7,000; I did not have the coin up, but I absolutely had the cash there, and as far as I recollect there was Â£6,000

or Â£7,000; we wanted that altered; that was the whole subject of our conversationâ€”I had up this book; I did not have the ledger before meâ€”if I had compared the office cash-book with the ledger, I should have seen the discrepancy that existed; they could not have agreedâ€”this book contains the original record of each payment made as far as I recollect; I have hardly seen that book; the entries are made in abbreviationâ€”"A. E. S.,"Mr. Smithersâ€”I did not see the pass-bookâ€”these entries were made at the time Mr. Smithers was absent.

Re-examined. I had up the office each-book and examined itâ€”I did not find that the amount there corresponded with the amount in the rough cash-bookâ€”my recollection of that book is that it was not balanced every dayâ€”I took Mr. Wright's account, and it was perfectly correct with his statement; it consisted entirely of entries, that there was nothing wrong in any shape or descriptionâ€”I had no idea at that time that the ledger account was being made up in a way which did not correspond with this office cash-book.

By the JURY. Mr. Wright was responsible for the proper bookkeepingâ€”I do not know at all who gave instructions for the omission of these entries; Wright would be responsible for the proper dealing with all the entries in the office cash-book, and that would be put before the directors on the requisition of the accountant and manager, and we should look to them to see that it was right.

WILLIAM BLAIR ANDERSON . I am paying cashier of the London and Westminster Bank, Lothburyâ€”Mr. Smithers kept his private banking account thereâ€”I produce a copy of his accountâ€”on 27th November, 1890, his credit-balance was Â£362 14s. 10dâ€”on that same day Â£2,500 was paid in to his credit, and drawn out by a cheque to selfâ€”on 13th May, 1891, his credit-balance was Â£40 2s. 7d. prior to paying in Â£950; and on that same day Â£950 was paid out by a cheque to Mr. Hodsonâ€”on 16th July, 1891, his credit-balance was Â£209 4s. 7d.â€”by the 17th July it was reduced to Â£169 4s. 7d., which stood to his credit on that date.

Cross-examined. I do not know that he had an account with Brown, Janson, and Co.â€”his balance for the first half-year in 1890 was Â£6,055 10s. 5d.; for the latter half-year it was Â£23,430 6s. 1d.â€”in 1891, for the first half-year, it was Â£4,154 19s. 8d.; the account stopped on 15th October.
Re-examined. The Â£23,430 includes the Â£12,767, the loan of 5th December; on 5th December it was Â£2,500; on 12th December, Â£400; on 9th October, Â£1,000, and on 10th October, Â£200.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was read as follows: "I was. one of the founders of the bank, and became managing director shortly afterwards. For convenience sake payments were made by Mr. Wright for me out of office cash. From time to time I made payments to Mr. Wright, balancing the accounts at the end of the year, and from the year 1881 to the year 1888 such payments were made for me, and were repaid partly during each year, and balanced at the end of the financial year. In 1888 I lodged with Mr. Wright the deeds of my freehold house and stabling at Brighton, which at that time were valued at Â£5,000, and I told Mr. Wright to take care of them, as they were valuable, and would be a protection to the bank for moneys I might be owing through his payments. In 1889 the payments were made as usual,

and in August, before I went to Buenos Ayres, I repaid the whole of the moneys then due, Â£9,000. During my absence, as usual, payments were made for me by Mr. Wright, and in July, 1890, I was expecting to be sent to me, through the foreign branch at Buenos Ayres, a sum of Â£7,000. Instead, however, of Â£-7,000 arriving, on account of the high premium payable on gold I only received Â£4,000; and that amount was paid to my account, and the balance expected from Buenos Ayres was placed in suspense, and debited to me in "Branches' floating entries account. "In 1890 the payments were continued as usual, and they now form subjects of the present charge against me. This sum would have been repaid by me but for the financial crisis in Argentina, by which I, equally with others interested in Argentine securities, suffered enormous losses. But for this crisis I was in a position to have repaid such advances, irrespective of the security of the freehold houses, the deeds of which I had placed with Mr. Wright as security for the bank. I emphatically deny that I allowed these payments to be made for me with any fraudulent intention. My present position arises from misfortunes over which I had no control. During my management the bank for years past made gross profits of upwards of Â£100,000 per annum, and was a flourishing institution, but was compelled to stop through non-receipt of the requisite remittances from the River Plate, owing to the crisis in Argentine finance, which latter likewise occasioned my own difficultiesâ€”Signed,
E. A. SMITHERS. " Several witnesses deposed to the prisoner's high character.

GUILTY.â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the JURY
on account of his high character and the laxity on the part of his directors, which enabled him to continue the practice of employing the moneys of the bank in such a manner for so many years. â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

208.
JOHN RALPH BLACKWELL (25) and
FRANK ACLAND (25)
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£435, with intent to defraud.

p.rs: PLEADED GUILTY to the uttering, and MR. ABINGER, for the prosecution, offered no evidence against him for the forgery. NOT GUILTY.

div1.p: JOSEPH THOMPSON . I am a turf-accountant; on the 23rd, the hall-porter at the Victoria Club spoke to me, and I went into the hall and saw the prisoner Aclandâ€”he handed me a letter, with this cheque enclosedâ€”I got into a cab and drove with him, and in consequence of what he said on the way I gave him into custody. (The letter stated: "Dear Sir,â€”Will you oblige me by cashing the enclosed cheque and handing proceeds to bearerâ€”SHAFTESBUEY.")

ALFRED MA LONE Y . I am clerk at the National Bank, Charing Cross branchâ€”we have no customer named Algernon Bathurstâ€”this cheque was supplied to Mr. Reginald Brewer on April 7, 1889; his account was closed in September, 1890.

REGINALD BREWER . I am managing clerk to a turf commission agentâ€”I had formerly an account at the Charing Cross branch of the National Bank; it was closed rather more than a year agoâ€”this cheque came out
of my bookâ€”there was a receiving order against me, and the cheque-book was either sold in the drawers or in one of my pockets.

ASHLEY, EARL OF SHAFTESBURY . I am a member of the Bachelors' Club; this letter is not in my writing, neither is the endorsement to this cheque; I do not know the drawerâ€”I know Mr. Thompsonâ€”I do not know Aclandâ€”this letter is on the club paper.

TROUD (Police Inspector). I was in the Old Bell when Blackwell came inâ€”he came to me in the bar and said, "Mr. Stroud, there are rumours going about the West-end that I am wanted; what is the matter?"â€”I said, "Yes, there is something the matter; I want you for being concerned with Acland for getting a Large sum from Mr. Thompson, a bookmaker"â€”he said, "I had nothing to do with the job"â€”I took him to Bow Street, and heard Gregory read the statement to himâ€”he said, "I am not concerned in it to the extent of that statement"; he made a further statement; I cautioned him, he made no reply.
Cross-examined. Gregory is one of my officers; he brought me a message from the prisoner, in consequence of which I went to the public-house; I think he intended to give himself up.

FRANK ACLAND (the Prisoner). I know the prisoner Blackwell as Jack Russellâ€”I met him in Piccadilly Circus about a fortnight before I went to the Victoria Club; he said he should be wanting me, and he took me down and introduced me to Flash Fred, who forged the chequesâ€”I went home with him that nightâ€”I subsequently met him at the Buttercupâ€”I went to Belgrave Square to get Lord Shaftesbury's addressâ€”Fred told me to go thereâ€”Jack was thereâ€”a cheque was written out, and they were going to send it to Lord Shaftesbury's tailorâ€”I went there, and found that his lordship was out of town, and went back and told them both; they were waiting for me; I told them that the family was out of town, and they agreed to let the matter dropâ€”I next saw Blackwell ten days or a fortnight afterwards, with Fred, outside Piccadilly Restaurant; they said they wanted me to take a cheque in to-morrowâ€”Blackwell was there, but Fred said it allâ€”on the Monday I met Fred and Jack by appointment, at 23, Albert Street, and Blackwell gave me the blank cheque and a draft, and I copied itâ€”Jack had then gone out to buy a clean shirt and collar, and he bought me this waistcoat and shirt at a shop in Brompton Road, and brought them in, and I dressed at Fred's, Jack being thereâ€”I do hot know who wrote this letter; it was not written in my presenceâ€”Jack and I came out of the house and hailed a cab, five minutes' walk off, in Sloane Streetâ€”Jack told the cabman where to go, and got out at Piccadilly Circus, and went to a restaurantâ€”he came back and we went to Covent Gardenâ€”he said he would wait for me outside, and I was to bring the money to him; and if I missed him I was to meet him at the Buttercupâ€”it was understood that I was to receive a second share, I suppose; it was not discussed at all, but there were three of us in it, and we were to have our shares.

Cross-examined. I gave information to the Police-officer; I was committed for trialâ€”mine is the hand that wrote out the chequeâ€”I did not get the note-paperâ€”I have been in trouble once before for uttering a chequeâ€”I did not write it; it was not a forgery, because there was

nobody of that nameâ€”I got four monthsâ€”someone was mixed up with me in it; I do not suggest Blackwellâ€”I have been in the Buttercup public-house twiceâ€”the house I went to with Blackwell was the St. James's tavernâ€”this new waistcoat is the one Blackwell gave meâ€”I was not with him when he bought it.
CHARLES BODE . On 23rd November I took a fare from Victoria Club, Wellington Street, and drove two menâ€”I afterwards picked out one of them at Bow Streetâ€”Blackwell is the man.

Cross-examined. It was three weeks afterwards before I picked him outâ€”the man I drove was young, with a slight moustache, a little above the medium height; two or three of the other men had a slight moustacheâ€”I did not see any with grey whiskers or beardsâ€”they were standing in a rowâ€”I only went in onceâ€”the inspector asked me to go inâ€”he did not tell me he believed the guilty man was thereâ€”I did not come up three times; I turned back onceâ€”I identified him, but he was dressed differentlyâ€”I walked up and down the lineâ€”the inspector said, "Go and put your hand on the man you know"â€”that was the only hesitation I had.

Re-examined. The cab was hailed at 12.45; it was stopped at Piccadilly Circus, and the prisoner got out, and came back in five or ten minutes and said, "Now to Victoria"â€”that was the Victoria Club, Wellington Streetâ€”we stopped at the corner of Southampton Street, and the prisoner got out and left the other manâ€”that was opposite the Covent Garden Hotel.

GETTING (Police Sergeant). I was at the station when Bode walked along the line of eight or nine menâ€”the inspector said, "Do you see anyone?"he said, "That is the man," and put his hand on Russell's shoulderâ€”I read the statement to Russell.

Cross-examined. I wrote it down and Acland signed it; it was all written at the same timeâ€”I took two statementsâ€”they were not read over to Blackwell; I had not got it in my possession at the Police-court. (The statement was here put in and read.)â€”I was at the Police-court and heard Horace Myers called for the prosecutionâ€”the cabman may have been at the station more than five or six minutes before he was called into the roomâ€”we fetched some of the people in from the gallery of the Police court, and some from a public-house; none of them were policemen off dutyâ€”some of them had a slight moustache, and some a heavy oneâ€”I cannot say whether any of them were workpeople, they were all dressed respectablyâ€”this man was brought up from the cells and told to place himself where he likedâ€”his height is about 5 feet 9 inches.
By the COURT. We looked out for men who resembled Blackwell.
Re-examined. Blackwell was not conspicuous by his height, and there was no one with a grey beard.
HORACE MYERS . I am a clothierâ€”I sold the waistcoat which Acland is wearing, to two menâ€”I had other customers in the shop, and was dressing the window, and did not criticise them.
Cross-examined. I said at Bow Street, "I did not sell the vest to the prisoner, I am certain of that; it was a delicate-looking man I sold it to"; that is true.

BLACKWELL
GUILTY**.

â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerkenwell on December 19th, 1887.â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: to a conviction of felony at this Court on

div1.p:
June 27th, 1887. Recommended to mercy by the Prosecution.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

209.
MARIE TICKERIDGE and
RICHARD BENNETT
, Unlawfully endeavouring to conceal the birth of a child of Marie Tickeridge.

GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the JURY.â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour each.

210.
FRANK JONES (20) and
ROSE JONES (19)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Frederick Williams, with intent to steal, to which

FRANK JONES
PLEADED GUILTY â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.
MR. BLACKWELL Prosecuted, and MR. F. GRIFFITHS Defended Hose Jones. CHARLES F. WILLIAMS. I keep a coffee-shop at 43, Chandos Streetâ€”about 1.30 a.m. on 24th December I was aroused by a constable, and went down and found two constables there and the two prisoners in the passageâ€”the female prisoner had lived with me as a waitress for about two months, and had left about a monthâ€”while she was there the key of the shop was lost; this is it (produced)â€”when I went to bed the door was latched but not bolted.

Cross-examined. This was one of two keys; it is not the key nowâ€”when she came she told me where she had been living, and I knew that it was a very respectable placeâ€”she was a very good waitressâ€”she stayed away all night and I told her if she did that again she would have to leave, but I did not give her notice; she told me her mother was very ill, and she would not do it againâ€”I did not send her away for any bad conduct; she left some clothes with meâ€”I always leave the door on the latch, as I have lodgersâ€”I keep my money in my bedroomâ€”a man called about 12.45 on that night and wanted a bed, but I was fullâ€”I left the door on the latch; it never fails to catch.
Re-examined. When the man came I did not go to the door; I looked out at the windowâ€”the female prisoner had taken her clothes away before the night of the burglary.

GEORGE MOEL (496 E). On 24th December, about 1.20 a.m., I was on duty in Chandos Street, and tried certain doorsâ€”I went to No. 43, pushed it open, and found the prisoners inside; I asked them what they were doing there; the female prisoner said, "It is all right, he has come to see me; don't make a noise"â€”he said, "lama burglar; take me to the station; I have done nothing"â€”I called a constable, and took them to the stationâ€”I found on Frank Jones this stick, a pair of pincers, a razor, a box of matches and two keys, one of which the prosecutor"identifiesâ€”on Rose I found this quantity of string.
Cross-examined. She had one end of the string, and he the otherâ€”I try all doors; I tried this door a quarter of an hour before, and it was shut. Police Sergeant 4. (Not examined in chief.)

Cross-examined. Rose Jones was charged with burglary before Christmas, and I went to Aldgate and found, from the wife of the superintendent, that the two prisoners had one room there, and lived there as man and wife; but there was no one thereâ€”Christmas intervened, and when I went again the place was shut up.

REV. WILLIAM HARVEY SMITH . I live at Rose Cottage, Stamford Hill, and am President of the General Baptist Assemblyâ€”I have known Bose Jones since she was eleven years old, as a Sunday and Bible-class scholar, and for about three years as a communicant, and have never heard a word against her characterâ€”she left the neighbourhood about six weeks ago, and the understanding was that she had gone away to be marriedâ€”I know that the banns were published, but further than that I cannot goâ€”I have seen Frank Jones in my chapel, but know nothing of him.
Cross-examined. The banns were put up at DUD mow, in Essex, some time in Septemberâ€”I have not seen her since, and don't know whether, the ceremony was ever gone through.

ROSE JONESâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

211.
HENRY ALBERT RAVEN
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£6, with intent to defraud.

ARTHUR TALBOT SMITH . I am a member of the Bar, but not in practiceâ€”I live at Hampton Cottage, Sunburyâ€”the prisoner came into my service as page boy in Julyâ€”I request my servants to give their names and addresses, and the prisoner went out of the room and brought back this paper (produced) just writtenâ€”he remained with me till Octoberâ€”about October 1st I was coming up to London, and did not require his servicesâ€”I bank at the London and Westminster Bankâ€”I kept my cheque-book in a drawer of a writing-table in the dining-room, which was almost always lockedâ€”the key was on my watch-chain, on my dressing-tableâ€”he had access to that room and to the keys in the morningâ€”I draw cheques for wages every week, and he has got cheques cashed for meâ€”they were often changed at Mr. Trotter's, the fishmongerâ€”after the prisoner left my service I got my bank-book and found three forgeriesâ€”no part of these three cheques (produced) is written by me or by my ordersâ€”I examined my cheque-book, and found cheques 75, 76, 91, and 92 had been torn outâ€”I do not think the signatures are good imitations of mineâ€”here are three signatures of the prisoner, in this servants' wages-book, and I have no doubt that the signatures to these cheques are the prisoner'sâ€”this "5"in "September 5," and the "g"in "wages" and the "g"in "bridge,"in the address, are exactly the same; and the "H "in "House," and the "H"in "H. Raven,"his own signature.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. You used to come into my room and take my clothes' out and brush themâ€”I never heard you take the keys.

ERNEST WILLIAM TROTTER . I am postmaster at Sunburyâ€”I cashed these two cheques of 5th and 12th December, for some person whom I do not remember, and paid them into my bankâ€”I was in the habit of cashing small cheques for wages for Mr. Smithâ€”they were sometimes brought by the prisoner, sometimes by other servants and messengers.

WILLIAM DUNN . I am a clerk in the London and Westminster Bank, Westminster branchâ€”Mr. Arthur Talbot Smith is a customer of oursâ€”thee three cheques were paid by the bank and passed through the-Clearing-house,
and Mr. Smith was debited with themâ€”they all three came through Messrs. Glyn.

HARRY MORGAN (Detective F). On 8th December, from information I received, I went to Lily Road, Fulham, and found the prisonerâ€”I said, I am Inspector Morgan. You are charged with stealing three blank cheques, filling them in, and uttering them"â€”he said, "No"â€”I took him to the station, showed him the three cheques, and said, "Mr. Smith says they are in your writing"â€”he said, "No, sir."

â€”
NOT GUILTY .

212.
HENRY ALBERT RAVEN
was again charged upon two other indictments with forging and uttering cheques for Â£3 and Â£6, with intent to defraud.â€” No evidence was offered.

â€”
NOT GUILTY .

213.
WILLIAM GEMPESTEIN
, for the wilful murder of
Frederick Charles Swain.
JOHN TRIM (112 K) produced and proved a plan of the place in which this occurrence took place.

CHRISTOPHER TAYLOR . I am a fireman on board the steamship John Brightâ€”I am now staying at 412, Penny Fieldsâ€”on 8th December last our vessel was lying in the Inner Mill wall Dockâ€”on that night I was in company with three firemen, named Frederick Charles Swain, John Cooper, and John Bahrs, who is also called Johnsonâ€”we were all employed on the John Brightâ€”that same night there was lying in the dock a German vessel, called the Liebensteinâ€”that night I and Swain, Cooper, and Bahrs went to the George public-house, and off and on we remained there till closing-timeâ€”we were in the public-barâ€”I heard some German singing going on in another part of the houseâ€”at closing time we left, and walked in the direction of the docks, down the Glengal Road; we walked on the right-hand side, two and two, I and Cooper first, Bahrs and Swain following two or three yards behindâ€”as we were walking down, the prisoner struck Cooper; two other men were with the prisoner; I now know they were Krause and Striblowâ€”they came together off the road to usâ€”they were saying something in German which I could not understandâ€”Cooper was knocked downâ€”the Germans went away towards the dock, hardly at a walkâ€”Cooper got up and we walked on togetherâ€”when we got near the policeman's box and the dock gates we saw the Germans standing up there, waiting about; the three came up together, and they struck Cooper again; I don't know who struck him the second time; he got knocked down again, and when on the ground Krause kicked himâ€”I went into the prisoner like to stop him, to push him awayâ€”I made a rush at him to charge him for knocking Cooper aboutâ€”I got a few blows at a doorway, and he got the same from meâ€”I saw something bright in his hand, and I felt a cut in my left hand; it was bleedingâ€”I saw that after it was finishedâ€”Swain and Bahrs were coming up to us when they saw the men getting on to us, and the prisoner then left me and went off for themâ€”he was the only

person there thenâ€”he was the only man I was strikingâ€”I don't remember where Krause and Striblow were; they had not gone away, they were all close by, but in what position I can't tellâ€”the prisoner went up to Swain, and I heard Swain call out, "I am stabbed"â€”the prisoner then made a rush to pick up his cap; he stooped down to pick something up, and then ran awayâ€”at the time the prisoner went towards Swain, Bahrs was near himâ€”I did not hear him call out; I did not see anything happen to him; he was still standing up, and Swain alsoâ€”I did not see either of them fallâ€”the prisoner ran over the bridge right past the policeman's box; they all ran togetherâ€”the policeman at the dock gates pursued them, and within a short time he brought the prisoner back, and he was taken to the stationâ€”Swain was then lying on the ground; I could not say when he fellâ€”he was not speaking or making any sign of being aliveâ€”Bahrs was in the police-box lying down; I did not see him fallâ€”I remained on the same spot all the timeâ€”Bahrs was calling out as if he had been hurtâ€”then I and Cooper, the prisoners, and some policemen all went to the station togetherâ€”I think there were three policemen there thenâ€”the prisoners were charged at the stationâ€”I don't remember whether they made any answerâ€”I afterwards saw the dead body of Swain in the mortuary.

Cross-examined. Our ship had come into dock about seven that nightâ€”this was our first night ashoreâ€”we had come from the Persian Gulfâ€”we went into the George about half-past nineâ€”some of us went out to get shaved, and then went back, and left about closing timeâ€”we were in the public barâ€”no word passed between the Germans and us thereâ€”we came out first, and the Germans followed; there were four English and three Germansâ€”I did not see Striblow do anythingâ€”Krause kicked Cooper and then went away from usâ€”I don't know where he wentâ€”when Cooper was knocked down I don't know whether he said anything; I caught hold of him to prevent him making a noise, to prevent him following the Germans and fighting with themâ€”I saw two dock constables where the Germans were, Howard and Smithâ€”I and Cooper waited till Swain and Bahrs came upâ€”I don't remember one of us saying, "There are the three men; they have been getting on us, let us fight them"; I never said soâ€”I did not hear the words, "There are those cursed Germans, let us have a row with them"â€”the Germans did not retreat across the bridge and we follow themâ€”all I did from first to last was to give the prisoner some blows.

Re-examined. I did not see Striblow do anything; I saw nothing in his handâ€”when Krause went away I was closed with the prisoner; it was then I saw something bright in his hand, and after that I saw the cut.

JOHN COOPER . I am twenty-one years of ageâ€”I was a fireman on board the John Bright, lying in Millwall Dockâ€”we went to the George, and left at closing-time, and came up the Glengal Road; Taylor was with me; Swain and Bahrs were just behind usâ€”as we were walking down the road the prisoner came up and knocked me down; Krause and Striblow were with himâ€”he did not say anything; he ran away, and the other two with him, up Glengal Road, towards the dockâ€”I got up and went on in the same direction with Taylorâ€”a few yards from the dock gates the Germans came back and met us, and the prisoner knocked me
down againâ€”Krause and Striblow were with him; I was knocked down and Krause kicked me, and I saw nothing more.

Cross-examined. All through this affair Striblow did nothing that I sawâ€”I felt injured the first timeâ€”I did not try to run after the men or to fight themâ€”Taylor did not catch hold of my arm to prevent my doing soâ€”he said, "Don't make a noise," and I did notâ€”I did not hear any of my companions say, "There are the Germans, let us fight them"â€”I did not make a rush at the prisoner.

JOHN BAHRS . I live at 38, Penny Fieldsâ€”I am not now an inmate of Poplar Hospitalâ€”I was a fireman on the John Brightâ€”I am an Austrian by birth; I am known as Johnson on board the shipâ€”on this night I remember leaving the George about closing-timeâ€”Cooper and Taylor talked down the Glengal Road in front of me and Swain; we were a few yards behindâ€”as we went along the prisoner Krause and Striblow came behind usâ€”I and Swain got on the side to let them pass, and Cooper was shoved down; I did not see who did it; they were walking arm-in-armâ€”Swain said, "You should not do that, we are walking along quietly here, and do not trouble anybody"â€”they made no answerâ€”they walked on ahead of us, in the direction of the dock gatesâ€”after we had walked some yards farther I met a man named Ball, whom I knew, and I stopped and spoke to him, Swain stopped with me; Cooper and Taylor were walking slowly ahead of usâ€”I remained talking to Ball about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, and then I and Swain went on in the direction of the dock gates; the other two had got a good way ahead of us; when we got up-to the outer gates Cooper and Taylor were fighting with the prisoner Krause and Striblow; they were fighting with their hands, all five of themâ€”I and Swain were walking up to themâ€”the other two were walking on the other side of the roadâ€”the prisoner was standing between me and Swainâ€”I heard Swain call out, "I am stabbed"â€”the prisoner said to me in German, "What is it that you want? there you are"â€”afterwards I felt that I was stabbedâ€”I saw the blood running out of my left armâ€”one of them, Krause or Striblow, came up to me and tried to strike me, and I pushed him back in the mud; that was before I felt myself stabbedâ€”at that time one was on the other side of the road, and the other was about in the middle; neither of them was near enough to have stabbed meâ€”they came up to me and tried to strike me, and I pushed them back, not both, one of them: I could not say whichâ€”I did not call out; I went over to Swain and asked him if he was stabbedâ€”after I was stabbed the prisoner ran awayâ€”he raised his hand to his mates and ran right after the police-box, in the direction of the bridge; I did not see him after thatâ€”Krause and Striblow ran in the same directionâ€”Swain was then lying on the ground; I did not see., him fall; he could not speak, he was groaningâ€”I became unconscious, and don't know what happened till I found myself in the hospital.

Cross-examined. As we went along one of the Germans gave Cooper a shove sidewaysâ€”I did not see whether they struck him a blow or notâ€”the Germans were walking arm-in-armâ€”I don't know the width of the pavement there; I did not notice that there was a pavementâ€”after Cooper was knocked down the Germans still went on arm-in-arm.

GEORGE BALL . I am a ship's fireman, living at 116, Brunswick Street, Poplarâ€”on the early morning of 9th December I was in the Glengal Road, and saw three men loitering about on the George side of the bridge

â€”I went on and met four men, one of whom, Bahrs, I knewâ€”I talked to him for about ten minutes; another young man stopped with us, and the other two men went on aheadâ€”the two men I was talking to seemed to be soberâ€”I did not notice anything after I left Bahrs.

GEORGE HOWARD (Millwall Docks Constable 31). At half-past twelve on the early morning of 9th December I was at the dock gates, and I heard some quarrelling going on between some German and English sailors near the bottom of the Glengal Road, near the George public-houseâ€”after the quarrel three of the Germans came up the road and passed by the gate going towards the bridge; in a few minutes they returned and met the Englishmen at the gateâ€”the four Englishmen came up to the gate nearly together, there may have been a few yards dividing themâ€”when the Germans and Englishmen met they renewed the quarrel again, with words and blows, and it did not last a minute before the man called out he was stabbedâ€”I did not see any blows dealt; not thinking anything was going to occur I was not looking; I had two gates to attend to, and I cannot tell what happened; my attention was attracted by hearing the cry, "I am stabbed!"â€”I went towards him, and he was turning towards me, and as soon as I saw the blood on his neck I ran to the man nearest to him (the prisoner) and followed him over the bridge to the gate, and caught him there and brought him back; Swain was lying on the ground apparently dead; I believe I said, "See what you have done," and he said, "Not me"â€”Bahrs was lying on the ground when I returned; he was bleeding from his arm, which ho was holdingâ€”I took the prisoner by the arm, and went to Cubitt Town Police-stationâ€”another constable took Krauseâ€”Striblow had not been brought back thenâ€”at the station all three men were charged together; no interpreter was there at the timeâ€”I do not think the prisoner made any answerâ€”I left him there in custody; I was not at the station afterwards when the interpreter was there.

Cross-examined. I said before the Magistrate that there was a quarrel, and "Shortly afterwards they came back, and met the Englishmen again, and recommenced quarrelling, and then got to blows;" and I may have said, "And the prisoners moved back about ten yards, the Englishmen driving them back towards the dock bridge"â€”I don't remember saving that, but I may have done soâ€”they were all mixed up togetherâ€”the three men were standing in the dock when I gave my evidence.
Re-examined. I was looking after my two gates, and the cry, "I am stabbed!"first called my attention.

JOHN SMITH (Millwall Dock Police 20). I was in the dock in Glengal Road with Howard on this eveningâ€”when I was in my box, I saw the prisoner, with Krause and Striblow, come up the road, from the direction of the George;. they stopped about a minute opposite the box, and then passed on towards the dock bridgeâ€”directly after I saw them returning from the direction of the dock bridge, towards me, and in the direction of the Georgeâ€”they stopped about twenty yards from my box in the middle of the roadâ€”at that time I saw four men, who seemed to be together, coming from the direction of the George; they stopped at the gate, and about the time they stopped one of the men, seeing the men standing in the road, said, "Those three Germans have been getting on to us, and we will fight them"; and the four men passed on towards

the threeâ€”almost as soon as all seven men met in the road one man called out, "I am stabbed!"â€”Howard and I rushed towards them, but before we reached them a second man called out, "I am stabbed!"â€”then the three Germans ran away over the dock bridgeâ€”I accompanied Howard to the bridge; he blew his whistle for the gate-keeper on the other side of the bridge to stop the men at the gateâ€”I returned to the gate, and saw Swaine lying on the footpath outside the box apparently dead, and Bahrs lying on the bottom of the box groaningâ€”I did not see anything in any of the men's hands, from where I stood I could not see a blow struck, and I could not see sufficiently to identify one man from anotherâ€”Howard brought back the prisoner in custody; he was wearing a cap, I believe, and a leather jacket like be has got now.

Cross-examined. When the Englishman said, "These Germans have been getting on us; we mean fighting them,"I was about twenty yards from the Germans, who were then standing still; the Englishmen went towards them.
LEWIS SAMUEL WILLIAM INNOCENT . I am landlord of the Georgeâ€”there were only three German sailors in my houseâ€”they were all sober when they left; the house was clear at twenty minutes past twelve.

WILLIAM CULLING (Inspector K). I followed the prisoner into the Isle of Dogs Police-stationâ€”I charged him; no interpreter was present, and the prisoner said nothing in answer to the chargeâ€”Constable Wynne brought two caps to the station, and at the time he did so the prisoner had a cap in his handâ€”when Wynne held the caps up the prisoner said, pointing to one of them, "Mein cap, mein cap"â€”it was given to himâ€”I have searched at the scene of this affray in order to discover a knife, we have not found anythingâ€”a diver has been employed in the dock, but has not found anything.
JAMES HAWKINS (Inspector K). At half-past ten a.m., on 9th December, I charged the prisonerâ€”Mr. Rosenberg, the interpreter, was there.

EDWARD ROSENBERG . I am an interpreterâ€”about half-past ten a.m., on 9th December, I was at the station when Hawkins charged the prisoner, and I interpreted the charge to him, and he seemed to understand meâ€”I cannot tell exactly what the nature of the charge was, but whatever Hawkins told me I interpreted correctlyâ€”the prisoner made statements which I correctly interpreted to the inspector, who took them down in writing.

Cross-examined. The first time the prisoners all spoke together, and made statements which I was unable to give to the inspectorâ€”there were three men behind a long tableâ€”the inspector said something to me in English, which I repeated in German to the three menâ€”they were then very anxious to make statements, but I prevented them, because the" inspector told me that any statements they desired to make they could make before the Magistrate, and he told me to caution themâ€”I did not exactly stop them, I only told them what the inspector saidâ€”the inspector said they would have an opportunity of making statements before the Magistrate, and I interpreted thatâ€”before that the prisoner was desirous of making a statement.
Re-examined. After I told them something about the Magistrate they all made a statement which I interpreted, and the inspector took down in writing.
JAMES HAWKINS (Re-examined). On this morning I told the three men

they were charged with being concerned together in feloniously killing William Swaine by stabbing him in the neck in Glengall Road, and they were further charged with feloniously cutting and wounding John Bahrs by stabbing him in the arm with a knife; the prisoner was also charged with cutting and wounding Taylor, and all the men were charged with assaulting Cooper by knocking him down and kicking him at the same time and placeâ€”those charges having been interpreted they all seemed anxious to address me, and started off together to do soâ€”I told them they could make any statement they wished before the Magistrate; from their demeanour I had an idea they thought I was trying the case, and I told them I was simply charging themâ€”the prisoner said, "We walked; some five or six persons accosted us, and knocked us about, and said, 'You bâ€”â€”y Dutchmen!' we crossed the road to where the policeman was standing, and one of our assailants pulled off his coat, challenged us to fight him, and struck me a blow on the chest; we ran away, me and my mates, a policeman blowing his whistle, and he got hold of us."

JAMES CRISP (293 K). In the early morning of 9th December I was at the corner of Glengall Roadâ€”I heard a whistle blown from the dock gates; went up Glengall Road, and found the prisoner in custodyâ€”I afterwards took Krause to the stationâ€”I searched the prisoner at the station, and only found a handkerchief on him.
Cross-examined. I arrested Krause twenty yards from the constable's box, on the opposite side of it, and on the right-hand side of the road, the box being on the left.

WILLIAM PALMER (341 K). I was on point duty in Glengall Road on this early morning, and soon after a quarter to one, from information which reached me, I went to the dock gates, where I found the deceased man Swaine, and took him to the mortuaryâ€”Mr. Leslie soon afterwards saw him there.

WILLIAM MURRAY. LESLIE . I am a registered medical practitioner, of 531, Manchester Road, Poplar, and divisional surgeon of policeâ€”on the morning of 9th December I was called to the dock gates, and there saw a dead man lying on his back on the pavementâ€”he was taken to the mortuary, where on the next day I made a post-mortem examination of himâ€”I found on him two wounds, one on the back of his left hand, uneven, jagged, and somewhat triangular, cutting through two tendons, and the other, on the left side of the neck, a gaping wound extending through the skin, nerves, veins, and chief artery, between that point and the lower border of the first ribâ€”it was two inches or more in depth, but it was difficult to know its exact end, on account of its passing into the pleural cavityâ€”it passed through the sub-clavian artery, which was completely severed, and through part of the first rib, splintering the boneâ€”it was a wound that would have required considerable force to inflictâ€”it was the fatal woundâ€”death was due to syncope from loss of blood, occasioned by the wound in the neckâ€”both wounds might possibly have been caused by the same implement, but I could not swear to itâ€”the wounds must have been occasioned by a broad-bladed instrument, because the transverse length of the wound was considerably over an inch, in fact I should say at the top it was one-and-a-quarter inch; it was impossible to say whether the implement was pointed or not, because the end of the wound was in the pleural cavityâ€”I could not be certain whether the weapon had more than one edgeâ€”it was a wound that
could have been inflicted by a chisel or by a knife; but it must have been broad-bladed and used with considerable force.

JOHN COOPER (Re-examined). I was at the Police-station when the prisoner was brought inâ€”he had Swaine's cap in his hand; this is it; Swaine was wearing it on that night when we came down Glengall Road before we met the prisoner, and after we met him first; Swaine was still wearing it till we got to the dock-gatesâ€”I did not see Swaine lose it nor the prisoner pick it up.
Cross-examined. I don't know whether there was a general scrimmage and they were feeling for their caps in the darkness; I was lying in the middle of the road.
JOHN TRIM (Re-examined). There is pavement on both sides of the road going down to the dock-bridgeâ€”on the right-hand side it is about five feet nine inches or six feet wide.

p.hi: The following Witnesses were called for the Defence.

div1.p: LUDWIG KRAUSE (Interpreted). I am assistant-engineer on board the Liebensteinâ€”I was eighteen years old yesterdayâ€”on the evening of 8th December I left the Liebenstein about seven o'clockâ€”I met Striblow at the dock-gates, and went with him to the George public-house, and at eleven o'clock I went to the George againâ€”I heard a number of Germans singing in there, and I went into the compartment and joined in with them; one of them was the prisoner and the others my shipmatesâ€”Killgrass and Sewer were not there then, but they had gone on shore that eveningâ€”I remained till closing-time, and then I, the prisoner, and Striblow left to go on board our ship, and walked arm-in-arm on the right-hand side of the path going towards the dock-gatesâ€”we passed two Englishmen without any interference, and then we came up to a second pair of Englishmenâ€”I left the prisoner's arm, and went a little bit in the road; the prisoner, in passing the two Englishmen, shoved one of them aside; then I came on the pathway again, and the three of us went towards the dock-gatesâ€”we were on the right-hand side of the road; I saw the constable's box on the left-hand sideâ€”when we got to the bridge Striblow said, in the prisoner's hearing, "Sewer and Killgrass are still on shore; we will wait and join them, so that we can go on board together"â€”we all turned round, with our faces towards the George, and I saw the four Englishmen coming up the roadâ€”I said, "We bad better go on the other side of the road, so we might not meet together with the Englishmen"â€”we all three then crossed to the constable's box on the left-hand side of the roadâ€”the four Englishmen followed us; when we saw that we stoppedâ€”Cooper approached us and put himself into a fighting attitude; he pulled his coat back, and then tried to attack meâ€”I saw that he had closed with' Gempesteinâ€”I stood there; I was attacked by somebody who struck me; I lost my capâ€”I was then in the middle of the roadâ€”I shoved away the man who was attacking me; I did not say anything to himâ€”I saw the prisoner was fightingâ€”Striblow ran awayâ€”I do not know if he ran away before I was attacked and the prisoner was fightingâ€”the prisoner ran awayâ€”he told me he was twenty years old.

Cross-examined. I had no weapon on meâ€”the prisoner is carpenter on the Liebensteinâ€”I have seen him in possession of a chisel on board shipâ€”when the Englishmen came up to us at the outer gate of the. docks,

they were two and twoâ€”we stood about a quarter of a second by the constable's boxâ€”I did not see the prisoner outside the gates knock Cooper down; I only saw him strike him with his fist; I did not see Cooper fall downâ€”I did not do anything to Cooper at that time; I never saw him lie on the groundâ€”Cooper tried to attack me; I shoved him away from me, that was allâ€”I did not hear anyone call out "I am stabbed!"â€”I could not understandâ€”I heard someone speaking, but I could not understand whatâ€”I did not hear anyone say in Gorman, "Was ist est? Das du wilst? Da hast du."

GOTHELF STRIBLOW . I am a German, and one of the crew of the Liebensteinâ€”on. this evening I was with Krause and the prisoner at the George at closing-timeâ€”two other' of our shipmates were on shoreâ€”I, Krause, and the prisoner left the George and went up Glengall Road towards the dock, walking on the right-hand side of the wayâ€”we pasted two Englishmen, and then came up to two other Englishmenâ€”Krause went into the middle of the road, and I went between the two Englishmen, and the prisoner pushed one of them; I did not see if ho fellâ€”Krause came on to the path again, and we three walked on to the dock bridge, when I suggested we should wait for Killgrass and Sewerâ€”as we waited, I saw the Englishmen coming up on the right-hand sideâ€”Krause said, "Let us go on the other side of the street, for that we don't come again to the English fellows"â€”we crossed over to the left-hand side whore the constable's box wasâ€”the Englishmen came up, and one said, "Come, they are the three Germans; let us fight with them"; and at the same moment I saw that the prisoner and Cooper were fightingâ€”I said to the prisoner, "Come, Gempestein, let us go on board; I don't like this"â€”he said in German, "Master, you can't expect that I shall be beaten by this man"â€”I saw the other two Englishmen, Swaine and Bahrs, come up; one fellow gave me a smack in my left eye, and I ran away, and an English fellow pushed me, and I fell downâ€”the man that struck me in the eye struck me on the knee with his foot; I cannot say who it wasâ€”I ran across the road, and when I was on the other side I heard someone holloa out, I am stabbed!"â€”I am married.
FREDERICK VOGT . I am captain of the Liebensteinâ€”the prisoner has been one of my crew since I joined the ship on 6th Octoberâ€”no has borne the character of a peaceable and quiet man since then.
Mr. JUSTICE CAVE considered that there was not evidence to support the charge of murder.

GUILTY
of manslaughter â€”
Eighteen Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner for wounding Bahrs.

div1.p:
214.
LUDWIG KRAUSE
, Unlawfully assaulting
John Cooper.
Mr. MATHEWS, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: NEW COURT.â€”Tuesday 19th, Wednesday 20th, and Thursday 21st, January, 1892.

div1.p:
215.
CHARLES WILBRAHAM PERRYMAN was indicted
for maliciously and unlawfully writing and publishing a scandalous, malicious, and defamatory libel of and concerning
Anthony Pulbrook. To this a justification was pleaded.
MESSRS. GRAIN and ARTHUR GILL Prosecuted; MR. COCK, Q. C., with MR. MALONY, Defended.

Before plea, MR. COCK applied to quash the indictment on the ground that it woe bad, at the word "falsely"woe omitted, for which omission there was no precedent. In support of this he referred to several authorities, among others to Archbold, p. 973, Styles' Reports, p. 663; Craft v. Bryett, Saunders' Reports, p. 310, and Crown Circuit Companion, p. 293.

MR. GRAIN contended that these old authorities were superseded, that the "falsely"was mere surplusage, and woe implied in the word "maliciously,"but if the Court thought fit, it could amend the indictment by inserting the word. MR. GILL referred to 14 & 15 Vic. c. 100, Sec. 26, which stated that no indictment could be insufficient for want of the averment of any matter that was unnecessary to prove. MR. COCK, in reply, contended that this indictment was not framed upon the Statute, but on the Common Law; and although it was not necessary on the part of the prosecution to prove "falsity,"it was necessary to allege it in the indictment. The COMMON SERJEANT doubted the power of the Court to amend, but as the question of truth or falsehood was here raised by the plea of justification, there was a distinct issue before the Jury, lie did not think it absolutely necessary that "falsely"should appear in the indictment, and therefore was not bound to quash it.

p.hi: put in an order of a Judge in Chambers authorising the prosecution, also an extract from the Register of Newspaper Proprietors, describing the defendant as the proprietor of the "Financial Observer and Mining Herald. "

div1.p: EDWARD SUMNER ROBERTS . I am a commercial clerkâ€”I got these two papers (produced) at the office where they are published, 96, Queen Street, Cheapside, on 11th September, 1891; they are dated August 22nd and September 11thâ€”I read certain passages in those papersâ€”at page 427 in the paper published on 22nd August there is an allusion to "The attorney, Anthony Pulbrook," and lower down there is a Terse referring to "an attorney named Pulbrook"â€”reading that, I say it refers to Mr. Pulbrook as a solicitor.

Cross-examined. I am a commercial clerkâ€”I would rather not say in whoso employment; I object to do soâ€”I have come here this morning on the express understanding that I am not to produce their names; not to say anything that does no? refer to this caseâ€”my present employers do not wish their names made a subject of ribaldryâ€”I will not tell you their nameâ€”I was in the employment of Mr. Pulbrook from about May, 1891, to something like the end of Septemberâ€”I gave evidence before the Aldermanâ€”I was with Mr. Pulbrook as his book-keeper, shorthand correspondent, and clerk; also secretary of one of his Companies, the North Mexican Milling and Mining Companyâ€”if he conducts his business economically it proves that he is an honest man, and not like your clientâ€”it was a Company which he financedâ€”I think he financed very considerably; he is hereâ€”I was in Court during the time he gave evidence before the Magistrateâ€”I heard it. (Upon the witness being asked tÂ» state what he heard the prosecutor say before the Magistrate, MR. GRAIN objected, as the best evidence would be that of the deposition, but on MR. COOK pressing the point, as to credit, the COMMON SERJEANT would not exclude it. A number of questions founded upon the depositions were put to the witness seriatim,

to most of which he replied that he had no recollection, that he did not hear, and that a good deal was in the form of observations by counsel.)â€”I have no idea whether Mr. Pulbrook had anything to do with the Meat Consumers' Company; I never heard of it beforeâ€”I believe I have heard something of the Provident Supply, but I am not sureâ€”I believe he was a promoter of the United Service Stores, a very successful thing, I believeâ€”I never heard that it was wound upâ€”I never heard of the Anglo-French Provision Company or the Investment Registration Stock Exchangeâ€”I know the North Mexican Milling and Mining Company; I am not sure about the North Mexican Silver Mining Company: I think these two Companies were developedâ€”Mr. Pulbrook was a director; he put the principal amount of money into itâ€”I can't say whether any of the Companies ever paid a dividendâ€”I know nothing about other Companies except the one I was concerned with as secretary; the directors of that Company were Lord Teynham, Mr. Tallack, an East India merchant of Great St. Helens, and Mr. Phillipsâ€”that Company is still going on and is likely to do soâ€”I never looked at the agreement under which the Company was constituted; I suppose it is at the officeâ€”I think I have heard of the Mont de PiÃ©tÃ© of Englandâ€”I never heard of it in connection with Mr. Pulbrookâ€”I think I have heard of the North Mexican Foundryâ€”I can't say whether that was one of Mr. Pulbrook's Companiesâ€”I don't know whether he is a director of the New Munro Gold Minesâ€”I have not heard of the British Columbia Trust and Agency; I never was in the office of that Companyâ€”I know the Honduras Gold Companyâ€”I don't know whether that was one of Mr. Pulbrook's Companiesâ€”I have heard the Cotton Powder Company mentioned in the office, that was not one of his Companies that I know ofâ€”there was an Omnibus Company; I was in the office when that was registered; I don't know much about itâ€”very likely Mr. Pulbrook was concerned in bringing out that Company, but that was before I was in the office.
HENRY SMITH . I am summoning officer at the Mansion Houseâ€”I was present when the summons in the name of Perryman was calledâ€”that is Mr. Pulbrook.

p.hi: The following Witnesses were called for the Defence.

div1.p: CHARLES PHILLIPS . I am a clerk of the Incorporated Law Societyâ€”I produce a letter from Mr. Perryman of September 21st, 1891, the first letterâ€”that was placed before the Council, and as the prosecution was then pending against Perryman at the instance of Mr. Pulbrook, it was decided to let the consideration of the matter stand over till that prosecution was disposed ofâ€”subsequently, on 31st December, a letter was received signed,

C. W. PERRYMAN; I have not that letterâ€”the letters are formal, and relate to a complaint lodged under the Solicitors' Act, 1888â€”one point the Law Society took was that the complaint was not in proper form not being verified by affidavitâ€”I produce a copy of the affidavit; used on the application before the Court; the original is filed in Courtâ€”it is made by Watson Smith and John Worsley Forbesâ€”that matter was disposed of by the Court on 9th June-that has nothing to do with this matterâ€”I can prove the writing of the letter,.

DAVID HILBERT . I am one of the firm of Odell and Co., sheriff's officers, of 36, Coleman Streetâ€”a fi, fa. in the action of the Big Golden Quarry Mining and Water Power Company, Limited, against Perryman,

was lodged with us on 6th August, 1891â€”I have the warrantâ€”it is a direction to levy execution for Â£73 6s. 2d., and Â£1 1s. 8d. costsâ€”the date of the judgment is 8th August, 1888â€”the verbal instructions from Mr. Pulbrook were not to execute the warrant, as he was getting some further informationâ€”the warrant was only required for 96, Queen Street, on that dayâ€”on Friday, 7th, the warrant was to be held over till 10.30 a.m.â€”my partner, Mr. Odell, was not in town on Thursday, but on Friday, in consequence of a conversation with him, I wrote to Mr. Pulbrook. (This was to the effect that Mr. Pulbrook, not having kept the appointment, between half-past ten and eleven, if he did not wish the warrant executed he must send in due course)â€”we received an answer from Mr. Pulbrook countermanding the warrant the same dayâ€”on Saturday, 8th August, Mr. Pulbrook called about twelve o'clockâ€”we then received orders to wait till he came a second time, when he would accompany me to the defendant's officeâ€”he said he wished another warrant to be issued for the printing-office at 12, St. Thomas-the-Apostle; that was the office of the Financial Observer and Mining Heraldâ€”I had that warrantâ€”the judgment is of the same dateâ€”I received the usual fee of half-a crown on itâ€”he said he did not want it executed till a quarter past two at 96, Queen Street, as Mr. Perryman was expected to go out of town by two o'clockâ€”he gave no instructions as to the time the warrant was to be executed at the printing-office, simply stating that he wished the paper stopped, if possible, because, if I remember, he said it contained a libel he did not want to appearâ€”soon afterwards Mr. Joy cameâ€”Mr. Pulbrook wanted him to be my man in possession at 96, Queen Streetâ€”about two p.m. Mr. Pulbrook came to the office and said he was ready, and wished Joy to come with usâ€”I told him I would not adopt Joy as my man in possession; I preferred to have my own man thereâ€”he said he would indemnify meâ€”I said I should not take that, I should put my own man thereâ€”he said there were certain papers he wanted to find, and that Joy knew where they were, as Joy had received some information from a clerk of Mr. Perrymanâ€”my instructions were to seize the papers in the safeâ€”I told Pulbrook I had only power to seize bonds or money, or securities for money, and only those goods that we could soilâ€”he said he wanted two transfersâ€”I told him he had no power to seize themâ€”he said I was to do anything to get at the contents of the safeâ€”I have given no proof of my evidence for Perrymanâ€”I went to Perryman's officeâ€”I saw a clerk of Mr. Perryman, who informed me Mr. Perryman had gone out, but would be back in about five minutesâ€”I reached the office about 2.20â€”Pulbrook and Joy accompanied meâ€”I told Joy I could give him no direction under my warrant, that if he came he came at his own riskâ€”Perryman came in and spoke to meâ€”Pulbrook was not presentâ€”I then went to 12, St. Thomas-the-Apostle, to execute the"second warrantâ€”I found the premises closedâ€”I had left a man in at Queen Streetâ€”I reached the printing-office about three o'clockâ€”I went back to my officeâ€”I found this pencil note from Mr. Pulbrook (read) "Perryman: The things wanted are two transfers of the Caledonian Deferred Converted Stock to Owen, and an indiarubber stamp 'Certificate lodged for the Caledonian Railway Securities. '(Signed) A. Pulbrook. "And at the bottom: "For the Caledonian Railway Secretary"â€”on the Monday Mr. Pulbrook called at my office; he saw Mr. Odellâ€”I heard Mr. Odell tell Mr. Pulbrook that was not the proper course to

secure the documents; the object of a fi. fa. or execution was to recover the debt; the proper way was to lodge an information at the Mansion House, and obtain a search warrantâ€”names wore mentioned; Mr. Austin was mentionedâ€”he was not a party to the fi. fa. or judgmentâ€”he had nothing to do with the Big Golden Quarry actionâ€”a second name was mentionedâ€”one name was a witness, or had something to do with criminal proceedings against Ferrymanâ€”some correspondence passed between our firm and Ferrymanâ€”on 10th August we received this letter from Mr. Ferryman. (Acknowledging letter of 8th, and enclosing copy of letter from Mr. Ferryman, and urging the witnesses firm to proceed with the fi. fa. Another letter read, 15th August, Pulbrook to Odell and Co., complaining that the debt had not been received; no man was in possession, and that Odells would be held liable for any lossâ€”we had withdrawn from possession on an understanding from Messrs. Vernon and Son, which satisfied us. (Read, letter 17th August, Odell and Co. to Pulbrooh, stating arrangements were made whereby the plaintiff company would not be prejudiced, and that there was no ground of complaint. Also, reply of same day, stating that jndgment against Perry man teas still in full force, and there was no ground for withdrawing. Also, 19th August, Odell and Co. to Pulbrooh, in reply to letter of 17th, stating they were satisfied with the undertaking, and declining to search for a paper they had no power to seize).

Cross-examined by MR. GBAIN.
