Our duty when in possession would be to prevent anyone taking away a security; but private books or papers we have no power to seizeâ€”if a safe was condemned we should take it away, provided we could not get the keyâ€”it would be legal then to force it open, and our duty to see what was in itâ€”if we had gone in for Â£50, and found Â£100 in bank-notes, we should be paid of!, with our feesâ€”we did seize the safeâ€”the debtor would not have any right to take anything away without the consent of the man in possession; but the man cannot be in more than one room at a timeâ€”if, as in this case, we are satisfied with the guarantee, the man in possession goes outâ€”then the debtor could take what he pleasedâ€”we should seize a cheque made payable to and endorsed by the debtor; or if not endorsed, I might add, with a good signatureâ€”I would not seize a transfer; it has no valueâ€”probably should take it, or a certificate for what it was worthâ€”I should leave a stamp or manifold writerâ€”they would be condemnedâ€”I should ask the debtor to open a safe, or a drawer that was locked, or any receptacle that might contain property that ought to be condemned and seizedâ€”Mr. Odell took the guarantee of Vernon and Sonsâ€”I have never been in possession where no one was there to represent the debtorâ€”I take it the debtor's solicitor would look after the premises being secured.

Re-examined. A transfer of North-Western stock to Brown I should seize, subject to the claim of Mr. Brownâ€”I should seize a third person's propertyâ€”if in a bank I did not find sufficient money I should seize the securities belonging to other people, subject to their claim.

EDGAR THOMAS ODELL . I am a member of the firm of Odell and Co., Sheriffs Officers of the City of Londonâ€”I have given no proof; I have been subpÅ“naed by the defendantâ€”on 0th August a writ of fieri facias was lodged in the suit of the Big Golden Quarry Mining and Water Power Company against Perrymanâ€”I knew where Perryman carried on business as a newspaper proprietorâ€”I had known him for some timeâ€”in ordinary course we should execute the writ the same day, or perhaps the

same hourâ€”it was delivered to me during business hours on the 6thâ€”I found it on 7th August, and the instructions, which seemed oddâ€”I wrote a memorandum to Mr. Pulbrook, as he did not come at 10.30 on 7th, and kept the appointment mentioned in the instructions, and a countermand was endorsedâ€”I went out of town again at 6.56 p.m.â€”on Monday, 10th, Mr. Pulbrook came to see meâ€”I had had my ordinary letter on Sunday morning, telling me what had occurredâ€”these instructions are rather unusual; our duty is to break open anything to find any cash or securities, or anything of value that we can seize; that is, after a reasonable timeâ€”in thirty-seven years I have only had to break open an iron safe onceâ€”that was not on the Saturday afternoon, when the gentleman had leftâ€”the date of the judgment struck me as peculiar, and) then the instructions, coupled with the fact that the warrant emanated from Mr. Pulbrook, put me on my guard, and the Company being the plaintiffs Company in liquidationâ€”Pulbrook said the object was not to got the money; he did not care anything about thatâ€”I asked him. what be wantedâ€”he said he wanted an India rubber stamp, which, as a fact, we considered as valueless, and a transfer of Caledonian stock, which he alleged had been taken away and produced at the Mansion House, and which was the reason the Alderman dismissed the summons against Perrymanâ€”I daresay Pulbrook was with me twenty minutesâ€”he said, 11 Will you open the safe?"â€”I told him "No"â€”Mr. Perryman would not give us the keyâ€”there was a summons to set aside the judgmentâ€”I said, "It occurs to me this is not the proper process for you to get possession of the information you require; you ought to swear an information, and five Mr. Perryman into custody, and let the detective search the office"â€”he said, "I have told them so"â€”I said, "You mean down. the street?"â€”I was then in Coleman Street, in my office; he said, "Yes," and a name was mentionedâ€”other persons were interested in attacking Perryman; they had no connection with this Companyâ€”one of them had already attempted to attack Perrymanâ€”I took an undertaking to pay me debts and costs, with which I was perfectly satisfiedâ€”a correspondence followed.

Croat-examined. I did not see Perryman, I was not on the premises; my partner wasâ€”I did not see Perryman till long afterâ€”I never asked anyone to open the safeâ€”I differ a little from what my partner said in his evidence; if I had levied that execution, and had found the safe open, I should have looked for money, bills, and bonds and securities for money; if I had seen a transfer I should have taken no notice of that; I do not want inter pleadersâ€”I told Pulbrook Perryman had refused to open the safe, from information I had first from the letter from my partnerâ€”the interview with Pulbrook on the Monday made me anxious to take the undertaking and get out of it.

Re-examined. The refusal to open the safe was on the Saturdayâ€”I believe on the Saturday, when Ferryman returned from lunch, he was asked whether he would open the safe, and refusedâ€”I had also been told of itâ€”Joy was running in and out of the office the whole day; we wore never free from him bringing messages.

SAMUEL HAYMAN . I am from the office of the Registrar of Joint Stock Companiesâ€”I produce the file of the following Companies: The London Meat Consumers Company, Limited, registered by Mr. Pulbrook, of 31, Threadneedle Street. 16th December, 1865, dissolved in 1888â€”a list of

(MR. COCK read a circular expressing a hope that proxies would not be entrusted to Mr. Pulbrook, and stating that certain allegations made against him had not been refuted; that the directors had investigated charges against him, and had come to the conclusion that he (Pulbrook) had grossly abused his position; that he had drawn money from the Secretary on I O Us and cheques)â€”I have never seen or heard of such a circular before I heard of it in courtâ€”I ceased to be a director about six months after that, because I refused to attend the meetingsâ€”fresh directors were appointed, and I refused to sit with themâ€”in July of the previous year the company had not gone on to my satisfactionâ€”I was the means of calling a meeting of shareholders, and obtained a very large majority to remove the directorsâ€”we passed first a resolution expressive of want of confidence in the board; a poll was taken, and there were proxies representing two to one against the directorsâ€”I then passed a resolution requesting the directors to resign; they refused to do soâ€”I told them at the general meeting, "Now, I will pass a resolution removing you. You know perfectly well that that resolution requires a three-fourths majority, and I have only two to one; but it will go forth to the world that you, as directors, are sitting on the board and that the shareholders have passed a resolution of want of confidence in you"â€”then they resignedâ€”I and Major Cotton were appointed directorsâ€”the directors had appointed a committee to investigate as against me; the chairman of the committee was the late Boswall Preston, one of the largest shareholders in the companyâ€”I explained matters to him, and from that time he supported me throughout; he

said: "These people say you have power to appoint a director, and that you will exercise that power in an improper way; will you agree to appoint me a director, as I am the largest shareholder in the company?"I said "Certainly"â€”Mr. Surrente, who had got up the committee to appoint me, asked Major Cotton to be one of the committeeâ€”I said I did not care, so long as he was an independent shareholder: "Appoint whom you like"â€”at that time the returns of the company were going down at the rate of Â£2,000 a monthâ€”I set aside every other business and worked the company, with the result that in three months the returns were increasing at the rate of Â£1,500 a month; I then found gross irregularities had taken place in the management of the company, and that Surrente had been embezzling money, and I told the directors that we must make an example of the man; he was prosecuted and committed for trialâ€”at the annual meeting at which the accounts were brought forward, Major Cotton said he had not seen the accountsâ€”afterwards, when I was abroad, two additional directors were appointed, who were nominated by Major Cottonâ€”the chairman and myself contended that those appointments were illegal, and we refused to attend any other meeting; and I have written to those directors from time to time that they are not legal directors, and would be responsible for all the fees they had takenâ€”the end of it was I refused to be a directorâ€”the gentlemen against whom I have made these charges have been directors of the company ever since, for nine yearsâ€”Mr. Aspland became my clerk at 5s. a week, and when he left I was paying him Â£3â€”Mr. Coxhead is a working carpenter; he acted for me in holding these sharesâ€”Miss Pulbrook, my daughter, is 28â€”she acted for me with regard to these shares; all the shares have been fully paid upâ€”Miss Howe did not act for me, but for herselfâ€”the North Mexican Silver Mining Company was started to purchase certain mines from Mr. Bell, an American, and all the share capital was handed to himâ€”then further money was raised by debentures, Â£100,000â€”no dividend was paid on the shares of that company, because by the constitution of the company, by the issue of the debentures, every amount of money subscribed by the company was to be paid back on the debentures before the vendor could receive a shilling on his sharesâ€”Â£4,000 interest was paid on the debentures; that was money deposited for that purpose, not from any earnings of the companyâ€”the debenture-holders took possession and managed the. company, and sold it to me on an engagement by me to raise Â£25,000, and give everyone the right to retain his interest in the companyâ€”I did not sell the company to the Vendors, Limitedâ€”this was ail by contractâ€”then the Mexican Mines Development Company was startedâ€”I and my two clerks were the directorsâ€”I, as trustee for the debenture-holders, sold it to the Development Companyâ€”the Vendors, Limited, never sold itâ€”then the Worth Mexican Milling and Mining Company was started; that has not paid any dividendâ€”an execution against that company for Â£160 was put in at my office, and there was a return of nulla bonaâ€”the money was paidâ€”these photographs were put up in my office to give the shareholders an idea of what the property consistedâ€”I never wanted to make a market for shares; I was content to have it stand on its own meritsâ€”the Milling and Mining Company has a banking account at the London and South-Western Bankâ€”I have not the book

hereâ€”there is a minute-book; that is not hereâ€”the directors are Lord Teynham, Francis Tulloch, Mr. Hoffman, and myselfâ€”Mr. Hoffman investigated independently, and agreed to accept management and share of profits, it was so goodâ€”Mr. Tulloch has never made one penny-piece out of my companies; he would not take anything unless the company succeedsâ€”he depends on the results of the sharesâ€”I daresay I could get the banking accountâ€”the minute-book is in the City; it would not show what business was doneâ€”I have not brought the minute-book of one of these companies, or any booksâ€”I do not think I am improperly called a company solicitor, but I am not to be slatedâ€”I agree that "if there were no unscrupulous solicitors there would be no bogus companies"â€”I do not agree in this," that for facility of walking round the Companies Act commend us to Mr. Pulbrook"â€”two persons have been described as City thieves in a particular articleâ€”I know their names, but till September 5th I never knew that. I was includedâ€”I know that Mr. Perryman called me "the eminent ass"â€”it is perfectly clear, by his putting two hyphens that he includes me as a City thiefâ€”Mr. Owen lives somewhere in Hertfordshireâ€”while Mr. Sanbridge was his solicitor, Mr. Bellairs introduced him to meâ€”I never knew that Bellairs had had a dispute with Mr. Perryman; he never mentioned his nameâ€”Mr. Owen took criminal proceedings against Mr. Perryman at the Mansion Houseâ€”I was put into the box, and cross-examined, I believe, as to whether Mr. Bellairs introduced Owen to meâ€”a transfer was produced and handed to the Lord Mayorâ€”it was suggested to the Lord Mayor that this was a prosecution got up by Bellairs and not substantially by Owen; and the Lord Mayor, on seeing the documents, said, "Here I have a transfer into Mr. Owen's name before the summons was issued on the 21st," and consequently he dismissed the summonsâ€”when the transfer has been lodged at the company's office and the corticated is issued by the company of the lodgment of that transfer, any person, other than the person in whose name it has been registered, can deal with itâ€”the certificate is simply a certified transfer announcing that the transferor of the property has lodged the title-deed at the office, and when he does so it will be in his name, but it is perfectly competent on taking that transfer back to the company's office to have that certificate cancelledâ€”it could be done without Owen's authorityâ€”I wrote to Perryman saying I had authority from Owen for Perryman to deliver to me the transfer of the Caledonian Deferred stock; I attended in consequence of that on April 28th and saw Perrymanâ€”(MR. COCK read a letter of April 30th from the witness to Perryman, saying that he had called yesterday with Owen's authority to receive the Caledonian Stock, and that he had to request him to deliver it to Owen or himself (Pulbrook) in the course of the day; a letter of the same date from Perryman to the witness, saying that the statements in the letter were untrue, that Pulbrook had never been informed that the transfer was at Perryman's solicitors, nor was any appointment made to deliver it that day; and a letter from Perryman to Owen, of May 23rd, declining to have any communication with Mr. Pulbrook)â€”at the time I went to the office, before I put in the execution, I did not know that the position Perryman had taken was that he would not hand over the transfer to Owen till he had paid the costs which Perryman had been put to by the prosecution, or that Owen could bring an action against him for the transfer, and he would counter-claim for malicious prosecutionâ€”I saw a letter from Perry
man

declining to hand over the transfer unless he were paid Â£100â€”(MR. COCK read a letter of May 11th, from Owen to Perryman, expressing surprise that he had not delivered the stock to Pulbrook; a Utter from Ferryman declining to have any communication with Pulbrook; a letter from Owen acknowledging receipt of certificate of shares in the Kensington Stores, and saying that he had no occasion to have an interview with Perryman; that all he required was for him to hand over hit property to himself or Pulbrook; a letter from Perryman to Owen expressing his willingness to make a settlement to him on Owen's paying Ferryman's costs, which he put at Â£100, in defending himself against the charge made against him; a letter from Owen, saying that neither his stock nor money had been returned to him; a letter from Perryman to Owen, saying that he could defend himself against any further steps Owen wished to take to recover any further moneys he said Perryman held, but that he was willing to settle with Owen if Owen would pay the damages he had been put to; and a letter from Perryman on 30th, July to Owen, saying that he was ready to come to a settlement with him if he would pay the costs incurred in the prosecution)â€”as far as I was concerned this transfer was the property of Owen, ray clientâ€”I had seen a letter from Perryman, contending that it was notâ€”I never gave instructions to take it in execution at the suit of the Big Gold Quarry Companyâ€”what I explained to the sheriff was, "I have an execution against Mr. Perryman; I have only just heard that he has goods which can be seized; I am told no printer will print his paper"â€”nominally Perryman has been carrying on business in the City for eighteen months or two yearsâ€”I saw in the newspapers that he had a dispute with Mr. Foster, who had prosecuted him, and that his principal witness was Plumbley; I knew that the prosecution had come to an end; I believe the summons was withdrawnâ€”Joy, who had been in Perryman's employment, and Plumbley were at Mr. Foster's office when we had a meeting on 5th or 6th of Augustâ€”I knew Plumbley had been a witness against Perryman; it was suggested that Joy should give some information about Perryman; he volunteered to do soâ€”I said with respect to the information something like "Oh! I have thought of a better plan than that, as by going in through the sheriff there will be no tainted evidence,"after I had consulted with Mr. Graham and Mr. Fosterâ€”Mr. Graham and Mr. Plumbley had no interest in the Big Gold Quarry judgmentâ€”Mr. Ley ton was the liquidator of the Big Gold Quarry Companyâ€”I had seen Ley ton before,1 made that observationâ€”there were two meetings the same day; I had not seen him before the first meeting, but I had before the secondâ€”Bellairs was interested in the companyâ€”I registered it; Mr. Ogle was the person prominently interested, I thinkâ€”at that time I cannot say if I had any authority from the liquidator of the company to take any proceedings, but I made the application for it immediatelyâ€”afterwards I arranged "for Joy to go into the office with the sheriff's officer, to point out the particular safe where the securities were, and that that safe might be broken open by the sheriff"â€”those were your words, not mineâ€”you asked me certain questions without reference to names and periods, and they are all mixed up together.

Me examined. Mr. Owen was my client; he is here to-day, prepared to be a witnessâ€”he gave me instructions to take criminal proceedings against the prisoner in reference to the alleged misappropriation of some Caledonian stocks, or money that had been sent for that purposeâ€”

I applied for process at the Mansion House, and my client swore an informationâ€”process was granted, and a summons in due course was issued on 26th March, 1891, calling on Perryman to appear at the Mansion Houseâ€”he appeared, and was represented by Mr. Cockâ€”I was a witnessâ€”a document was handed by Mr. Cock, and passed up to the Lord Mayor; I did not see it then, and I had never seen it till it was put into my hands to-day, except that I just saw it passed; my memory is that it was on blue paper. (The document was read. It was a transfer to Owen of stock in the Caledonian Railway Company, stamped 19th March, 1891, and having a certificate at the side. MR. GRAIN proposed to put in two letters, the first being dated 28th March, in relation to the charge at the Mansion House. MR. COCK having objected that they were not relevant to the issue, and that the matter did not arise out of his cross-examination, the COMMON SERJEANT ruled that they were not admissible)â€”these two documents were handed to me in the course of the inquiry with reference to Mr. Owenâ€”I am still authorised to act on his behalfâ€”on the depositions taken from me when Mr. Cock examined me is a phrase that I thought a document was there which had been forged; I gave that answer upon information which Joy had given to meâ€”it was after he gave me certain information that I gave the instructions to Messrs Odell and Co.â€”I had not at that time looked into the section dealing with search warrantsâ€”directly after the proceedings at the Mansion House a writ was issued by Perryman against Owen for malicious prosecutionâ€”no statement of claim has been delivered; nothing has been done in prosecution of the action beyond issuing the writ; it can be dismissed at any time for want of prosecutionâ€”up to the present time Owen has not received a shilling of consolidated stock or anythingâ€”in reference to all the companies no complaint had been made against me with the exception of one which was dealt with by Vice-Chancellor Bacon, the Isle of Wight Sanatorium. (Mr. GRAIN proceeded to ask the Witness what Vice-Chancellor Bacon had said. Mr. COCK objected. The COMMON SERJEANT ruled that the evidence was inadmissible.)â€”thirteen years ago I was solicitor to the Prudential Supply Association, which became the Regent United Service Stores; they took over the business of the Public Supply Association in Regent Streetâ€”I went abroad, and while I was abroad the solicitor for the Public Supply Association was appointed solicitor, and acted, and when I came back proceedings were taken, and I was appointed by the directors to act, and a technical objection was taken that I had come forward of my own motion and appeared for the company; but I had always been the recognised solicitor for the company, and Vice-Chancellor Malins told me in chambers privately that he had been wholly mistaken in the caseâ€”when he found my bill of costs taxed at Â£300, which was allowed, he admitted his mistakeâ€”the Omnibus Proprietors' Company is a good company, and is going to pay a dividend, the chairman told me; it only started last Mayâ€”the West-end Stock Exchange is a good company, and has been paying dividends up to this time of 15 per cent.â€”the Mexican Milling Company is a good company, and likely to yield very large profits to the proprietorsâ€”the shares are not quoted on the Stock Exchangeâ€”we have refused to have anything to do with it.
PHILIP WILLIAM TUBBS . I am an omnibus proprietor, and am managing director of the Omnibus Proprietors' Company, Limited, which is registered under the Joint Stock Companies' Actâ€”I was an owner of

omnibuses before the company was formed by omnibus proprietorsâ€”I consulted Mr. Pulbrook as to the formation of the company as a solicitorâ€”the company never went to the public at allâ€”the money was subscribed by ourselves; it was something like Â£17,000 which was paid for the purchase of the stockâ€”various proprietors subscribed who are now members of the company, which started on July 1st, and we have just paid an interim dividend of 8 per cent., but we could pay a peat deal more; if we put our stock into the market we could get a good deal more than we paid for itâ€”Mr. Pulbrook merely acted as solicitor, and was simply paid as such, nothing else.

Cross-examined. There are twenty shareholders at Â£1 eachâ€”the company was started in July, and the dividend was declared and paid before these proceedings commencedâ€”it was declared ten days or a fortnight agoâ€”we know nothing of any proceedings in October.
Re-examined. The declaration of the dividend had nothing to do with it; it was a flourishing, going companyâ€”the dividend was paid out of money honestly earned.

JOSEPH PINNOCK OWEN . I am a builder and decorator, of Wheathampsteadâ€”I had a few copies of the Financial Observer sent me last autumnâ€”I then wrote to the prisoner, and ultimately sent him a chequeâ€”I received no documents of title with reference to any stock, only the bought noteâ€”on Monday, March 16th, I communicated with Mr. Pulbrook, and gave him certain instructions. (MR. COCK objecting to this evidence being given, the COMMON SERJEANT ruled that it was not admissibleâ€”that the facts leading up to and included in the prosecution at the Mansion Mouse could not be gone into.)â€”I was present at the Mansion House when Mr. Perryman answered to a summons in my caseâ€”from the time I sent a cheque to the prisoner I have never received anything for it, bar the West Indian. Gold Mining Company.

LAMPTON BEVAN . I am secretary of the Cotton Powder Company, Limited, which manufactures Toniteâ€”the predecessor of that company, carrying on the same business, had been in existence twenty years, with the same works at Favershamâ€”during the twenty years dividends have been paidâ€”in 1890 I applied to Mr. Pulbrook, and instructed him to carry out some alterations in the company's legal constitution; and in pursuance of that a company called the Cotton Powder Company was registeredâ€”Mr. Pulbrook prepared the memorandum and articles of associationâ€”he was paid nothing for doing that, beyond the ordinary professional chargesâ€”the shareholders in the first company exchanged their shares for shares in the new companyâ€”I have the transfersâ€”it was a company limited in the ordinary wayâ€”I have the balance-sheet for. 1890; 14 per cent, was paid on the first preference, 10 per cent, on the second preference, and 5 per cent, on the ordinary sharesâ€”it is not a bogus company.
Cross-examined. This company was registered at the end of 1890â€”we have had a dividend for one yearâ€”Mr. Pulbrook registered the articles of association, and had no other connection with it.

HORACE ANDREWS . I am a member of the bar in Americaâ€”I held the power of attorney of Mr. Bell, who was the owner of the North Mexican Milling and Mining Company's territory, and I came into connection with Mr. Pulbrook in reference to the sale of that territory to the North Mexican Silver Mining Companyâ€”it was arranged that

persons in England subscribing should have the whole of their subscriptions returned before any profits were returned to the vendorâ€”this is a prospectus of the North Mexican Silver Mining Company. (MR. COCK objected to the prospectus being used in evidence; the COMMON SERJEANT ruled that it could not be produced.)â€”the territory alluded to in the North Mexican Silver Mining Company is the same territory now being worked by the North Mexican Milling and Mining Companyâ€”I have been in Mexico, but never. very near this propertyâ€”I have 100 shares in the Milling and Mining Companyâ€”I made inquiries about the company last September or October when I was in Mexicoâ€”this original agreement of the North Mexican Silver Mining Company is signed by me.

Cross-examined. I first came to England in 1882, a year and a half before the Silver Mining Company was floatedâ€”I came over on other businessâ€”I have been going backwards and forwards for the last ten yearsâ€”I have introduced other property on to the English market, that has not been turned into companies that I know ofâ€”this was turned into a companyâ€”Mr. Bell was over here at the time this company was promotedâ€”the money that was raised from the public was raised on debenturesâ€”all the shares went to the vendorâ€”there was nothing to prevent the vendor unloading his shares, except that a certain portion he had to set aside for the subscribers to the debentures, that is for the debenture moneyâ€”independently of the debenture shares, he or his co-promoters had 120,000 Â£1 shares in his hands ready to be put on the market; but a certain portion of the shares he was under obligation to give to certain partiesâ€”Mr. Bell was formerly a judge of the Supreme Court of Texas; at this time he had retired from the bench on account of paralysis of his hand; he is now in Texasâ€”on 30th January, 1884, when this company was registered, he was not doing any businessâ€”he did not come with me when I came firstâ€”he was here when the company was startedâ€”he and I came over for the purpose of turning this company in America into a Joint Stock Companyâ€”I assisted him in doing itâ€”that company liquidatedâ€”I don't know that on the debentures about Â£120 was raised from the public besides the sharesâ€”I had nothing more to do with it after the liquidationâ€”I held shares in the old companyâ€”I never received any dividend on themâ€”I was a shareholder at the time the company was wound up; I had parted with some of my shares; I got nothing for those I held, nor did anybody to my knowledgeâ€”I had, I think, three debentures; I gave them to my sons; they received some interest out of the Â£4,000 originally deposited I think, nothing except thatâ€”so far as I know no person who invested money in that company has ever received a farthing except what came out of the Â£4,000 deposited under the articles of association, and so far as I know not a farthing has been got out of any one of the companies into which this has been developed and changedâ€”I only know from what I have heard to whom the Â£ 100,000 raised on debentures was transferred on liquidationâ€”I think the liquidator was Everingham Smith, in the Cityâ€”when the company was started its office was in Mr. Pulbrook's office.
Re-examined. Mr. Han bury Tracy, M. P., Mr. Lowther, and Mr. Oastler, of Oastler and Palmer, were trustees for the debenture-holders of the North Mexican Mining Company.
The JURY found that the publications were libels; that the libel of August 22nd was true and that of September 5th untrue, and that neither was published

p.hi: said that this amounted to a verdict for the Crown on the plea of Not Guilty, and a verdict for the Crown on the plea of justification.â€”Judgment respited.

div1.p:
216.
JAMES DERBY (42)
, Feloniously wounding
William Shippey, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.
MR. ST. AUBYN Prosecuted,

WILLIAM SHIPPEY . I am a general dealer, of 6, Hampden Street, St. Pancras, and have a pony and trapâ€”I have known the prisoner two years and eight monthsâ€”I have never done him any injury; I have lent him moneyâ€”on 7th December, between three and four p.m., he said, "Halloa, Ship, how are you getting on?"â€”I said "All right, how are you getting on?"â€”he said, "Come and have a look at my ponyâ€”"â€”his stable is next doorâ€”I went and looked at the pony, and he picked up a four-pronged pitchfork and stabbed me with it, sayingâ€”"Take that, you b"â€”it went through my nostril; I bled and fell down, and when I came to I ran to the top of the roadâ€”I was taken to the station, and the doctor attended meâ€”I have never injured the prisoner, or caused dissension between him and his wife.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You did not let me have half of your stableâ€”you did not lend me your pony and barrow all through the winterâ€”I did not pull you down with a broom, nor did you say if I hit you with the broom you would hit me with the pitchfork.

JOHN THOMPSON . I am a surgeon, of 70, Oakley Streetâ€”I attended Shippey; he had two punctured wounds, one half an inch below the lower eyelid, and one right through the cartilage of his nose, but not very deep on account of the boneâ€”I dressed the wounds; one of them might have been very seriousâ€”I sent him home to bed.

FREDERICK COLLINS . I stopped the prisoner, and Shippey charged him with stabbing him with a pitchforkâ€”he said, "Yes, I did do it; and I wish I was bâ€”â€”well out of it; he has tried to ruin me and my wife"â€”this is the pitchfork.
Crofts-examined. You did not say that you could not avoid doing it, you were taking your own part.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, stated that Shippey attached him, and he only acted in self-defence to prevent his being brained.

div1.p:
â€”
GUILTY of unlawfully wounding. Recommended to mercy by the JURY
on account of the provocation. â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

217.
EDWIN SMITH
, Forging and uttering a request for Â£200, with intent to defraud.

JANE GOURLAY . I am married, and live at 105, Harpinger Road South Lambethâ€”in September last I lived at 220, South Lambeth Roadâ€”I received this letter (produced), afterwards from five to seven letters came, addressed W. S. Ashburnham; the defendant called for themâ€”no one of that name lived in the house.
JOHN HOLLAND CROFT . I live at 2, Oakhill Avenueâ€”I desired to

let No. 1, and on September 22nd the prisoner and Le Grand, who has been convicted here (Nee page 77), came, and I agreed to let it at Â£6â€”the prisoner drew up this agreement in my presenceâ€”they each paid half the rent; Le Grand came into occupation on the 23rd with his wife and familyâ€”he was arrested a few days afterwards, and his wife and children remained till I took possessionâ€”the prisoner never returned.

JAMES WEBSTER . I am a turf commission agent, of the Pas de Calaisâ€”on September 4th, 1891, I received this letter enclosing this cheque it is endorsed by a clerk in my service; I paid it in to my account, and received other letters and telegrams, in consequence of which I made certain bets on horse racesâ€”on September 11th I received this letter, and sent a letter to the address given in these other letters, enclosing this cheque for Â£150, which is debited to my account at the bankâ€”it represents the balance due to the persons sending the letter after the transactions I had for him.

FREDERICK GEORGE NETHERCLIFT . I live at 10, Bedford Row, and have been an expert in handwriting for forty-eight years I have compared this agreement, signed Edward Smith, proved to be the prisoner's writing, with this letter of September 3rd; they are written by the same person, and so is Mr. Webster's letter; so are these forged cheques for Â£200 and Â£150.

Cross-examined. I have been engaged in cases in which photographs have been furnished to the jury, so that while I was being examined the jury could view them, and see to what I was alludingâ€”this cheque is dated September 3rd, and in the agreement there is "September 22nd"â€”I do not say that the "p' s"resemble each other, but look at the figure 9 in 1891â€”there is not a resemblance in the "e"â€”there is nothing uncommon in the "t,"only that the dash is made away from the down strokeâ€”the "s' s" are very much alikeâ€”there is no resemblance in the "h"in "two hundred" and the "h"in "furnished house"; but I can find a resemblance in other documentsâ€”numbers of people do not make the "T"like this in "Two hundred" and "To Mr. J. Croft".â€”it is not like a lady makes itâ€”ladies do this kind of thing more than men; I am alluding to anonymous lettersâ€”women write anonymous letters more than men, and in country villages from 150 to 200 per-cent.â€”the "8"in the cheque, is written in a free commercial handâ€”I do not call the prisoner's a commercial hand; the cheque is filled in more carefullyâ€”I do not call the writing of the cheque a disguised writingâ€”I was examined on Le Grand's trialâ€”of all the documents I have examined I do not suggest that any of them are disguised, but some are written more carefully than othersâ€”I said on Le Grand's trial that I saw a most striking similarity in the letter "T"â€”the writing is the same character, only written more carefullyâ€”I was shown a pocket-book; that did not enable me to come to any conclusion as to the writing of the cheque; it came with the other documentsâ€”the only thing I recognised in it was the little "d,"it has a very small turn roundâ€”I do not say it is not often made like that.

Re-examined. I have got my memorandumâ€”the capital "C"in "Croft,"the "S"in "St. James's Square," and the "S"in September, and the final "s,"in which there is just a dash down, and the "M"in "Mr." and in Morgan are all found in the chequeâ€”the original document and the letter to Mrs. Fraser. (The witness pointed out several other

similarities between the original document and the letter to Mrs. Fraser, also between the letter of September 4th and the writing of the cheque. The agreement was read, also the prisoner's letters of 3rd, 4th, and 11th September', 1891.)

WILLIAM ASHBURNHAM . I reside at 30, Dover Street, Piccadillyâ€”I have an account at the St. James's Square branch of the London and Westminster Bankâ€”I sometimes draw cheques similar to those produced; they are obtainable at my club, I only use them thereâ€”the cheque for Â£200, or the two cheques for Â£150 each, or the blank forms, or the letters produced, are none of them signed by me or by my authorityâ€”I think I first became aware of the Â£200 cheque on 28th September; I saw it at the bankâ€”I had no knowledge of the Â£150 cheque, dated in September, until after they were cashed.
Cross-examined. I have never seen the prisoner before, to the best of my beliefâ€”it is known at the club that I use those blank forms; I only use them there.

WILLIAM PETER DENNING . I am one of the cashiers at the St. James's Square branch of the London and Westminster Bankâ€”I paid a cheque for Â£150 across the counter in three Â£50 notes, as directed on back of chequeâ€”Nos. 35658, 59 and 60, 6th January, 1891â€”I believed the signature was W. Ashburnham's at the timeâ€”the cheque for Â£200 came to the bank in the ordinary course of things for the purpose of crediting Mr. Ashburnham's account with it, which we did.
Cross-examined. I cannot identify the prisoner.

CHARLES JOHN WILLIAMS . I am a Note Inspector of the Bank of Englandâ€”I produce notes 35658, 35660, which have bf en returned to the Bank and cancelledâ€”the date is 16th January, 1891, and they are endorsed "J. Devereux."

WILLIAM JAMES (Detective Sergeant D). On 26th September I arrested Le Grand at Maiden Stationâ€”the prisoner was with himâ€”he ran awayâ€”I had no knowledge of these forgeries then, and no authority to arrest himâ€”I took Le Grand to the Police-station, and then searched The Oaklands, Acacia Groveâ€”in a bedroom on the ground floor I saw some clothes, documents, and a portmanteau belonging to Le Grandâ€”I found some documents in a drawer containing clothesâ€”there was an envelope addressed, "The Hon. W. Ashburnham,"containing three documents (produced)â€”one was an unused cheque for Â£200, dated 25th Septemberâ€”in another envelope I found a blank book of forms and some loose forms in the same roomâ€”I got a warrant for the prisoner's arrest somewhere in November, and arrested him a little before 10 p.m. on 12th December in Landor Road, Claphamâ€”Holder was with meâ€”I said, I must arrest you on a charge of forgery"â€”he said, M Very well; I shall not attempt to run away"â€”nothing was found on the prisoner relating to this chargeâ€”his address was searched.

Cross-examined. I was not examined before the Magistrate, but Mr. Moore was; the portmanteau was found in the same roomâ€”they wore undoubtedly all Le Grand's things; I got a warrant for the prisoner the same day as Le Grand was committed for trialâ€”Inspector White received some lettersâ€”we did not make inquiries about anybody in consequence of themâ€”I don't know what he did with themâ€”I knew an expert was engaged in the caseâ€”in one letter two men were mentioned; we made inquiries about them before the prisoner's arrest, but

could not find themâ€”one of them I don't think is living; the other I know is; the letters came by postâ€”I saw them before the prisoner's arrestâ€”the post-mark is "London Mâ€”the prisoner did not tell me he had given information to the policeâ€”perhaps he didâ€”Holder, Hitching, and Gow were the names in the lettersâ€”I found Hitching had been changing a lot of bank-notes, which were undoubtedly the proceeds of these cheques; the prisoner gave certain information about Hitching; some of the notes were cashed in the neighbourhood of Chiswickâ€”the prisoner lived at Kilburn, and was arrested at Clapham; I have only seen the three notes in Mr. Williams's possession that he produced; I do not know if they were paid in at Bedford Park; I have traced about twenty notes, besides the ones Mr. Williams produced; some of them to Hitching; the prisoner has not given any useful information; Le Grand gave no information; the prisoner went quietly to the stationâ€”I had no struggle with Le Grand.
Re-examined. I was at another Police-court when this case was tried before the Magistrate; I had no information about the prisoner's whereabouts up to the time I arrested him.

HENRY MOORE (Police Inspector). I saw the prisoner on 18th December, at Rochester Row Police-court; he said, "My name is Edwin Smith; I gave it as Everard Smith," and when charged he said, "Do I understand I am only charged for the Â£150 cheque?"â€”I said, "That is all at present"â€”he said, "That's all right."

JAMES HOLDER (Detective Officer). I was with Sergeant James when the prisoner was arrestedâ€”we conducted him to his apartmentsâ€”James said we were arresting him for forging a cheque for Â£200â€”he said, "Very well; I will not attempt to run away"â€”at the station Inspector Moore read the charge; all that the prisoner said was said before us both.

Cross-examined. We searched the houseâ€”he made a statement while he was in my charge, which I took down in writing; I have got it here, signed by himâ€”I did not tell him he had assisted the policeâ€”I saw some letters to White purporting to be from the prisonerâ€”I read some of themâ€”I worked with Sergeant James in this matterâ€”we inquired about some people, but not in consequence of those letters.
F. G. NETITERCLIFT (He-examined). The endorsement on the three Â£50 notes is the same writing as that in the agreement; they are written by the same person.
Cross-examined. It was not a woman's writingâ€”I recognise the writingâ€”I compared them with all the documents.

FREDERICK FOX . I am employed at Olympiaâ€”I have known the prisoner about eighteen months; I also know Honbold, alias Morley, and Gow; they are two distinct peopleâ€”in August I had a conversation in the Roebuck, at Chiswick, with Honboldâ€”some time after that I met a friend named Andrews, and we went in the Roebuck and had some refreshment, and I saw Honbold and Gow in the private barâ€”they had some forms similar to these in front of me that they were writing onâ€”there was a book on the counter that looked like a large note-book with "Ashburnham"in gilt on itâ€”Honbold was showing some forms to Gow which were written onâ€”I saw a cheque purporting to be signed by "Ashburnham"â€”I have seen Ashburnham writing before in this publichouse, on the same sort of paper as this; I took the documents to be

receiptsâ€”there was a conversation between them when Honbold was showing them to Gowâ€”I could not pick out the cheque I sawâ€”(a cheque was handed to the witness)â€”the writing was similar to this in every respectâ€”Honbold put them into his pocket when he saw I was lookingâ€”I had a further conversation with him, and afterwards with the prisonerâ€”Andrews is hereâ€”I have not been intimate with the prisonerâ€”I saw Gow about the 16th September.

FREDERICK LUMLEY . I live at 131, Selway Road, Shepherd's Bushâ€”I have met Gow at Chiswickâ€”I went to several places with the prisoner; one place was Short's, in St. Paul's Churchyard; he spent a lot of money, which was in Bank of England notesâ€”I don't know the amountsâ€”he changed six or seven at various places in London.

ALFRED AHRENFELD . I am a lithographic writer, and have been an expert in handwriting for about twenty years at 44, Fleet Streetâ€”I have seen the admitted writing of the prisoner in the agreement to take this houseâ€”I do not think the writing in the agreement is the same as that in the other documents.

Cross-examined. I first saw these documents last Saturday morningâ€”the "91"in the agreement and the "91"in the cheque for Â£200 are very similarâ€”I cannot point out any difference between the two "9's"â€”they are not the same; the "9"in the admitted writing has a flat top, the other has a round topâ€”the "C" in "Croft" and the "0"in "Co"are not the same; the "C"in "Croft"is circular, the "C"in "Co. "is flat; no one could say they were the sameâ€”the "S"in "square" and the "S" in "September"are totally differentâ€”the final "a"in "James"' and the "s"in "months"are similar in formationâ€”one is larger than the other, and the "s"in "months "has a circular topâ€”I of ten see that kind of "s"â€”I gave evidence in this court as an expert about 1885 or 1886â€”the "M"in "Mr." and the "M"in "Maiden"do not resemble each other at allâ€”the letters signed "W. Ashburnham,"to Mrs. Fraser and Mr. Webster slightly resemble the admitted writingâ€”the general character of the writings do not agree; there is no resemblanceâ€”I do not dispute that the "y"in "Surrey" and the "y" in "pay,"in the letter to Mrs. Fraser, are similarâ€”there is no peculiarity in themâ€”I gave evidence in this building four or five years agoâ€”the charge was sending threatening letters and extorting moneyâ€”I gave evidence for the prisoner; he was acquitted on one charge and convicted on anotherâ€”I have given evidence in other courts, but only once before here.
Re-examined. I have often given evidence in courts of justiceâ€”the "9 "in the unuttered cheque of 1891 and the "9 "in the cheque for Â£200 are totally distinct.
WILLIAM JAMES (Police Sergeant, Re-examined). I have been to the Bank of England for the proceeds of two different chequesâ€”the Bank in each case gave me three Â£50 notes.
GUILTY .

The prisoner then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of attempting to obtain Â£150 on a forged cheque in 1889.â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

218.
ANNIE HOWARD (19) was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury, alleged to have been committed upon a charge of rape made by her before F. Mead, Esq., at the Thames Police-court.

p.hi: The details of this case are unfit for publication.

div1.p:
â€”
NOT GUILTY .

219.
JAMES RICHARD THOMAS (29)
, Unlawfully omitting certain material particulars from a cash-book of his employer, with intent to defraud.

MESSRS. C. MATTHEWS and BODKIN Prosecuted, and MR. GLENN Defended. GEORGE LOUIS COLLINS. I was a draper's manager, at 225, Amhurst Road, Hackney, but have leftâ€”I have known the defendant about two yearsâ€”about eighteen months ago or more I met him in the City, and told him I was thinking of starting in the coal trade; he said he was the manager of a coal company, and could supply me with coalâ€”I arranged to have a commission on the coal that was sold, which could hardly be called a partnershipâ€”I took an office at Neville Road, Stoke Newington, in the name of "G. L. Collins and Co., Coal Merchants and Contractors"â€”some advertisements of this kind were prepared. (A card model of a coal cart.)â€”I continued in possession of the premises five week she got some orders, and so did Iâ€”I sent them to the Seaborne Coal Company, who executed the orders, as I had no carmen or vansâ€”I have nothing to do with ordering the coal to be loaded, that was done by the companyâ€”it never came to profit; I was to be paid by commission on the coal sold by both of usâ€”we were each to have a commissionâ€”the orders which I procured were executed, and the carmen of the Seaborne Company received the moneyâ€”I handed the prisoner the money I receivedâ€”about ten tons of coal were supplied to my orderâ€”after four or five weeks I suggested to Thomas that it would not pay me, and I had better have done with itâ€”I had paid the rent of the office, 6s. a week, and got no returnâ€”I went to the landlord; Thomas became the tenant, and I leftâ€”this letter of 23rd July, 1890, to me, was written by the prisoner. (This stated that the witness's interest in the business would cease from that day.)â€”I assented to thatâ€”I also ordered coal from the Seaborne Company for my private purposes, and in September, 1891, lowed them Â£15 2s. 3d.; I received the account on 2nd October, 1891, and paid Thomas that day Â£9 2s. by this cheque (produced), Â£6 in gold, and threepenceâ€”the cheque is stamped by the London and Westminster Bank, and endorsed "R. Thomas"â€”I did not know that Thomas had an account at that bankâ€”I received this receipt (produced)â€”I did not owe the Seaborne Company Â£33 16s. 4d. in October, 1890, or any money whatever; I entirely cleared my indebtedness by the payment of the Â£15.

Cross-examined. I canvassed for orders, and sent them up addressed sometimes to Thomas and sometimes to the Seaborne Coal Company; they were executed by the Seaborne Coal Company on their own consignment notes, and I was to have a commissionâ€”the people did not all pay the carman when they got the coal; some did.
Re-examined. I sent the company about a dozen orders during the five weeks I was in the business.

GEORGE HARRIS . I am a greengrocer, of 11 1/2, Greycoat Place, Westminsterâ€”I have given the defendant orders for coal; I paid him Â£2 4s. on 11th May, 1891, for coal supplied to me from the wharf, and got these receipts in returnâ€”this receipt is signed J. R. Thomasâ€”on 9th June I paid him personally Â£1 2s. for a further quantity of coal, and he signed this receipt.

Cross-examined. I was in the habit of going there to pay the money, hut on these occasions he came to meâ€”he did not come to me for ordersâ€”the money was taken through to an office at the back; the safe is at the back.

JOHN BALKER DAWSON . I am a licensed victualler, of 58, Grosvenor Road, nearly opposite the wharfâ€”I got coal there occasionally, and gave the order to Mr. Thomasâ€”on May 22nd and 23rd I received coal from the wharf, and paid Mr. Thomas 11s. 6d. and Â£2 17s. for it in cashâ€”he signed these two receipts (produced)â€”I think I sent it over to the officeâ€”I paid one amount over my own counter.

JOSEPH GARD . I am a coal dealer, of 11, Horseferry Roadâ€”I have been in the habit of receiving coal at Parliament Wharfâ€”I ordered it of the defendant or his clerkâ€”on June 8 I owed the Seaborne Company three sums of Â£1 11s. 6d., each, and paid Mr. Thomas in cash, and got these receipts in return.

LAURENCE MCKIE . I am a coal dealer, of 1, Douglas Street, Westminsterâ€”I have ordered coal at Parliament Wharf of Mr. Thomas and his clerkâ€”I received two tons of coal, value Â£2 17s., on 22nd Juneâ€”I or my son or daughter paid it, and got this receiptâ€”on July 1st I paid Â£4 15s. for a further lot of coal; this is the receipt.
RICHARD EDWARD LANTON : I am assistant cashier to Messrs. Watney, of the Stag Breweryâ€”they paid Â£2 4s. for coal in August lastâ€”this is the receipt (produced).

FREDERICK JOSEPH HANCOCK . I am an undertaker, of 10, Neville Street, Stoke Newingtonâ€”I let off part of my shop to Mr. Collins at 6s. a week as a coal agentâ€”he continued my tenant four or five weeksâ€”the name of Collins was put upâ€”I saw the prisoner there once or twice, and he became my tenant after Collins left, but Collins's name was kept upâ€”in November, 1891,1 got back the keys of the premisesâ€”the prisoner paid me about Â£5 rent in the twenty weeksâ€”there was no written agreement; nobody represented Thomas at the office that I know ofâ€”we took charge of the lettersâ€”the office was locked up all day long, and the blind down in Mr. Collins's time.

SIDNEY HILL . I am a clerk at the Vauxhall branch of the London and South Western Bankâ€”I produce a copy of the prisoner's banking"account, which I have examined with the original entries in the bank booksâ€”I also produce an affidavit of Mr. Henry Christie, the manager, which verifies the copy, and a certificate from Somerset House certifying that we have furnished a list and summary under the Companies Actâ€”on October 3rd, 1891, Â£15 2s. is credited to the accountâ€”I made the entry in the waste-book; it is not hereâ€”I did not receive the Â£15 2s.â€”I made the entry from the credit slip, which is written by the customerâ€”the credit slips are keptâ€”I have never seen this cheque of 2nd October for Â£9 2s. before, to my knowledgeâ€”it has the stamp of the London, and
South Western Bank on itâ€”it seems to have been paid into the prisoner's accountâ€”the endorsement is his writing. (The Witness was sent to fetch the waste-boo I and paying-in slip.)

GEORGE RICHARD BULLEX . I am general manager to Mr. John Edey, coal merchant, 16, East cheap, who has wharves in many parts of London; he has the Parliament Wharf, Grosvenor Road, Pimlico, which is carried on under the style of the Seaborne Coal Companyâ€”in June, 1890, when he acquired that wharf, the prisoner was manager of it, at Â£2 a week; after which the prisoner continued as manager, at the same salary, to 17th November, 1891â€”his duty was to keep the books of the wharf, a cash-book and ledgerâ€”he had also to collect moneys and give receipts for money collected, and forward such money to the head office in Eastcheap weekly, from June to the end of 1890â€”at the beginning of 1891 the prisoner was told to keep weekly sheets in addition to cash-book and ledger; he was provided with themâ€”he had to enter on them such coal as had been sold on credit and for cash during the week, and such cash payments as had been made by the persons to whom originally coal had been sold on creditâ€”he had to return it with an account of the outgoings for the week attached to itâ€”he would deduct the outgoings from the receipts, strike the balance, and return the balance so struck to his employerâ€”I had no notion that, in the name of Collins, the prisoner was occupying premises where a coal agency had been established, at 10, Neville Road, Stoke Newington, during this timeâ€”I knew he had a private banking account, because during 1888 I gave a reference for it to be opened, but I had forgotten the factâ€”I have no knowledge of the amounts the prisoner was paying into his private banking account from January to November, 1891â€”he had no authority to endorse chequesâ€”his duty with regard to cheques drawn to the order of the Seaborne Coal Company was to forward the cheques themselves; he was not authorised to deal with them in any way, or to sign in the name of the firm for themâ€”I am general manager to Mr. Edey at East cheapâ€”Parliament Wharf was under my jurisdiction; I had to visit it and see how things were going on there, and in that way I came into personal relationship with the prisoner from time to time, and to me these accounts and things came forwardâ€”Mr. Edey is largely employed elsewhere than in London; he has over 1,000 clerks in his employmentâ€”the prisoner had no authority to have cheques made out in his own name for coal supplied by the Seaborne Coal Companyâ€”a cheque drawn to the prisoner he should have sent on to the head office, with the cash balance at the weekly intervalsâ€”in the meantime there was a safe in the office where he could put valuables and cheques till the end of the week, when he would bring them himself, or sometimes they would be collected from himâ€”from the beginning of 1891 he sent forward regularly, from week to week, the weekly cash-sheetsâ€”on the cash-sheet of 16th May, 1891, there is no entry of Â£2 4s. received from Mr. Harris on 11th Mayâ€”I find payments of 10s. 6d. from Marsh, and Â£1 1s. from Lawlorâ€”I find no entry of Harris's Â£2 4s. in the cash-book or in the ledger; nor any entry in the cash-sheet of 23rd May of 11s. 6d. or Â£2 17s. received from Mr. Dawson on 23rd Mayâ€”sums appear as small as 11s. from Jones, 10s. 6d. from Rowlands, and 5s. 3d.â€”there is no entry in the cash-sheet or ledger of the 11s. 6d. or Â£2 17s.â€”in the cash-sheet of 13th June there is no entry of two sums of Â£1 11s. 6d. each, paid by Mr. Gerardâ€”there

are entries of sums as small as 4s. 9d. from Sidler, and 10s. from Rutherford; and there are only two sums on the sheet which exceed in amount Â£1 11s. 6d.â€”I do not find on this cash-sheet, either, Â£1 2s. paid by Mr. Harrisâ€”I find no entry in the cash-book or ledger of the two sums of Â£1118. 6d. or of the Â£1 2s.â€”there is no entry in the cash-sheet of 27th June of Â£2 17s. from Mr. M'Kay on 22nd June; all the sums in the sheet, except one, are small amounts, such as Chamberlain 10s. 6d., Francis 10s., Rowland Collins 5s.; the highest is Â£1 1s. 6d.â€”there is no entry in the cash-book or ledger of the Â£2 17s.â€”there is no entry of Â£4 15s. from M'Kay on 1st July in the cash-sheet of 4th July, nor in the cash-book or ledgerâ€”there, is an entry on June 12th of Â£2 18s. 6d., and on June 7th of Â£2 17s.; there is no subsequent entry of Â£4, or any sum near itâ€”there is no entry of Â£2 4s. on 17th August from Mrs. Watney, in the cash-sheet of 22nd August; nor in the cashbook or ledgerâ€”I find smaller sums in that cash-sheetâ€”there is no entry of Â£15 2s. 3d. on 3rd October from Mr. Collins, in the cash-sheet, cash-book, or ledgerâ€”the largest sum in that cash-sheet is Â£15 from Chambers, and there is a separate receipt for that; I have seen both Chambers' and Collins' receiptsâ€”I had no notion that on 3rd October Â£15 2s. had been paid by the prisoner into his own private accountâ€”Collins' ledger account, after 2nd October, showed that he was indebted to the Seaborne Coal Company Â£81 9s. 4d.â€”when that entry was first discovered that was believed to be a genuine debt, and we applied to Collins for payment of it, and we had from him this receipt of 2nd October, showing that on that day lie had paid for everything that had been supplied to him by the companyâ€”there is no record in the journal or any book of Â£15 2s. 3d.â€”the receipt did not turn up till after the prisoner was arrestedâ€”on account of entries in the journal we applied to customers for payment of their accounts before 2nd October; they objected that they had already paid, and produced receipts, and that caused the first investigation into the matterâ€”I and Mr. Edey were present on 17th November, when the prisoner came to 16, East cheap, to make explanation and give account (Mr. Edey has an attack of influenza, and is unable to get out)â€”Mr. Hall, the solicitor, asked the prisoner what explanation he could give as to these deficiencies, and he said he could give no explanationâ€”he was given into custodyâ€”the cash-sheets are all in the prisoner's writingâ€”these nine receipts and the letter to Collins, of 23rd July, 1890, are in his, writing-subsequent to his arrest I went with Mr. Edey to Parliament Wharf, and found a book of paying-in slips, which caused us to make inquiry at the London and South-Western Bank.
By the JURY. I have not the delivery notes showing where the Â£81 worth of coal went to.

Cross-examined. There is an order-book in which all orders, as given, were entered by the prisoner, or whoever was in the office to receive the orderâ€”the accounts appear in the ledger, but not the receipt in these cases; thus, Harris's order for coal, amounting to Â£2 17s. 2d., appears in the ledgerâ€”in every case it would appear in the books in the prisoner's writing that the man had had the coal and owed the money; and the entry of the money having been paid does not appearâ€”that applies to all except Collinsâ€”we found out that these amounts had not been paid, by writing round to people whose names appeared in the book as

debtorsâ€”it is customary to write from time to time to persons whose names appear in the books; I don't think it is customary to send a circular asking if they owe the money; I have not done thatâ€”I and Mr. Edey had access to the books at all times when we asked for themâ€”this wharf originally belonged to the Metropolitan Coal Association; I was manager under them of another wharfâ€”in November, 1889, the prisoner was employed at this wharf, I thinkâ€”it belonged to the Metropolitan Coal Association, and the Seaborne Coal Company had its name up thereâ€”I had the superintendence of the horses at the prisoner's branch then; I don't know that there was any friction between usâ€”after Mr. Edey purchased the business my name was struck off the bills, at his requestâ€”the time Mr. Neville and Mr. Sheriff were general managers of the Seaborne Company was so short that I can scarcely remember what was done thenâ€”Mr. Edey took over the business in June, 1890; the prisoner had been there from November, 1889; but for nine months of that time the business was in the liquidator's handsâ€”I don't remember any misunderstanding about Scrivenerâ€”the Block Fuel Company rented part of the wharf; they paid Â£100 a year rent, and were to have storage room, and the prisoner was paid 10s. a week extra for keeping their booksâ€”he had to keep the other company's books as well, and to attend to the office work of the Block Fuel business, they had a man to do the outside businessâ€”I do not think that the prisoner had a good deal to do thereâ€”he had to go out and collect accountsâ€”he went and canvassed for orders when he collected the accounts; he was not forced to canvass, but it was part of his dutyâ€”he had to overlook all the men; he did not superintend the weighingâ€”he did not make out all the accounts; the head clerk in the office did that; it was part of the office workâ€”during a short period of the time he had to hire bargesâ€”the early part of the time that Edey had the Seaborne business the prisoner had to see to it and superintended the unloading of vesselsâ€”two trolleys were sent out to sell coal in the streets by retail, and they were under the prisoner's superintendenceâ€”he complained once or twice that he was overworked, and wanted more assistance; he only had a lad in the office to help himâ€”I am not aware that at one time he had to pay for extra work himselfâ€”I swear I did not know that he was dabbling in coal himselfâ€”he gave me no explanation as to Collins and Co., or as to the Â£81â€”he did not give me the names of persons who owed money to Collins and Co.â€”he did not tell me that the accounts headed Collins and Co. were for coals sold on commission to different people; he told me just previous to his arrest that there were two others in the account, Carr and Holtâ€”the prisoner was not constantly seeing Edeyâ€”sometimes he received several letters a week from himâ€”the prisoner came to the City once a week, but he did not always see Edeyâ€”he might have come more than once a week sometimesâ€”he has discussed business with Mr. Edey on about two occasionsâ€”I have not heard from Mr. Edey, and do not know if he told him about the customers that owed money to Collins and Co.â€”I asked Mr. Edey if he took down from the prisoner the names and addresses of all the persons who owed Collins and Co. money; he said noâ€”I don't know if there are letters from the prisoner to Mr. Edey asking for assistanceâ€”the solicitor has letters which I have looked through, I have not read them allâ€”he told he wanted more assistance there, and he complained to Mr. Edeyâ€”at the end of the financial year, in June, 1891,

there was a general settlement of accounts, and Mr. Edey complained to the prisoner of numerous mistakes in the books; the prisoner said something to the effect that he was overworked, and the books were not as regularly kept as they ought to have beenâ€”Mr. Edey was an accountant; his clerks investigated the booksâ€”I introduced the prisoner to this bank to open an account thereâ€”I did not do it because money payments had to be made on account primarily of the Block Fuel Company, and afterwards of the Coal Association that had to be made by chequeâ€”he did not tell me that persons who supplied goods to the Block Fuel Company wanted to be paid by cheque, and would not take cash, and that he wanted an account for that purposeâ€”he said it was for a private accountâ€”M'Sibbing deals in coalâ€”he supplied two or three lots to the wharf during 1890, when the company was short of coalâ€”it was not supplied to the prisoner personally that I am aware ofâ€”he paid for them out of the company's moneyâ€”I do not know that they were paid for by a cheque on this accountâ€”when the prisoner was away only a lad would be at the office, and payments would be made to him by persons who came in to pay accountsâ€”I do not know that two wooden bowls were kept there, one for the Block Fuel and the other for the Coal Company; I did not say at the Mansion House that I knew it, but that it was contrary to my instructionsâ€”I don't think I ever saw the wooden bowls; my memory is a blank about itâ€”a rough cash-book was kept by the lad, who entered moneys he received, and they would be posted up from thatâ€”an omission in the rough cash-book would not find its way into the other books, unless it was thought ofâ€”the rough cash-book was kept contrary to my instructionsâ€”we had no bowl for money at our own wharf, and only the boy kept a rough cash-bookâ€”a lad named Howard, who had been at the wharf, left about March, 1891â€”I do not remember a number of accounts being afterwards found which Howard had not entered upâ€”I know of no complaints being made by the secretary of the Block Fuel Company shortly before June, 1891; it was done directly between the Block Fuel Company and the prisonerâ€”I believe the prisoner mentioned it to Mr. Edey in my presenceâ€”he did not say to the effect that he had no time to keep the books properly, that the Block Fuel orders could not be executed because he had no time to attend to them, and he must give up the Block Fuel business unless he had further helpâ€”Mr. Edey had no interest in the Block Fuel Company except that they paid him Â£100 a-year for the use of the wharfâ€”I believe Mr. Edey then came to see if he could use the whole wharf if the Block Fuel people wentâ€”I believe it was suggested that the prisoner must give up the Block Fuel business if he could not have more assistanceâ€”I believe Herman was sent from another wharf for two or three daysâ€”in January, 1891, a return was asked for but never receivedâ€”Mr. Edey sent the prisoner Â£5 5s; I did not see the accompanying letterâ€”the business had increased during the winter months; it was a new business, and would naturally increase.

Re-examined. It was after an investigation that the weekly sheets were institutedâ€”it was the prisoner's duty every week to bring his cash and his sheetsâ€”he would generally see me because Mr. Edey was not thereâ€”the Block Fuel Company went into liquidation, and gave up possession of the place about April, 1891â€”his complaint of too much to do was listened to, and remedied by the lad Howard being taken away

and one of his own relatives (Mr. Wearn), 18 or 19 years old, being given to himâ€”he did not complain any furtherâ€”the rough cash-book was not authorised; it was not with the set of books in the business; it related to payments received by the lad in the officeâ€”there might hare been an entry or two of money received by the prisoner, but nothing of any account; it was kept by the ladâ€”I have seen Mr. Holtâ€”the payments to Mr. M'Sibbing for one, two, or three lots of coal would come to something under Â£100; it was in 1890.

THOMAS WILLIAM HALL . I am solicitor to Mr. Edey, who is unable to be here to-day through influenza and bronchitis; I have a certificate to that effectâ€”he was here five or six days agoâ€”on 16th November, when the prisoner was present, Mr. Edey said to me, "I should like you just to speak to Mr. Thomas"â€”I said, "What explanation have You to give of this case? let us take the first one," and I took them one after the otherâ€”the prisoner turned to the accounts and the books and said, "I can give no explanation; I don't think the customers can have the receipts"â€”I said it would be necessary to give him into custody, and he was so givenâ€”he said to Mr. Edey, Is there no other Way out of this?"â€”Mr. Edey replied "No. "

Cross-examined. The prisoner did not ask to be allowed to examine the books and materials at the wharf, nor say he could not explain without doing soâ€”the prisoner and Mr. Bullen were left alone; with that exception I was present at the whole interviewâ€”when I got there I found him in the waiting-room; I cannot say if he had been with Mr. Edey beforeâ€”he opened the ledger and cash-book at various dates.
SYDNEY HILL (Re-examined). I have now got the waste-book containing entries in my handwriting with reference to the items of the cash payment of Â£15 on 3rd October.

THOMAS FULLER . I was cashier on 3rd October, 1891, at the London and South Western Bank, Vauxhallâ€”this paying-in slip was brought to me on that day; it is in favour of James R. Thomas; acting on it, Â£15 2s. was placed to the credit of the prisoner's accountâ€”it was paid by cheque for Â£9 2s. and cash Â£6.

SYDNEY HILL (Re-examined). The credit entry of Â£15 2s. was carried to the prisoner's credit on 3rd October, by Â£6 money and a cheque for Â£9 2s. on the London and Provincial Bank, Kingsland, drawn by Collinsâ€”in the ordinary course the customer would make up this slip.
WILLIAM HENRY WEARN . I am the prisoner's cousin, and was employed under him at this wharfâ€”this slip of 3rd October, 1891,1 wrote under his instructions.

Cross-examined. I am twenty-oneâ€”I went to the office about the middle of Julyâ€”the prisoner complained that he had more work than he could get through in the course of the dayâ€”I had to stay late with him after office hours from time to time to complete the workâ€”I do not remember a bundle of delivery tickets, for coal drawn from other wharves, that had been left by Howard being discoveredâ€”I had to make entries from a bundle of delivery tickets; I was there late that night and early next morning with the prisoner; the books were a lot behind when I went there, and I had to enter them upâ€”the system was to keep a rough cash-book, whoever was in the office, and the prisoner made up his book from the rough cash-bookâ€”money taken was put into wooden bowlsâ€”the office could only be entered by travellers and others

employed by the firmâ€”there is a swing door into the office where the safe is; if anybody came in, we should ask them what they wantedâ€”people can walk through to the wharf and then into the office where safe and bowls are keptâ€”I went to Mr. Holt once to ask if he had collected some money from customers of Collins and Co., and if he would call and see the prisoner; I did not bring back any money.

Re-examined. I went to Holt, on the prisoner's instructions, to ask him to come and see the prisoner in relation to coals said to have been supplied to Collins and Co., the money for which was outstandingâ€”Holt afterwards came, but did not see the prisonerâ€”it was the duty of whoever received any sum to enter it in the rough cash-book, and put the money in the bowl, which would be placed in the safe at nightâ€”ordinary care was taken with regard to the money, and in entries made in the bookâ€”usually the person who received the money entered it, or it was handed over to the prisoner if he were thereâ€”if I was there, I used to enter it; if the prisoner were there, he would enter it, or hand it to me to enterâ€”there should have been the entry of every sum in the bookâ€”the bundle"of delivery notes was when I first went there in Julyâ€”the Block Fuel Company had then for some time ceased to exist.

ROBERT WALKER . I was formerly clerk to the Block Fuel Syndicate, Limitedâ€”this wharf was one of their branchesâ€”they went into liquidation on March 25, 1891; they carried on business at the wharf up to 3rd or 10th April last year.

Cross-examined. The prisoner settled up the accounts by about 25th April by paying about 5s., and any accounts outstanding then were collected from the City office; the accounts were supposed to be settled each week. He-examined. April 25th was the last day he was concerned in this matter.

JOHN DAVEY . I am a yard foreman at Parliament Wharfâ€”the prisoner was there as managerâ€”I don't remember his private address; he told me to send the coals up there to his house, and said "Call at my house for the delivery tickets"â€”his house was up north, the other side of Hollowayâ€”I did not go thereâ€”he very often told me to send coals thereâ€”sometimes he would bring delivery tickets to send with them in the name of Mr. Collinsâ€”if he did not bring the tickets I used to have a slip of paper, which he left on the clerk's desk, to take with them; some of the slips were in his writing, and some in the clerk's, I believeâ€”the delivery tickets were not the printed tickets of the Seaborne Coal Companyâ€”I suppose it went on for nearly twelve monthsâ€”the house was somewhere in Dalstonâ€”I said I thought it was not quite right without tickets; he said, "It will be all right; send them up with my orders."
By the JURY. The prisoner was in the habit of sending away coals with slips of paper made out in his writing, and not with printed official forms of the Seaborne Company.

Cross-examined. A great many times we did not have the slips back signed; it was only when we took them to Collins that we used to have them backâ€”the slips were to send up to his houseâ€”I don't know where the coals went toâ€”I cannot give the name of anybody to whom they were sent in this way except Collinsâ€”the carman would not bring the slips backâ€”the coals were taken up to his house, and he would give them
orders where to take them toâ€”the slips were nothing more than his name and address, and only his name on someâ€”the carman did not provide himself with an ordinary form before he started.

EDWARD WINDER (85 City). On 17th November the prisoner was given into my custody by Mr. Bullen, to whom he said, "Is there no other course but this?"â€”Mr. Bullen said, "I can see no other course"â€”in answer to the charge at the station he said, "I have nothing more to say than I have already stated to Mr. Bullen. "

p.hi: The prisoner in his statement before the Magistrate said that if, in answer to hit request at various times, matters had been properly looked into, no facts to support the charge could have been discovered.

div1.p: Evidence for the Defence,

JOHN MCKIBBIN . I am a coal porter, of Arthur Road, Brixtonâ€”between September, 1890, and February, 1891,1 sent coal to the defendant and he paid me with these cheques (produced)â€”I think he was in an average way of business, he and a clerk and a manager were in the yardâ€”I think latterly the staff was insufficient to cope with the business, when the younger one went in I think he was short-handedâ€”this coal would represent about Â£190, about 350 tonsâ€”it was delivered to a barge at the wharf.

JOHN FISHAN . I am assistant officer of the high bailiff of the Shoreditch County Courtâ€”there is a judgment against the defendant obtained in October for Â£3 16s. 6d., it is still unsatisfiedâ€”I received a judgment on February 25th, 1891, at the suit of the London and Westminster Loan Company; the high bailiff returned it to the Court; I do not know whether it has been satisfied, it has not been paid to usâ€”he has not gone to gaol for it.
Cross-examined. I did not know that he had a private banking account into which he was paying money, or that he paid in Â£15 2s. on October 3rdâ€”I could not meet with him.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

220.
HENRY CORY (17)
, Unlawfully attempting to carnally know
Edith Menlove, aged ten years. Second Count, for an indecent assault.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY
on the Second Count. â€”
Six Months' without Hard Labour; being paralysed.

221.
WALTER HENRY COUTTS (19)
, Stealing a cap, gown, hood, and bag, the goods of
Henry Moore Bleeby.

HENRY MOORE BLEEBY . I am a "lieutenant"in the Salvation "Army"; I am a B.A.(Lond.)â€”I was slightly acquainted with the prisoner at the beginning of Decemberâ€”on 29th December he stated that he was from South Africa, and was a Bachelor of Cape Town University, and a nephew of Baroness Burdett-Coutts and Sir Gordon Spriggs, and asked me if I would lend him my robes to be photo
graphed

in, as they were somewhat similar to hisâ€”I lent him my cape, gown, hood, and a bag to take them inâ€”he said he was to be married on 8th January, and return to South Africa on 9thâ€”he should have returned my things on 31st Decemberâ€”I found he was not related to the Baroness, and was not what he had stated; and I went to his lodgings on the 30th and found the things thereâ€”I asked him what he meant by the deception he had carried on; he said there were my things, that I could take themâ€”they are worth about Â£5â€”the prisoner has nothing to do with the Salvation "Army"; he is a grocer's assistant I found.

WILLIAM BUTTERFIELD . I am a wine porter, of 4, Trafalgar Road, Haggerstoneâ€”about 12.50 on 30th December I was in Fleet Street, standing out of the rain, when the prisoner, who had two parcels, said, "It was not like this in Australia"â€”I had never seen him beforeâ€”I asked him what part of Australia he came from; he said "Sydney"â€”a few seconds afterwards he asked me whether I could show him a pawnshopâ€”I told him there was one in Fleet Street, on the right-hand side, and I went with him there; it was full of people, and he did not go in then we went on to Fore Street, I carrying the parcel of books and the prisoner the other parcel; he asked me to go, and said he would pay meâ€”he said the parcel he was carrying was a clerical robe and hat; that he had only been over here three weeks, and that he was going to pawn them; he wanted Â£3 on them, as he owed his landlord Â£2 15s. for board and lodgingsâ€”he took the parcel of books from me and took that and the other parcel into the pawnshopâ€”I did not go inâ€”he came out in about ten minutes with both parcels, and said the pawnbroker said they were no good to himâ€”he asked me if I knew a bookseller's; he would try to sell the booksâ€”we went to two bookseller's, but did no businessâ€”then he mentioned the name of the Rev. Mr. McKay, and said he knew himâ€”the two booksellers and myself advised him to go to Mr. McKay and get assistance from him if his story was trueâ€”he thought Mr. McKay was going to advance money on the robeâ€”then he tried another pawnbroker's in the Kingsland Road; he came out and said, "They only offered me Â£1 for the robe, I wanted Â£2"â€”then we went to Mr. McKay'sâ€”I did not go with him into either of the two pawnbroker's.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You said you would pay meâ€”I did not say I would take you to a bookseller's.
Re-examined. I was with him from 12.45 till he was taken into custody, through Mr. McKay, about five o'clockâ€”he did not pay me.

GEORGE PETER MCKAY . I am a Baptist minister, of the Manse, Watford Roadâ€”I first saw the prisoner on 30th December, when he came to my house and said he was lodging at the house of one of the members of the church of which I am pastor, and he was in temporary difficulties, because he had come from South Africa, his people being very wealthy people there, and he having passed his B. A. degree, they were anxious he should have a holiday; that at Southampton he had lost his bag, with Â£40, and the people with whom he had been lodging for ten days or a fortnight naturally wanted the money; that he had been to his father's bankers in the City, and they had cabled to Cape Town, but while he was waiting he was in financial difficulties, and he desired me to give him a letter to the people with whom he was lodging requesting them to keep him for a week or so until his money did comeâ€”I said, "I cannot do so unless I know more about you"â€”he said he had with him

his cap and gown belonging to the B.
