A. degree, and those he offered to leave with me as security, if I was in any way security for him, or he would leave them with the people with whom he was stayingâ€”I said I should go to the house with himâ€”he said he was willing; and I went to the house with himâ€”on the way I made various inquiries of him as to his people; he said his father was very wealthy, and had been three times Mayor of Cape Town, and asked me if I knew Sir Gordon Spriggs, and other peopleâ€”I went into the prisoner's room at his lodgingsâ€”he asked me to wait a moment, and he came back in one or two minutes saying it was all right; that while he had been out a letter had come from his father's bankers to the effect that they had had a reply, and that he might go tomorrow and obtain the moneyâ€”I said, "Perhaps you will kindly show me the letter?"â€”he said he would, and left the room, and in a few minutes returned with a pencil note, which he carefully doubled over, showing me only a portion, and I found that was a request for him to call at an address in Ludgate Hillâ€”I said this was no letter such as he had given me to understand he had receivedâ€”I began to turn it over, and he said he could not show me that, and made a snatch at it, and it was tornâ€”I afterwards looked at the part I had in my hand, and found it was a request for him to call, lest a charge of obtaining money by false pretences should be preferred against himâ€”he had told me he had a number of books which he was willing to leave with me, as well as the cap and gownâ€”when I had seen the books, I communicated with the policeâ€”he gave me to understand that the cap and gown were his own property, and he wished to leave them with me as security.

WILLIAM WRIGHT (Detective N). Clover brought the prisoner to the stationâ€”when the charge of stealing this cap and gown was read to him, he said, "I did not steal the books nor the gown"â€”Clover is ill.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence said that he did not intend to steal the things but meant to redeem them when his people sent his money.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour. There was another indictment against the prisoner for stealing the books.

222.
ANNA MARGARETTA FLUGEL, alias
REESE
, Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences two dresses and other goods from
Peter Robinson, and other goods from
Thomas Wallis and Co. by false pretences. Other Counts, For conspiracy with other persons.

FRANK CROCOMBE . I am assistant to Messrs. Wallis and Co., of Holborn Circusâ€”on 21st November, between eleven and twelve midday, the prisoner came into my department and wanted to be shown some dresses; she said she was commissioned by Mr. Mikschik to purchase a dress for his wife; she presented this card, "Mr. J. E. Mikschik, engineer and artist, 41, Finsbury Pavement, London, E. C. "; she said the things were to be sent to 28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch End; I wrote the address on this piece of paper; she selected a dress, and also a black Jersey bodiceâ€”I

made out this invoice for Â£3 12s.â€”she said the goods would be paid for on deliveryâ€”I put them into a box and sent it down to the parcel officeâ€”about twenty minutes afterwards Miss Barnard, an assistant in another department, handed me this paper, "Mr. Mikschik, 28, Glaslyn Road, mantle, Â£5 19s. 6d. "; I took the prisoner to Miss Barnardâ€”I did not rive credit: the goods were sold for ready money, to be paid for on delivery;. this cheque for Â£17 2s. 11d. was brought back by the porter who took the goods; it went to our bankers in due course, and came back endorse "Account closed."

ADELA MARCHANT . I am an assistant to Messrs. Wallisâ€”on 21st November the prisoner was brought to my department by Mass Barnard; she said she wanted a hat; she selected one, and said it was for a gentleman for his wife; the price was Â£1 3s. 9d.â€”she said she wanted ft tent with some other goods that she had bought at our establishment; he showed me a card, with an address upon it; I wrote the address in her presence, "Mr. Mikschik, 28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch Endâ€”I made out an invoice; this is itâ€”she said the goods were to be paid for on delivery; she said she wanted a coat for a little child, and I took her to another department.

CLARA MARY LETHEREN . I am an assistant to Messrs. Wallis & Coâ€”on 21st November the prisoner was brought to me by Miss Marchant; she purchased various goods and all sorts of underlinen for a lady, and a costume for a childâ€”she gave the address on a card, when I wrote on a piece of paper (as before), the articles came to Â£6 7s. 8 1/2 d.; she said the goods were to be paid for on deliveryâ€”I gave the goods and the bill to Mr. Crocombe.

Cross-examined. I parted with the goods because I thought they were to be paid for on deliveryâ€”I was told a gentleman would pay for them, by a chequeâ€”we invariably send goods to be paid for on delivery.

CECIL AUST . I am a porter to Wallis & Co.â€”on Saturday, 21st November, I received a parcel addressed to Mr. Mikschik, 28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch End; also an envelope enclosing the billsâ€”I went with them to that address; I knocked at the door; it was opened by a man he told me to take the parcel into the houseâ€”I went into a room and saw a woman and a little childâ€”the man and woman spoke to each otherâ€”the man gave me this cheque for Â£17 odd, and I left the goodsâ€”the prisoner is not the woman I sawâ€”on the Monday I handed the cheque to the cashierâ€”the man went out of the room and I brought back the chequeâ€”the figure 7 was a little wet.

Cross-examined. I did not see the prisoner thereâ€”when the man opened the door I said, "Is this Mr. Mikschik?"he said, "Yesâ€”he did not say, "I am Mr. Mikschik"â€”I said I had some clothes from Wallis's, and he said, "Come in, please. "

HILDA GAUSTER . I am an assistant at Peter Robinson'sâ€”on November, about two o'clock, the prisoner was brought into my department by another assistantâ€”the prisoner spoke to me Germanâ€”I am of German nationalityâ€”she said, "I am commissioned by a gentleman friend to buy a costume for his wife as a birthday present, and she selected one at seven guineasâ€”when she first came in she asked me if I recollected serving her about twelve months agoâ€”I said, No, as I see so many people in the course of the day"â€”she then said she wanted better dress, and she selected one at thirteen guineasâ€”the body ol the

first dress was not made up, and she said she would buy a jersey to wear whilst the body was madeâ€”I then took her into the mantle departmentâ€”on the way there she said the gentleman could well afford to make a handsome present, because the lady was bringing him a fortune, 25,000 something, either pounds or marksâ€”she selected a mantle at four guineas, and then a fur mackintosh at 31s. 6d., a hat for three guineas, an umbrella for Â£ 8s. 6d., and sundry other articles, making Â£41 10s. 8d.â€”I made out these two billsâ€”these (produced) are the umbrella, the dress, the mantle, and petticoat I sold herâ€”all the other articles I have since seen at the pawnbroker'sâ€”she gave me a card, and I copied the address on this other card, "Mr. J. E. Mikschik, Engineer and Artist, 41, Finsbury Pavement, E. C."â€”she also showed me a private card, with "28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch End,"on it, and I copied it in pencilâ€”she said the goods were to be paid for on deliveryâ€”I believed her statement.
Cross-examined. I understood that she was buying these goods for Mr. Mikschik for his wife; that she was their agentâ€”it was the promise for payment on delivery that induced me to part with them.

JOHN AUSTIN . I am a salesman in the employ of Peter Robinsonâ€”on 21st November I received a box addressed to Mr. Mikschik, 28, Glaslyn Road, which I took with some bills to that addressâ€”the prisoner opened the door; I told her I had brought goods from Peter Robinson'sâ€”she said, "Bring them inside"â€”I took them into a room, where was another woman and a childâ€”the prisoner said the other lady could not speak Englishâ€”I opened the box; it contained dresses and various articles of apparel; the prisoner examined them, and the other lady tried them on in my presenceâ€”the prisoner said they were all correctâ€”I gave these two bills to the prisoner, one for Â£32 and the other for Â£9 oddâ€”she left the room, leaving them on the tableâ€”she came back and gave me this chequeâ€”it appeared to have been just written; it is for Â£41 10s. 8d.â€”I took with me this delivery note, which was signed "A. Mikschik"â€”I took the cheque and handed it to our cashierâ€”on the following Wednesday he gave it back to me, and I went back to 28, Glaslyn Roadâ€”the prisoner was not there; only a broker's man in possessionâ€”I met Sergeant Brock-well there.
Cross-examined. I am sure it was the prisoner who opened the door to me she left the bills on the table when she went out of the room, and returned with the cheque.

WHITEMAN COOPER . I am assistant-manager of the London Trading Bank Limited, 12, Coleman Streetâ€”on 12th October, 1891, J. E. Mikschik, of 41, Finsbury Pavement, opened an account with a credit of Â£22 17s. 2d.; I saw him sign the signature-bookâ€”I have a certified copy of his accountâ€”he paid in, on 27th October, Â£20, on 28th October 7s., on 2nd November Â£2, 5th November Â£5, in all Â£50 4s. 2d.â€”he drew out the whole of that between 24th October and 17th November, by a bout twenty-one separate cheques, leaving the account on 17th November 4s. 9d. to the good; the bank charged that as commission on the account, and closed the account by this registered letter on 17th November after that cheques were dishonouredâ€”these cheques from Wallis and Peter Robinson, signed by our customer Mikschik, were presented; there was nothing to meet it, and I caused it to be marked "Account closed"â€”both cheques are after due notice of the closing of the accountâ€”when Mikschik opened the account he gave a reference to one of our customers

known to us a dozen years, who brought and introduced him as a respect able man known to himselfâ€”Mikschik had two cheque-books during the time he had an account; he did not return the unused cheques after the closing of the account; we have never received themâ€”I know the prisoner; she opened an account in the name of Annie Reese, on 1st August, 1890; it was closed in January, 1891â€”one cheque was presented after it was closedâ€”I never saw her from that time to thisâ€”the cheques (produced) are all signed by her, and these are some of the counterfoils of cheques issued to her.
Cross-examined. Our customer who introduced Mikschik was Begelmeyerâ€”Ellis and Co., in the Wool Exchange, introduced the prisoner.

MARIA LOVELL . I am the wife of Charles Henry Lovell, a packer, living at 3, Temple Street, Dalstonâ€”about one o'clock on 28th October, 1891, the prisoner came alone, and took a bed-room and fitting-room at 7s. a-week; and she came the same night with a man, and slept there; they occupied the two roomsâ€”she never told me her name, but I heard it mentioned by some one at the door as Reeseâ€”they went out about ten a.m., and came back about five and took tea, and stayed inâ€”the prisoner said they had a mantle-maker's business in the Cityâ€”on every Wednesday their rent was dueâ€”on Saturday, 14th, I asked the prisoner to pay the rent due, and on the Sunday she said she would see what she could do for me before mid-day Tuesday, and she told me she had bought four machines and a table and some irons, and was going to set up in business for herself in the Cityâ€”on the following Wednesday, 18th, she paid me 10s.â€”on 21st November the prisoner came home about six o'clock, bringing Julia Kumer with herâ€”the prisoner said she was one of her hands she had brought from the Cityâ€”Kumer had a parcelâ€”the prisoner said she had been working very hard all the week making a dress and mantle, and when she sent them home by a little boy who was not to leave them without being paid, they could not pay him, and so he brought them back, and there they wereâ€”she asked me who she could get to pledge themâ€”I had been asking her for more rentâ€”I said, "I will"â€”she was carrying this umbrellaâ€”she opened the parcel and took out this dress and mantle, and told me to pledge themâ€”she also took out this petticoat, which afterwards I saw hanging up behind the parlour doorâ€”I pledged the things about six o'clock at Mr. Ridgway's, close by, where I had been before and was knownâ€”they knew my proper name, but I pledged always in the name of Smithâ€”they lent me on them Â£1, less two-penceâ€”I gave the 19s. 10d. and the ticket to the prisonerâ€”she had stated no price, but told me to get as much as I couldâ€”I don't know how far it is by road from 28, Glaslyn Road to our house; it took us three-quarters of an hour to go by railâ€”on the Sunday, the day after the pawning, the prisoner told me if I liked to come to 28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch End, there were some odds and ends, if I would like them and would fetch them, and I went on Monday morning with Mrs. Ryderâ€”I saw the prisoner on the step of 28, Glaslyn Roadâ€”she beckoned me in and told me there were a few odds and ends for meâ€”there was a bassinette done up, and she said I must get on home, as she had to get into the Cityâ€”Kumer was acting as servant there, as far as I sawâ€”in the kitchen were table, chairs, and thingsâ€”I went into no other room, but the' doors of other rooms were open, and, as I passed by, they looked nicely furnished

â€”I took away the odds and endsâ€”about four the same afternoon the prisoner came to my house with a young woman, who spoke in a foreign language, which I did not understandâ€”after a short time the prisoner came and asked mo to take a note to Baudach's barber's shop in the Ball's Pond Roadâ€”some one else took it, and afterwards Reese, the man. living with the prisoner, came and spoke to the prisoner and the foreign womanâ€”they remained some time together in a roomâ€”this blotting-pad I have seen in use by the man Reese in my rooms which they hired; I saw the police seize it, and they have had it sinceâ€”the prisoner came back in the evening alone, and later Reese cameâ€”on 20th, I think, the police came and asked me some questions, and I gave them informationâ€”I last saw the prisoner, before I saw her at the Policecourt, on Wednesday, the next day, when she left my houseâ€”the policeman said to her, in my presence, that he had arrested Reeseâ€”during the time the prisoner was at my lodgings I saw her making a plain bodice, which I once afterwards saw her wearing; beyond that I have not seen her do anything.

Cross-examined. She is foreign; I always understood her; she does not speak English as well as I doâ€”I might be mistaken in what she said about 4he pledging; I understood generally that she wanted me to pledge themâ€”she said, Take them and get as much as you can on them"â€”I asked them to make them as much as they couldâ€”I am in the habit of dealing at the pawnshop, and my credit is good thereâ€”Â£1 was the utmost I could get.

SARAH HANNAH RYDER . I am the wife of Joseph Ryder, of 26, Valentine Road, South Street, Hackneyâ€”on Monday, 23rd November, I went to see Mrs. Lovell, and I saw the prisoner also, who said that a friend of hers was going to move; and she said to Mrs. Lovell, "Would you like to go there; there will be a few things you can have"â€”I went with Mrs. Lovell next morning to 28, Glaslyn Roadâ€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”Mrs. Lovell took away some thingsâ€”on Sunday evening, 22nd, Mrs. Lovell showed me this umbrella; the prisoner was not there then, but afterwards Mrs. Lovell said to her, "I have shown my friend your umbrella"â€”and the prisoner said, "It does not much matter."

KATE FLORENCE BARNARD . I am an assistant in Messrs. Wallis and Company's mantle departmentâ€”on 21st November one of our assistants brought the prisoner to meâ€”she wished for a mantle for another lady she selected oneâ€”I made out this invoice for Â£1 5s. 6d.â€”she said the mantle was to be sent to 28, Glaslyn Road; I got the name from another departmentâ€”she said the size did not matter, it was for a married ladyâ€”she wished to see a hat, and I took her to another departmentâ€”I gave the mantle to one of the assistants to be put with other goods.
Cross-examined. She told me the goods were not for herself, she was commissioned to buy them for another ladyâ€”I delivered them to Mr. Crocombe to be sent to where other goods had been ordered.

SARAH GLOVER . I am the wife of William Glover, we lodge at Mrs. Lovell's, 3, Temple Streetâ€”on 23rd November the prisoner, whom I knew as Mrs. Reese, asked me to go to Crouch End with herâ€”a woman she called Mrs. Mikschik was with her, and the man Reeseâ€”we went to the bottom of Temple Street together, and then I went alone to Crouch End with a note, which Mrs. Mikschik asked me, in the prisoner's presence, to take; the prisoner gave me sixpence for my fareâ€”
the servant, Miss Kumer, was in the house there aloneâ€”all the things in it were packed up; Miss Kumer came back with me to Temple Street.

JULIA KUMER (Interpreted). I am now a general servant in Mrs. Baudach's service, at 80, Ball's Fond Road she is a midwife, and her husband a barberâ€”on 22nd November I went into her serviceâ€”before that I had been in Mrs. Mikschik's service, at 28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch Endâ€”the prisoner, whom I knew as Mrs. Reese, came to the house on the Friday previous to my leaving the service, with a man whose name I do not knowâ€”Mr. and Mrs. Mikschik were in the house, and the prisoner and the man stayed in the room, where they were for some timeâ€”next day, Saturday, the prisoner came to Glaslyn Road, and was with Mrs. Mikschik that afternoonâ€”a man came and went into the room they were inâ€”the prisoner said, "That is my brother"â€”later that evening she told me to carry a parcel for her to Dalston; I did so; I saw Mrs. Lovellâ€”the prisoner took it from me and undid it; it contained a dressâ€”on Sunday, the prisoner told me I could not stay in Mrs. Mikschik's service any longerâ€”Mr. and Mrs. Mikschik lived at 28, Glaslyn Road; I was never in the prisoner's serviceâ€”I have never been to a shop in the City kept by the prisonerâ€”I think this is the house key of 28, Glaslyn Roadâ€”I think this is a photograph of the prisoner's brother.

Cross-examined. I only saw the prisoner at the Mikschiks' on the Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Mondayâ€”I had not seen her before thatâ€”I was in Mrs. Mikschik's Service for six weeksâ€”the prisoner told me that all these transactions she did for Mrs. Mikschik; I did not hear her say that they were well offâ€”two gentlemen, whose names I do not know, first came to ask me to give evidenceâ€”they asked me several questions; they did not threaten me in any way.
Re-examined. Mr. Tauber lived at 26, Glaslyn Road.

FRANK GYNGELL . I am manager to Mr. Fish, a pawnbroker, of 179, Kingsland Roadâ€”on 25th November the prisoner pawned this umbrella with meâ€”this is the duplicate. (In the name of Mrs. Reese, 3, Temple Street.)
Cross-examined. I lent her 4s. on it; it is not gold-mounted, as described; it is a metal mount, plated with goldâ€”I believe I could sell it for 15s. 6d., but they always deteriorate by lying by.

ERNEST HARVEY . I am manager to Walter Ridgway, pawnbroker, of 21, Dalston Laneâ€”this dress and mantle (produced) were pawned with me on November 21st for Â£1, in the name of A. Smith, 3, Temple Street, but her name is Mrs. Lovell.

Cross-examined. They are worth Â£3 or Â£4, but I would not lend more than Â£2 10s. on them, because they would deteriorateâ€”she asked me for the most I could lend, and if she had pressed for more I would have lent 30s. moreâ€”I have heard that they were sold by Peter Robinson for Â£17 4s.

MARY GROOMBRIDOE . I am the wife of a constable, and have searched females at Highgate Police-stationâ€”I searched the prisoner there, and found a large number of documents, which I handed to Sergeant Brockner.
MARIA SCHENY . I am the wife of George Schenyâ€”on December 7th
I searched the prisoner at Northfield Hall, Highgate, where the Sessions are heldâ€”she was wearing this petticoat.

HERMAN BTTERMAN (Detective Sergeant). On 24th November I arrested Carlos Otto Holfieldâ€”this (produced) is his photographâ€”he has several aliasesâ€”he has gone by the name of Reeseâ€”he had five months' hard labour last year in Germanyâ€”he was taken there on an extradition warrantâ€”I found this latch-key on him and two return halves of railway tickets from Broad Street to Crouch End, and from Broad Street to Dalstonâ€”the latch-key belongs to 28, Glaslyn Road, but the lock has been removedâ€”I also found on him a pawn-ticket for a dress and mantleâ€”he made a statement to me, in consequence of which I went to 3, Temple Street, Dalston, on 24th December, and saw the prisonerâ€”I told her in English to turn out her box; there was some dirty linen in it, so I did not do it myselfâ€”she did soâ€”I told her I had arrested the man she was living withâ€”she handed me, among other things, a number of cheques and counterfoils, and these eight cards, "Mr. T. E. Mikschik, Finsbury Pavement"â€”Bedal Alogaher, alias Holfield, is the man who has gone to Germanyâ€”there is a firm of Mikschik and Powder, architects and builders.
Re-examined. I know Holfield, but not under the name of Ventura.

THOMAS BROCKWELL (Detective Sergeant). On November 25th, by direction of the Commissioners of Police, I went to 28, Glaslyn Road, Crouch End, and found a broker's man in possession, on behalf of the landlordâ€”I looked over the house, and found a small quantity of furniture leftâ€”on 30th November I received this joint warrant against the prisoner and Mikschikâ€”I could not find themâ€”a warrant for a woman named Mikschik was obtained on 18th Decemberâ€”her description was circulated, with the usual information which goes to the City Policeâ€”on 3rd December, about eight o'clock, I stopped the prisoner in Bishopsgate Street, from the description I had receivedâ€”I said, "Is your name Mrs. Reese?"â€”she said, "Yes"â€”I said, "I am a police officer; you are wanted on a charge of obtaining a quantity of goods, by false pretences, from Messrs. Wallis and Co, Holborn Circus, on 21st November; there is also another charge against you of obtaining a quantity of goods from Peter Robinson and Co., of Oxford Street, on the same day"â€”she said, "I did get the things for Mr. Mikschik"â€”I took her by train, and pulled some photographs out of my pocket, which I had got in the course of my inquiryâ€”she was sitting by my side, and when she saw this one she said, "This is Holfield'S wife"â€”Holfield is the man who was living with her at 3, Temple Street; she is a woman of the townâ€”it is a photograph of a woman and childâ€”I found it at 11, Alfred Place, Tottenham Court Roadâ€”the prisoner gave her name at the station, Anna Margaretta Flugel, and said she had no fixed homeâ€”I knew that she and Reese, alias Holfield, had been living at 3, Temple Street, Dalston; I went there on December 9th, and found this blotting-pad, which has been identified as used by Reese; I spoke to the landlady, and took it away with meâ€”a number of documents were found on the prisoner, in German, relating to her identity and nationalityâ€”I directed Mrs. Groom-bridge to search her, who gave me this pawnticket for an umbrella.
Cross-examined. I found a passport on the prisoner, which gave me full information as to her name, and I said, "Is your name Mrs. Reese?"
â€”she said, "Yes"â€”the passport gives her name Anna Margaretta Flugel, nÃ©e Reeseâ€”she produced the pawn ticket herself.

GUILTY .â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

223.
JOHN BUTLER,
DAVID APPLEBY,
MICHAEL HAYES,
JOHN MCCARTHY , and
ARTHUR HAMPSHIRE were indicted for
a riot, and assaulting
William George Sells,
Frederick Chadwick, and others.
MESSRS. C. MATHEWS, GILL, and STEPHENSON Prosecuted; MR. TRAVERS

JOHN WINGFIELD . I live at Forest Hill Terrace, and am foreman at Carron Wharfâ€”a strike commenced at the wharf on September 14th, in consequence of the determination to employ permanent hands; it continued to the end of Novemberâ€”during that time the work was done by free labourers not attached to the Unionâ€”the wharf was picketedâ€”Hampshire was employed there, and went out when the strike commenced.
Cross-examined. I have known Hampshire five or six yearsâ€”he occasionally sampled tea, but he was looked upon as a labourer.

JOHN PROAL . I am a clerk in the employ of the London and Edinburgh Shipping Company, employed at the Hermitage Steam Wharfâ€”there was a strike there at the same time as at the Carron Wharf; the same reason applies to both'â€”the wharf was picketed, and the work was done by free labourers, with the assistance of the clerks and engineersâ€”Butler was employed as a stevedore; the strike did not affect them, but when the men went out on strike Butler went out with them.
Cross-examined. I have known Butler seventeen or eighteen yearsâ€”he has borne a good character as far as I knowâ€”I believe picketing is a perfectly legitimate occupation.

JOHN REGAN (Thames Polios Inspector). I have been on duty while the strike has been going on, and have seen Butler acting as a picketâ€”complaints were made of his using bad language to the tree labourers at the wharf, and I spoke to him more than once, and advised him to tell his companions whatever they did not to take the law into their own handsâ€”he knew the case I was engaged inâ€”I have known him fourteen or sixteen yearsâ€”on one occasion he had a subscription listâ€”I know Hampshire as being on strike, but not McCarthyâ€”I have accompanied the free labourers from Wapping Railway Station to their workâ€”they would pass the Union Hall to get to Wapping Station, and in passing it I heard, McCarthy and Hampshire calling them blacklegs, cows' sons, and whâ€”'s sons.

Cross-examined. I have known Butler fourteen years as a hard-working, honest manâ€”he once complained to me of the free labourers using bad language to him, and I told him I would try and stop itâ€”I have known Hampshire about two years; he is an honest, hard-working manâ€”he was employed as a tea samplerâ€”I have known McCarthy from a child; he is an honest, hard-working man, in constant employmentâ€”he was not on strike; he was working at St. John's Wharf.
WILLIAM GEORGE SELLS . I live in Newcastle Street, Greenwichâ€”I went into employment at Hermitage Wharf as a free labourer when the

strike began, and worked there from September to Novemberâ€”I am not working there nowâ€”on 1st November I came up from New Cross to Cannon Street Station, and got into the wharf about 11.55â€”when I was close to the bridge leading to the wharf I met two men, who asked me where I was going; I said, "To work"â€”one clutched the handkerchief I had my food in, and got away, and as I crossed the road to get away Butler struck me with his fist on the right side of my cheekâ€”he was not one of the two menâ€”the blow drove me into the road, and I fell, and a few came round me, and somebody put a sharp instrument into my back, and I was laid up for three days, but I did not attend a doctorâ€”when Butler struck me he called me a black whâ€”s bastardâ€”I have known Butler by sight seven or eight weeksâ€”I saw him standing at the beer shop opposite the wharf gateâ€”I have heard him threaten people, and say lie would wait on themâ€”I remained on the ground, face downwards, till some man picked me up, and then went into Hermitage Wharf.

Cross-examined. I saw the two men quite distinctly; I cannot say their namesâ€”I did not describe them to the policeâ€”I saw a policeman in the lane, 400 or 500 yards awayâ€”I was on the ground five or six minutesâ€”there were 150 or 160 women, children, and men thereâ€”I started from Cannon Street Station to walk alone, and I was alone when the two men came upâ€”my bundle could be seen in my hand.

JACK CHADWICK . I live in Dunswood Street, Euston Roadâ€”I am not connected with the Unionâ€”I was employed at Hermitage Wharfâ€”I go by train to Bishopsgate Station, and walk to the wharfâ€”on the night of 1st November I started with my son, and on arriving at Bishopsgate proceeded to walk to the wharf, and when we got to the bottom of Nightingale Lane eight or nine men came towards us; and there were a lot behind themâ€”it was then about 11.30, we had to get to work about twelveâ€”as we reached the men I heard a whizzing noise, and said to my son, "look out, Fred!"he bobbed his head, but caught the blow by the side of his head; I made a grasp at the article, and to the best of my opinion it was a strap with a piece of lead or a knot at the endâ€”Butler is the man who used it, but I did not know his name; I had seen him once, a day or two before, when he said he should like to thrash meâ€”I saw a big lump on my son's head, over his right ear, and a flow of blood cameâ€”we went straight to our work, met a constable, and made a statement to himâ€”my son worked for two or three days, and then got ill, and has done no work since; he is disarranged in his mind, and my brother is looking after him.

Cross-examined. He is not hereâ€”this was just before we got to the swing bridgeâ€”I started at ten o'clock and this was about 11.30; I had to get to my work at twelveâ€”the thing which whizzed knocked my son downâ€”a second blow was struck, and it would have knocked Nelson down, who was just behind me, if I had not spoken in time; I said, "Look out, Nelson!" and pushed him on one sideâ€”at the time the blow was struck I heard some one say, "Here is another blackleg; let them have it!"
Re-examined. My son's health was all right till then.

CHARLES BULL . I live at Glenster Road, Greenwich, and was working as a free labourer at the Hermitage Wharf while the strike was going onâ€”at that time I have seen Butler walk up and down outside the wharfâ€”I came to London Bridge Station to go to my work, and went by

myself with no police escortâ€”I carried my food in a handkerchief in my handâ€”about a quarter to twelve p.m. on 1st November I was going towards the Hermitage Wharf, and when I got to the bottom of the lane, just by the bridge, I saw some men, one of whom said to me (it was not one of the prisoners), "We will have you out of it in a week's time," and called me a fâ€”g bastardâ€”I walked onâ€”Butler, who had been on the opposite side by the corn wharf when those expressions were made use of loud enough for him to hear, followed me and said, "What will you do?" and as he spoke he struck at me; I put up my left arm to defend my face, at which the blow was aimed, and he caught me on the armâ€”he was arrested in the act by a plain-clothes constableâ€”I went to the station and charged him.

Cross-examined. I am employed by the Shipping Federationâ€”there was a very great crowd about thereâ€”I cannot say if they were with Butlerâ€”I don't know who the three or four men who spoke to me were; they did not attempt to assault meâ€”it was past twelve when the assault was all over and I got to the Hermitage Wharfâ€”only a bridge, not quite so long as this Court, divides it from the Carron Wharfâ€”I did not, at about the time I was going in, see thirty free labourers charging a lot of Union men; nor did I hear Sergeant White trying to dissuade them from doing itâ€”I heard no suggestion that they did charge the crowdâ€”there were a lot of women and children in the crowdâ€”I did nothing to Butlerâ€”I did not use my stevedore's hook, it was in my pocket; my hand was on itâ€”I should have been obliged in self-defence to nee it if a great many had been on me; I don't say I should have used it; it was half-way out of my pocketâ€”I did not try to strike anybodyâ€”I stopped Butler's blow with my left arm; it hurt me for a timeâ€”it was with his fist.

Re-examined. I was assaulted close to the swing-bridge, just outside the wharf gatesâ€”I should reckon there were over a hundred there at the time; it was the time that all the free labourers would be going into workâ€”the men were going about in twenties and thirties.

EDMUND STREETER (314 H). On the night of 1st November I was sent in plain clothes to Hermitage Wharfâ€”I was with another plain-clothes constableâ€”I was at the bridge at nearly twelve o'clock, and saw the crowd outside as the men were going to their workâ€”I saw Butler strike at Bull, who guarded the blow off with his arm, and I ran up and put my hand on to Butler, and said I was a police constable, and should take him into custody for assaulting the man while following his employmentâ€”Bull ran into the wharf; I called him back from the doorâ€”I took Butler to the station.

Cross-examined. I was coming over the bridge when Butler struck Bull, and was about twelve yards off; no persons were between me and Bullâ€”I did not see two or three men speak to Bullâ€”I did not hear anything said by Butler or Bullâ€”I and another constable were together all the time.

ETHELBERT AUSTEN (60 H). On 1st November I was sent with the last witness to the wharf, in consequence of what was going onâ€”I went into Hermitage Wharf about a quarter to twelveâ€”I saw about 100 people scattered about outsideâ€”I saw Butler raise his hand to strike Bull, and Bull raise his to protect his faceâ€”as Butler struck at him he said, "You bâ€”â€”bastard!"â€”I went up at once to take him into

custodyâ€”I took him part of the way to the station, and then handed him to Streeterâ€”I and the other constable were sent to the wharf between half-past eleven and a quarter to twelve, and we hurried there sharply on account of what was happening there.

Cross-examined. I and Streeter were not exactly together on Hermitage Bridge; he was a little behind me, two or three yards or a footâ€”I distinctly heard Butler use the expression; he said it pretty loudâ€”I did not hear Bull make any replyâ€”when I first saw Butler and Bull they were walking over the bridge together, not in a friendly way; Butler was halloaing at himâ€”I did not take any notice of the words that were said until this blow was struck.
Re-examined. There was a good deal of shouting and noise there as these men were going in at the wharf gates.

CHARLES MADDOX . I was in November, Constable 148 Hâ€”at twelve o'clock on the night of 1st November I was on duty at the Hermitage Bridge, where I had been sent in plain clothes in consequence of the state of thingsâ€”I found a number of people outside the gates; there was a great deal of noise; the free labourers were going in to their work at the timeâ€”I saw Appleby quarrelling with several menâ€”I saw him strike a man several blows, I think about the shouldersâ€”I cannot say if he was a free labourerâ€”he came across and complained to meâ€”I at once told Appleby I was a constable, and should take him into custody for an assault on a manâ€”he struck me across the head and body with a stick and ran awayâ€”I followed, caught him, and with another constable's assistance took him to the station; he said, "I will go quietly."

Cross-examined. The man I saw assaulted by Appleby made no complaint at the station that I am aware of, and I do not know that he is going to be called here to-dayâ€”I was in plain clothesâ€”there was a great deal of noise and disturbanceâ€”Appleby is a little man; he was rather excited he smashed my hat in with his stick, I was not hurtâ€”he said at the station, when charged, "I ran because the crowd ran"â€”he went quietly to the station.

FREDERICK HERBERT (223 H). About twelve on this night I was on duty on the bridgeâ€”I saw Appleby running away, followed by Maddox; I went to his assistance and caught Appleby; he went quietly to the station.
Cross-examined. I did not see any assault.

WILLIAM GEORGE TURNER . I am employed at Hermitage Wharfâ€”I know Appleby by sight, he worked at the coffee-shop opposite the wharf, where a crowd of thirty to fifty men used to stand while this strike was going onâ€”I have noticed Appleby, while I was at work, standing at the door laughing and jeering at us.
Cross-examined. I don't object to his laughing, but it was not right when we were at workâ€”I have seen him for about six months, but have had no dealings with himâ€”I don't know about his character.
Re-examined. I did not use the coffee-shop.

FREDERICK STYLES . I live at Graveney Road, Tootingâ€”I am not a member of the Union; I was employed at the Hermitage Wharf while the strike was going on, as a warehousemanâ€”on this night I went to work about 11.45â€”I had to go out of East Smithfield and by Nightingale Lane, the corner of which is about five minutes' walk from the wharfâ€”I saw there several men on one side of the way, and Hayes standing by

himself on the other sideâ€”four men were going directly in front of me I directly we turned the corner Hayes, who had no beard then, struck me across the head with something of metal; my hat took the brunt of the blow, but it cut my head; and when I took my hat off the blood came out of my hatâ€”it knocked me to the groundâ€”I got up and I looked at the man; he stood there and never moved, and I had plenty of opportunity of observing himâ€”I looked round and saw such a menacing crowd of from ten to twenty men as to put me in fear, and I went to the wharfâ€”afterwards a doctor was sent for, and my head was dressedâ€”I described Hayes, and afterwards I saw him in custody and charged him.

Cross-examined. My head is all right nowâ€”I had never seen Hayes before to my knowledgeâ€”I heard no word when I was struckâ€”he did not move away after he struck me, but stood still, and I got up and looked at himâ€”I said nothing; I was not going to argue with an armed manâ€”I saw no weapon in his handâ€”I did not see a constableâ€”there were no women and children in the crowd; I met them afterwards with the other crowd on the bridgeâ€”there seemed to be an absence of police on this night.
Re-examined. I should think two hundred free labourers were employed at the Carron and Hermitage Wharves at this time; we could not nave a constable to look after each of us.

FREDERICK DICCONSON . (254 H). On this night, about 11.55, I was in uniform near the corner of Upper East Smithfield and Nightingale Laneâ€”I saw between twenty and thirty people standing near that cornerâ€”I saw Hayes strike Styles, and went to arrest him, when I was struck in the middle of my back by some one else, and turned roundâ€”I then went after the man who struck me, but he got awayâ€”I then went back, and, with the assistance of another constable, took Hayes, who was with some men, to the stationâ€”I afterwards went to the wharf, where I found Stylesâ€”I took him to the station, and he picked out Hayes from other menâ€”at the time Hayes struck Styles he said, "These are some of the blacklegs, let us give it them "

Cross-examined. I saw Hayes strike him and knock him to the groundâ€”I was six feet away, and heard his observation distinctlyâ€”I came back in ten minutes after chasing the man who hit me, and found Hayes standing about ten yards from the place where the assault took placeâ€”he lives at 18, Upper East Smithfield, about three hundred or four hundred yards from this place.
Re-examined. Upper East Smithfield leads up to this bridge; it is at the top of Nightingale Lane, and Lower East Smithfield at the bottom.

PERCY JOHN CLARK , M. R. C. S. I practice at Spital Squareâ€”I examined Sells on 13th Novemberâ€”I found a punctured wound, almost entirely healed, on the bottom of his spineâ€”I saw a corresponding hole in his trousersâ€”it was such a wound as would be caused by the pointed end of a stevedore's hookâ€”I examined Styles on the morning of 2nd November; he was suffering from a contused wound, about one inch long, on the left side of his head, at the back; such as would have been caused by some heavy, blunt instrument, such as the edge of this hookâ€”it had bled a good deal, but was not serious.
Cross-examined. A good many other things might have caused it; a poker would not, it would require something with more edge.

ARTHUR THOMAS ASKEW . I live at Bower Street, and am a free labourer, and I was working at Carron Wharf during the strikeâ€”on this night I was coming down Nightingale Lane to go to work a little before twelve, with Armstrong and Stroudâ€”Armstrong was ten or fifteen yards in front, and Stroud some distance behind meâ€”as I went up to the wharf I saw a party of menâ€”one of them spoke to me, and another, whom I do not identify, struck me with his fist on the right side of the mouthâ€”he was partly behind and half covered by the man who spoke to meâ€”I complained to a constable.
Cross-examined. I was in the road.

FREDERICK WINSLEY (402 H). On this night, about 11.40, I was on duty in Nightingale Laneâ€”I saw Askew and Armstrong approaching to go to their work, and McCarthy and about thirteen or fourteen men were running backwards and forwards on the road that leads to the docks, halloaing and shoutingâ€”I watched them and saw McCarthy strike Askew in the face; Askew ran towards the docksâ€”I apprehended McCarthy for the assaultâ€”he had been shouting and halloaing with the crowdâ€”I had seen him and Hampshire before with others against the walls, when I was one of an escort taking free labourers to the wharvesâ€”I was patrolling Nightingale Laneâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”I never took my eyes off him after the assault till I apprehended himâ€”another man was a few yards behind when Askew was struck, but there was no one with himâ€”Hampshire was not there at the time.

Cross-examined. McCarthy and his party were going towards the London Docks the opposite way to Askewâ€”I arrested McCarthy immediately after he assaulted Askew; he only ran about five yards and then stood still; he ran after Askew, who ran awayâ€”he said, "I ran because the crowd ran; I did not strike him"â€”Askew failed to identify himâ€”I was not ten yards awayâ€”there were only about twelve or fourteen people aboutâ€”I did not ask them to identify him, because they were with himâ€”none of the other prisoners were with him at the time.
PERCY JOHN CLARK (Re-examined). Serjeant Rolfe is suffering from bronchitis, and unable to leave his bed.

WILLIAM HENRY NELSON . I live at Carnbrook Terrace, Old Kent Road, and was working at Hermitage Wharf, and on this night I was going to work down Nightingale Lane about 11.30â€”I walked behind Chad wick and his sonâ€”I saw men coming from the opposite direction, and as they got close to me they said, "Here come some more bâ€”â€”blacklegs, let them have it"â€”Butler, whom I knew by sight, struck young Chadwick with either a piece of leather or a piece of rope with something at the end of it; it made a sissing noise as it went through the airâ€”a second blow was aimed at me, and Chadwick said, "Look out, old pal" and pushed me on one side, and I escapedâ€”I made my way off as quickly as I could.

EDWARD ARMSTRONG . I am a labourerâ€”on November 1st I was going to work at Carron Wharf, and Hampshire, who was with another man, said, "Where are you going to?"â€”I said, "Mind your own business"â€”I was advised to go back by the men with me, and attempted to do soâ€”I had a bundle in my handâ€”the crowd got round me, and Hampshire said, "This is one of the bâ€”â€”y blacklegs," and made a blow at me; I drew back, and tried to get out of the crowdâ€”I received kicks from persons who I cannot identify; I staggered, and got another
kickâ€”Hampshire said, "You bâ€”â€”y well shall not go to work tonight"â€”I was kicked on my thigh and testicles, and went to the hospital.
PETER HENDERSON (178 H). I took Armstrong to the hospital.

HARRY SLY (455 H). On November 1st, about 11.45 p.m., I was on duty in Nightingale Lane, and saw Armstrong coming along shouting "Police!"â€”he pointed out Hampshire as the man who assaulted him, and charged him; he said, "All right, I will go quietly to the station."
Cross-examined. He said to the inspector at the station, "I only crossed the street."

JAMES PROUD . I live at Stone Street, Limehouse; I was working at Carron Wharf; on November 1st Armstrong and I went to work togetherâ€”we met some men in Nightingale Lane, and Hampshire said, "Here is another of the cows' sons coming," and asked Armstrong where he was going and what he had his tommy forâ€”that is the name for foodâ€”he hit at Armstrongâ€”thirty or forty others came round, and I went back; I did not go through the crowd.
Cross-examined. It was about 11.40â€”I did not say at the Police-court, "I told Armstrong not to answer."

JOHN OWEN (349 H). On the night of November 1st I was on fixed point duty, and was told off to assist some labourers to the Hermitage and Carron wharves; there was a disturbance in Nightingale Lane, and I saw Hampshire there; he saw Armstrong speaking to me and ran up the Lane; I called to No. 274, who. stopped him and took him to Leman Street-station.
Cross-examined. This was about 11.40; Hampshire might have heard Armstrong say that he had assaulted himâ€”he only ran seven or nine yards.

WILLIAM WRIGHT . I am one of the free labourers working at Carron Wharf; I live at Edmontonâ€”on this Sunday evening I left home so as to get to my work by twelve o'clockâ€”I saw a man on the ground on Tower Hill, surrounded by a crowd, but I did not see them do anything to him; there was too much of a scuffleâ€”I was with two other menâ€”I heard a yell at the top of Nightingale Laneâ€”I got a blow on the side of my face from a tall man in a light suit, which knocked me downâ€”I heard one of my friends screamingâ€”I managed to dodge awayâ€”I felt something which I thought was a hookâ€”I was carrying my bag in my hand.
Cross-examined. I was given in custody by mistake.

JOSIAH SLATTENDEN (Police Inspector). Complaints were lodged with me, and I placed constables on special duty outside the wharves, and had men, some in uniform and some in plain clothes, to escort the menâ€”I did not know Appleby till the charge was made against him; I believe he keeps a cook-shop opposite Hermitage Wharf; I have seen a bill posted in the window, "No blacklegs served here"â€”I was on duty in Leman Street on Sunday night when Hayes was brought in and charged with assaultâ€”I sent for Styles, who identified himâ€”Hayes said, "When outside my place, seeing some men standing about down there, I went to see what it was, when I was arrested and brought here"â€”I took the charge against Hampshireâ€”Hayes said, "I paced the distance out, and it would take 176 yards; there is a bend in the road, and he would not be able to see"â€”Hampshire said, "I stepped up to him and

asked him if ho was going to work, and ho said, (What has that to do with you?' I said, 'You had bettor go back'"â€”I thon wont down Nightingale Lane, and saw fragments of broken bottles and some hats and food; a number of people complained of assaultsâ€”most of the people going to work take their food in their handkerchief.

Cross-examined. Hampshire was charged with attempted assaultsâ€”the Union men have not come to mo to complainâ€”the strike ended at the end of Novemberâ€”a great number of Union men have been taken back; I believe Hayes said he was standing outside his house and wont to see what it was; ho did not say that he could see anything from his house.

FRANCIS SMITH . I am a labourer at Hermitage Wharf; I went there after the strikeâ€”I used to go from Deptford to Wapping Station, where I arrived at 11.20 or 11. '30, and five or six constables mot me, and under their protection I went to my workâ€”going down Union Street, Wapping, I passed the Union Hall; it is ton minutes' walk from Hermitage wharfâ€”on Sunday, November 1st, I came to Wapping Station with my companions, and mot five or six constables waiting outside; we went down with them, and the doors of the Union Hall were thrown open, and about 150 men rushed out and said, "Here they are, lads; let us set about them"â€”they followed us down, bullying us all the wayâ€”when we got close to Coleman's Wharf I was caught hold of by my arm, and pulled among the crowdâ€”I had my food in my hand; they took it away from mo, and also my hatâ€”I was hit on the side of my faceâ€”I ran towards my fellow-workmen, and got into Hermitage Wharf; the Union men followed us thereâ€”my face was swollen from the blow, and I could not oat anything for two days.
Cross-examined. I did not notice any of the defendants thereâ€”it is a little over a quarter of a mile from Hermitage Wharf to Carron Wharf; it would take about ten minutes to walk.

FRANK MORRIS (38 Y). On the night of November 1st I went to Wapping Station with four other constables to escort those men to Hermitage Wharfâ€”when we got to the Union nail, about 150 men came out into the roadway; they opened and allowed us to passâ€”we were in uniformâ€”they were shouting, hooting, and halloaingâ€”some of thorn went forward to the bridge to make a stand and prevent us crossing, but other constables came to our assistance, and enabled us to pass over, and we got the men in.

GEORGE LISLEY . I live at St. Olave's Chambers, Boroughâ€”on Nov. 1st I was going to work at Hermitage Wharfâ€”I turned into Nightingale Lane about 12.40, and saw about fifty men coming towards St. George's Street from the wharf, and another crowd about twenty yards from me coming from Hermitage Wharfâ€”they joined the first crowd and assaulted four men, struck them, and kicked thorn after they were downâ€”I heard a man groaning, and heard someone say, "Give the b-s work; let them have it!"â€”I then saw three men going in the same direction towards the wharf with handkerchiefs in their hands, carrying their foodâ€”the crowd went over to them and knocked them down and kicked them in the same manner; I heard groans from themâ€”there were 100 or 120 in the crowdâ€”I also saw three other men assaulted and kickedâ€”I saw three or four men leaving, and thought it host to leave with themâ€”I walked right into the crowd unrecognisedâ€”I had no food with meâ€”I ran to Leman Street Police-station and gave information.
Cross-examined. I did not see any of the prisoners.

GEORGE NEWBURY . I was employed at Carron Wharfâ€”I was going to work on this Sunday night down Nightingale Lane about 11.60, and mot twenty or thirty men, one of whom gave me a blow on my cheek with a hook like this (produced)â€”it cut my cheekâ€”I was knocked senseless, and taken to the hospitalâ€”a policeman came across to meet meâ€”I saw lots of people chased, but did not see anyone struck.
Cross-examined. I do not know the prisoners.

DR. ARTHUR ST. LEDGER STATHAM . I examined the witness Armstrong, and found his left nostril a good deal swollenâ€”that is consistent with such a kick as he has described; it would cause considerable painâ€”Newbury was brought to the hospital at the same time with an incised wound, just below his right eye, down to the bone; it might have been caused by this hook.
Cross-examined. Any sharp instrument would do it.

WILLIAM O'SHEE . I am a free labourerâ€”on Sunday night, November 1st, about twelve o'clock, I was in Nightingale Lane, going to work, ahead of other labourers, and a mob of twenty or twenty-five men ran across my face, knocked me down, kicked me, and said, "Give it to him!"â€”I was struck on my face and bled; it knocked me down.
Cross-examined. I am a stevedoreâ€”I had a hook like this, and so had all the men who were going to work.

JAMES WHITE (Police Sergeant). I was on duty outside Carron Wharf, and saw the workmen coming to the wharf followed by a crowd, which surrounded them as they got close to the wharf, and shoutedâ€”with assistance I got some of the men out of the mob, and got them safely on to the wharfâ€”the crowd shouted "Blackleg!" and used bad language.

Cross-examined. A suggestion was made that the "blacklegs"should charge the crowd, and about thirty of them left the wharf and went for the crowd, which consisted of men and womenâ€”directly they charged the crowd dispersed, and about half an hour afterwards we managed to get them awayâ€”the crowd scattered, but many of them returned again at about 11.55.
Re-examined. A number of them came in with signs of assaultâ€”the people who rushed out on the crowd came along Lower East Smithfield, after the other labourers had arrived.

APPLEBY,
GUILTY of a common assault â€”
Discharged on Recognisances.
BUTLER,
Eight Months' Hard Labour;
HAYES,
Four Months' Hard Labour;
McCARTHY,
Three Months Hard Labour; and HAMPSHIRE,
Six Months Hard Labour.

224.
EMILE COSTER
, Forging and uttering an authority for the delivery of two cases of eggs.

GEORGE STONE (Constable Great Pattern Railway). I am in charge of the Spitalfields Station dopotâ€”persons coming to fetch goods from there bring an order signed by Andrews, the foreman porterâ€”I have known

for eighteen months the prisoner, who has been employed by different egg merchants to repair cases of eggs and sample themâ€”he has had opportunities of being aware of the course of business required to get goods outâ€”on 5th January, about 4 p.m., he came and said he was coming presently for two cases of eggs, and he pointed to two cases on the bankâ€”he came back about an hour afterwards with a barrow, and said he had come for the two cases of eggs, and added, "And you may as well take the pass now"â€”he gave me this pass and pointed to the same two cases and said, "These are the two cases I want. "(The pass was, "Pass Liver man with two cants of eggs.â€”Andrews. ')â€”I looked at the pass, which is made out irregularly, as there is no date on itâ€”I asked him where he got it from; he said he got it from the Jew to whom the eggs belongedâ€”I asked him where the Jew was; he said he was gone to sign for the eggs, and was coming downâ€”I asked him where the Jew got the pass; he said, "From Foreman Andrews"â€”I said, "Andrews never made out this pass; this is not Andrews's writing; you will have to wait"â€”I detained him in my boxâ€”Andrews came along, and I asked Andrews if he knew anything about the pass; he said, "No"â€”I took the prisoner to the station, and he was handed over to the Metropolitan Policeâ€”the two egg cases he pointed out were standing close to my boxâ€”I have found out since that they belong to Mr. Uhlâ€”they were marked with a round 0 in a ring, not with Uhl's name.

Cross-examined. I only knew the prisoner by the name of Jackâ€”he speaks Englishâ€”I know nothing against his character; he has never been charged with anything of this sort beforeâ€”there were lots of cases of eggs there; those two were lying separate from the others, two or three yards offâ€”I never saw the prisoner write, and do not know if this is his writing or notâ€”he put the barrow up where the eggs were standingâ€”I would not let him load themâ€”it is not usual for people to give up a pass till they have got the goods on the barrow, and are coming out of the gate; he understood the conduct of business there very wellâ€”he did not say he was going to wait till the man came downâ€”he could not go away; he did not try toâ€”if he had taken them I might not have known who had done so; they might not have been missed for two or three monthsâ€”he gave me no description of the Jew.

Re-examined. We have no means of ear-marking a box that goes out, and I could not have identified the person who took those particular boxesâ€”these two cases lying separate were the easiest to load up at once.

EDGAR ANDREWS . lama foreman porter of the Great Eastern Railway at Spitalfields depotâ€”it is my duty to give passes to enable persons to take goods from the depotâ€”this pass is not my writingâ€”it is not exactly the regular formâ€”it is a good imitation of my writingâ€”if a strange police man who did not know my writing had been on the gate he might very likely have passed them outâ€”I aid not authorise anyone to write this; I did not give any such note as this to the prisonerâ€”I was called by Stone to his box on 5th January, and I saw the prisoner detained thereâ€”Stone asked me if it was my writingâ€”I said noâ€”the prisoner said, "It is not my writing, some Jew man gave it to me"â€”he did not give me the Jew's name nor tell me where he had met himâ€”no one came to my office at that time to sign for two cases of eggs.
Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner for six or seven years, I daresay, coming for cases of eggsâ€”as far as I know he is a perfectly

honest manâ€”I have never seen him write, and cannot say if this is his writingâ€”these eggs are consigned to different peopleâ€”the prisoner has been acting as porter lately; I don't know that he has taken any cases of eggs, but he has repacked them if damaged, or anything of that sortâ€”the order is in the usual form, so that the prisoner would have no reason to suppose it was wrong if some one else gave it to himâ€”at first he said I gave it to him, and afterwards, when I said it was not my writing, that a Jew did; he did not describe the Jewâ€”the prisoner said the eggs were signed for in the book, and I went to the office to seeâ€”I believe another officer was there when Stone went for a constable.

Re-examined. When I came back from the office I told him there was no such name in the book, and that they had not been signed forâ€”I give passes on a foreman's order, which is checked by our weigherâ€”the prisoner told me nothing about the man, except that he was a Jew.
By the JURY. We have plenty of genuine orders with no numbers on, and we have them different sizes.

JAMES WEDGE . I live with my father at 4, Hunt Street, Spitalfields; he lets out costermongers' barrowsâ€”on 5th January, about a quarter to four p.m., the prisoner, whom I knew, came for a barrow, saying he was going to the Great Eastern depotâ€”I did not see anyone with himâ€”he went away with it.
Cross-examined. He has hired barrows before.

GEORGE MANSFIELD (447 H). On 5th January the prisoner was given into my custody at the Spitalfields depot at twenty minutes past five for forging an orderâ€”when charged at the station he said, not write the order; it was given to me by a Jew man; I did not touch the eggs"â€”he has given no further description of the Jew, or told me anything more about him; that is the only statement he has made so far as I. know.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "The pass is not in my writing; I had no intention to take the eggs. I did not touch them. "

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character from an employer.

div1.p:
GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy by the JURY on account of his previous good character. â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

225.
EDMUND OSBORNE (54)
, Feloniously wounding
Annie Osborne, with intent to murder. Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

MESSRS. FORREST FULTON and C. F. GILL Prosecuted, and MR. CHARLES MATHEWS Defended. ANNIE OSBORNE. I live at of Roberts Road, West Hamâ€”the prisoner is my husbandâ€”we have been married about twenty-seven years; we only occupied the upper part of the houseâ€”on 10th November I got home about ten minutes to six in the evening and went upstairs; there was no light in the roomâ€”I went to take off my things, and was going to get a light, when I heard somebody come upstairs and come into the room; I believe it was my husband; I saw no one, it was dark, it was a man; I got a blow on the right side of my head, and I don't re
member

any moreâ€”I was standing, undoing my bonnetâ€”I don't remember hearing anything said before I was struck; I don't remember being taken to the hospital; when I recovered consciousness I found myself there, being attended by the doctors.

Cross-examined. My husband was always very kind to me and also to his children; we have four living, one diedâ€”on 9th January, 1887, he had a very severe accident, and he has not been like the same man since; he fell from a ladder when working at the Board school at West Ham, he has since suffered very much from his headâ€”he was laid up for six weeks from the accident, and I had to nurse himâ€”since then he has been strange at times, very excitable, and complained very much of his headâ€”sometimes I have had to bathe his head all night long, sometimes he has been raving, clasping his head with his hands, and frothing at the mouth very muchâ€”very little drink excites him, two glasses of mild ale will disturb himâ€”when we were first married he was a licensed victualler, and kept the Fountain public-house at Lower Clapton, from there we went to the Bull's Head at Stepneyâ€”after that he took to making a living by window and blind cleaning, and so supported himself and usâ€”he has a brother Thomas; he was queer in his head, and almost all the familyâ€”Thomas had a daughter named Millyâ€”I know her quite well; I have not seen her for two or three yearsâ€”she was very strange in her mannerâ€”my husband had two sisters; Emma, who is living, and Mary Ann, who is deadâ€”I saw her a day or two before she diedâ€”she suffered from epileptic fits, and I believe she died in oneâ€”I believe she was 42 years of ageâ€”I had known her all my lifeâ€”she was subject to these fits up to the end of her lifeâ€”the sister Emma is insane, and is at the Essex County Asylum at Brentwoodâ€”I believe she has been there for seventeen years; She was at the Asylum at Bow before she went to Brentwood.

Re-examined. My husband never assaulted me before, never to give me a blow; sometimes he has been rather cross in family affairs, but never to give me a blowâ€”I do not remember making any statement at the hospitalâ€”I can write (looking at a paper); I put my cross to thisâ€”I don't remember having this read over to me; I might, but I was very bad that nightâ€”my husband was not given to drink very often, but when he went out and he met with anyone to give him a glass or two, it made him like a madmanâ€”after he gave up the public-house he was employed as a potman at the Freemasons' Hotelâ€”he had been backwards and forwards there two or three years, off and on, when they wanted anyone; he had not been there for two months before 10th Novemberâ€”he bas suffered from delirium tremens very much; he used to see all kinds of strange thingsâ€”I don't think he ever went to a doctor for it.

THOMAS SMITH . I live at 6, Roberts Roadâ€”the prisoner, his wife, and family lived in the two rooms above meâ€”on Tuesday night, 10th November, about seven, I was in my mother's roomâ€”I heard the prisoner come in and go upstairs; I did not see himâ€”about a quarter of an hour afterwards his wife came in; I saw herâ€”as she went upstairs I heard her say, "Oh, here you are, then!" she went into the front roomâ€”I heard somebody moving about in that roomâ€”shortly afterwards I heard him beating her with a poker; I heard Mows, and I heard her say, "Oh, let me be!"â€”I went to the stairs and listened; I did not go upstairs; I was alone in the houseâ€”the prisoner's door was closedâ€”the blows went on for about half-an-hourâ€”afterwards I heard the prisoner come down-stairs;

I did not see him go outâ€”I was in the kitchen thenâ€”I went out, and when I came back the doctor and the policemen were thereâ€”my father and mother have lived there about a yearâ€”I have often seen the prisoner during that time.

WILLIAM JARVIS . I am a labourer, and live at 7, Franklin Street,. Bromleyâ€”I married a daughter of the prisonerâ€”on 10th November, about seven in the evening, the prisoner walked into my room and said, "Take that off of that chair;"there was a wash hand basin on the chairâ€”my wife was in the roomâ€”he then put his hand in his pocket and took out a piece of bread and bacon and a piece of cord, and put it on the table, and said, "That is all I have to give you; I have been and killed your mother"â€”he had had a drop; he appeared to be under the influence of drinkâ€”I jumped up, and he said, "Here you are," and he shook hands and asked how I was getting onâ€”I said, "All right," and then he said, "Bill, you won't see me any more; I have been and killed my missus"â€”he said he was going to give himself up at West Ham; he kissed my wife and said, "Good-bye; I am going to give myself up at West Ham"â€”he repeated thatâ€”I did not notice anything on his handâ€”he then leftâ€”I went to his house; it is all half a mile from mineâ€”Godwin, my landlord, went with meâ€”I went half-way up the stairs, and I heard the woman groaning; I did not go into the room; I turned down again and fetched Dixon from the next door, returned with him, and we both went upstairs; he tried the room door, but could not get inâ€”we came down again and saw the prisoner; he was going into the house; Dixon went for a policeman, and! went for a doctorâ€”I did not go into the room at all, and did not see the woman before she was taken to the hospitalâ€”I had only married the prisoner's daughter two days before this; I had been courting her for about two yearsâ€”during that time I saw a good deal of the prisonerâ€”I don't know much about his habits.
Cross-examined. He was very queer on this night, very strangeâ€”I had not seen much of him during the last two yearsâ€”my attention was not called to his strange manner at any time.

JOSHUA DIXON . I am a labourer, and live at 8, Roberts Roadâ€”I have known the prisoner and his wife about five yearsâ€”on the night of 10th November, about half-past seven, Jarvis came to my house, and from what he said I went next door to No. 6, and went upstairs; I turned the handle of the door, but could not get inâ€”I could just put my head round, and I could see into the room, and I saw Mrs. Osborne lying behind the door, groaningâ€”there was no light in the room, it had just gone outâ€”I came downstairs to get a policeman, and met the prisoner on the doorstepâ€”he said nothingâ€”I went out and got a constable and came back with himâ€”we went up into the room, and I saw the prisoner there sitting on a chair near the windowâ€”Mrs. Osborne was still lying on the floorâ€”there was a quantity of blood behind the door, and splashes on the wallâ€”Mrs. Osborne said, "Lock that old s-up"â€”he was very drunkâ€”I have seen him on other occasions under the influence of drink, but not very often.
Cross-examined. I have described them as hard-working couple, but both addicted to drink.
By the COURT. I saw the prisoner in the street as I was going for the constable, and he could hardly stand as he came along.
THOMAS COUCH (575 K). I was called by the last witness to 6, Roberts

Road, Abbey Laneâ€”I went upstairs and heard someone talking in the front-roomâ€”I knocked at the door and received an answer telling me to come in; I went inâ€”I had a great deal of trouble to push the door open, and when I got in I found the woman lying against it on the ground, on her left side, insensibleâ€”there was a very large amount of blood on the floor, and her head was covered with bloodâ€”someone brought a lightâ€”the prisoner was sitting on a chair in the roomâ€”I said to him, "What have you been doing?"â€”he said, "I don't know"â€”I asked him to assist "me to lift his wife on to a chair; he made no reply, and never moved to assist me at allâ€”some man had followed me upstairs, and I got the woman into a chair, and sent for Dr. Grogonoâ€”a plain-clothes officer arrived shortly afterâ€”I searched the room and found this poker lying against the wall, under a piece of metal; it was covered over, but I think it had got there accidentally; I don't think it was put there; it was covered with dry bloodâ€”when Dr. Grogono came he dressed the wounds temporarily, and ordered her to be removed to the hospital in a cabâ€”I do not know the prisoner personally; I believe he is well known to the police; he has lived there some timeâ€”I had seen him that evening, about a quarter of an hour before I was fetched; he passed me when I was on fixed point duty in High Street, Stratfordâ€”I saw him go into a corn dealer's shop and come out againâ€”he seemed very unsteady, and was evidently under the influence of drink, from the whole of his demeanour.

BENJAMIN GULLY (98 K). From something I heard on this night I we it to No. 6, and saw the last witness there bathing the woman's headâ€”I saw the prisoner in the roomâ€”I asked Couch, in the prisoner's presence, what he had done it with; he said, "Look;" and I saw this poker at the end of the bed; I took possession of itâ€”I said to the prisoner, "You must consider yourself in custody"â€”he said, "I think I have killed my missus, I hope I have"â€”I searched him, and took him to the stationâ€”he there said, "Is that woman, my wife, dead or alive? I want to know; I hope she is dead, she has been cruel to me; if I dont see her in this world, I will in the next; I know I have done it, and I hope she is dead, and I shall be too, soon; her blood is on my hands; I done it with a poker, and you will find it at 6, Roberts Road; what a wicked man I am; is she in the mortuary?"â€”he was drunk.
Cross-examined. I formed that conclusion from his manner, and he smelt of drinkâ€”I took down at the time what he saidâ€”he said it at intervalsâ€”he was sitting at the table in the station.

WALTER ATKINS GROGONO . I am Divisional Surgeon at Stratfordâ€”on Tuesday evening, 10th November, about a quarter to eight. I was called to 6, Roberts Roadâ€”I went into the upstairs front room, and there found Annie Osborne, supported by the constable; the prisoner was there, sitting on a chair by the windowâ€”the woman was suffering from severe injury to the right side of the head; the parietal bone was fractured, the temple bone and the mala boneâ€”she was bleeding profusely, and there was a large amount of blood about the roomâ€”she was not consciousâ€”she was also suffering from a number of punctured wounds about the faceâ€”I dressed the wounds as well as I could, and arranged for her removal to the West Ham Hospital in a cabâ€”I saw the constable find the poker; these were blood-stains on the handle, not on the point; it was fresh bloodâ€”this is the poker; the injuries to the head were caused by the knob at the end, and the punctures by the pointâ€”the prisoner was not
present all the time I was thereâ€”T had him removed first; the constable took him away; he was simply mumbling; I did not take much notice of him.

Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner for some years, and have attended him professionally, first in 1890, and the commencement of 1891â€”he came to me suffering from nervous excitement and melancholia, severe pains in the head, and restlessness at nightâ€”I prescribed for him; he continued to come for some little timeâ€”I heard of his accident from a fall from a ladder, from a considerable height, on his headâ€”I did not connect his complaints to me with the fall at the time; I did afterwardsâ€”the first time he came to me I was not told of the accident; I first heard of that at the commencement of 1891, and then I did connect themâ€”I did not hear at that time that there was insanity in the family; I heard of that since this investigationâ€”I now know that his sister Emma has been in the County Asylum seventeen years; that his brother Thomas is said to be an odd man; that his daughter Milly is said to be very strange; and that his sister Mary Ann suffered from epilepsy, and is said to have died in an epileptic fitâ€”epilepsy is likely to be hereditary, and if so, likely to be communicated to more than one of the childrenâ€”there is a form of epilepsy known as masked epilepsy; that is a very insidious form of mental disease; the victim to that disease may go on for a long time without betraying that the brain is in any way affected by it, and then may have an outbreak of suicidal or maniacal mania, that is perfectly objectlessâ€”when the fit is on, the patient may be betrayed into very aggravated violence, during which time he would be perfectly insane, perfectly unable to control his actions, or distinguishing right from wrongâ€”I saw the prisoner before the Magistrate on the second and third or fourth remands; I had no conversation with him; I noticed that his appearance was wild and scared on both those occasionsâ€”it did not impress me with the appearance of his being a sane man; he appeared to be watching, and staring about the Court, and in a most anxious and nervous conditionâ€”he had then been over a fortnight in custody.

Re-examined. It is almost impossible for me to say how many times I attended him before 10th November; he was under my care altogether for two or three months, coming to the surgery every third day or soâ€”I know something about his relations, and have conversed with him on the subjectâ€”his symptoms were those of a man of a highly nervous temperament, and perhaps taking too much; it was hardly a case of chronic alcoholismâ€”I gave him nux vomica and bromide of potassiumâ€”I have had a good deal to do with lunatics, and am constantly called on as a witnessâ€”I should certainly expect a man charged with attempting to murder his wife to be sometimes wild and scared; but I think there was something more than that here; he had a peculiar wild appearanceâ€”I think absence from drink, while in custody, would improve his condition; it might at first have a delirious effect, but not for any length of timeâ€”I once saw him bordering on delirium tremens, that was in 1890, the first time I saw himâ€”masked epilepsy is a kind of false epilepsy; a man may have a kind of fit, without the distinct symptoms; it is epilepsy where there is an absence of the ordinary symptoms accompanying the disease.
By the COURT. In masked epilepsy there is not the frothing of the mouth, or twitching of the mouth and limbs; the man may tumble

down insensible; so may a man who has had too much to drink; but then his breath would smell strongly of alcoholâ€”the diagnosis of the complaint is somewhat obscureâ€”I did not see anything about him on 10th November, I did not examine him; in my opinion he had not the complaint then.

WILLIAM FRANCIS . I am House Surgeon at West Ham Hospitalâ€”on 10th November, at a quarter-past eight, Annie Osborne was brought there, suffering from compound depressed fracture of the skull, fracture of the frontal bone, and a compound fracture of the mala bone; all the injuries were on the right sideâ€”there were fourteen scalp woundsâ€”she was consciousâ€”I helped to perform an operation on the skull, which was successfulâ€”she was under my care for some timeâ€”she was in danger three weeks; she has not entirely recovered now, she has to some extent; the dead bone is still coming away from the skull, but she is doing perfectly well; she is still in the hospitalâ€”she was not able to give evidence for a considerable time.

JAMES HARVEY (Inspector). On 10th November I went to the West Ham Police-stationâ€”I there saw the prisoner in custodyâ€”he said, "Is she dead?"â€”I said, "No; she is not"â€”he said, "She ought to be; I hoped she was"â€”I went to the hospital and saw the wife, and on my return I charged him with attempting to murder his wifeâ€”when the charge was read over to him he said, "I hope she will not die now"â€”he made several statements, hoping she would die, and hoping she was deadâ€”afterwards he said, "God bless her! I hope she will not die now"I first saw him at five minutes to nine, he was then drunkâ€”I saw him again at 9.45, he was still drunk; so drunk that I could not take him to the hospital; he could not walk, he was sitting on a chair in the reserve room.

Cross-examined. He was mumbling the whole time in an indistinct wayâ€”I was at the Police-court on 25th November and 2nd Decemberâ€”I should say he had nothing to drink on those daysâ€”he would have none while in custody of the policeâ€”there have been no complaints against him to the police; I knew him personally.

JOHN JAMES PITCAIRN . I am one of the medical officers of Her Majesty's Prison at Hollowayâ€”I am an M. R. O. P. and L. RC. P.â€”I have studied insanityâ€”I have a diploma with regard to thatâ€”I assist Dr. Gilbert, who is illâ€”I have had the prisoner under my observation from 11th November; at first every day, recently every other dayâ€”I have had conversations with himâ€”from instructions I specially directed my attention to himâ€”I have formed the opinion that he is sane, and responsible for his actions.

Cross-examined. That is an opinion based upon my examination since he has been in custodyâ€”I first saw him on 11th November, the night of his arrivalâ€”I have not had him under my special observation from that time; he has been under Dr. Gilbert's observation up to 20th December; from then down to 13th January my attention has been specially directed to him, daily; I have seen nothing during that time to lead me to think him otherwise than saneâ€”I have been in Court since the hearing of this case, and heard the evidenceâ€”during the time he has been under my observations he has shown no sign of suffering from the headâ€”epilepsy is frequently found in members of the same familyâ€”there is such a thing as masked epilepsy; it is a word frequently advanced in the case

of criminals; it is held in great doubt by high authorities; it is impossible to cite them offhand; I think Dr. Savage throws some doubt upon itâ€”Dr. Blandford is a well-known authority on diseases of the mindâ€”I am not aware that he advances it as a well ascertained disease, or that he does not; I am myself somewhat sceptical with regard to itâ€”I have never seen a case; I will not deny that there are men of science in the profession who have asserted its existenceâ€”I do not think that epileptic fits may be absent, and yet masked epilepsy existâ€”an act may be committed without motive in an epileptic fit; he might be the victim of homicidal or suicidal mania, and if so took life he would not be responsibleâ€”frothing of the mouth is not an indication of epilepsy in all cases; it is in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred; I have never seen a case without frothing; I have read of cases without it; in every case I have seen it has invariably occurred.

Re-examined. Frothing would only be while the fit was on; it is very transitoryâ€”an injury to the head would render a man more liable to the effects of drink than an ordinary person; delirium tremens would be consonant with such a conditionâ€”I examine a very large number of prisoners during the yearâ€”I was in communication with Dr. Gilbert with regard to the prisoner's condition.

By the COURT. In my opinion the prisoner was not suffering from epilepsy on 10th November, nor from masked epilepsyâ€”assuming this savage attack was in a fit of epilepsy, a man would not be likely, either while the fit was on or immediately afterwards, to go about talking of what he had done; from the evidence I have heard the actions were those of a drunken man; in epilepsy there would not be the slightest recollection of it; in confirmed epilepsy the fits have a tendency to occur at stated intervals of a day or a night, perhaps a week or a monthâ€”it is uncertain in different individuals.

GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the JURY.â€”
Eighteen Years' Penal Servitude.

226.
ALFRED HAYDEN
, Feloniously receiving a quantity of granite pitching, the property of the
North Metropolitan Tramway Company.

CHRISTOPHER CHARLES FROST .
