I am a carman, of 17, South Grove, Mile End Roadâ€”on 9th October I was in the employ of the North Metropolitan Tramway Company, and was carting stones in the Barking Roadâ€”I left the job about a quarter to nine, and was going through the Commercial Road to Barking; there were two carts besides mine, driven by Shea and Richards; we met a man with a rubbish cart, and had some conversation wit a him, in consequence of which I left my cart in the road, and went up a gateway, and saw the prisonerâ€”I asked him if he could do with the stonesâ€”he asked if they had come down the streetâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said he would come and have a look at themâ€”we went on, and he followed in a horse and van with another personâ€”he came and had a look at the stonesâ€”he asked what we wanted for them; we said 15s.; he said he would give 12s., and said, "Very well, this man will settle with you"â€”that was a dark man, Brownâ€”we went up a sort

of mews, and threw over the three loads of stones into a yard, and Brown paid us 13s. between the three of us, and we shared itâ€”the initials of the company were on our carts, with the numbersâ€”I was afterwards charged with stealing the stones, and convicted.

Cross-examined. I first saw a young man, and asked him if the governors could do with some old stones; I did not call them rubbish stones; they were half stones; there was not much more than half a load in each cartâ€”the carts were standing in a line, one behind the otherâ€”the prisoner looked at each cart from behind; he might be there five minutesâ€”I told him they were worth 25s.; I had never seen him beforeâ€”we thought we were going to get 15s., and another 1s. for beer.

JOHN SHEA . I am a carmanâ€”on 9th October I was employed by the North Metropolitan Tramway Company to take a load from Whitechapel to Barking depÃ´t, with Frost and Richardsâ€”the name of the Company was painted on the front of the cart, and the words "permanent way"â€”we met the prisoner, and Frost had some conversation with him, and he came to the carts with a dark gentleman, and then saw the prisoner; he came and walked round the carts; Frost said he wanted 15s. for the stonesâ€”the prisoner said he would give 12s., and the dark man said, "And is. for a pot of beer each"â€”we then went and threw the stones into a yardâ€”the dark man went with us, and told us where to put themâ€”we then left and shared the moneyâ€”I was afterwards convicted of stealing the stones.
Cross-examined. The prisoner and the dark man were there about five minutes; they stopped and considered together; I did not hear what they saidâ€”these stones were old and dirty.

CHARLES EDWARD RICHAEDS . I am a carmanâ€”I was employed with the others to take these stones to Barking depÃ´tâ€”we stopped on the road, and were told that a man wanted some stones over at the piggeriesâ€”we saw the prisoner, and Frost asked him if he could do with a load of stonesâ€”he said he would come and look at themâ€”he came with a dark gentleman and looked at themâ€”I can't say whether he saw the names on the cartsâ€”I was convicted at West Ham of stealing the stones.

MARTHA MOORCROFT . I am the wife of George Moorcroft, of la, Blanche Street, Hermit Road, opposite Mr. Chambers' yardâ€”on 9th October I was in the shop, and saw Frost go up the gateway with a load of stones; the other two waited outsideâ€”a dark man drove up and spoke to themâ€”all the carts were then taken into the gateway and unloadedâ€”I can't say if the prisoner was there at that time; he was there in the course of the day.
Cross-examined. The yard belongs to Mr. Chambersâ€”I know the prisoner by sight as an agent; he comes to see that everything goes on right at the yard.

JIM SMITH . I am a road foreman in the employ of the Companyâ€”on 9th October I was at work in High Street, Whitechapel, we were taking up old stones and putting down newâ€”we send the old ones to the Barking depotâ€”Frost was working for us as a carmanâ€”at 8.15 I sent him with a load to the depot with the other two menâ€”afterwards, on 16th October, I went with my employer, Mr. Ansell, to the yard in Hermit Road, and identified the stones there.
JOHN WILMER RANSELL . I live at 297, Amhurst Roadâ€”I am resident engineer of the Companyâ€”Frost was employed by us under Smith

on 9th Octoberâ€”on 15th October I went with Detective Sergeant Dicker to a yard in Blanche Street, Hermit Road, and there identified a quantity of stones, the property of the Company, which had been used in Whitechapel; there were about three tons and a quarter, the value of them would be about Â£3 4s.â€”on the evening of 16th October I went to Plaistow Station and saw Frost, Shea, and Richards there in custody; the prisoner came there and said that the men came to him in the yard and asked if he could do with some old stones, that he went and looked at them, and gave 16s. for them; and he produced a book with an entry of 16s. as having been paid for themâ€”he said he was foreman to Mr. Chambers.

Gross-examined. I said before the Magistrate that the value of the stones was 15s. a loadâ€”they were good stones, going to Barking depot to be redressedâ€”I think the Magistrate said that the man who received the stones should be prosecutedâ€”the three men pleaded guilty, so the prisoner was not called as a witnessâ€”he said to me that he had bought the stones for his master, and that he was in the habit of buying things in that wayâ€”the stones were not concealed, they were lying in the roadâ€”we do sell stones sometimes, but always from the depot, not in this wayâ€”the prisoner spoke to me very freely, and answered any questions I asked.
Re-examined. We do not sell stones before their second dressing, then we sell them from our depotâ€”I believe Mr. Chambers has been a customer of ours.

FREDERICK DICKER (Detective Sergeant). On 15th October I accompanied Mr. Ransell to a yard in Hermit Road, and showed him a pile of stones, which he identifiedâ€”about four in the afternoon of the 16th I went to Montague Street, Coburg Square, and there saw the prisonerâ€”I said to him, "You have a pile of stones in your yard at Hermit Road which has been identified as stolen, can you tell me from whom you bought them?"â€”he said, "I don't know the men, but I might if I saw them again"â€”I said, "Did you get a receipt for them?"â€”he said, "No"â€”I said, "Did you take the name and address of the carts?"â€”he said, "I only had a few minutes to see them; I asked them to wait and I would come and look at them; I went to the corner and looked at them, and offered them 16s.; I then went away, and left the money with the man who was working for me to pay for them"â€”I then asked him to accompany me to the Police station to see if he could identify the men, as I had some in custody; he went went with me to Plaistow Station and identified Richards and Shea; he did not identify Frost at first.

Cross-examined. He gave his evidence freelyâ€”I did not think it necessary to caution himâ€”I saw the stones in the yardâ€”I saw two carts in the mews; it struck me as suspiciousâ€”I did not make inquiry; I was engaged in another caseâ€”I have made inquiries about the prisoner; he bears the highest character.
NOT GUILTY .

227.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for a like offenceâ€” No evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

228.
JOHN McCULLOCK (26) and
JOHN STEVENSON (28),
Obtaining, by false pretences, from
Max Joseph Michalowsky, two coats and other goods and Â£2, with intent to defraud. Second Count, for conspiring with others to defraud.

MAX JOSEPH MICHALOWSKY . I am an outfitter, of 7, Dock Streetâ€”about 1.30 on 23rd November the prisoner came to my shopâ€”McCullock said they had been recommended to stop at my place, and asked what I would charge; I said 16s. a week, or half-a-crown a day, for board and lodging; they said yesâ€”I asked what ship they came from; both said the Australasian, and that they were going to be paid off the next day at the Ship, ping office, Tower Hillâ€”we agreed the price, and one stopped in the shop while the other fetched their bagsâ€”I served them with two pairs of boots at 13s. 6d., an overcoat for McCullock at Â£1 17s. 6d., and lent 3s. 6d., to McCullock and 2s. 6d. to Stevenson, as they said they wanted to go to the barberâ€”when they returned I served them with a suit of clothing and Stephenson with an overcoat, hat, collar, and tieâ€”they asked for the loan of a sovereignâ€”I said I had not much change, but lent them 15s. eachâ€”they went away and said they would come back for teaâ€”I next saw them in custodyâ€”I was induced to part with my goods by their saying they were going to be paid off the next day, and I saw they had tickets.

Cross-examined by McCullock. I employ a man, Maxâ€”he did not come with youâ€”I have not been cheated before by sailors with a Board of Trade ticket as you hadâ€”I said at the Police-court I had been cheatedâ€”your bags contained rags, the sweepings of the forecastle; they were shown at the Thames Police-court, and were not worth one shillingâ€”nobody could wear those clothesâ€”I deny that Max brought you; one of my men was in the shopâ€”two when I sold you the clothes, and a man stopping at my place entered the transaction, as I can't writeâ€”Max was not then in the shopâ€”the money I advanced was not your changeâ€”we went over to the public and stood drinks.

Cross-examined by Stevenson. You bought the clothes, and went to the barber while the missus got your dinner readyâ€”you put the boots on in the shop, and your clothes on in a back roomâ€”you did not pay for the clothes.

MYER KOUMISKI . I am a shoemaker, of 38, Wentworth Streetâ€”I work for the prosecutorâ€”I heard the arrangements made for boarding the prisoners, 16s. a weekâ€”the prisoners said they were going to be paid to-morrowâ€”they went upstairs to get their clothesâ€”they asked for a little money to go to the barberâ€”I did not see them after that day.

Cross-examined by McCullock. I was working when you came about four yards from the doorâ€”Max went upstairs with you for the clothesâ€”I do not know if he came in with youâ€”he was not in the shop, that is a mistake.

LOUIS JOHN BOWDEN . I live at 71, Wellington Street, Gravesendâ€”I am a Board of Trade Inspectorâ€”on 22nd November I boarded the ss. Australasian in the riverâ€”it is my duty, and I questioned the prisoners, who were sailors, as to how much of their pay they wished sent home or receive on account, and where they wished it to be sent; they said to Glasgow, and their money transferred to Greenockâ€”I agreed to thatâ€”I ascertained over Â£11 was due to eachâ€”that was forwarded by the superintendent at the pay-officeâ€”the prisoners signed forms which I

handed to the superintendent directly where the money was to be sentâ€”one asked for Â£1 and the other 15s.; I advanced them 10s., the amount allowed by the Board of Tradeâ€”they said they would sleep in the ship, and go home in the morning.
Cross-examined by McCullock. Your wages must be paid through the medium of the Board of Trade.

FREDERICK CHARLES GILBERT . I am a Board of Trade officer at Tower Hillâ€”I produce the prisoners' pay warrants. (MR. BOWDEN identified the prisoners signatures.)â€”I received those from Greenockâ€”the prisoners were paid off at Greenock.

HENRY WHITBREAD (Detective H). I received warrants for the prisoners' arrest; the prisoners were handed over to me by the Glasgow police on 16th Decemberâ€”I read the warrants to themâ€”McCullock said, "If we were not drunk, we should not have gone there"â€”Stevenson said, "We paid for all we had. "

p.hi: The prisoners in defence stated they were induced to go to the prosecutors by his "runner,"Max, and paid for what they had, and drank together with the change the prosecutor gave them.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

229.
HUGH LANG (27)
, Robbery, with other persons unknown, on
Thomas Jones; putting him in fear, and stealing his watch and chain and Â£1 10s.

THOMAS JONES . I live at 18, Hill Street, Custom Houseâ€”I am a firemanâ€”on 4th January I saw the prisoner in the Marine Hotel bar; we had a drink, and then I had to pay my Union subscriptionâ€”I went away and returned to the Marine Hotelâ€”the prisoner, when I went to the back, came behind and struck me in the eye, and sung out to three menâ€”he put his arms round my neck and his hand in my pocket; I had thirty shillings and my watch and chainâ€”he hauled it out and slung me down; by the time I got up they had goneâ€”I was bleedingâ€”I made a complaint at the Seamen's Unionâ€”at the Police-station, when the prisoner lifted his hat up, I identified him.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner, You are a stranger to meâ€”I asked you to have a drink about two p.m.â€”the Seamen's Union is about 150 yards from the Marine Hotelâ€”I left the Marine Hotel about 3.30 or 3.45â€”I did not identify another man at the Police-station.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I live at. 30, Cleaver Road, Custom Houseâ€”about four p.m. I was at the Union officeâ€”the prisoner was standing alongside the counter and speaking to the secretaryâ€”I have known the prisoner a great many years by sightâ€”I saw him with the prosecutor in the office of the Unionâ€”they went out together.

FRANCIS FOWLER . I live at 52, New Mill Streetâ€”I am the secretary of the Tidal Basin branch of the Sailors' Unionâ€”the Railway Tavern and the Marine Hotel are about 150 yards offâ€”on 4th January I was in the office between three and fourâ€”the prosecutor came in and paid 9s. 6d. contribution and 2s. 6d. levyâ€”he knew what he was doingâ€”the prisoner followed himâ€”fifty minutes afterwards the prosecutor came back bleeding from the eyeâ€”he made a complaintâ€”in consequence of that complaint I gave information to the police, and put the prosecutor on the right track.
GEORGE PHILLIPS (160 K). Between three and four on 4th January

the prosecutor was brought to me by Fowler, bleeding and in a bad stateâ€”in consequence of information given I looked for the prisonerâ€”I called him outside the Lilliput, and said, "I shall take you on suspicion of assaulting and robbing a man of Â£2 and his watch and chain"â€”he said, "All right; I suppose I shall have to suffer for somebody else"â€”the prisoner wanted to change his overcoat with another man who came into the station, but was refused; then he put his hat over his eyes, and said he was not there, but the moment he lifted his hat the prosecutor said, "That was the man "at once.
Cross-examined. Another man was not arrested before you.

HUGH MONAGEN . I did not see the prisoner at the Union officeâ€”I saw him in the public-house with the prosecutor, who called for drinkâ€”the prisoner came out of the Marine Hotel between two and threeâ€”I did not see you on the wooden bridge when you said you were going homeâ€”nor on the kerbstoneâ€”I saw you go into "Charley Short's"â€”I saw you going towards the Marine Hotel, and then going back to Short'sâ€”when you came out of Charley Short's you went back to the Marine Hotelâ€”yon stopped there a considerable timeâ€”I saw you come out and go back to Short's.
Cross-examined. I signed my deposition, and was bound over to appear hereâ€”I cannot swear to what happened between three and four.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, said he drank with the prosecutor, but was anxious to get home, and was innocent of robbing him.

div1.p: GUILTY .*

He also
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction in Clerkenwell in October, 1883.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

230.
GEORGE DUFF (62)
PLEADED GUILTY** to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Alexander McKnight, and stealing two coats and other articles, having been convicted of felony at this Court in October, 1887.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

231.
ARNOLD BRABB (39)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Fenn, and stealing twelve rings and other articles, his property.
MR. MUIR, for the prosecution, stated that this was a case of mistaken identity, and not a shadow of imputation rested upon the prisoner; he therefore offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

232.
MARY ANNE GILBY (33)
, Unlawfully neglecting
Thomas Gilby, in a manner likely to cause injury to his health.
NOT GUILTY .

233.
EDWARD SMITH (21) and
JOHN CARTER (22)
, Robbery with violence on
Thomas Raven, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.

THOMAS RAVEN . I am a railway porter, of 12, Gifford Street, Wandsworthâ€”on 26th December I was with Thomas Sylvester in High Street, Clapham, and was about to enter the Two Brewers public-house when the prisoner Smith hit me across my nose and snatched my watch and chainâ€”I had not said anything to himâ€”I held on to him, and Garter hit me across my nose, and took my watch and chain from Smith, who broke away from me and got into a court; I followed, and saw a constable take himâ€”I saw Carter in the Perseverance public-house on the Sunday night, and gave him in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. This was Boxing Night, but I had not had a holidayâ€”I was coming home from work, and had Â£2 5s. 8d. on me; that was not takenâ€”four or five others were with the prisonerâ€”there was plenty of room for any one to pass, but they did not make way for usâ€”they were between me and the public-house, and I was about four yards from the doorâ€”I got hustled by the prisonersâ€”I knew them both by sightâ€”I do not know Lycettâ€”I could not recognise Carter that night, being too much knocked about and from loss of bloodâ€”I did not know very well what I was doing, but I had the prisoners' faces in my head, and could pick them out when I came round a bitâ€”the first blow nearly stunned me.
Cross-examined by Carter. The prisoner said, "Is there anybody here you can recognise?" and I said I would look at them another time.

THOMAS SYLVESTER . I was with Raven, going into a public-house, and the prisoner Smith rushed up and stole Raven's watch and chain, and handed them to Carter, who told Smith to pinch himâ€”I saw both the prisoners strike himâ€”after Carter got the watch he got up in a cart, and Raven ran after Smith and held him till a constable was coming up; he then broke away, but was given in custodyâ€”I knew Carter before, and have no doubt about him.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. Five or six men were standing between me and the public-house, all rough-looking charactersâ€”Smith was not one of the group; he rushed out of the public-houseâ€”I was very much frightenedâ€”it was Boxing Night; I had not been at workâ€”Raven was very much dazed.
Cross-examined by Carter. You went down to the station that night, and when I knew you were outside I called Raven.

GEORGE BENNETT (Policeman). I went to the Two Brewers, and saw a number of people outside, and the two prisoners; Carter had & pony-barrow, and Smith got inâ€”Raven came up from the same direction, and Smith ranâ€”he made a communication to me, and I took Smith to the station and charged him with stealing a watch and chain, and violently assaulting Raven, whose nose and mouth were bleeding; he looked dazed, as if he had had a thorough good hiding; his face was smothered with bloodâ€”Smith made no reply to the chargeâ€”on the Sunday afternoon I went out, in plain clothes, with Raven, who gave me a signal by raising
his hat; Carter came out of a public-house, and Raven said, "That is the man who received the watch from Smith"â€”Carter said, "I will go with you, governor; I know nothing about it. "
Cross-examined. There were a number of rough-looking men about-Smith was admitted to bail after he had been on remand a week.

MR. LYCETT. I was with you, and followed Smith to the station Raven came out, and you said to him, "What do you charge Smith with? has he got a watch and chain about him?" he said, "No"; the constable came up, and Raven said he could not identify you.

By MR. SANDS. I did not see Raven knocked about; I saw no one struck. I did not see Raven covered with bloodâ€”it was I who had the struggle with himâ€”he struck me first, and I struck him in self-defenceâ€”Smith was standing byâ€”Carter was not thereâ€”I only struck Raven once; he struck me and knocked me down, and I struck him; we had a bit of a tussle, and he got up and said that Smith, who was standing by, had his watch.

â€”
GUILTY .

Carter then
PLEADED GUILTY** to or conviction of felony at Wandsworth Police-court on February 26th, 1885.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour each.

234.
FREDERICK PAVEY
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

JOHN ASPLAND . I keep the King's Head, Tootingâ€”on the night of December 16th I served the prisoner with half a pint of 4d. ale; he paid with a penny, and then called for a second half-pint and put down a florin before he was served; my barman Jeffreys took it up and showed it to meâ€”I bit a piece out of it; it felt grittyâ€”I told the prisoner it was bad; he said he did not know itâ€”I said that I should give him in charge; he said he did not mind thatâ€”I told him he had passed one three weeks before; he said he did not know it was badâ€”that was a half-crown, three weeks before Boxing Dayâ€”I had spoken to him about it at the time.

Cross-examined. He comes in about twice a week, but he had only been in once in the intervalâ€”he knew that I knew himâ€”I thought he was a respectable man until he brought the second coinâ€”he made no attempt to run awayâ€”I have said, "I know he has been a little bit strange in the bar"â€”I gave the half-crown back to him because he said he received it in his wagesâ€”three farthings were found on him, not sufficient to pay for the beer.
Re-examined. I bit the half-crown, and it was gritty.

GEORGE FELLOWS (Detective V). Mr. Aspland gave the prisoner into my custody at the King's Headâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said, "I received it in change at a tobacconist's shop up the roadâ€”I took him to the station, and then he said, "I found it under the carpet in the roomâ€”he might have had drink, but was not the slightest the worse for itâ€”I searched him in the house, and found three farthingsâ€”the landlord gave me this piece of coin, and said to the prisoner, "You brought a bad half crown here about three weeks ago"â€”he said, "I did not know it was bad. "
Cross-examined. He has been in Wandsworth Infirmary in consequence of a heavy fallâ€”he suffers from giddiness, and I have been told he is not
quite right in his headâ€”he is a respectable man; there is nothing against him.

MARY ASPLAND . I am the prosecutor's wifeâ€”about three weeks before Christmas I saw the prisoner in the bar about 9.30â€”he asked for half a pint of beer; I served him; he gave me 1d., and about twenty minutes afterwards he called for more, and put down a half-crownâ€”I took it up, And said, "This is bad; did you know it was bad?"â€”he said, "No, I nave just taken it"â€”I showed it to my husband.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to the Queen's Mintâ€”this coin is bad; it is bentâ€”grittiness is one of the indications of a coin being counterfeit if the teeth sink into it."
NOT GUILTY .

235.
JAMES WARREN (31) and
MARY ANN SULLIVAN (24)
, Unlawfully administering to
Katherine Moore certain rum with intent to stupefy her, and enable Warren to have connection with her.

WARRENâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

SULLIVANâ€”
GUILTY**
on all counts except those for assault. â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

236.
OSBORN HINBEST (36),
CATHERINE HINBEST (40), and
JOSEPH WARD (17)
, Stealing a basket of tools, the property of
Robert Thompson. Second Count, Feloniously receiving the same.
MR. MUIR Prosecuted, MR. LAWLESS appeared for 0. Hinbest, and MR. SANDS for Catherine Hinbest.

ROBERT THOMPSON . I am a carpenter, of Montagu Terrace, Forest Hillâ€”on 28th November I was working at a house at Forest Hill; I think it was No. 272â€”at the end of the day, about 6.30,1 left my tools locked in a roomâ€”I returned at seven a.m., and found the door-jamb split right down, and the tools gone; these are them (produced)â€”I gave no authority to anyone to take them away.
Cross-examined. It is very uncommon for workmen to sell their tools; they sometimes pawn them.

BERNARD WENNESTEIN . I am a jeweller and watchmaker, of 157, High Street, Batterseaâ€”my premises were broken into on 27th July, and I missed over thirty watches, and a box with some rings and little bits of goldâ€”I identify these two watches as stolen from my place.
Cross-examined. They are-Worth more than 15s. each to the customers they belong to.

ALFRED HOOK . I am a carpenter, of 20, Eastman Road, Pengeâ€”on 2nd October I was working at a house at Lavender Hillâ€”I left soma, tools in a room upstairs at 6.30, and at 6.30 a.m. I found the room door forced open and the tools gone; two saws, a plane, and a chiselâ€”these are them (produced).

HENRY PERCY THOMPSON . I am a clerk in holy orders, of Raven House, Bridge Road, Batterseaâ€”on 28th October I missed this hose (produced), which was screwed on to a tap in my back gardenâ€”it was partly cut off and partly jaggedâ€”it is mine, and is worth 30s.

NATHANIEL HITCHMAN . I am a mason's assistant, of 2, St. James's Grove, Batterseaâ€”this is my watchâ€”I lost it on November 7 at the Havelock public-house, Battersea Park Road; that is half a mile from 151, Battersea Park Road, and 150 yards from Ashwin Streetâ€”there
was a little scuffle with some lads rushing to get out, and when I got home I missed my watchâ€”it had a bow and a chain thenâ€”I value it at Â£1

JOHN CHARLES BELL . I am an estate-agent, at 470, Battersea Park Roadâ€”this india-rubber mat is mineâ€”I know it because I had it specially made to fit the lobby outside my officeâ€”I missed it after dark on November 19, and informed the police.
Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. I only know it by the shape; the front edge is longer than the back edgeâ€”I value it at Â£1.

HENRY MYER . I am manager to William Gardner and Co., sugar-refiners, of Plough Lane, Batterseaâ€”I have seen a sack containing fifty-six lbs. of saccharine, marked, "B. B. and Co."â€”we stamped that sack for a customer as distinguished from our own mark, but it is one of our bags, and the saccharine is exactly like oursâ€”here are other sacks here marked, "B. B. and Co."â€”these others are bags, not marked, but exactly like ours, and these marked, "Gardner, Hill and Co. "are oursâ€”we never send out empty bagsâ€”we get some back and some we do notâ€”these two have been usedâ€”Hampton is our principal carrierâ€”the carriers' men have access to the place where the bags are storedâ€”we keep thousands of bags in stock, and have no means of checking the loss of a few.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. We supply a great quantity of saccharineâ€”I believe there is one other manufacturer of itâ€”I should not miss a bag of it; there is nothing to identify it byâ€”these are not old sacks, they have never been used; this one has been used and has our mark on it.

HENRY PERRETT . I am a solicitor, of 75, Bank Buildings, Queen Victoria Streetâ€”prior to 1890 I acted for the owners of two houses, 2 and 4, Hart Street, Battersea, and in April, 1891, Osborn Hinbest came to know whether I had a client who would lend Â£450 on two houses belonging to his wifeâ€”I told him I had, but I must have his wife's retainer or authority to get the moneyâ€”that was brought me, signed by Mrs. Hinbestâ€”I secured the money, and the loan was (completedâ€”I wrote this letter to Hinbest. (This stated that as the prisoner had not called according to promise, he would be charged 10s. 6d. extra).

Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. It was freehold property; I advanced the money on mortgageâ€”the title-deed is in Mrs. Catherine Hinbest's name, conveying to her the freehold, dated May 15th, 1888, conveying it to her absolutelyâ€”he only paid me one or two small sums, she paid me the restâ€”I paid the insurance, which was made out in her name alsoâ€”I see her here; she is the female prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. I had not known her before thisâ€”she is described in this document as the wife of Osborn Giuseppe Hinbest I inquired of her whether she was Mrs. Hinbest; she said, "Yes"â€”I made all necessary inquiries to protect my clientsâ€”Osborn Hinbest was not a party to either deedâ€”I went to the premises and saw the female prisoner thereâ€”the result was that I felt justified.

Re-examined. No question of title turned on the question as to whether she was married to Hinbest or notâ€”I made no investigation to verify whether that was the factâ€”I asked her whether she was his wife, and she said, "Yes"â€”I found she was trading as Catherine Ward, and I put that into the transfer.
ALFRED BEECHAM . I live at 141D, Battersea Park Road; the house

belongs to me; it is a shopâ€”there are two rooms and a wash-house at the back, and a yard, and a piece of ground, but no shedsâ€”I let it on June 1st to Mr. Hinbest at 12s. per weekâ€”I never took the rent myself; these are two receipts. (Dated May 29th, and June 2nd, 1891.)

Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. I frequently passed by; he was more frequently there than anybody elseâ€”there are two rooms behind the shop on the same floor, and my boy told me that he slept thereâ€”it has been a greengrocer's shop, it is now a marine store dealer's shop.

JOHN WHITE . I married the daughter of the female prisoner on August 3rd, 1890â€”I have known the female prisoner between three and four yearsâ€”I did not know her when her late husband was aliveâ€”I have been in the shop in Arthur Streetâ€”the mistress managed the top shop and Mr. Hinbest managed the bottom shop, No. 141, since 1890â€”I have seen Hinbest at two, three, or four shops since 1890, attending to the placeâ€”since he took No. 141 he has not attended to the other business, but he used to come up of a night when the business at 141 was closed, but not every nightâ€”if he got to Arthur Street before the business closed he generally sat in the kitchenâ€”the mistress paid the sorters since 1890â€”I fix 1890 as the date because after I got married I used towork somewhere else, and I came back at the beginning of 1891â€”I know nothing about it for that yearâ€”at the beginning of 1891 the mistress paid the sortersâ€”I am the son-in-law of Catherine "Wardâ€”I do not know whether Osborn Hinbest is married to her, but I hear they are not married.
Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. Osborn Hinbest took the place, and slept there every nightâ€”the female prisoner managed the businessâ€”he slept at No. 141.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. It was a week or two ago that I heard they were not marriedâ€”they have been living four years as man and wife, and I believed they were married till Mr. Herry, the solicitor who defended her at Wandsworth, told me a week or two ago that they were notâ€”the solicitor has been changed since then.

JOHN WINDSOR (Detective Sergeant V), On 3rd December I received two search-warrants for Nos. 2 and 4, Arthur Street, and 141, Battersea Park Road, and went with an officer to 4, Arthur Street, between three and four p.m.â€”No. 2 and No. 4 are both marine store shops; No. 3 is a shed on the opposite side of the way, used for stowing rags, bottles, and bonesâ€”I saw the female* prisoner at No. 4, and said, "You are Mrs. Hinbest?"â€”she said, "Yes"â€”I said, "I know Mr. Hinbest is not in; we are police-officers, and have a warrant to search your place"â€”she said, "You won't find anything here"â€”Sergeant Bancroft commenced searching the kitchen and the shop; and among some rags he found this watch and two spoons (produced) and handed them to meâ€”I did not actually see them foundâ€”while I was searching the shop the male prisoner came to the door, which was bolted; I let him in and said, "You know me?"â€”he said, "No; what are you doing here?"â€”I said, "We are police-officers, and are searching your premises under a search-warrant"â€”he said, "Let me see it"â€”I read it to him; he said, "I don't know anything about it"â€”I showed him the watch and spoons, and said they had been found among the rags on the premises; he said, "I don't know anything about them, I am not in the business; if there is anything here I know nothing about it"â€”he remained in the kitchen,

and I and other officers were engaged in searching; and in a back room up among a large quantity of rags, entirely covered, I found this basket with two lots of tools in it, and in the shop downstairs, among a quantity of rags and bones, I found two india rubber mats, one of which has been identified by Mr. Bellâ€”I showed them to the three prisoners at No. 4, and said, "These things will ultimately form the proceeds of various larcenies, and you will be taken in custody for receiving them"â€”they were taken to the station, when the female prisoner said she bought the mat for 3s. of a man whose name she gaveâ€”"Ward said, u Yes, he left some lead for us; he has not yet been paid"â€”these things were before them at the timeâ€”with regard to the tools, she said, "They have been there a long time"â€”the hose was found next morning upstairs, also covered with ragsâ€”at the Police-court the female prisoner said as to the hose, "I purchased that from a man named Coleman; I do not know his address, but he is well known; I gave 3s. for it"â€”Ward said, "Yes, that is quite right"â€”I subsequently gave directions for Coleman's arrest; he was taken, and said, "I know nothing about it"â€”he was taken to the Police court and confronted with the three prisonersâ€”I said to the female prisoner, "Is this the man you bought the watch of?"â€”she said, "Yes"; I said to Coleman, "If this person says she gave you 3s. for that watch, is that true?"â€”he said, "No"â€”he was placed with several others, and Hitchman failed to identify himâ€”he was charged and dischargedâ€”the female prisoner said, "Yes, that is true; I did give you 3s. "; he said, "No, that is all that I owe her, half-a-crown"â€”Coleman was dischargedâ€”I served a copy of this notice on Osboro Hinbest on the 2nd at Hollowayâ€”this is the originalâ€”the name at 4, Arthur Street, was "Catherine Ward, Marine Store Dealer"â€”when 141, Battersea Park Road was searched, Sergeant Foley showed me four finger-plates which he found; they were taken away with other thingsâ€”I found these letters, one on the female prisoner and one among the papers; also this letter, from Mr. Perrett, and a half-sovereign; and these papers, at 4, Arthur Street, not on the person of anybodyâ€”I have known the prisoners in Arthur Street three years, and during the last six months I have seen the three prisoners there and a younger son of the female prisonerâ€”I have seen Osborn there, morning and evening, once or twice a week, but I was not always that way. (Several receipts were here put in.)

Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. There were six remands at the Policecourtâ€”I was put into the box, but not, I think, four timesâ€”I did not see the finger-plates foundâ€”I was called after Sergeant Foley.

Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. I never saw a place so full as it was; every room, even the kitchen and bedroom, had all sorts of lumberâ€”Coleman was arrested in consequence of the female prisoner's statement; it was her word against Coleman's.
Re-examined. I found no books at Arthur Street.

JOHN FOLEY (Police Sergeant). On December 3rd I assisted in searching at Arthur Street and 141, Battersea Park Roadâ€”at Arthur Street I found, in an anteroom at the top of the stairs, a bag of saccharine marked "B. B. and Co.,"concealed under some ragsâ€”I also assisted in the search of the next shop, No. 2, and found fifty new sacks, and other sacks, amounting to between 400 and 500, distributed in various parts, and somewhat concealed; the prisoners, I believe, had let that shop, and were clearing it out to make room for the incoming tenantâ€”the bags

wore all loose, not tied up in any wayâ€”some of the bags, with the name of "Gordon, Hill, and Co.,"had been turned inside out to conceal the marking, and other bags packed into themâ€”they are identified by Mr. Myerâ€”I went to Battersea Park Road, with other officers, on the 4th, and in a room at the back of the shop, just alongside the bed which Hinbest was supposed to occupy, I found these four finger-plates, which were taken to the station and shown to the prisoners with the other property, and they were asked how they accounted for the sacksâ€”Ward said, "These sacks were brought with the saccharine by one of Austin's men on Tuesday morning"; that would be December 1stâ€”I asked how much he paid for themâ€”he said, "I did not pay for them, my mother was not at home at the time"â€”the mother said she had not seen the propertyâ€”the lad gave a description of the man who brought themâ€”Hinbest said he knew nothing at all about themâ€”I found no business books at either house.
Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. The bed looked as if it had been used; there were bed-clothes on itâ€”I saw no washing utensilsâ€”the finger-plates are worth about 8d. each.
Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. I found the new bags at No. 2 with a lot of rubbishâ€”that was the place where the sorters workedâ€”I found bags full of bags turned inside out.

HENRY JARMAN (Detective Serjeant W). I assisted the other officers at the search at Arthur Streetâ€”I went upstairs with Ward, and in the front bedroom found two watches, part of a watch-chain, seven brooches, two bangles, a silver necklace, a coral necklace, a plated tankard, two chains, four rings, a meerschaum pipe, and a watch bow; some were in a chest of drawers, some in the drawers, and some on the mantelpiece and in various parts of the roomâ€”Mr. Wennestein identified the two watches; I found this one on the drawers, and Ward said, "That is my watch, and the other is my brother's; I bought them; that one has a bow, but one hand is off"â€”I said, "You are a young man buying things like these"â€”he said, "I am seventeen, and am a partner in the business"â€”we also found a quantity of new silk in the drawers.
Cross-examined by Mr. SANDS. The articles were lying about all over the place, not locked upâ€”this is all the jewellery I could findâ€”there is one English lever watch.

JOHN PATRICK (Police Sergeant 69 V). I am located in Batterseaâ€”I assisted in searching 2 and 4, Arthur Street, and found a watch without a bow, concealed under a quantity of rags; I was present on 2nd December when Osborn Hinbest charged a lad named Mulroy with' stealing some rags; he said that his business was at 141, Battersea Park Road, and that he occupied premises at 3a, Arthur Street and signed the charge-sheetâ€”the things were supposed to be stolen from 3, Arthur Streetâ€”Hinbest said they were his propertyâ€”3, Arthur Street is a warehouse, and there is a warehouse opposite No. 2 and No. 4.
Cross-examined by MR. SANDS. Mulroy made some statement when he was charged, and after that a fresh warrant was applied for.

WILLIAM STEVENS (186 V). I assisted in searching Nos. 2, 3, and 4, Arthur Streetâ€”I found at No. 4 a number of window fittings, and in this sack these 43 finger-plates, and in the backyard a number of sacks of old bottlesâ€”I have been about that neighbourhood for the last six months,
and have seen the three prisoners there frequently; I have seen Osborn at two o'clock and at eight p.m. frequently in the evening.
Cross-examined by MR. LAWLESS. It took eight or nine of us three days to search the place and turn the rags and filth over; I found a large number of other things which have not been identified.

WILLIAM HENRY RICKARDS . I am a builderâ€”in October last I was building some houses at Footbridge Road, Clapham Common, and had a number of window fittings stored at No. 68, and 47 finger-platesâ€”these 262 window fastenings and 47 door-plates produced, are identical with what I lostâ€”they are worth Â£3

THOMAS BATES (Policeman). I was present at the London Sessions, Newington, in April, 1889, when Osborn Hinbest was convicted of receiving stolen goods, and sentenced to twelve monthsâ€”the prisoner is the man.
Osborn Hinbest's statement before the Magistrate. I have nothing to say, only I have never seen the things."
Ward's Defence. I do not know anything about it.

p.hi: submitted that the prisoner Catherine ought to be acquitted, as she could not receive from her husband. There being no allegation as to who the thief was, the
to say whether the two Hinbests were man and wife.

div1.p:
â€”
GUILTY on the second count.
OSBORN HINBEST**.â€”
Five years' Penal Servitude.
CATHERINE HINBEST.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
WARD.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

237.
GEORGE HERBERT BUSH
PLEADED GUILTY to two indictments for housebreaking
and burglary, after a conviction at Worship Street on August 6, 1889, in the name of
Arthur West.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

238.
GEORGE WARNE (34)
, Unlawfully taking
Elizabeth Hill, aged under sixteen, out of the possession of her mother, with intent, &c.

GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the JURY, the girl being as bad as the prisoner, and evidently looking older than sixteen. â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.

239.
THOMAS McCAWLEY (21) and
GEORGE ROBERTSON (18)
, soldiers, Robbery with violence on
John Hurley, and stealing 7s. 6d., his money.

JOHN HURLEY, JUNIOR . I am a labourer, and live at Warlingham Stationâ€”on Saturday evening, the 26th December, about half-past eight, I was going from Caterham to my homeâ€”as I was passing Wapsis Lodge, which is about five minutes' walk from home, the two prisoners came upâ€”McCawley said, "Give me the price of a drink"â€”I said,** I have no money to give, and I know nothing about you"â€”McCawley said, "We must have some," and he tried to put his hands in my coat pocketâ€”I had nothing in that pocket; I had 7s. 6d. in three half-crowns in my left-hand trousers pocket, and is and a few halfpence in my right hand pocketâ€”I told McCawley to keep his hands out of my pockets, and then he said to Robertson, "Of! with your belt"â€”they both took off their belts, and McCawley struck me on the back of my head with his

belt, knocking me to the groundâ€”then they dragged me about thirty yards up a bye-lane, going to Upper Warlinghamâ€”both got on top of me, and one (I cannot say which) put his hands in my pockets and took these three half-crowns outâ€”I felt the hand in my pocketâ€”Robertson was on me and McCawley was standing up kicking me in the backâ€”McCawley said to Robertson, "Have you got it?"â€”Robertson did not say anythingâ€”my father came up to my assistance and hit one of them with a half-gallon bottle which he had in his handâ€”they got off me then and turned on him, and when I rose up I saw they had him on the ground kicking him, and when I got to his assistance they ran awayâ€”directly I got up I found my three half-crowns were goneâ€”I was not able to follow themâ€”I could not see anything of them after they ran awayâ€”I had a cut on the head, and my back was very much hurt; I have not been able to do any work since.

Cross-examined by McCawley. I, my father, and another man were together when you met us; there were three of usâ€”I don't know where my brother was; I saw him when I got up, after you had us on the groundâ€”you knocked me down with your beltâ€”I don't know how you did it when my father and the other man were with meâ€”my brother is James Hurley; he came up after you struck me; we did not know he was coiningâ€”it was you put your hand inâ€”I did not say in my last statement that it was Robertson, but youâ€”the other man was with my father and meâ€”I cannot say if my brother was with you; I did not see him before I got off the groundâ€”I could not do much when you hit me on the head with your belt.

Cross-examined by Robertson. I was with my father and another manâ€”it left an injury on my headâ€”McCawley said to you, "Have you got it?"â€”I did not see my brother when I met you firstâ€”my father is an old man.

Re-examined. I was with my father and Burkisâ€”when McCawley came and spoke to me and put his hand in my pocket and they assaulted us, Burkis turned to light his pipe, I believe, and my father was on the other side of the roadâ€”I did not know my brother was thereâ€”the prisoners had big coats on them.

JOHN HURLEY, SENIOR . I am the father of the last witnessâ€”I am a labourer, living at the stationâ€”on the Saturday night after Christmas, about half-past eight, I was going home from Caterham with my son and Burkis, when. the two prisoners, who were coming from Warlingham way, met us against Wapsis Lodgeâ€”they came to my son and stopped him, and wanted money for beer, and he said he did not have any money and they had a few words more, but I heard one of them, I don't know which, say, "Off with the belts," and then one of them hit him and knocked him down, and they both came down on him and dragged him about thirty yards up a bye-lane going to Warlinghamâ€”I had a bottle in my hand with half a gallon of beer in it, and I went and hit one of them with the bottle, and McCawley then came and hit me, knocked me down and kicked me, and broke my nose, with his foot I supposeâ€”when I hit one with the bottle both were on top of my sonâ€”I recognised the two men directly, because there was a light in the house opposite, and they dragged my son into the bye-lane, and it was dark thereâ€”when they kicked me I was knocked senseless, and when I got up they were goneâ€”I went to the
barracks and reported it, and they told me to go up next morning at ten o'clockâ€”the postmen found some of their clothes next morning.

Re-examined by McCawley. I was with my son and the other man, and saw you knock my son downâ€”I could not tell which of you two took off your belt; I saw the belts swingingâ€”you both asked him for the price of a drinkâ€”you knocked up against himâ€”I was a few steps away; I went forward; I did not think it would come to what it didâ€”I saw one of you swing your belt and knock my son down, and you dragged him into the side roadâ€”I went over as quick as I could, as soon as you knocked him down and dragged him into that laneâ€”the bye-road is not thirty or forty yards from the lodgeâ€”I saw it doneâ€”I had a man with meâ€”I did not see you take any money.
Cross-examined by Robertson. I was coming with my son and one manâ€”we did not come and flock round youâ€”it was a bottle I hit with.

Re-examined. I and my. son were coming from Caterhamâ€”I heard them speak to my son, and went on a little bit, as I did not think it was coming to anything till I saw the belt swinging and knock him down.

HARRY BURKIS . I am a labourer, and live at Upper Caterhamâ€”on this Saturday night I was going along the road with the two John Hurleys, and when we got opposite Wapsis Lodge we met two soldiers, the two prisonersâ€”the tall one asked John Hurley, junior, for the price of a drinkâ€”he said he had not got anything, and did not know anything about themâ€”they then started going across the road; the three of them went across, and then the father went acrossâ€”I was standing in the middle of the road lighting my pipe; Hurley shouted out, and I went across to himâ€”the soldiers were gone then; they ran awayâ€”I did not see them do anything to Hurley; it was too dark, I could not see; I saw young Hurley lying down in the ditchâ€”I could not see the old manâ€”I picked the young man upâ€”I had seen the prisoners before that evening in the valley.
Cross-examined by McCawley. I never had anything to do with youâ€”I did not see you coming along the road before we met you; I did not see you do anything; I only heard what you said to him.

Cross-examined by Robertson. I was coming down the road, and you came up to us; you asked John Hurley for the price of a drink; I did not see you take your belts off or using themâ€”when John Hurley got hold of you he was not lying on his back; you had gone when I got up.
Re-examined. All I heard of the disturbance was hearing them shout out.

JAMES HURLEY . I am a brother of the prosecutor, and the son of John Hurleyâ€”on Saturday night, 26th December, I was coming along Caterham Valley, in conversation with McCawley and Robertson; we went towards Warlingham, and when we got within 200 yards of Warlingham Station Robertson said, "I will go no further, as we are getting out of bounds, and shall be late at barracks"â€”they asked me for the price of a drink, and I put twopence into McCawley's hand he said, "I am sure you have got some more"; I said, "I have not; I have done no work since last Saturday "; McCawley said to Robertson, "Have you got your revolver?"he said, "Yes"â€”McCawley said to me, "You need not follow us any further"â€”I said, "I am not following you, I am going after my father and my brother"â€”we got to the he age

and met my father and brother, and they asked him for the price of a drinkâ€”my brother said, "My father has got a bottle here, and if you like to come home you can have a drink"â€”they answered, "We want some money, and we must have it"; and they hit my brother, I don't know what with, but he fell to the ground, and they dragged him about thirty yards up a bye-lane; I ran part of the way up, and they were on top of himâ€”I did not hear anything saidâ€”I stopped there till my father rushed up and hit him with the bottle he had in his hand, and the prisoners got off him and knocked my father down, and kicked him and ran away, and jumped over a hedgeâ€”I did not see any more of themâ€”I was close to them, about a dozen yards away from themâ€”on the Sunday I found a belt with 135 on it, over the hedge where they jumped over.

Cross-examined by McCawley. Robertson asked me for the price of a drink, but I gave the twopence to youâ€”I don't know what you did with itâ€”my father and brother stopped behind, and I returned when I met themâ€”I did not say anything to my fatherâ€”I did not go to them and speak to themâ€”we did not get round youâ€”I kept half-a-dozen yards away from youâ€”I saw one of you knock my brother downâ€”I did not see you kick him; but I saw one of you kick my father; I cannot say which of you, because it was darkâ€”I found the belt over the hedge the next dayâ€”you jumped over that hedge into a meadow when you ran away.
Cross-examined by Robertson. I said nothing to my father; I never went so far as my father, when you met them I stoppedâ€”the belt was over the hedgeâ€”I gave it to my father.

By the JURY. McCawley had had a drop of drink, I believe, but Robertson was quite rightâ€”none of my party was intoxicated, we were all sober; we went to the barracks afterwards, and they can prove we were sober.

THOMAS BUSH . I am postman at Warlingham Stationâ€”on Sunday, 27th December, I was coming down the road in the early morning, and came against somethingâ€”I struck a match, and found this cape, cap, and stick; I picked them up and carried them to the office, and gave them into the hands of Mr. Grabholt, the Master of Warlingham Stationâ€”I found them in the middle of the road.

JOHN STEELE . I am a sergeant in the Scots Guards, quartered at Caterhamâ€”this cap, No. 209, is the property of Private George Robertson, and this cape, No. 303, is the property of Thomas McCawley; this. stick is the property of Robertson, and this belt belongs to Private McCawleyâ€”I remember the night of 26th December; I was at the barracksâ€”I did not see any of the Hurleys; if they came to make a complaint I did not receive it.

WILLIAM TIDD JOHN . I am a surgeon, practising at Caterham Valleyâ€”on Sunday, 27th December, I saw the prosecutor, John Hurley, junior, and his fatherâ€”John Hurley, junior, had a cut on the right side of his head and a bruise on the bridge of his nose, and his face was scratchedâ€”the cut on his head could be caused by a blow from something sharp; it might have been done with this belt; it was not seriousâ€”the bruises on the back of his head were not serious, but they looked as if he had had several blowsâ€”the father had his nose damaged; it was badly
broken; I cannot say how it was done; it might have been done by a kick.
Cross-examined by McCawley. It looked as if his nose had been stamped upon; I should say it could be done by one of these buckles.

JOHN BRIDE . I am an Inspector of the Surrey Police, stationed at Caterhamâ€”on 27th December, at nine a.m., the prosecutor came to the station and made a complaint; he handed me this cap, cape, and stickâ€”I saw he was injured in the faceâ€”I told him he would have to accompany me to the barracksâ€”we went there, with Hurley, senior, and James Hurleyâ€”I made my complaint to the sergeant-major, and the prisoners were paraded, and identified by Hurley, senior and juniorâ€”I charged them with violently assaulting John Hurley, senior, and John Hurley, junior, and stealing from the person of John Hurley, junior, the sum of 7s. 6d. in money, on the highway at Caterham, on 26th December, 1891â€”McCawley replied, "That is wrong; they attacked us first"â€”Robertson said nothingâ€”I took them to the station; nothing was found on themâ€”the cap was lying on the table, and Robertson said, "That is my cap. "
The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate. Robertson says:" We do not wish to say anything. "McCawley says: We are not guilty as to the money part."

McCawley's Defence. We met these men in a public-house, and they asked me the road; we walked out, I first and Robertson after me; he said, "It is as near this way as the other"; we walked about two miles on the road, and I said, "It is time to go back to barracks"; we met the two men Hurley; they got round us, and he hit me on my eye; I gave him a punch and took off my belt; he struck me, and I fell; I got up and ran; I was sober; it is all false about the money.

Robertson's Defence. We went to the public-house and were drinking there, and this man Hurley struck McCawley; he came over to me and said, "Do you know this man?"â€”I said, "No"; two men came in and shook hands with us; a third came and we walked out; they said, "Will you go home with us?"â€”we said, "Yes," and went about a mile; I said, "We are going too far," and we turned back as far as this hedge, and the son went and spoke to the father; they got round us, and the son hit McCawley, and McCawley hit him back; McCawley got knocked down, and I went to his assistance and got knocked down and kicked; the father had something tied up in a handkerchief; I ran; I was glad to get away, but John Hurley kept hold of my hand and said, "Come and kick them "; they were all drunk in the public-house.
NOT GUILTY .

240.
THOMAS WILLIAMS (21),
JOHN DIMBER (17), and
HENRY FALBY (16)
PLEADED GUILTY
to burglary in the dwellinghouse of
Thomas Binstead, and stealing thirty-three coats and other goods.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

241.
GEORGE BROOKS (18),
FREDERICK SMITH (37),
JAMES LEWIS (18), and
JOHN CONNOR (22)
, Burglary in the dwellinghouse of
Thomas Barrett, and stealing three jackets, eight overcoats, and other goods, his goods and chattels. Second Count, receiving the same.

THOMAS BARRETT . I live at 3, Causeway Place, Newington Causeway, S. E; I closed my premises on the evening of 8th Decemberâ€”I was called up by two constables about two a.m.; I saw my clothing was goneâ€”a pane of glass was brokenâ€”I had fastened the shutter; it was loweredâ€”I missed sixteen coats, three pairs of trousers, and two waistcoatsâ€”this coat was shown to me as having been on Connorâ€”it is mine; there is the tacking cotton; that was there on the Wednesday nightâ€”I had just started the job, but being a particular job I could not go on with it, and so hung it up till the next morningâ€”this handkerchief was shown to me as having been found on Lewis; that is mine.

JAMES AL (9721). On 10th December I saw the prisoners loitering in the neighbourhood of 3, Causeway Place, Borough, about two a.m.â€”I examined the glass of the window of No. 3â€”I had been there shortly after oneâ€”it was all safeâ€”I roused the prosecutor, called the assistance of another constable, who went inâ€”I remained outside till the prosecutor came out with the other constable and Brooks.
Cross-examined by Smith. I saw you between eleven and one o'clock that night.

WILLIAM GENTLE (Detective M). On 10th December I went with Dywell and three officers to the lodging-house at 21, Southwark Place, shortly after nine a.m.; I went up to the bedroom and saw Smith, Connor, and Lewis in bedâ€”we awoke themâ€”Lewis said, "What do you want?"â€”I said, "We are police officers, and shall arrest you for breaking and entering a tailor's shop in* the Causeway last night"â€”he said, "All right"â€”we took them downstairs, and handed them over to the other officers, who took them to the stationâ€”I searched the kitchen, and found this sack containing coats, trousers, and waistcoatsâ€”I took them to the station, they were identified by the prosecutor as his property, and having been stolen from his shop the previous nightâ€”the prisoners were chargedâ€”they made no replyâ€”Connor was wearing this coat at the stationâ€”it was identified by the prosecutor.

Cross-examined by Smith. I think the bedroom in the lodging-house holds twenty-six bedsâ€”if another man had been sleeping where you were, and answered the description given me as accurately as you did, I should have taken him to the station.

Cross-examined by Connor. I did not notice a bundle of clothing when I first went into the lodging-house kitchenâ€”a man named Baker was arrested, but we were unable to get sufficient evidence against himâ€”the deputy's son identified him as the man who brought the clothes inâ€”but we found the boy told lies.

THOMAS DYWELL (Detective M). I went with Gentle to 181, Great South wark Street on the morning of the 10thâ€”I found Connor, Lewis, and Smith in bedâ€”I arrested Lewisâ€”I searched himâ€”I found this pocket-handkerchief in his left-hand coat pocketâ€”the prosecutor identified itâ€”I assisted Connor to put this coat onâ€”when I charged Smith he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "You will be charged with being concerned with others in committing the burglary"â€”the burglary had been mentionedâ€”I saw the property at the lodging-house which was identified by Gentle.

Cross-examined by Smith. I did not say at the Police-court, "I am almost sure you are innocent"â€”I did not find anything on you relating to the robberyâ€”I should have taken anyone sleeping where you were

who answered your descriptionâ€”I did not know Baker had committed the burglary, or I should have detained himâ€”I apprehended him, took him to the station; but from inquiries I made, and from the statements made by the boy, I found it was impossible for the crime to have been committed by the time the boy statedâ€”the boy said he saw Baker come into the lodging-house at 10.30 with the clothes under his arm; then he said it was a quarter to eleven, and then shortly before elevenâ€”I do not know what you said yes to; you said it when chargedâ€”I did not try to connect you with the handkerchief found on Lewisâ€”you did not at the Police-court correct the u underwriter" and he did not have to cross anything off, to ray knowledge.

Cross-examined by Connor. From inquiries we found it was impossible for the burglary to have been committed between ten and eleven, therefore Baker was liberatedâ€”the boy made a statement at the Police-court; he did not make this statement to me, that when he saw Baker come in with the clothes in his arms he said, "Take those out of this house, you will get my father into trouble," and that Baker replied, "Hold your noise; it is all right; don't say nothing till the morning."
Re-examined. I was cross-examined by Smithâ€”he asked if he had been previously convicted.

PATRICK HANSHEET (138 M). I was with 97 M on 10th December, and found the window broken at 3, Causeway Placeâ€”I examined the premises with Barrettâ€”I found Brooks under the tailor's board in the front room, concealed in brown paper; I pulled him out and asked him what he was doing; he said, "I only came in for a doss"; I said, "A quantity of clothing has been stolen "; he said, "I know nothing of it, I have not stolen it"â€”I took him to the station; he was charged; he made some remark, "I know nothing of the clothing"â€”I searched himâ€”I found threepence on him.
JAMES NORRIS (327 M). I produce my tunicâ€”I took it to Barrett to mend on 9th Decemberâ€”I next saw it at the Police-station amongst the stolen propertyâ€”Dywell showed it to me.

JAMES BALL . I am the lodging-house keeperâ€”I found three coats, two overcoats, and a short jacket under No. 40 bedâ€”I took them to the Police-stationâ€”that property was afterwards identified by the prosecutor.

Cross-examined by Smith. The morning after the robbery I was informed of the robbery by my sonâ€”he said Baker brought some clothes into the house between 10.30 and 11â€”I knew Baker as a lodgerâ€”when I went my rounds at one o'clock on the 10th you were in bed.
Cross-examined by Lewis. You were in bed at one o'clock when I went my rounds.
Cross-examined by Connor* You were also in bed then.

p.hi: held there was no case except with regard to Connor and Brooks.

Brooks' defence was that he went to the tailor's shop for lodgings, when he was apprehended by the constable and told of the robbery. He could say the others were innocent, from what Baker told him of the robbery.

div1.p: Connor's Defence. I found the coat in the passage when going to be! about ten minutes to one; I asked whose it was, and, no one answering, I put it on, but I had nothing to do with the burglary.
Witness for Connor. WILLIAM TAYLOR. On that very night Connor came to me at 10.15, and stayed till he went home, at about 12.45.
NOT GUILTY .

242.
JAMES PARSONSON
, Unlawfully and carnally knowing
Rose Silvester, a girl aged fourteen years and ten months. Second Count, attempting, etc.

GUILTY .â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

243.
FREDERICK FULLER (41)
, Unlawfully uttering to
Ada Tiley a counterfeit sixpence.

ADA TILEY . My father keeps a tobacconist's shop at 648, Old Kent Roadâ€”I am twelve years oldâ€”on the Sunday evening after Christmas Day, about 8.30 p.m., I was in the shopâ€”I served the prisoner with one pennyworth of shagâ€”he gave me this sixpenceâ€”I said, "This is a bad one"â€”he said, "Try itâ€”I took it to my motherâ€”she bit itâ€”a piece came out of it.
Cross-examined. I was alone in the shop; mother was in the parlour at the backâ€”my brother went for a policemanâ€”he is sixteen years oldâ€”he was away from five to ten minutes.
Re-examined. Mother did not leave the prisoner till the policeman came.

PHOEBE TILEY . I am the mother of Ada Tileyâ€”she brought me this sixpenceâ€”I bit it; a piece came out of itâ€”I walked round to the shop-doorâ€”I identified the prisoner as having come in the summerâ€”I said I should lock him up, as he was the same man as came in the summer with a bad shillingâ€”I told him he had been beforeâ€”he said he thought I had made a mistakeâ€”I said I was sure I had notâ€”I had the sixpence in my handâ€”I said it was badâ€”on Monday, 22nd June, I was preparing for a birthday party when the girl who served brought me a shillingâ€”I bit it, and a piece came outâ€”the prisoner made offâ€”I saw him through the parlour-window, which looks over the shopâ€”I am almost sure he is the same manâ€”the parlour is raised four steps above the shop, and commands a view of it.
Cross-examined. I was standing at the window looking through the curtainâ€”that was just after dinner, between two and three p.m., on 22nd June.

WILLIAM HANCOCK (109 P). I was called to this house on Sunday evening, the 22nd Decemberâ€”Mrs. Tiley said, "This man came in with a sixpence for one pennyworth of tobacco," and that the girl Ada took the sixpence, and said it was badâ€”he said, "You had better examine it"â€”so she went in to her mother, who bit a piece out, and she knew the man as having been beforeâ€”the prisoner replied he was entirely innocent, and did not know it was badâ€”he denied having been there beforeâ€”I took him into custodyâ€”I searched himâ€”I found nothing on him.
Cross-examined. I was about a hundred yards from the shop when fetchedâ€”this is the sixpence.
SUSIE DAY . I am assistant to Mrs. Tileyâ€”the prisoner came with a shilling in June, and again with sixpence in Decemberâ€”when he gave

me the shilling I served him with a pennyworth of shagâ€”I took it to Mrs. Tiley in the parlour, who bit a piece out of it; and when she came into the shop the prisoner made off, and we have not seen him since till he brought the sixpenceâ€”when he came the second time I was in the kitchen, but I came up into the shop a few minutes afterwards and identified the prisonerâ€”I told Mrs. Tileyâ€”I am positive he is the man.
Cross-examined. I could see from the kitchen into the shop through a windowâ€”I heard the prisoner ask for a pennyworth of shag.

JONATHAN NEEDHAM LEETION . I am a builder, of 292, Paradise Road Lambethâ€”the prisoner was in my employment from 7th or 8th June for between six and seven months in June, at 73, Paradise Road, opposite my houseâ€”his hours were from six a.m. to eight or nine p.m.â€”that is between two and three miles from the Old Kent Roadâ€”from my books he was painting the staircase in Juneâ€”we were preparing the house for Inspector Jeffreys, of Westminster, to come in on 24th Juneâ€”we were working at the house about a monthâ€”I first knew him when he came to work for me in Juneâ€”he is respectable; I always found him straightforward.
Cross-examined. We worked fifteen or sixteen hours a day when pushedâ€”the prisoner was working at this house on 22nd Juneâ€”his wages were 7 1/2 d. an hour, Â£1 17s. 6d. a week, and overtime.

ALFRED MOSES . I am a jobbing builder, of 108, Paradise Road, Lambethâ€”I have known the prisoner from the 2nd April to 6th Juneâ€”I employed himâ€”I lent the ladders for Leetion's jobâ€”I could not remember the date.
Cross-examined. The prisoner has not worked for me latelyâ€”I lent the ladders in June.
NOT GUILTY .

244.
GEORGE LONGDEN (45)
, Feloniously marrying
Euphannas Thornton, during the lifetime of his wife
Hannah.

JOHN THORLEY (Detective). I arrested the prisoner in the Park Road, Battersea, at 5.45 p.m. on 9th Decemberâ€”I told him I was a police officer, and should take him into custody for marrying Euphannas Thornton, on 18th November, 1885, his wife Hannah Longden being still aliveâ€”he said, "I did not know I was doing wrong. When I parted with my first wife a deed of separation was drawn up and signed by a lawyer, and I thought I was doing no harm by marrying again"â€”I asked him if he had said anything to his second wife about having been married beforeâ€”he said no, he did not think there was any occasion for itâ€”I produce the two certificatesâ€”one certifies a marriage solemnised at the Wesleyan Chapel, Hill gate, in the district of Stockport, Cheshire, on 18th December, 1870, between George Longden and Hannah Brewers; the other a marriage between George Hamilton Longden and Euphannas Thornton, on 18th November, 1885, at Everton, in the parish of Whartonon-the-Hill, Lancashireâ€”I asked him it he had two namesâ€”he said he had only one.
ELIZABETH BROADHURST . I live at 89, Bridge Lane, Stockportâ€”I am a single womanâ€”I was present at the marriage of my sister, in 1870, with the prisoner.
EUPHANNAS THORNTON . I live at Park Road, Batterseaâ€”I was married
to the prisoner on 18th November, 1885â€”this is the certificate I hadâ€”I did not know he was married.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You knocked me about and nearly murdered meâ€”you gave me your wages and borrowed some back to spend on other womenâ€”you were very strange, and I sought your relations, and found your wife.
The prisoner said he signed "Q. H." became his first wife's name was Hannah; he had lived very unhappily, and had lost Â£20 and Â£60 worth of goods.

GUILTY .â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8TH, 1892.
